SPARKS, NEVADA MUNICIPAL CODE 
____________ 
Published by Order of the City Council, 2011 
____________ 

> 
PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a republication of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Sparks, Nevada. 
Title, Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The title, chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of three parts separated by a period. The figure before the first period refers to the title number, the figure after the first period refers to the chapter number and the figure after the second period refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of title 1, chapter 1 is numbered 1.01.020. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents the title of a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a title of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the title. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
MUNICIPAL CODE TITLE T1:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 CODE INDEX CDI:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Janet Cramer, Editor, and Eric Grant, Vice President, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Linda Patterson, City Clerk and the other members of the city staff for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Municipal Code which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

Title 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 1.01 - CODE ADOPTION 
Sections: 

Section 1.01.010 - Adoption. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Section 268.014 of the Nevada Revised Statutes, there is adopted the "Sparks Municipal Code," as published by Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. 
(Ord. 975 § 1, 1974.)(Ord. 2474, § 1, Amended, 3/25/2013) 
Section 1.01.020 - Title-Citation-Reference. 
    This code shall be known as the "Sparks Municipal Code" and it shall be sufficient to refer to said code as the "Sparks Municipal Code" in any prosecution for the violation of any provision thereof or in any proceeding at law or equity. It shall be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to, amending, correcting or repealing all or any part or portion thereof as an addition to, amendment to, correction or repeal of the "Sparks Municipal Code." Further reference may be had to the titles, chapters, sections and subsections of the "Sparks Municipal Code" and such references shall apply to that numbered title, chapter, section or subsection as it appears in the code. 
(Ord. 975 § 2, 1974.) 
Section 1.01.030 - Codification authority. 
    This code consists of all the regulatory and penal ordinances and certain of the administrative ordinances of the city of Sparks, Nevada, codified pursuant to the provisions of Section 266.160 of the Nevada Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. 975 § 3, 1974.) 
Section 1.01.040 - Ordinances passed prior to adoption of the code. 
    The last ordinance included in this code was Ordinance 950, passed October 22, 1973. The following ordinances, passed subsequent to Ordinance 950 but prior to adoption of this code, are adopted and made a part of this code: Ordinances 951, 952, 953, 954, 955, 956, 957, 958, 959, 960, 961, 962, 963, 964, 965, 966, 967, 968, 969, 970, 971, 972, 973 and 974. 
(Ord. 975 § 4, 1974.) 
Section 1.01.050 - Prior code text. 
    Except as the same shall have been altered by ordinance amendments, repeals and additions, the textual contents of the ordinance code adopted by this chapter shall contain without change the text of the 1962 Sparks Municipal Code and the supplements thereto; provided, that nothing in this section shall prevent the correction of purely clerical errors, in spelling, typing, printing or punctuation, title re-numbering and re-classifying of code provisions, and the name changes or composition, without change of legal effect. 
(Ord. 975 § 5, 1974.) 
Section 1.01.060 - Prior code headings and other editorial matter. 
    The classification and arrangement by chapter, title, article and number of sections of the 1962 Sparks Municipal Code and supplements thereof, as well as the section headings and source notes and other editorial matter formed no part of the text of that code. Such inclusions were only for the purpose of convenience, orderly arrangement and information, and no implication or presumption of any legislative construction is to be drawn therefrom. The code adopted by this chapter has entirely changed and superseded the classification, arrangement and numbering systems of the 1962 Sparks Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 975 § 6, 1974.) 
Section 1.01.070 - Reference applies to all amendments. 
    Whenever a reference is made to this code as the "Sparks Municipal Code" or to any portion thereof, or to any ordinance of the city of Sparks, Nevada, the reference shall apply to all amendments, corrections and additions heretofore, now or hereafter made. 
(Ord. 975 § 7, 1974.) 
Section 1.01.080 - Title, chapter and section headings. 
    Title, chapter and section headings contained herein shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any title, chapter or section hereof. 
(Ord. 975 § 8, 1974.) 
Section 1.01.090 - Reference to specific ordinances. 
    The provisions of this code shall not in any manner affect matters of record which refer to, or are otherwise connected with ordinances which are therein specifically designated by number or otherwise and which are included within the code, but such reference shall be construed to apply to the corresponding provisions contained within this code. 
(Ord. 975 § 9, 1974.) 
Section 1.01.100 - Effect of code on past actions and obligations. 
    Neither the adoption of this code nor the repeal or amendment hereby of any ordinance or part or portion of any ordinance of the city shall in any manner affect the prosecution for violations of ordinances, which violations were committed prior to the effective date hereof, nor be construed as a waiver of any license, fee or penalty at said effective date due and unpaid under such ordinances, nor be construed as affecting any of the provisions of such ordinances relating to the collection of any such license, fee or penalty, or the penal provisions applicable to any violation thereof, nor to affect the validity of any bond or cash deposit in lieu thereof required to be posted, filed or deposited pursuant to any ordinance and all rights and obligations thereunder appertaining shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. 975 § 10, 1974.) 
Section 1.01.110 - Effective date. 
    This code shall become effective on the date the ordinance adopting this code as the "Sparks Municipal Code" shall become effective. 
(Ord. 975 § 11, 1974.) 
Chapter 1.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS. 
Sections: 

Section 1.04.010 - Definitions. 
A.  The following words, terms and phrases, whenever used in this code, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section unless from the context a different meaning is intended or unless a different meaning is specifically defined for such words, terms or phrases. 
1.  "Charter" means Chapter 180, Statutes of Nevada 1949, as amended by the Legislature of the State of Nevada, entitled "AN ACT to incorporate the City of Sparks, in Washoe County, and defining the boundaries thereof, and to authorize the establishing of a city government therefore, and other matters relating thereto, and repealing all acts and parts of acts in conflict herewith." 
2.  "City" means the City of Sparks, Nevada, or the area within the territorial limits of the City of Sparks, Nevada, and such territory outside of the city over which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or statutory provision. 
3.  "Council" means the city council of the City of Sparks, Nevada. "All its members", "all councilmen" or "all councilpersons" means the total number of persons comprising the council as provided by the general laws of the State of Nevada. 
4.  "County" means the County of Washoe, Nevada. 
5.  "Law" denotes applicable federal law, the Nevada Constitution, NRS and statutes of the State of Nevada, the NAC, the SMC and ordinances of the City of Sparks, and any and all other rules and regulations which may be promulgated under such laws. 
6.  "Month" means a calendar month. 
7.  "NAC" means Nevada Administrative Code. 
8.  "NRS" means Nevada Revised Statutes. 
9.  "Oath" includes an affirmation or declaration in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to "affirm" and "affirmed." 
10.  "Ordinance" means a law of the city; provided that a temporary or special law, administrative action, order or directive may be in the form of a resolution. 
11.  "Owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
12.  "Person" means natural person, any form of business or social organization and any other nongovernmental legal entity, including but not limited to a joint venture, joint stock company, partnership, association, club, company, limited liability company, corporation, business, trust, organization, or the manager, lessee, agent, servant, officer or employee of any of them. 
13.  "Personal property" includes money, goods, chattels, things in action and evidences of debt. 
14.  "Property" includes real and personal property. 
15.  "Real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
16.  "Sidewalk" means that portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
17.  "SMC" means Sparks Municipal Code. 
18.  "State" means the State of Nevada. 
19.  "Street" includes all streets, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, places, squares, curbs or other public ways in this city which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use, or such other public property so designated in any law of this state. 
20.  "Tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land, includes any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
21.  Title of Office. Use of the title of any officer, employee, board or commission means that officer, employee, department, board or commission of the city. 
22.  "Written" includes printed, typewritten, mimeographed , photocopied or digitally copied. 
23.  "Year" means a calendar year. 
(Ord. 923 § 1, 1973: 1962 Code § 1.010.) (Ord. 2471, § 1, Amended, 2/11/2013; Ord. 2102, Amended, 05/29/2001) 
Section 1.04.015 - Use of "may," "must," "shall" and "is entitled"; explanation of flush lines. 
A.  Except as otherwise expressly provided in a particular section of the SMC or required by the context: 
1.  "May" confers a right, privilege or power. The term "is entitled" confers a private right. 
2.  "May not" or " no*** may" abridges or removes a right, privilege or power. 
3.  "Must" expresses a requirement or duty to act. 
4.  "Shall" imposes a duty to act. 
5.  "Shall be deemed" or "shall be considered" creates a legal fiction. 
6.  "Shall not" imposes a prohibition against acting. 
B.  Except as otherwise required by the context, text of a section of the SMC that: 
1.  Follows subsections, paragraphs, subparagraphs or sub-subparagraphs that are introduced by a colon; 
2.  Is not designated as a separate subsection, paragraph, subparagraph or sub-subparagraph; and 
3.  Begins flush to the left margin rather than immediately following the material at the end of the final subsection, paragraph, subparagraph or sub-subparagraph, applies to the section as a whole, in the case of subsections, or to the subdivision preceding the colon as a whole rather than solely to the subdivision that the text follows. 
(Ord. 2102, Add, 05/29/2001) 
Section 1.04.020 - Grammatical interpretation. 
    The following grammatical rules apply to the SMC: 
A.  Gender. The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter genders. The use of masculine noun or pronoun in conferring a benefit or imposing a duty does not exclude a female person from that benefit or duty. The use of a feminine noun or pronoun in conferring a benefit or imposing a duty does not exclude a male person from that benefit or duty. 
B.  Singular and Plural. The singular number includes the plural and the plural includes the singular; 
C.  Tenses. Words used in the present tense include the past and the future tenses and vice versa, unless manifestly inapplicable; 
D.  Conjunctions. Conjunctions are to be construed in their ordinary meaning, unless the context clearly requires a different interpretation. 
(Ord. 923 § 2, 1973.) (Ord. 2102, Amended, 05/29/2001) 
Section 1.04.025 - Construction. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in this section, the words, terms and phrases used in the SMC shall be construed according to the plain meaning of such words, terms and phrases in their common and approved usage, with a view to effect the objects and purposes of the ordinances and to promote justice. 
B.  If words, terms or phrases are specially defined in a title, chapter or section of the SMC, that special definition shall govern the construction of such words, terms or phrases. 
C.  If technical words, terms or phrases used in the SMC have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law, such words, terms or phrases shall be construed to give effect to that peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(Ord. 2102, Add, 05/29/2001) 
Section 1.04.027 - Computation of time. 
    Computation of time under the SMC is necessary to determine the time within which an act must be done. Time under the SMC shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day. If the last day falls on a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday celebrated by the city, the last day shall be deemed to be the day following the weekend or legal holiday (whichever applies). 
(Ord. 2102, Add, 05/29/2001) 
Section 1.04.030 - Principals in criminal cases. 
    Every person concerned in the commission of a misdemeanor, whether he directly commits the act constituting the offense, or aids or abets in its commission, and whether present or absent; and every person who, directly or indirectly, counsels, encourages, hires, commands, induces or otherwise procures another to commit a misdemeanor is a principal, and shall be proceeded against and punished as such. The fact that the person aided, abetted, counseled, encouraged, hired, commanded, induced or procured, could not or did not entertain a criminal intent shall not be a defense to any person aiding, abetting, counseling, encouraging, hiring, commanding, inducing or procuring him. 
(Ord. 1484 § 1, 1985: Ord. 923 § 3, 1973.) (Ord. 2102, Renamed, 05/29/2001) 
Section 1.04.040 - Acts by agents. 
    When an act is required by an ordinance or the SMC that is capable of performance by an agent as well as a principal, the required act shall be construed to authorize and include the act performed by an authorized agent. 
(Ord. 923 § 4, 1973: 1962 Code § 1.020.) (Ord. 2102, Renamed, 05/29/2001) 
Section 1.04.050 - Repeal shall not revive any ordinances. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not repeal the repealing clause of such ordinance or revive any ordinance which has been repealed thereby. 
(Ord. 923 § 5, 1973.) 
Section 1.04.060 - Severability. 
1.  If any provision of the Sparks Municipal Code, or the application thereof to any person, thing or circumstance is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the provisions or application of SMC which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of SMC are declared to be severable. 
2.  The inclusion of an express declaration of severability in the enactment of any provision of SMC in an ordinance or the inclusion of any such provision in SMC does not enhance the severability of the provision so treated or detract from the severability of any other provision of SMC. 
(Ord. 2102, Add, 05/29/2001) 
Section 1.04.070 - Citation of Sparks Municipal Code. 
    The component parts of a section of SMC and the proper manner of citing them are indicated in the following example of the outline used: 
000.000 Sample outline [title of section]. This is a sample section of SMC, which can be subdivided as follows: 
A.  This is a subsection. 
B.  Subsections are designated with capital letters, and can be subdivided into paragraphs which: 
1.  Are numbered by Arabic numerals; 
2.  Are cited as "paragraphs 1 and 2 of subsection B of SMC 000.000" and can further be subdivided into subparagraphs which: 
a.  Are designated by lower case letters; and 
b.  Are cited as "subparagraphs a and b of paragraph 2 of subsection B of SMC 000.000 and can be further separated into sub-subparagraphs which are: 
i.  Designated by lower-case Roman numerals; and 
ii.  Cited as "sub-subparagraphs i and ii of subparagraph b of paragraph 2 of subsection B of SMC 000.000. 
(source note) 
(Ord. 2102, Add, 05/29/2001) 
Chapter 1.10 - COUNCIL PROCEDURE 
Sections: 

Section 1.10.010 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2564, § 1, adopted Oct. 22, 2018 repealed former § 1.10.010 in its entirety which pertained to public hearings-Required in certain cases and derived from Ord. 1108 § 1, 1977. 
Section 1.10.020 - Meetings-Regular, special. 
A.  The city council must hold regular meetings on the second and fourth Mondays of each month at a time and place convenient to the city council and the public. If a regular meeting date falls on a national, state or city holiday, the council must hold the meeting on the next business day. 
B.  Special meetings may be held on request of the mayor or of a majority of the city council. Notice of special meetings must be given in compliance with the city charter and the Nevada Open Meeting Law. 
(Ord. 1514 § 1, 1985.) 
Chapter 1.11 - MUNICIPAL COURT PROCEDURES 
Sections: 

Section 1.11.010 - Court of record; recording. 
    The Sparks Municipal Court is hereby designated as a court of record in accordance with NRS 5.010. Proceedings in the municipal court may be recorded in any method recognized by the Nevada Supreme Court. 
(Ord. 1718, 1991.) 
Section 1.11.020 - Recording: operation of equipment; transcription of recordings; use of transcript. 
A.  Each judge shall appoint a suitable person, who need not be a certified shorthand reporter and may have other responsibilities in the court to operate the recording equipment. The person so appointed shall subscribe to an oath that he or she will so operate it as to record all of the proceedings. 
B.  The municipal court may designate any certified person to transcribe the recording into a written transcript. The person so designated shall subscribe to an oath that he or she has correctly transcribed it. The transcripts may be used for all purposes for which transcripts are used and is subject to correction in the same manner as other transcripts. 
(Ord. 1718, 1991.) 
Section 1.11.030 - Recording; preservation; destruction. 
    The recording of each proceeding in municipal court must be preserved until at least 30 days after the time for filing an appeal expires. If no appeal is taken, the judge may order the destruction of the recording at any time after that date. If there is an appeal to the district court, the recording must be preserved until at least 30 days after final disposition of the case on appeal. The municipal court may order the destruction of the recording at any time after that date. 
(Ord. 1718, 1991.) 
Section 1.11.040 - Filing of appeals. 
    An appeal in a civil or criminal case must be taken and perfected in the same manner as the same type of appeal from the justice's courts, as provided in the Nevada Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. 1718, 1991.) 
Section 1.11.050 - Recording; payment of fees. 
A.  The fees for transcripts, processing an appeal, and copies must be paid by the party ordering them in accordance with the municipal court procedures. 
B.  In a civil case the preparation of the transcript need not commence until the fees have been deposited. 
C.  In a criminal case, upon a finding of a party's indigency by the court, such fees shall be waived or paid by the court. 
(Ord. 1718, 1991.) 
Section 1.11.060 - Transmission of transcript, other papers, recording, and copy of docket to district court. 
A.  The court shall transmit to the clerk of the district court the recording and/or transcript of the case, all other papers relating to the case, and a certified copy of his or her docket in accordance with the Nevada Revised Statutes, District Court Rules, and the Washoe County District Court Rules. 
B.  The judge shall give notice to the appellant or his or her attorney and to the other party that the recording and/or transcript, all other papers relating to the case, and a certified copy of the docket have been filed with the clerk of the district court. 
(Ord. 1718, 1991.) 
Chapter 1.12 - CONTEMPT OF COURT-GENERAL PENALTY 
Sections: 

Section 1.12.010 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Unless specifically provided, any person violating any provisions or failing to comply with any of the mandatory requirements of the provisions of this code is guilty of a misdemeanor. Any person convicted of a misdemeanor under the provisions of this code shall be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars or by imprisonment not to exceed six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
    Each such person is guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of the provisions of this code is committed, continued or permitted by any such person, and he shall be punished accordingly. 
(Ord. 1338 § 1, 1981: Ord. 926 § 1, 1973: 1962 Code § 115.010.) 
Section 1.12.020 - Penalty scope. 
    In case of amendment of any section of this code containing provisions for which a penalty is provided in another section thereof, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to apply to the section so amended, whether reenacted in the amendatory ordinance or not, unless specifically provided otherwise. 
(Ord. 926 § 2, 1973.) 
Section 1.12.030 - Violation-Failure to appear after admission to bail. 
    Every person charged with violating any of the provisions of this code who has been admitted to bail, whether provided by deposit, surety or upon his own recognizance, and has not been recommitted to custody, who fails to appear at the time and place required by the order admitting him to bail, or any modification thereof, unless he is excused by the judge of the municipal court by order of the court, is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 846 § 2, 1971: 1962 Code § 116.010.) 
Section 1.12.033 - Acts or omissions constituting contempts. 
    The following acts or omissions shall be deemed contempts: 
A.  Disorderly, contemptuous or insolent behavior toward the judge while the judge is holding court, or engaged in judicial duties at chambers, or toward masters or arbitrators while sitting on a reference or arbitration, or other judicial proceeding. 
B.  A breach of the peace, boisterous conduct or violent disturbance in the presence of the court, or in its immediate vicinity, tending to interrupt the due course of the trial or other judicial proceeding. 
C.  Disobedience or resistance to any lawful writ, order, rule or process issued by the court or judge at chambers. 
D.  Disobedience of a subpoena duly served, or refusing to be sworn or answer as a witness. 
E.  Rescuing any person or property in the custody of an officer by virtue of an order or process of such court or judge at chambers. 
F.  Disobedience of the order or direction of the court made pending the trial of an action, in speaking to or in the presence of a juror concerning an action in which the juror has been impaneled to determine, or in any manner approaching or interfering with such juror with the intent to influence the verdict. 
G.  Abusing the process or proceedings of the court or falsely pretending to act under the authority of an order or process of the court. 
H.  Failing to appear in accordance with a written promise to appear in court, regardless of the disposition of the charge upon which the person was originally arrested. 
I.  Failing to appear before the municipal court after having represented in writing to a peace officer or other authorized person of the city, county, or state that the person will appear to answer a charge of violating any provisions of this code, regardless of the disposition of the underlying charge. 
J.  Failing, refusing, or neglecting to comply with the terms of any order, judgment, or other process issued by the municipal court. 
(Ord. 2565, § 1, Added, 10/22/2018.) 
Section 1.12.035 - Procedures and penalty for contempt. 
A.  The processes and procedures set forth in Chapter 22 of the Nevada Revised Statutes apply to a determination of contempt under SMC 1.12.033. Any person who is found to have violated the provisions of SMC 1.12.033 shall be punished in the same manner and with the same effect as provided in NRS Chapter 22 and this section. 
B.  Upon the answer and evidence taken, the court shall determine whether the person proceeded against is guilty of the contempt charged. 
C.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection E, if a person is found guilty of contempt, a fine may be imposed on the person not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or the person may be imprisoned not exceeding 25 days, or both. 
D.  In addition to the penalties provided in subsection C, if a person is found guilty of contempt pursuant to subsection C, the court may require the person to pay to the party seeking to enforce the writ, order, rule or process the reasonable expenses, including, without limitation, attorney's fees, incurred by the party as a result of the contempt. 
E.  Except as otherwise provided by law, when the contempt consists in the omission to perform an act which is yet in the power of the person to perform, the person may be imprisoned until the person performs it. The required act must be specified in the warrant of commitment. 
(Ord. 2565, § 2, Added, 10/22/2018.) 
Section 1.12.040 - Criminal contempt. 
    Every person who commits a contempt of the municipal court of any one of the following kinds is guilty of a misdemeanor: 
A.  Disorderly, contemptuous or insolent behavior committed during the sitting of the court, in its immediate view and presence, and directly tending to interrupt its proceedings or to impair the respect due to its authority; or 
B.  Breach of the peace, noise or other disturbance directly tending to interrupt the proceedings of the court; or 
C.  Willful disobedience to the lawful process or mandate of the court; or 
D.  Resistance, willfully offered, to its lawful process or mandate; or 
E.  Contumacious and unlawful refusal to be sworn as a witness or, after being sworn, to answer any legal and proper interrogatory; or 
F.  Publication of a false or grossly inaccurate report of its proceedings; or 
G.  Assuming to be an attorney or officer of the court or acting as such without authority. 
(Ord. 2565, § 3, Amended, 10/22/2018; Ord. 846 § 3, 1971: 1962 Code § 116.020.) 
Section 1.12.050 - State misdemeanors. 
    The commission of any act within the corporate limits of the city or the failure to perform any act within such corporate limits which is made a misdemeanor by the laws of the state of Nevada is declared to be and shall constitute a misdemeanor under this code. 
(Ord. 1510 § 1, 1985.) 
Section 1.12.060 - Minimum or maximum state law penalties. 
    When under this code an offense is set forth which is identical to or substantially similar to an offense set forth under state law, and a minimum or maximum penalty is set forth under state law for that offense, the minimum or maximum penalty for the violation of the city code provision shall be the same as that provided for the violation of state law. 
(Ord. 2565, § 4, Amended, 10/22/2018; Ord. 1546 § 1, 1986.) 
Chapter 1.13 - MUNICIPAL COURT ADMINISTRATIVE ASSESSMENT 
Sections: 

Section 1.13.010 - Administrative assessment. 
A.  When a defendant pleads or is found guilty of a misdemeanor, including the violation of any municipal ordinance, the judge shall include in the sentence the sum of Ten Dollars ($10.00) as an administrative assessment for the provision of court facilities and render a judgment against the defendant for the assessment. 
B.  The provisions of section A do not apply to: 
1.  an ordinance regulating metered parking; or 
2.  an ordinance that is specifically designated as imposing a civil penalty or liability pursuant to NRS 244.3575 or 268.019. 
(Ord. 1867, 1995.) (1929, Amended, 07/14/1997) 
Section 1.13.020 - Collection. 
    The money collected for an administrative assessment for the provision of court facilities must not be deducted from the fine imposed by the judge but must be taxed against the defendant in addition to the fine. The money collected for such an administrative assessment must be stated separately on the court's docket and must be included in the amount posted for bail. If the defendant is found not guilty or the charges are dismissed, the money deposited with the court must be returned to the defendant. If the judge cancels a fine because the fine has been determined to be uncollectible, any balance of the fine and the administrative assessment remaining unpaid shall be deemed to be uncollectible, and the defendant is not required to pay it. If a fine is determined to be uncollectible, the defendant is not entitled to a refund of the fine or administrative assessment he has paid and the judge shall not recalculate the administrative assessment. 
(Ord. 1867, 1995.) (1929, Amended, 07/14/1997) 
Section 1.13.030 - Installment payments. 
    If the judge permits the fine or administrative assessment for the provision of court facilities to be paid in installments, the payments must be applied in the following order: 
A.  To pay the unpaid balance of an administrative assessment imposed pursuant to NRS 176.059; 
B.  To pay the unpaid balance of an administrative assessment for the provision of court facilities pursuant to this ordinance; and 
C.  To pay the fine. 
(Ord. 1867, 1995.) (1929, Amended, 07/14/1997) 
Section 1.13.040 - Transfer of funds. 
    The money collected for administrative assessments for the provision of court facilities in municipal court must be paid by the clerk of the court to the finance director on or before the fifth day of each month for the preceding month. The finance director shall deposit the money received in a special revenue fund. The city may use the money in the special revenue fund only to: 
A.  Acquire land on which to construct additional facilities for the municipal court or a regional justice center which includes the municipal court. 
B.  Construct or acquire additional facilities for the municipal court or a regional justice center that includes the municipal court. 
C.  Renovate or remodel existing facilities for the municipal court. 
D.  Acquire furniture, fixtures and equipment necessitated by the construction or acquisition of additional facilities or the renovation of an existing facility for the municipal court or a regional justice center that includes the municipal court. This paragraph does not authorize the expenditure of money from the fund for furniture, fixtures or equipment for judicial chambers. 
E.  Acquire advanced technology for use in the additional or renovated facilities. 
F.  Pay debt service on any bonds issued pursuant to subsection 3 of NRS 350.020 for the acquisition of land or facilities or the construction or renovation of facilities for the municipal court or a regional justice center that includes the municipal court. 
    Any money remaining in the special revenue fund after five (5) fiscal years must be deposited in the municipal general fund for the continued maintenance of court facilities if it has not been committed for expenditure pursuant to a plan for the construction or acquisition of court facilities or improvement to court facilities. The finance director shall provide, upon request by a municipal court, monthly reports of the revenue credited to and expenditures made from the special revenue fund. 
(Ord. 1867, 1995.) (1929, Amended, 07/14/1997) 
Section 1.13.050 - Regional justice center sizing. 
    If money collected pursuant to this ordinance is to be used to acquire land on which to construct a regional justice center or to pay debt service on bonds issued for these purposes, the county and the participating cities shall, by interlocal agreement, determine such issues as the size of the regional justice center, the manner in which the center will be used and the apportionment of fiscal responsibility for the center. 
(1929, Added, 07/14/1997) 
Chapter 1.16 - WARDS OF THE CITY 
Chapter 1.20 - HOUSE NUMBERING 
Sections: 

Section 1.20.010 - Requirements generally. 
A.  Each lot and parcel of land within the city limits abutting upon any public street shall be numbered as provided in this chapter. 
B.  The owner of each house and building shall display the number assigned to the lot or parcel on which the house or building is located in a conspicuous position on such house or building. 
(Ord. 1962 Code § 65.010.) 
Section 1.20.020 - Numbering on streets running east and west. 
A.  Beginning at the east line of the city limits, each street which runs east and west, north of the Southern Pacific Company tracks, shall be numbered by assigning one hundred numbers to each block of lots abutting upon such street, and two numbers shall be assigned to each twenty-five foot lot or measurement of land in each block. Odd numbers shall be assigned to the lots or measurements of land which lie upon the left side of the street and even numbers to the lots or measurements of land which lie upon the right side of the street, beginning with number one at the east end of the street and continuing to the west end of the street. 
B.  Numbers on all streets east and west, south of the Southern Pacific Company tracks, shall be as provided in this subsection. The first block east of Poplar Street shall be the 1400 block, the next block the 1500 block, and so on westerly to the west limits of the city adjoining the property of the Nevada State Hospital. 
(1962 Code § 65.020.) 
Section 1.20.030 - Numbering on streets running north and south. 
A.  Beginning at the south line of A Street, each street which runs north and south shall be numbered by assigning one hundred numbers to each block of lots abutting upon such street, and two numbers shall be assigned to each twenty-five foot lot or measurement of land in each block. Odd numbers shall be assigned to the lots or measurements of land which lie upon the left side of the street, and even numbers to the lots or measurements of land which lie upon the right side of the street, beginning with number one at the south end of the street and continuing to the north end of the street, except that the numbering of 15th Street shall begin at Wadsworth Avenue. 
B.  Numbers on all streets running north and south on the south side of the Southern Pacific Company tracks shall be as provided in this subsection. The first block south of the tracks shall be the 200 block, the next block the 300 block, and so on southerly to the south city limits. 
(1962 Code § 65.030.) 
Section 1.20.040 - Labor assignment. 
A.  The city council shall appoint a suitable person to perform the labor of measuring the lots and lands within the city and assigning numbers to each lot and measurement of land and to each house and building upon such lots or measurements of land. 
B.  The person so appointed shall give to the occupant of each house and building a ticket bearing the number assigned to such house or building. 
C.  The person so appointed shall receive such compensation for performing the labor herein specified as the city council shall order and allow. 
(1962 Code § 65.040.) 
Section 1.20.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who refuses or neglects to comply with the provisions of Section 1.20.010 shall be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars or more than twenty-five dollars. 
(1962 Code § 65.050.) 
Chapter 1.30 - EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN 
Sections: 

Section 1.30.010 - Adoption. 
    Pursuant to the Civil Defense Act of 1950 (P.L. 93 - 288 as amended) and NRS Chapter 414, The Emergency Operations Plan approved March 25, 2002 by Resolution No. 2788, as may be amended from time to time, is hereby adopted and shall be complied with to the greatest extent possible in the event that an emergency is declared by the mayor or his authorized designee. 
(Ord. 2133, Amended, 04/08/2002; 1960, Added, 11/24/1997) 
Title 2 - ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL 
Chapters: 
Chapter 2.01 - CODE OF ETHICS 
Sections: 

Section 2.01.010 - Purpose and intent. 
A.  The city council finds and declares as follows: 
1.  The people have a right to expect from their elected and appointed representatives at all levels of government assurances of the utmost in integrity, honesty and fairness in their dealings; 
2.  The people further have a right to be assured to the fullest extent possible that the private financial dealings of their governmental representatives, and of candidates of those offices, present no conflict of interest between the public trust and private gain; and 
3.  The representative form of government is founded upon a belief that those entrusted with the offices of government have nothing to fear from full public disclosure of their business holdings as they pertain to the business before the Sparks city council. 
B.  The city council intends to sustain, to the extent necessary, public confidence in government at all levels, by assuring the people of the impartiality and honesty of their officials in all governmental transactions and decisions. 
C.  The provisions of this chapter are to be construed liberally, to the end that the public interests are fully protected. 
(Ord. 1440 § 1 (part), 1984.) 
Section 2.01.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, certain words and phrases are defined and certain provisions shall be construed as hereinafter set forth unless it is apparent from the context that a different meaning is intended. Whenever any words and phrases used in this chapter are not defined in this section but are defined in the state laws regulating such matters, any such definition therein is deemed to apply to such words and phrases used in this chapter. 
A.  "Appointed official" means salaried employees of the city. other than elected officials and temporary employees, who are not subject to the city's civil service system as established in Article IX of the city Charter. These include, without limitation, the city manager, persons appointed by the city manager, and persons appointed by elected officials. 
B.  "Business entity" means any organization or enterprise operated for economic gain, including, but not limited to, a proprietorship, partnership, firm, business trust, joint venture, syndicate, corporation or association. 
C.  "Campaign contributions" means all donations of money, subscriptions, pledges, loans, conveyances, deposits, payments, transfers or distribution of money from all sources. 
D.  "Candidate," for the purposes of this chapter, means and includes any individual seeking election or appointment as an elected official as defined in this section. This includes, without limitation, any person: 
1.  Who files an affidavit of candidacy; 
2.  Who files to fill a vacancy in an elective office. 
E.  "Direct financial interest" means a relationship to any business entity or real property in which an appointed official, elected official, candidate, and/or immediate family member is involved as a trustee, beneficiary of a trust, director, officer, employee, owner in whole or in part, limited or general partner, or a holder of stock or stocks or securities of any class or classes. 
F.  "Elected official" means a person designated as an elective officer of the city in the city Charter. 
G.  "Gift" means anything of economic value which individually or cumulatively exceeds three hundred dollars in value, but not including campaign contributions or gifts from any relative by blood or marriage, notwithstanding the definition of "relative herein, or gifts of personal hospitality of an individual. "Personal hospitality of an individual" means hospitality extended for a nonbusiness purpose by an individual, not a corporation or organization, at the personal residence of that individual or his family or on property or facilities owned by that individual or his family. Exception: Regardless of value, gift(s) from an employer need not be reported. 
H.  "Immediate family" means the spouse and dependents of an official or candidate. 
I.  "Real property" means any interest in or option to purchase any interest in any real property in the Truckee Meadows. 
J.  "Relative" means the parents of the official and his/her spouse, and the official's natural and adopted children regardless of dependency. 
K.  "Truckee Meadows" means that area bounded, generally, by the Virginia City, Mount Rose Highway on the south, Verdi on the west, Stead, Sun Valley and Spanish Springs Valley on the north, and the crest of the Virginia and Pah Rah Ranges on the east. 
L.  "Trust" means a legal title of property held by one party, the trustee, for the benefit of another, the beneficiary. 
(Ord. 1440 § 1 (part), 1984.) 
Section 2.01.030 - Duties of the city clerk. 
    The city clerk shall supply forms from statements and other information required by this chapter and furnish such forms and information free of charge for use by persons subject to the requirement of this chapter and shall notify each person required to file under this chapter. The city clerk shall notify the city attorney, the candidate or the elected official when anyone required to file a statement fails to do so within the prescribed time. 
(Ord. 1440 § 1 (part), 1984.) 
Section 2.01.040 - Filing by candidates. 
    Each candidate for any city elective office shall file under oath, at the time of his/her filing papers of nomination, a disclosure statement containing the information set forth in Section 2.01.050 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1440 § 1 (part), 1984.) 
Section 2.01.050 - Information required. 
A.  Name, address and phone number, if any, of the candidate; 
B.  The length of residence in the state of Nevada and the length of residence in the city; 
C.  The precinct in which the candidate is registered to vote: 
D.  The name, principal address and the general description of the business activity of any business entity conducting business with the city or within the Truckee Meadows, in which the candidate has or had a direct financial interest at any time during the immediate preceding twelve months; 
E.  The source or sources of each loan exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars. Exceptions: The mortgage on the residence of the candidate, a loan for purchase of an automobile for private use; or a debt secured by mortgage or deed of trust for land located outside the Truckee Meadows; 
F.  In the case of real property, a listing of all real property or interest therein, including options to purchase, located in the Truckee Meadows, together with the location and name, if any, by which such property is commonly known, whether said real property was owned outright or held in whole or in part under a corporation or partnership; 
G.  Whether the candidate has ever been convicted of a felony. If yes, explain the circumstances; 
H.  Whether the candidate has filed for personal bankruptcy within the last seven years; 
I.  The name of any person or entity providing a gift to the candidate within the preceding twelve months, and a description of the gift. 
(Ord. 1440 § 1 (part), 1984.) 
Section 2.01.060 - Campaign contributions-Reports required. 
A.  Every candidate for city elective office must report the total amount of his/her campaign contributions on forms provided by the city clerk on such dates and covering such periods as may be required by the Nevada Revised Statutes. 
B.  For each contribution or series of contributions from a single contributor totaling three hundred dollars or more, the name of the contributor must be stated, together with the total amount of the contribution. 
(Ord. 1440 § 1 (part), 1984.) 
Section 2.01.070 - Conflict of interest-Elected officials. 
A.  An elected official must abstain from voting on or participating in the discussion of an item before the city council whenever such official has a direct financial interest. When the item is called on the agenda, the elected official must disclose the existence and nature of the direct financial interest prior to any testimony being introduced on the item. 
B.  Members of the city council and the mayor must disclose the existence of a direct financial interest of a relative regarding an item before the city council. Disclosure must be made prior to any testimony being received on the item. After disclosure, the official may discuss and vote on the item. 
C.  An elected official must abstain from voting on or participating in the discussion of an item before the city council whenever such official or member of his immediate family has accepted a gift from an applicant within the preceding eighteen months, or whenever such official or member of his immediate family has sold or entered into a contract for the sale of goods or services to an applicant during the preceding eighteen months which involves payment by the applicant of five hundred dollars or more. When the item is called on the agenda, the elected official must disclose the existence and nature of the conflict prior to any testimony being introduced on the item. 
D.  A member of the city council and the mayor may discuss and vote upon an item, after disclosure, if the benefit or detriment accruing to the official as a result of the decision, either individually or in a representative capacity as a member of a business, profession, occupation or group, is not greater than that accruing to any other member of the business. profession, occupation, or group. 
(Ord. 1440 § 1 (part), 1984.) 
Section 2.01.080 - Conflict of interest-Appointed employees. 
    An appointed employee who has a direct financial interest regarding a matter assigned to such employee for discretionary services must immediately disclose the existence and nature of said interest to the city manager. An appointed employee must disclose the existence of a direct financial interest to the city council at the time of any communication, written or oral, to the city council concerning the item subject to such interest. 
(Ord. 1440 § 1 (part), 1984.) 
Section 2.01.090 - Violation-Reconsideration of vote. 
A.  Within one month after the discovery that an elected or appointed official failed to disclose a conflict of interest regarding an item before the city council as required by law, the item may be brought back for reconsideration upon the request of one or more members of the city council. 
B.  Approval of an item by the city council where a violation of this chapter existed is voidable. The fact that a violation existed shall be prima facie proof that the applicant had knowledge of the violation at the time of initial approval. 
(Ord. 1440 § 1 (part), 1984.) 
Section 2.01.110 - Violation-Penalties. 
A.  Any elected official who willfully and knowingly violates the provisions of this chapter is subject to removal from office in accordance with procedure established in the city Charter. 
B.  Any appointed employee who willfully and knowingly violates the provisions of this chapter is subject to removal by his/her appointing authority. 
C.  The penalties set forth in this section are in addition to misdemeanor prosecution for violation of any section of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1440 § 1 (part), 1984.) 
Chapter 2.03 - WARD BOUNDARIES 
Sections: 

Section 2.03.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this ordinance is to delineate the criteria by which the City of Sparks will redistrict ward boundaries pursuant to the Sparks City Charter. 
(Ord. 2191, Add, 10/13/2003) 
Section 2.03.020 - Criteria for establishment and redistricting of ward boundaries 
    When considering establishment and redistricting ward boundaries the City shall consider the following factors: 
A.  The ward boundaries must include the block in which the council person resides for that ward; 
B.  The ward boundaries must be contiguous; and 
C.  Where ever possible the ward boundaries shall follow arterial/major streets. 
(Ord. 2191, Add, 10/13/2003) 
Section 2.03.030 - Criteria for incorporation of newly annexed lands into wards 
    Contiguous annexations and annexations implementing the Annexation program shall follow the pattern below. 
A.  West of Sparks Boulevard until the intersection of Sparks Boulevard and Pyramid Highway then west of Pyramid Highway in Spanish Springs Valley - Ward 5 
B.  East of Sparks Boulevard until the intersection of Sparks Boulevard and Pyramid Highway then east of Pyramid Highway in the Spanish Springs Valley - Ward 4 
C.  East of the incorporated boundaries of Sparks and south of Spanish Springs Valley and following the Truckee River - Ward 3 
D.  West of Sullivan lane and west/south of El Rancho - Ward 2 
(Ord. 2371, Amended, 08/13/2007; Ord. 2200, Amended, 12/08/2003; Ord. 2191, Add, 10/13/2003) 
Section 2.03.040 - Redistricting procedures based on the U.S. Department of Commerce Census Bureau Decennial Census. 
A.  The existing ward boundaries and ward population will be provided to each council person. 
B.  Following the criteria identified in 2.03.020 above, staff will generate a first draft of new ward boundaries and ward population. The population between wards cannot differ more than five (5) percent. This information will be provided to each council person. 
C.  Each council person will then have an opportunity to meet individually with staff to discuss any changes. 
D.  Staff will then try to reconcile the five (5) council persons' comments and changes, and produce a revised draft of new ward boundaries and ward population. This revised information will be provided to each council person. 
E.  Each council person will then have an opportunity to meet individually with staff to discuss any changes. 
F.  Staff will then try to reconcile the five (5) council persons' comments and changes, and produce a revised draft of new ward boundaries and ward population. If discrepancies exist a workshop with the entire Council will be scheduled. 
(Ord. 2191, Add, 10/13/2003) 
Section 2.03.050 - Interim redistricting procedures based on local data. 
A.  In the intervening years ending in 6, (e.g. 2006, 2016, 2026...) the City Council may request a new reapportionment. 
B.  The population of each ward shall be determined by the following method: 
1.  A housing unit population estimate method will be used to determine the interim ward populations. This method tracks housing building permits and demolition permits. 
2.  The base information from the decennial census, housing units per block by dwelling type as well as persons per household by dwelling type will be utilized. 
3.  The permit information will be added to the census information. 
C.  The existing ward boundaries and newly calculated ward population will be provided to each council person. 
D.  Following the criteria identified in 2.03.020 above, staff will generate a first draft of new ward boundaries and ward population. The population between wards cannot differ more than five percent. This information will be provided to each council person. 
E.  Each council person will then have an opportunity to meet individually with staff to discuss any changes. 
F.  Staff will then try to reconcile the five (5) council persons' comments and changes, and produce a revised draft of new ward boundaries and ward population. This revised information will be provided to each council person. 
G.  Each council person will then have an opportunity to meet individually with staff to discuss any changes. 
H.  Staff will then try to reconcile the five (5) council persons' comments and changes, and produce a revised draft of new ward boundaries and ward population. If discrepancies exist a workshop with the entire Council will be scheduled. 
(Ord. 2191, Add, 10/13/2003) 
Section 2.03.060 - Ward boundary map. 
    Pursuant to Section 1.040 of the Charter of the City of Sparks the City Council hereby adopts ward boundaries as depicted on the map on file with the City Clerk. 
(Ord. 2455, Amended, 10/10/2011; Ord. 2200, Amended, 12/08/2003; Ord. 2191, Add, 10/13/2003) 
Chapter 2.04 - ELECTIVE OFFICER 
Sections: 

Section 2.04.020 - Salary of municipal judge. 
    The salary of the municipal judges shall be adjusted with the first full pay period following July 1 of each succeeding year. The salary of all municipal judges shall be equal and shall be set by averaging the salaries of the appointed department heads (excluding the highest and lowest salaries) on the first full pay period following July 1 of each year and thereafter adjusted for any cost of living increases afforded to the appointed department heads during that fiscal year. In the event the average is lower than the previous year, the salary of municipal judges shall not be decreased. For purposes of this section, the city manager shall not be a department head. 
(Ord. 1726, 1992: Ord. 1679, 1990: Ord. 1621 § 2, 1988: Ord. 1567 § 2, 1986: Ord. 1379 § 1, 1982: Ord. 1206 § 1, 1978.) (Ord. 2141, Amended, 05/13/2002; 1947, Amended, 10/27/1997) 
Section 2.04.030 - Salary of city attorney. 
    The salary of the elected city attorney shall be fixed at an amount $5,000.00 more than the salary for a municipal judge. 
(Ord. 1914, 1996: Ord. 1679, 1990: Ord. 1621 § 3, 1988: Ord. 1567 § 3, 1986: Ord. 1377 § 1, 1982: Ord. 1204 § 1, 1978.) (Ord. 2175, Amended, 07/14/2003; 1966, Amended, 12/08/1997) 
Section 2.04.040 - Salaries of mayor and city council members. 
A.  The annual salary of the office of mayor shall be equal to that of a county commissioner of Washoe County as set forth in NRS 245.043, and shall be payable biweekly. This salary shall become effective the Monday following the general election in November, 2006. 
B.  The annual salary of city council members shall be eighty percent (80%) of that of a county commissioner of Washoe County as set forth in NRS 245.043, and shall be payable biweekly. This salary shall become effective for Wards 1, 3 and 5 the Monday following the general election in November, 2004. This salary shall become effective for Wards 2 and 4 the Monday following the general election in November, 2006. 
(Ord. 1913, 1996: Ord. 1682, 1990: Ord. 1621 § 3, 1988: Ord. 1567 § 4, 1986: Ord. 1376 § 1, 1982: Ord. 1375 § 1, 1982: Ord.1203 § 1, 1978.) (Ord. 2201, Amended, 12/22/2003) 
Chapter 2.05 - CITY DEPARTMENTS AND DEPARTMENT HEADS 
Sections: 

Section 2.05.020 - Duties of city attorney. 
    The city attorney shall: 
A.  Prosecute all actions or proceedings in the municipal court for the violation of any ordinance of the city; 
B.  Represent the city in all actions specified in subsection 3 of NRS 266.555 in the municipal court in which the city is a party; 
C.  Represent the city in all appeals to the district court from the municipal court; 
D.  Advise the city council or its committees or any city officer, when requested, upon all legal questions arising in the conduct of the city business; 
E.  Prepare or revise ordinances when so requested by the city council or any committee thereof; 
F.  Give his opinion upon any legal matter or question submitted to him by the city council, or any of its committees, or by any city officer; 
G.  Attend all regular, special and emergency meetings of the city council, and may attend executive sessions concerning public officers as provided in chapter 241 of NRS; 
H.  Prepare for execution all contracts and instruments to which the city is a party and shall approve, as to form, all bonds required to be submitted to the city; 
I.  Commence civil actions in which the city is a party only upon the express prior permission of the city council, except those cases in which the city council or staff is a party, civil actions in municipal court, and actions for preliminary or permanent injunctive relief brought pursuant to SMC 5.08.046; and defend the city in all civil actions in which it is a defending party; 
J.  Have the power to submit to arbitration any action, causes of action, accounts, debts, claims, complaints, demands and disputes for or against the city or in which the city is concerned as debtor or creditor; 
K.  Report in writing to the city manager and city council the outcome of any litigation in which the city has an interest within twenty-four hours after the conclusion of such litigation; 
L.  Make a biweekly written report to the mayor and city council of all pending litigation and the status thereof, including but not limited to cases in the municipal court in which the city has an interest; 
M.  Keep a complete record of all written opinions furnished by him; 
N.  Deliver all records, documents and property of every description in his possession, belonging to his office or to the city, to his successor in office, who shall give him a receipt therefore; 
O.  The city attorney may appoint such deputies as may be necessary subject to the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. 1306 § 1, 1981.) (Ord. 2528, § 1, Amended, 08/22/2016; Ord. 2081, Amended, 09/11/2000) 
Chapter 2.08 - CITY ORGANIZATION AND STAFFING DOCUMENT 
Sections: 

Section 2.08.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the city organization and staffing document and shall be in full force and effect until amended and then as amended until repealed. 
(Ord. 1674, 1990: Ord. 1495 § 1, 1985: Ord. 617 § 2, 1965: 1962 Code § 15.020.) 
Section 2.08.020 - Appointments to positions; organization of city. 
A.  Appointed positions authorized in the budget shall by filled by the city manager subject to ratification by the city council except those appointed positions which are to be filled n another manner as set forth in the city charter. 
B.  Prior to the recruitment of positions listed in the executive resolution, the city council shall review the classification range for each position. The classification ranges set for executive employees may be consistent with the city's classification plan. 
C.  Classified positions authorized in the budget shall be filled by the respective department head only. 
D.  From time to time the city manager may reorganize or consolidate departments and divisions in response to the needs of the city with the approved budget, such reorganization or consolidation subject to council approval by resolution. Additional appointed positions must be approved by council. 
(Ord. 2109, Amended, 06/25/2001) 
Section 2.08.030 - Vacancy filling. 
A.  The filling of position vacancies within any department will be dependent upon two factors, which are: 
1.  Availability of funds within the respective department; and 
2.  Prior approval of the city manager. 
B.  Compliance with all civil service commission and city directives will also be followed with regard to employment policies. 
(Ord. 1674, 1990: Ord. 617 § 4, 1965: 1962 Code § 15.040.) 
Section 2.08.040 - Powers and duties. 
    Each person occupying a position under a job classification in each department of the city shall possess all of the powers and duties as set forth in the job description for that position on file with the human resources division and such other powers and duties authorized by law. 
(Ord. 1674, 1990: Ord. 1495 § 3, 1985: Ord. 1279 1, 1980.) 
Section 2.08.060 - Appointed positions. 
    Appointed positions for the City of Sparks shall be adopted by Resolution of the City Council. The appointed positions for the City of Sparks shall be indicated and further described in an Executive Resolution or a Mid-Management & Professional Technological Resolution of the City of Sparks. 
(Ord. 1674, 1990: Ord. 1735, 1992: Ord. 1647, 1989: Ord. 1611, 1988.) (Ord. 2026, Amended, 05/24/1999) 
Section 2.08.070 - Classified positions. 
    All positions not appointed or elected shall be determined to be classified, subject to the rules of the civil service commission. 
(Ord. 1674, 1990.) 
Section 2.08.080 - Applicants for certain elected, appointed and classified positions; FBI fingerprint-based background check required. 
A.  Pursuant to NRS 239B.010 (1)(b) and P.L. 92-544, each candidate for an elected office set forth in subsection E and each applicant for an appointed or classified position set forth in subsection E shall provide a full set of his or her fingerprints and any required fee to the Police Department as a condition of candidacy or application and as a condition of employment. 
B.  A candidate or applicant for an elected, appointed or classified position set forth in subsection E shall submit to the Police Department all information required by the FBI or the Police Department for a FBI background check to determine suitability for the position. 
C.  The Police Department is authorized to submit the fingerprints of prospective officers and employees of the City, plus any required fees and any information required for the background check, to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History for a statewide background check and for submission to the FBI to obtain the FBI's nationwide background check of the applicant. The Nevada Department of Public Safety is hereby authorized to exchange such fingerprint data with the FBI for purposes of the background check. 
D.  After being duly noticed by the City and provided an opportunity to comply, failure or refusal of an applicant for an elected, appointed or classified position set forth in subsection E to submit to full fingerprinting or to provide information required by this section is grounds for denial of the individual's application for employment or involuntary termination of the individual's employment with the City. 
E.  A candidate for any of the following elected offices or an applicant for any of the following position or job titles shall comply with the provisions of this section and any other FBI or Police Department requirements necessary to obtain a FBI background check pursuant to this section: 
1.  Accounting Specialist (Parks & Recreation Only) 
2.  Administrative Assistant to City Attorney 
3.  Administrative Assistant to Municipal Judges 
4.  Administrative Secretary to Municipal Judges 
5.  Administrative Secretary (Police Only) 
6.  Assistant City Attorney I/II 
7.  Assistant Fire Marshall 
8.  City Attorney 
9.  Chief Municipal Court Clerk 
10.  Deputy Police Chief 
11.  Emergency Communications Dispatcher 
12.  Emergency Communications Specialist

14.  Fire Battalion Chief 
15.  Fire Captain 
16.  Fire Chief 
17.  Fire Fighter 
18.  Fire Marshal

22.  Legal Secretary I/II 
23.  Marshal

27.  Municipal Court Judge

29.  Office Specialist (Parks & Recreation Only) 
30.  Parks & Recreation Director
