Deal, operate, carry on, conduct, maintain or expose for playing any game of faro, monte, roulette, keno, fan-tan, twenty-one, big injun, klondike, craps, stud poker or draw poker, or any bank or percentage game, played with cards, dice or any mechanical device or machine for money, property, checks, credit or any representative of value, any gambling game or device, or any pool or poolroom, in which any person, firm, association or corporation keeping, conducting, managing or permitting the same to be carried on receives directly or indirectly any compensation or reward, or any percentage or share of the money or property played, for keeping, running, carrying on or permitting the same to be carried on; 
B.  Keep, maintain or play any slot machine or punchboard played for money or for checks or tokens redeemable in money or property. 
(Ord. 1130 § 1, 1977: 1962 Code § 105.456.) 
Section 5.24.050 - Prohibited uses of buildings. 
    It is unlawful for any person knowingly to permit any of the slot machines, games or devices mentioned in this chapter to be conducted, operated, dealt or carried on in any house or building owned by such person, except by a person who has obtained a license. 
(1962 Code § 105.459.) 
Section 5.24.055 - Operation of bar or bar-restaurant with restricted gaming. 
    The following shall apply to the licensing of bars with restricted gaming and bar-restaurants with restricted gaming: 
A.  Unless a bar is a grandfathered bar or a bar-restaurant is a grandfathered bar-restaurant, an applicant for a restricted gaming license to operate more than seven slot machines as incidental or ancillary to the operation of the bar or bar-restaurant, must have or install and then maintain at all times a bartop in which all of the permitted slot machines on the premises are installed and continuously operated as bartop machines, and no less than 12 of such bartop machines meet the 40-inch height minimum set forth in the definition of bartop machine, unless the location operates less than 12 bartop machines, in which instance all bartop machines except for one bartop machine shall meet the 40-inch height minimum. 
B.  A grandfathered bar or a grandfathered bar-restaurant shall not be required to comply with the requirements of subsection (A) above; provided, however, that a grandfathered bar or grandfathered bar-restaurant that has an existing bartop and bartop machines installed in the bartop as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives shall be required to comply with subsection (A) above in the event the owner, licensee, operator or transferee fails to operate and maintain the bar or bar-restaurant in a manner substantially similar to the manner of operation and physical layout of the bar or bar-restaurant as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives, including, but not limited to removing the bartop, if applicable, or reducing the number of bartop machines, if applicable, operated on the premises. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit an owner, licensee, or operator from improving, refurbishing or redecorating a bar or a bar-restaurant; provided any grandfathered bar or grandfathered bar-restaurant that operates slot machines on the premises pursuant to a restricted gaming license must continue to operate such bar or bar-restaurant in order to remain a grandfathered bar or bar-restaurant. 
C.  i.  Submission of Diagram. Each bar licensee, including a grandfathered bar, a grandfathered bar-restaurant, new bar or new bar-restaurant that operates slot machines on the premises pursuant to a restricted gaming license shall submit to the city manager or his designee a diagram of its premises, on an 81/2" by 11" sheet of paper, depicting the configuration of the bartop with the licensee's application for business license or annual application for business license renewal. The diagram shall depict, if applicable, the location of all slot machines, including bartop machines and other slot machines, and the location of the restaurant and kitchen, if applicable. The accuracy of the submitted diagram is subject to verification by the city manager or his designee. The city manager or his designee shall review the submitted diagram to determine whether (1) in the case of a grandfathered bar or grandfathered bar-restaurant, the premises is being operated as a grandfathered bar or grandfathered bar-restaurant, or (2) in the case of a bar or bar-restaurant, the premises is being operated in compliance with subsection (A) above. In the event a grandfathered bar or grandfathered bar-restaurant is not operating as a grandfathered bar or grandfathered bar-restaurant, the bar or bar-restaurant in no longer a grandfathered bar or grandfathered bar-restaurant shall reduce the number of slot machines in operation to seven within 30 days after notice from the city. In the event a bar or bar-restaurant is not operating in compliance with subsection (A) above, the bar or bar-restaurant shall reduce the number of slot machines in operation to seven within 30 days after notice from the city. 
ii.  Submission of Annual Report. Unless a bar with restricted gaming is a grandfathered bar or a bar-restaurant with restricted gaming is a grandfathered bar-restaurant, each bar licensee operating more than seven slot machines shall file a yearly report with the city manager or his designee setting forth its compliance with subsection (A) above, on forms prescribed by the city and signed by the licensee certifying the accuracy of the report. Each report shall be for a 12-month period beginning January 1 and concluding with December 31 of that year. The report shall be filed no later than 20 business days following the end of each reporting period. Failure to timely file the report, or filing a misleading or false report, may result in disciplinary action, up to and including revocation of the licensee's restricted gaming license. If any licensee reports noncompliance with subsection (A) above, it shall remove all but seven of the slot machines from the premises. 
D.  A bar or a bar-restaurant that, upon licensing and thereafter, continues to meet the bartop and bartop machine criteria set forth in subsection (A) above shall be considered to be a primary business, to which the operation of fifteen or fewer slot machines shall be presumed to be incidental or ancillary to the primary business. 
E.  The city manager or his designee may conduct an annual audit of each bar with restricted gaming and each bar-restaurant with restricted gaming that operates in excess of seven slot machines in conjunction with the operation of the bar. If the results of the audit establish a violation of this section, the number of slot machines operated by such licensee shall be reduced to seven slot machines within 30 days after notice from the [Business License Department] of non-compliance with subsection (A) above. After such a reduction in slot machines has been in effect for at least one year, the licensee may reapply for additional bartop machines but must comply with bartop and bartop machine requirements set forth in this section. If the next annual audit does not establish compliance with the bartop and bartop machine requirements, the licensee will again be reduced to the operation of seven slot machines and will not eligible for re-application for a three-year period. 
(Ord. 2533, § 2, Added, 5/22/2017) 
Section 5.24.060 - Exemption of social games. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit social games played solely for drinks or cigars served individually, games played in private homes, residences or clubs for prizes, or coin-operated machines operated solely for cigars or drinks. 
(1962 Code § 105.462.) 
Section 5.24.070 - Persons not qualified for gaming licenses. 
    The following persons are not qualified to hold any gaming license under the provisions of this chapter: 
A.  A person who has been convicted within the preceding five years of: 
1.  A felony or any crime which under the laws of this state would be a felony; 
2.  Any crime of which fraud or intent to defraud was an element, whether in this state or elsewhere; 
3.  Any crime of moral turpitude, embezzlement or larceny against his employer or any gaming licensee; 
4.  Unlawful possession or distribution of a controlled substance; or 
5.  Any law pertaining to gaming. 
B.  A person under the age of twenty-one years; 
C.  Any person in the constructive custody of any federal, state or municipal law enforcement authority; 
D.  A person who, by reason of being associated with organized crime, or being of notorious and unsavory reputation, is not a suitable person to receive a license; or 
E.  A person who has made a false, misleading or fraudulent statement on his or her application for a license or work permit. 
(Ord. 1453 § 1, 1984: Ord. 1152 § 2, 1978: Ord. 708 § 1, 1968: 1962 Code § 105.465.) (2162, Amended, 02/10/2003; Ord. 2162, Amended, 02/10/2003) 
Section 5.24.072 - Gaming employees-Temporary work permits. 
    The chief of police may issue a temporary gaming work permit for a period not to exceed 120 days. If the Nevada Gaming Control Board, within the 120-day period, notifies the chief of police and the applicant that the board objects to the granting of a work permit to the applicant, the chief of police shall deny the work permit and shall immediately revoke any temporary work permit which he has issued. If no objection is received from the board within the 120-day period, the permit shall be deemed permanent and expires on the date set forth on the permit. 
(Ord. 1453 § 2, 1984.) (Ord. 2162, Amended, 02/10/2003) 
Section 5.24.075 - Gaming employees-Work permit required. 
A.  A gaming establishment shall not employ a person, nor shall any person accept employment as a gaming employee or independent agent unless such person is the holder of a valid gaming work permit issued in conformity with the provisions NRS 463.335, regulations adopted pursuant thereto and this chapter. Such work permits are required by NRS 463.335, not the SMC. 
B.  A resident of the city who is required to possess a work permit, or the renewal thereof, shall fully complete an application on a form prescribed by the chief of police and may be required by the chief of police, or his designee, to furnish a birth certificate, alien registration card, or other reasonable identification card to prove such applicant's name, age, place of birth, legal residence in the United States, or any other information which is requested on the application. Each applicant must pay the administrative and investigation fee at the time of submission of the application. The fee shall be set by resolution of the city council. As required by Nevada Gaming Commission regulation 5.102, each applicant must submit written verification of employment by a gaming licensee at the time he or she submits an application. 
C.  If the applicant is otherwise qualified, a temporary permit may be issued pursuant to SMC 5.24.072, and a permanent work permit may be issued pursuant to NRS 463.335, regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and this chapter for a period of five years, measured from the applicant's birthday nearest the date of issuance. 
D.  A permanent work permit issued before January 1, 2003 shall expire on the expiration date set forth on the permit, unless sooner revoked. 
E.  Each work permit shall have clearly imprinted thereon a statement that it is valid for gaming purposes only. A work permit may be renewed by submitting an application for a new permit. 
F.  A work permit shall be suspended or revoked by the chief of police upon notification from the Nevada Gaming Control Board to take such action. 
(Ord. 1152 § 3, 1978: Ord. 1130 § 3, 1977.) (Ord. 2162, Amended, 02/10/2003; Ord. 2104, Amended, 05/29/2001) 
Section 5.24.076 - Screening of applications for gaming work permits. 
    Upon receiving an application for a gaming work permit, the chief of police shall screen the applicant to determine eligibility for a temporary work permit. The screening process shall include: 
A.  Review of the application to ensure that is has been properly completed; 
B.  Confirmation of the applicant's identity by means of a valid government-issued photo identification document; 
C.  An attempt to confirm the applicant's current mailing address through inquiry of the applicant or other means; 
D.  Review of all criminal records maintained by the city which are permissible to use to determine the eligibility of the applicant for a work permit; 
E.  Confirmation through the Nevada Criminal Justice Information System as to whether or not there is any outstanding warrant for the applicant's arrest; and 
F.  Confirmation that the applicant executed an authorization to allow the Nevada Gaming Control Board to conduct an investigation of the applicant's criminal history and to obtain criminal records. 
    When conducting a review of criminal records, the chief of police may review the criminal records maintained by the central repository for Nevada which are permissible to use to determine the eligibility of the applicant for a work permit. 
(Ord. 2162, Amended, 02/10/2003; Ord. 2104, Add, 05/29/2001) 
Section 5.24.077 - Denial of application for a gaming work permit. 
A.  The chief of police shall deny an application for a gaming work permit if he determines during the screening process that the applicant has: 
1.  Purposely failed to disclose, misstated or otherwise misled him or his department with respect to any material fact contained in the application; 
2.  Been convicted within the last three years of petit theft, larceny, fraud, embezzlement, drawing checks without sufficient funds, or any other misdemeanor involving a theft crime, or any crime related to the possession, use, or transportation of narcotics or possession of narcotics-related paraphernalia; 
3.  Been convicted within the last eight years of a crime which is a felony or gross misdemeanor in this state or an offense in another state or jurisdiction which would be a felony or gross misdemeanor if committed in this state; 
4.  Been convicted of any criminal offense involving or related to gambling, including larceny-related offenses committed against a gaming establishment; or 
5.  Has any criminal charge pending which is a felony in this state or an offense in another state or jurisdiction which would be a felony if committed in this state. 
B.  Criminal case dispositions gathered pursuant to the screening process, application, or both, may be relied upon by the chief of police in determining to deny an application. If the disposition of a criminal case remains unknown despite the screening process, the chief of police shall not rely on that case to deny a temporary work permit. 
C.  Except when the screening process is suspended pursuant to subsections D or E, the chief of police shall obtain a complete set of fingerprints of the applicant and forward them to the central repository for Nevada records of criminal history and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. 
D.  If the chief of police determines during the screening process that there is an outstanding warrant for the applicant's arrest, the screening process shall be suspended, the applicant shall not be charged the full fee prescribed by resolution, and a temporary work permit shall not be issued. 
E.  If the chief of police determines during the screening process that an applicant is not in compliance with a court order for child support, the screening process shall be suspended, the applicant shall not be charged the full fee prescribed by resolution and a temporary work permit shall not be issued. When possible, the chief of police shall advise such an applicant to meet with the district attorney or other governmental official having jurisdiction over the collection of child support from him and establish a payment plan that will allow him to obtain a work permit. 
F.  The chief of police may apply the criteria for denial set forth in subsection A to the holder of a gaming work permit issued by him before January 1, 2003. If the holder's conduct would require the denial of a new work permit based on an event that occurred before or during the term of the work permit, the chief of police may revoke the work permit. Appeals from such a revocation must be made pursuant to SMC 5.24.073 and 5.24.074. 
(Ord. 2162, Added, 02/10/2003) 
Section 5.24.078 - Denial of application for work permits filed after january 1, 2003; appeal. 
    A person who filed an application for a gaming work permit with the police department after January 1, 2003 may appeal a denial of that application to the Nevada Gaming Control Board in the manner provided in NRS 463.335. 
(Ord. 2162, Added, 02/10/2003) 
Section 5.24.080 - Individuals only to be licensed. 
A.  A license may be issued only to an individual person or persons who, as licensee or licensees, shall be held personally responsible for the orderly conduct of the business. 
B.  If an applicant for a license is not the sole owner of the business to be conducted on the premises for which the license is sought, the application shall be accompanied by a verified statement of the owner or owners of the business appointing the applicant as the agent of the owner or owners and authorizing him to apply for the license and conduct the business. 
(1962 Code § 105.468.) 
Section 5.24.090 - Gambling license-Application-Contents. 
    Any person desiring to conduct, operate or carry on any gambling game or slot machine, or any game of chance, shall submit a written and verified application for such license setting forth the following information: 
A.  The name, age, sex and residence address, and the addresses of all residences for the preceding five years, of the applicant; 
B.  A description of the premises to be licensed, stating the street and number and the portion of the premises to be occupied by the establishment for which the license is sought; 
C.  The particular type of slot machine, or the particular game or device, which the applicant proposes to carry on, conduct or operate on the described premises; 
D.  The name of the owner of the premises on which the licensed business is to be conducted, and the name of his authorized agent, if any; 
E.  A statement that, if the license is granted, the applicant will conduct the establishment, game or device in accordance with the provisions of the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city applicable to the conduct of such business, and that the application is made upon the express condition that, if the license is granted, it shall be subject to revocation in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1130 § 2, 1977: 1962 Code § 105.471.) 
Section 5.24.100 - Filing application-Payment of fees. 
    Applicants for a gaming license shall begin the licensing procedure by filing a license application with the chief license officer. An applicant shall then submit to a background investigation by the chief of police and approval by the council as provided in SMC §5.24.110. Upon receiving council approval, the applicant shall pay to the finance department the full amount of the annual fee applicable to the type of license for which application is made, and the license fee for the current quarter pro-rated to the end of said quarter. However, if the applicant has held a gaming license from the city for a period of not less than one year, the initial fee shall be the license fee for the current quarter pro-rated to the end of said quarter. 
(Ord. 1762, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.474.) 
Section 5.24.110 - Investigation-Council approval. 
A.  Each person required by state law to apply for a license at the proposed gaming establishment must submit to a background investigation by the chief of police. Each applicant shall supply such identity and background information as the chief of police deems necessary to perform a thorough background investigation. 
B.  Each applicant shall pay an investigation fee established by resolution which shall not be refundable. The applicant shall pay the actual cost of conducting the investigation in the event said cost exceeds the base fee. 
C.  Upon completion of the background investigation, the chief of police shall make a recommendation to the council regarding the suitability of each applicant to receive a gaming license. The council shall determine whether the applicant shall receive a gaming license. The council has full power and authority to deny any application for any cause which it deems reasonable. If an application is denied, the council shall adopt findings of fact stating the cause of denial. 
D.  The chief license officer shall issue a gaming license when the following conditions have been met: 
1.  The council has approved all the applicants who are required to apply for the gaming license. 
2.  The proposed gaming establishment has passed all required inspections by city, county and state agencies. 
3.  The initial license fee has been paid. 
(Ord. 1762, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.477.) 
Section 5.24.120 - Gambling license-Change of agent-Supplemental application. 
A.  Where a license has been granted to the agent of title owner or owners of a business, the authority of such agent is thereafter revoked and a new agent is appointed, a verified supplemental application shall be filed with the city clerk setting forth all the information required by Section 5.24.090. The supplemental application shall be considered in the same manner by the chief of police and the council as if it were an original application, except that the business may continue to operate pending approval or disapproval thereof by the council. 
B.  In giving any notice, the council or chief of police may rely on the information in the application and supplemental application. 
(1962 Code § 105.480.) 
Section 5.24.130 - Gambling license-Expiration. 
    Each license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire twelve months after the date of issue. 
(1962 Code § 105.483.) 
Section 5.24.140 - Gambling license-Display. 
    Each license issued for any gambling game or device shall be posted in a conspicuous place where such gambling game or device is installed, in order that it may be readily inspected by any person. 
(1962 Code § 105.486.) 
Section 5.24.150 - Gambling license-Transfer. 
A.  No license issued to any person to conduct or operate a gambling game or gambling device on any premises may be transferred to any other premises or to any other part of the building containing the licensed premises, except within the room in which originally located, without the consent of the council by majority vote. 
B.  No license may be transferred by the licensee to any other person, except as provided in Section 5.24.120. 
(1962 Code § 105.489.) 
Section 5.24.160 - Operation of businesses by receivers, assignees for the benefit of creditors, guardians and personal representatives. 
A.  If a receiver or assignee for the benefit of creditors is appointed for a licensed business, if a receiver, assignee for the benefit of creditors or guardian of the property of a person holding a license is appointed during the time for which such license was granted, or if a person holding a license dies during the term for which a license was granted, the receiver, assignee, guardian, administrator or executor may continue to carry on the licensed business on the designated premises for the balance of the term for which the license was granted, with the same rights and subject to the same restrictions and liabilities as if he were the original holder of the license, if permission of the council is first obtained. 
B.  Before continuing such business, the receiver, assignee, guardian, administrator or executor shall file a written and verified statement with the city clerk, addressed to the council, setting forth the facts and circumstances under which he has succeeded to the rights of the original licensee, and his legal qualifications. 
(1962 Code § 105.492.) 
Section 5.24.170 - Gambling license-Revocation-Grounds. 
    Any license may be revoked by the council if it appears to the satisfaction of a majority of the members of the council that a licensee or an employee has: 
A.  Been convicted, subsequent to issuance of the license, of an offense of such a nature that the licensee is no longer a suitable or qualified person to hold a license; 
B.  Made any false material statement in an application for a license; 
C.  Transferred, assigned or hypothecated a license; 
D.  Failed to pay any license fee in advance; 
E.  Refused or neglected to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(1962 Code § 105.495.) 
Section 5.24.180 - Gambling license-Revocation-Procedure. 
A.  The council may, on its own motion or upon complaint under oath of any person, institute proceedings to revoke a license by mailing a complaint stating the alleged reason for such proceeding to the licensee at the address shown in his most recent application or supplemental application. 
B.  The licensee shall, within five days of the date of such mailing, unless an extension of time is granted by the council, file with the clerk of the council a written and verified answer to the complaint. 
C.  The council shall fix a day and time for a hearing at which the licensee shall be given an opportunity to be heard. If the licensee fails to file an answer within the time required, or fails to appear at the place and time designated for the hearing, the council shall order the license revoked. 
D.  The council shall, within ten days from the date of the hearing, enter its order revoking or refusing to revoke the license. 
E.  There shall be no reopening, appeal or review of the proceedings before the council, except where it subsequently appears to the satisfaction of the council that the licensee's failure to answer or appear was due to matters beyond his control, and not to negligence. 
(1962 Code § 105.498.) 
Section 5.24.190 - Gambling license-Issuance after revocation. 
    If any license is revoked under the provisions of this chapter, no license shall be granted to the licensee within two years of the date of such revocation. 
(1962 Code § 105.501.) 
Section 5.24.200 - Gambling license-Revocation-False complaints. 
    It is unlawful for any person to cause any complaint to be filed with the council seeking the revocation of any license knowing such complaint to be unfounded in fact. 
(1962 Code § 105.504.) 
Section 5.24.210 - Gambling license-Fee refund not allowed when. 
    If a licensee ceases to operate a licensed business or if the license is revoked, there shall be no refund of the license fee. 
(1962 Code § 105.507.) 
Section 5.24.220 - Unlawful for operator to allow minor to gamble. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person operating any licensed gambling game or device, or any slot machine, to allow any person under the age of twenty-one years to play any such game, device or machine, or to loiter about a room or premises in which any such game or device, excluding slot machines, is operated or conducted. 
B.  In any legal action, it shall be no excuse for the licensee, employee or dealer operating or conducting any licensed game or slot machine to plead that he believed a minor to be twenty-one years old or older. 
(1962 Code § 105.510.) 
Section 5.24.230 - Cheating prohibited. 
A.  It is unlawful to conduct, carry on, operate or deal, or allow to be conducted, carried on, operated or dealt, any cheating or thieving game or device, or to deal, conduct, carry on, operate or expose for play any game played with cards, dice or any mechanical device, or any combination thereof, which may have in any manner been marked or tampered with, or equipped with an electrical or other device which might render the game more liable to win or lose. The use of marked cards, loaded dice or machines or devices which have been plugged or tampered with is unlawful. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to introduce or use any marked cards, loaded dice or other fraudulent device in any gambling game, to insert anything but a coin minted by the United States of America into a slot machine designed for coin operation, or to tamper with or in any way hinder any gambling game or device. 
(1962 Code § 105.513.) 
Section 5.24.240 - Excessive noise prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any licensee of an establishment to permit the creation of noises in such establishment by boisterous conduct on the part of individuals, by music or entertainment created by mechanical musical instruments or otherwise, or by dancing or other sources of vibration, which unreasonably disturb any person of ordinary sensibilities in any adjoining room, building or premises. 
(1962 Code § 105.516.) 
Section 5.24.250 - Duties of the chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall: 
A.  Inspect or cause to be inspected each premises where gambling games or devices are conducted or operated; 
B.  Investigate the qualifications of all applicants for licenses or employment in licensed establishments, report the results of his investigation to the council, and recommend the allowance or disallowance of each application; 
C.  Institute, through the proper authorities, proceedings, actions and prosecutions for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter relating to penalties, liabilities and punishments for refusal or neglect to corn ply with the provisions of this chapter; 
D.  Recommend to the council the revocation of any license if the licensee: 
1.  Has refused to comply with, or has violated, any of the provisions of this chapter, 
2.  Has been found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or of any law of the state regulating or pertaining to the conduct or operation of any gambling game or device, 
3.  Has misrepresented a material fact in obtaining a license, 
4.  Is no longer a suitable person to hold a license, having due consideration for the proper protection of the public health, safety, morals and good order, and the general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(1962 Code § 105.519.) 
Section 5.24.260 - Access of officials and officers to gambling premises. 
A.  Every official and police officer of the city shall have access to every part of the premises for which a license is issued at any time when such establishment is open for the transaction of business and at all other reasonable times. 
B.  No gambling business shall at any time be carried on behind locked doors. 
(1962 Code § 105.522.) 
Section 5.24.270 - Annual license fees-Payment in advance-Exception. 
    Gambling license fees shall be in the amounts provided in Sections 5.24.280 through 5.24.300 and shall be paid annually in advance, except that a licensee who has held a gambling license for not less than one year may pay the fee quarterly in advance. 
(1962 Code § 105.525.) 
Section 5.24.280 - License fees for specific games, devices and machines. 
A.  The annual license fee for each game of faro, chuck-a-luck, twenty-one, hazard, big six, baccarat, roulette or craps shall be four hundred twenty dollars for each layout upon which players may play. 
B.  The annual license fee for each game of tango, Chinese lottery, bingo or similar game, and for each race horse pool, shall be six hundred dollars. 
C.  The annual license fee for stud poker or draw poker for money shall be three hundred dollars per table. 
D.  The annual license fee for panguingui for money shall be one hundred forty-four dollars per table. 
E.  The annual license fee for pools or poolrooms where licenses are charged or percentages taken by the person conducting the same shall be three hundred sixty dollars. 
F.  The annual license fee for persons maintaining and operating punchboards shall be twenty-four dollars. Such a license shall authorize the licensee to maintain and operate as many punchboards as he wishes in one establishment. 
G.  The annual license fee for each money slot machine shall be one hundred twenty dollars for each separate coin operated mechanism on, or each separate denomination of coin played in, such machine. 
H.  The annual fee for each coin-operated twenty-one, poker, and dice game shall be one hundred twenty dollars per player position. 
I.  The annual license fee for each game of keno and race horse keno shall be nine hundred dollars. 
J.  The annual license fee for each race horse and sports book shall be one thousand two hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 1293 § 5, 1980: Ord. 1111 § 1, 1977: Ord. 1085 § 1, 1976: Ord. 648 § 1, 1966: 1962 Code § 105.528.) 
Section 5.24.290 - License fees for table games and devices not provided for specifically. 
    The annual license fee for each table game or device played for money, other than those specified in Section 5.24.280, shall be two hundred eighty-eight dollars for each such game or device. 
(Ord. 1293 § 6, 1980: Ord. 648 § 2, 1966: 1962 Code § 105.531.) 
Section 5.24.300 - License fees for distribution of information to race horse books. 
A.  The annual license fee for the distribution of information to race horse books, and for the installation, maintenance and operation of equipment incident thereto, shall be three hundred sixty dollars for each race horse book in the city to which such information is furnished, if the weekly fee paid by each operator of such a book does not exceed five hundred sixty dollars. 
B.  If such weekly fee exceeds five hundred sixty dollars, the annual license fee shall be one thousand four hundred forty dollars for each such book. 
C.  The issuance of such a license does not require the licensee to deliver such service to any race horse book licensed under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1293 § 7, 1980: Ord. 648 § 3, 1966: 1962 Code § 105.534.) 
Section 5.24.310 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(1962 Code § 105.537.) 
Chapter 5.28 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

Section 5.28.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the words and terms defined in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. 
A.  "Alcohol" means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl or spirit of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. 
B.  "Alcoholic beverage" means any distilled or rectified spirits, potable alcohol, brandy, whiskey, rum, gin, aromatic bitters, beer, wine and every liquid, semi-solid or solid containing alcohol capable of being consumed by a human being. 
C.  "Bartender" means any person who: 
1.  Opens a bottle, can or other container of alcoholic beverage for service to a patron in that container; 
2.  Pours or otherwise transfers an alcoholic beverage from a tap, or from a bottle, can or other container, into different containers (such as glasses or cups) for service to patrons; or 
3.  Mixes alcoholic beverages with other alcoholic beverages or with nonalcoholic beverages for service to patrons. 
D.  "Beer" means any fermented beverage of any name or description manufactured wholly or in part from malt, or from any substitute therefore, and includes such liquors as ale, beer, porter and stout. 
E.  "Convicted" means a finding of guilt resulting from a plea of guilty, the decision of a court or magistrate or the verdict of a jury, irrespective of the pronouncement of judgment or the suspension thereof. 
F.  "Council" means the mayor and the members of the city council. 
G.  "Dining area" means a place which is regularly and in a bona fide manner used and kept open for the serving of food to patrons for compensation: 
1.  Which has suitable kitchen facilities connected therewith which are authorized by a permit issued by the Washoe County Health Department - District Board of Health; and 
2.  In which alcoholic beverages and food prepared on the premises are served at separate tables or booths and are not served over a bar or counter; and 
3.  In which alcoholic beverages and food prepared on the premises are served separately or in combination. 
H.  "Fraternal club" means an organization of persons which: 
1.  Keeps, conducts and maintains an establishment solely for bona fide fraternal, social, recreational, benevolent or athletic purposes, and not for pecuniary gain; 
2.  Does not traffic in alcoholic beverages for profit; 
3.  Dispenses alcoholic beverages to its members or bona fide guests only; and 
4.  Does not maintain or possess a public bar or place for the sale of alcoholic beverages to the public. 
I.  "Holder" means a person to whom a license has been issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
J.  "Kitchen facilities" means commercial-grade kitchen items, including but not limited to, sinks, counters, ovens, griddles, grills, microwaves and dishwashers necessary to prepare and cook food served in a full-service restaurant. 
K.  "License" means a license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
L.  "Licensee" means any person to whom a license has been issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
M.  "Manufacturer-prepared alcoholic beverage" means an alcoholic beverage which is placed in a sealed container by the manufacturer, is labeled with its alcohol content by volume, and is served without alteration of the beverage in the container. 
N.  "Nudity" means: 
1.  The showing of the human female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any portion of the areola and nipple; 
2.  The showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, perineum, or anal area with less than a fully opaque covering of any portion thereof; or, 
3.  The depiction of the human male genitals in a discernible turgid state, whether or not covered. 
4.  For the purposes of this section, the breast feeding of a child by the mother of the child does not constitute a state of nudity, irrespective of whether the nipple of the mother's breast is uncovered during or incidental to the breast feeding. 
O.  "Package" means any immediate container of an alcoholic beverage which is filled or packaged by the manufacturer or bottler thereof for sale by such manufacturer or bottler. 
P.  "Person" means an individual or individuals. 
Q.  "Premises" means any place connected with and accessible to a licensed business including any outdoor area which is dedicated for seasonal use as a cafe or bar and which is approved by the city pursuant to chapter 5.77 of this code. 
R.  "Retailer" means any person who sells at retail any alcoholic beverage. 
S.  "Retail sale" means a sale to a consumer or any other person for any purpose other than for resale. 
T.  "Sale" means any transfer, exchange or barter in any manner or by any means for a consideration, and includes soliciting or receiving an order for, keeping or exposing for sale, keeping with intention to sell, and delivery of, any alcoholic beverage in the city. 
U.  "Wholesaler" means any person who sells at wholesale only any alcoholic beverage. 
V.  "Wholesale sale" means a sale to any person for purposes of resale. 
W.  "Wine" includes "fruit juices" and means all alcoholic beverages which are obtained by the fermentation of the juice of grapes or other fruits or agricultural products and which do not contain more than 24 percent alcohol by volume. 
(Ord. 1861, 1995: Ord. 1584 § 1, 1987: Ord. 1582 § 1, 1987: 1962 Code §105.186-105.243.) (Ord. 2099, Amended 4/23/01) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2099, Amended, 04/23/2001) 
Section 5.28.020 - Policy declaration. 
    It is declared to be the policy of the city that all establishments where alcoholic beverages are manufactured, sold or distributed in the city shall be licensed and controlled in order to protect the public health, safety, morals and good order, and the general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(1962 Code § 105.246.) 
Section 5.28.025 - Nudity prohibited. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to knowingly or intentionally appear in a state of nudity at any premises or establishment at which alcoholic beverages are sold or served under any alcoholic beverage license required by the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  It is unlawful for the holder of any alcoholic beverage license issued pursuant to this chapter, or for the holder's agent, a co-owner or any employee of the business, to allow any nudity by patrons, employees, performers or any other person in the premises or establishment at which alcoholic beverages are sold or served under such license. 
C.  It is unlawful for any person who is required to obtain an alcoholic beverage license pursuant to this chapter, but who fails to obtain such a license, to allow any nudity by patrons, employees, performers or any other person in the premises or establishment for which such a license is required. 
(Ord. 2099, Add, 4/23/01) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2099, Add, 04/23/2001) 
Section 5.28.030 - Manufacturer's license. 
    It is unlawful for any person to manufacture or bottle any alcoholic beverage for sale without first obtaining an alcoholic beverage manufacturer's license. The holder of such a license may manufacture and bottle any alcoholic beverage and sell the manufactured or bottled product at wholesale and, where zoning laws are complied with, at retail. 
(Ord. 1797, 1993: 1962 Code § 105.249.) 
Section 5.28.040 - Wholesaler's license. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell any alcoholic beverage, other than beer, at wholesale without first obtaining an alcoholic beverage wholesaler's license. The holder of such a license may sell all alcoholic beverages at wholesale only. 
(1962 Code § 105.252.) 
Section 5.28.050 - Delivery license. 
    It is unlawful for any person, without a fixed place of business in the city, to deliver any alcoholic beverage without first obtaining an alcoholic beverage delivery license. The holder of such a license may deliver alcoholic beverages for resale in the city. 
(Ord. 802 § 1, 1970: 1962 Code § 105.253.) 
Section 5.28.060 - Package license. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell any alcoholic beverage, other than beer, in packages without first obtaining an alcoholic beverage package license. The holder of such a license may sell all alcoholic beverages in packages, at retail only, for consumption outside the establishment where sold. 
(1962 Code § 105.255.) 
Section 5.28.070 - Fraternal club license. 
    It is unlawful for any fraternal club to sell any alcoholic beverage, other than beer, without first obtaining a fraternal club alcoholic beverage license. The holder of such a license may sell all alcoholic beverages at retail only, or for consumption on the premises only. 
(1962 Code § 105.258.) 
Section 5.28.080 - On-premises license-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell for consumption on the premises any alcoholic beverage, other than beer, without first obtaining either an on-premises alcoholic beverage license or a cabaret license. The holder of an on-premises alcoholic beverage license may sell all alcoholic beverages in original packages at retail only, or for consumption on the premises only. 
(1962 Code § 105.261.) 
Section 5.28.090 - On-premises license-Restrictions on location; walk-up windows. 
A.  No on-premises license shall be issued authorizing the sale of alcoholic beverages on any premises which is located within 500 feet of any school, school building, classroom or church or if denial of such a license is deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the City of Sparks. 
B.  Nothing in this section shall be construed to invalidate any license issued before April 16, 2009. Premises approved for the holder of an on-premises license before April 16, 2009 that are located within 500 feet of any school, school building, classroom or church qualify for continued use as an on-premises alcoholic beverage establishment by the person who was the holder on April 16, 2009 and by any subsequent holder who otherwise qualifies for an alcoholic beverage license, if denial is not deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare. The city council hereby declares its intention to purposefully apply the provisions of this section retroactively to prevent impairment of any property interest existing on or before April 16, 2009. 
C.  It is unlawful for any on-premises licensee or any employee thereof to sell alcoholic beverages through a walk-up window except during the hours alcoholic beverages are authorized for sale at a special event conducted pursuant to Chapter 9.34 of the SMC and when the area adjacent to said walk-up window is within the area designated for the special event. 
(Ord. 1861, 1995: Ord. 557 § 1, 1964.) (Ord. 2099, Amended 4/23/01) (Ord. 2423, Amended 4/13/2009) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009; Ord. 2018, Amended, 03/22/1999) 
Section 5.28.100 - Cabaret license. 
    It is unlawful for any person to permit any singing, dancing, floor show or entertainment to be conducted or carried on in any establishment where alcoholic beverages are sold without first obtaining a cabaret license. The holder of such a license may sell all alcoholic beverages in original packages at retail only, or for consumption on the premises only. 
(1962 Code § 105.264.) 
Section 5.28.110 - Dining room wine and beer license. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell wine or beer in a dining room without first obtaining a dining room wine and beer license, an on-premises alcoholic beverage license or a cabaret license. The holder of a dining room wine and beer license may sell wine and beer in original packages at retail only, or for consumption on the premises only. 
(Ord. 1115 § 1, 1977: 1962 Code § 105.267.) 
Section 5.28.120 - Beer wholesaler's license. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell beer at wholesale without first obtaining a beer wholesaler's license or an alcoholic beverage wholesaler's license. The holder of a beer wholesaler's license may sell beer only, and only at wholesale. 
(1962 Code § 105.270.) 
Section 5.28.125 - Beer delivery license. 
    It is unlawful for any person, without a fixed place of business in the city, to deliver beer without first obtaining an alcoholic beverage delivery license or a beer delivery license. The holder of a beer delivery license may deliver beer only for resale in the city. 
(Ord. 1115 § 3, 1977.) 
Section 5.28.130 - Beer package license. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell beer in packages without first obtaining a beer package license. The holder of such a license may sell beer at retail in packages only and only for consumption outside the establishment where sold. 
(1962 Code § 105.273.) 
Section 5.28.135 - Incidental beer and wine package license. 
    A business engaged primarily in the sale and delivery of flowers, food or crafts gift baskets or related goods other than alcoholic beverages may apply for an incidental beer and wine package license. The sale of beer and wine must be incidental to the primary business enterprise and constitute no more than fifteen percent (15%) of the total gross receipts of the business. The licensee may only sell beer and wine as part of a package which includes other goods. 
(Ord. 1791, 1993.) 
Section 5.28.140 - Fraternal club beer license. 
    It is unlawful for any fraternal club to sell beer without first obtaining a fraternal club beer license or a fraternal club alcoholic beverage license. The holder of a fraternal club beer license may sell beer only at retail, and only for consumption on the premises. 
(1962 Code § 105.276.) 
Section 5.28.150 - On-premises beer license. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell beer at retail for consumption on the premises without first obtaining an on-premises beer license, an on-premises alcoholic beverage license or a cabaret license. The holder of an on-premises beer license may sell beer only, and only at retail in original packages, or only for consumption on the premises where sold. 
(1962 Code § 105.279.) 
Section 5.28.155 - Exceptions to general prohibition on possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages in public places: park waivers, special events, temporary alcohol permit. 
    The following departments of the city may permit the possession, sale and consumption of alcohol in public places, which is otherwise unlawful under SMC 9.36.010: 
A.  Parks. The department of parks and recreation may waive the provisions of 9.36.010 for any group that reserves all or part of a city park or facility under the control of the department. Such a waiver is subject to all rules and regulations of the department, may allow only the consumption of beer and wine, is limited to the dates and times on which the parks or facility is reserved and is revocable by the director of the department or his designee for any violation of the department's rules and regulations or any violation of law by the person obtaining the waiver or any participant in the event. Every waiver issued by the department of parks and recreation must state on its face the conditions and limitations set forth in the preceding sentence. 
B.  Public property within Victorian Square. The special events office may issue a special event alcoholic beverage license to any applicant conducting a Chapter 9.34 special event on public property within Victorian Square (as defined in SMC 9.34.010). The provisions of SMC 5.28.160 and 9.34.025 govern the issuance of such licenses. A special event alcoholic beverage license issued by the special events office must state on the face of the license that it allows the sale and consumption of only beer, wine and manufacturer-prepared alcoholic beverages which do not exceed 12 percent alcohol by volume. The license is revocable by the special events supervisor for any violation of law by the licensee or his employees, agents or volunteers. 
C.  Public property outside of Victorian Square. The police department may issue a Temporary Alcohol Permit to any applicant conducting a Chapter 9.34 special event on public property outside of Victorian Square (as defined in SMC 9.34.010). The provisions of SMC 5.28.160 govern the issuance of such permits, which may authorize the sale and consumption of only beer, wine and manufacturer-prepared alcoholic beverages which do not exceed 12 percent alcohol by volume. A Temporary Alcohol Permit must state on its face that it allows the sale and consumption of only beer, wine and manufacturer-prepared alcoholic beverages that do not exceed 12 percent alcohol by volume. The temporary permit is revocable by the chief of police or his designee for any violation of law by the licensee, his employees, agents or volunteers, or by any participant in the special event. 
(Ord. 2446, Add, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.160 - Special event alcoholic beverage license. 
A.  Except as provided in subsections B and C, it is unlawful for any person to sell alcoholic beverages in packages or for consumption on the premises at a special event as defined in SMC 9.34.010 without first obtaining a special event alcoholic beverage license. 
B.  A person who has a permanent, fixed location that is licensed under the provisions of this chapter and lies within the exterior boundaries of a special event is not required to obtain a special event alcoholic beverage license for the special event and is not subject to the limitations on the types of alcoholic beverages which may be sold that are set forth in subsection H. 
C.  A sponsor of a special event who obtains a special event permit pursuant to Chapter 9.34 of the SMC and also obtains a special event alcoholic beverage license pursuant to this chapter may authorize any vendor who qualifies under subsection G to sell or serve alcoholic beverages authorized to be sold under subsection H. Such vendors are deemed to be operating under the special event permittee's special event alcoholic beverage license and are not required to obtain a special event alcoholic beverage license for the special event. 
D.  No special event alcoholic beverage license may be issued for a special event in Victorian Square (as defined in SMC 9.34.010) unless a special event permit has first been issued allowing the special event. 
E.  A special event alcoholic beverage license shall not be valid for more than seven (7) consecutive days, or, in the case of seasonal operations, more than one (1) day per week for a maximum of twelve (12) consecutive weeks. 
F.  Bartenders, other employees or volunteers serving alcoholic beverages under a special event alcoholic beverage license are not required to hold a work permit issued pursuant to SMC 5.28.240. 
G.  Except for the sponsor of a special event who obtains a special event permit, only applicants who hold a valid alcoholic beverage license issued by the City of Sparks, the City of Reno or the County of Washoe or which are a non-profit or charitable organization located within or having offices within Washoe County are eligible to receive a special event alcoholic beverage license. 
H.  A special event alcoholic beverage license issued by the special event office pursuant to SMC 5.28.155 and this section authorizes the sale of only beer, wine or manufacturer-prepared alcoholic beverages which do not exceed 12 percent alcohol by volume. 
I.  Every special event alcoholic beverage license issued pursuant to this section must specify what alcoholic beverages are allowed to be sold or served under the license. 
J.  All applicants must pay the fee for a special event alcoholic beverage license prior to obtaining the license therefore. 
(Ord. 1861, 1995: 1962 Code § 105.282.) (Ord. 2423, Amended 4/13/2009) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.165 - Unlawful to consume or sell alcoholic beverages on public property, exceptions. 
A.  It is unlawful to sell, serve, consume or drink an alcoholic beverage on public property without first obtaining a waiver from the department of parks and recreation (for special events within parks and ballfields), a special events alcoholic beverage license from the special events office (for special events within Victorian Square) or a temporary alcohol permit from the police department (for special events on public property outside of Victorian Square but not in parks or ballfields). 
B.  A person who violates a provision of this section shall be punished as provided in SMC 5.28.390. 
(Ord. 2446, Add, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.170 - Persons unqualified for alcoholic beverage licenses. 
    The following persons are not qualified to hold any license under the provisions of this chapter: 
A.  A person who has been convicted within the preceding five years of: 
1.  A felony or any crime which under the laws of this state would be a felony, 
2.  Any crime of which fraud or intent to defraud was an element under the laws of this state, other states or laws of the United States of America, 
3.  Embezzlement, obtaining money or property by false pretenses or larceny, 
4.  Robbery, burglary, or a crime involving the buying or receiving of stolen property, 
5.  A crime involving the use, possession, distribution, or sale of narcotic drugs. 
6.  A crime involving the unlawful use, carrying or possession of a firearm or other deadly weapon. 
B.  A person under the age of twenty-one years; 
C.  A person who is not qualified to hold a license to sell alcoholic beverages under any state or federal law or regulation; 
D.  A person who has one or more criminal convictions in this state, any other state or the United States of America that indicate that the person poses a threat to the general health, safety or welfare of others. 
E.  A person whose arrest is sought by warrant or otherwise by a law enforcement agency. 
(Ord. 1582 § 4,1987: 1962 Code § 105.285.) (Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.180 - Licenses other than package licenses prohibited where drugs are dispensed. 
    No license shall be issued authorizing the sale of alcoholic beverages on premises where drugs or narcotics are kept, stored, dispensed or sold, except beer package licenses and alcoholic beverage package licenses. 
(1962 Code § 105.288.) 
Section 5.28.185 - License required for each location where alcoholic beverages are sold or served. 
A.  An alcoholic beverage license is required at each location where alcoholic beverages are sold or served. An establishment selling or serving alcoholic beverages at more than one location under the same or a different business name is required to have a separate alcoholic beverage license for each location. 
B.  An establishment selling or serving alcoholic beverages may operate one or more bar areas within the same structure at the same location under one on-premises license. 
C.  "Location" has the meaning set forth in SMC 5.04.032 and, for purposes of this chapter, a business selling or serving alcoholic beverages which has a separate entrance and signage of a name that is different from other businesses sharing a common address is deemed to be a separate location. 
(Ord. 2446, Add, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.190 - Sole proprietors to be licensed individually; other business entities may appoint an agent as licensee. 
A.  A license may be issued only to an individual person, who, as licensee, shall be held personally responsible for the orderly conduct of the business. 
B.  If an applicant for a license is a sole proprietorship (in which one person is the sole owner of the of the assets of the business to be conducted on the premises for which the license is sought), the license may be issued only to the sole proprietor. 
C.  If an applicant for a license is not a sole proprietorship, the license may be issued to an owner or an agent of the owners. If an agent applies, the application must be accompanied by a verified statement of one or more of the owners of the business appointing the applicant as the agent of the owners and authorizing the agent to apply for the license and conduct the business. 
(1962 Code § 105.291.) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.200 - Licenses-Application to chief licensing officer-Contents. 
    Before any license is issued authorizing the sale of any alcoholic beverage, the applicant shall submit a written and verified application for such license to the chief licensing officer setting forth the following information: 
A.  The name, age, sex and residence address, and the addresses of all residences for the preceding ten years, of the applicant; 
B.  A description of the premises to be licensed stating the street and number and the portion of the premises to be occupied by the establishment for which the license is sought; 
C.  The type of license for which application is made, and, if application is for an on-premises alcoholic beverage license or a cabaret license, the maximum number of bartenders to be employed during any 24 hour period; 
D.  The name of the owner of the structure within which the licensed business is to be conducted, and the name of the owner's authorized representative, if any; 
E.  The applicant's physical address where he permanently resides, and any address or post office box number where he desires correspondence to be mailed; 
F.  Any other information deemed necessary by the chief licensing officer to identify the applicant and determine if the applicant qualifies for an alcoholic beverage license; and 
G.  A statement that, if the license is granted, the applicant will conduct the establishment in accordance with the provisions of the laws of the United States of America, the laws of the State of Nevada and the ordinances of the City of Sparks applicable to the conduct of such business, and that the application is made upon the express condition that, if the license is granted, it shall be subject to revocation in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(1962 Code § 105.294.) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.210 - Filing application-Fees. 
A.  Applicants for an alcoholic beverage license shall begin the licensing procedure by filing a license application with the chief license officer and paying the non-refundable fee for a license background investigation. An applicant shall then submit to a criminal fingerprint investigation by the chief of police as provided in SMC 5.28.220. Upon receiving approval of the chief licensing officer and the chief of police, the applicant shall pay to the finance department the full amount of the annual fee applicable to the type of license for which application is made pro-rated to June 30th. 
B.  Applications for special event alcoholic beverage licenses shall be reviewed and issued in accordance with the procedures set forth in SMC 5.28.160 and Chapter 9.34 of the SMC and any resolutions or regulations implementing said chapter. 
(Ord. 1762, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.297.) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.220 - Criminal fingerprint investigation by chief of police; approval; exception for gaming licensees and others. 
A.  Except as provided in subsections F, G and H, each person required to apply for an alcoholic beverage license at a proposed establishment must submit to a criminal fingerprint investigation by the chief of police. Each applicant shall supply such identity, background information and fingerprints as the chief of police deems necessary to perform the investigation. 
B.  Each applicant required to submit to an investigation must pay a criminal fingerprint investigation fee which shall not be refundable. The applicant shall pay the actual cost of conducting the investigation in the event said cost exceeds the base fee. 
C.  The chief licensing officer shall notify the chief of police of every application not requiring a police investigation to be performed because the applicant possesses a current, valid gaming license or is exempt from investigation pursuant to subsections G or H. 
D.  Upon completion of the background investigation (if required), and based on the requirements of this chapter, the chief of police shall determine whether the applicant is qualified to receive an alcoholic beverage license. The chief of police shall deny any application for any reason enumerated in SMC 5.28.170 or 5.28.300. After making a determination, the chief of police shall inform the chief licensing officer of the reason for the approval or denial in writing. By copy thereof, the chief licensing officer shall inform the applicant of the approval or denial. 
E.  The chief license officer shall issue an alcoholic beverage license when the following conditions have been met: 
1.  The chief of police has approved all of the applicants for the alcoholic beverage license. 
2.  The proposed alcoholic beverage establishment has passed all required inspections by city, county and state agencies. 
3.  The initial license fee has been paid. 
F.  An applicant for an alcoholic beverage license is not required to submit to a criminal background investigation by the chief of police if the applicant holds a current, valid license issued by the Nevada Gaming Commission which authorizes the applicant to engage in gaming or pari-mutual wagering. The burden of proving the issuance of such a gaming or pari-mutual license is on the applicant. The fact that an applicant holds a current, valid gaming or pari-mutual license issued by the State of Nevada does not automatically qualify the applicant for an alcoholic beverage license, and the chief of police may deny a license to any applicant for any reason enumerated in SMC 5.28.170 or 5.28.300. 
G.  An applicant for a license for an additional or different location who qualifies under SMC 5.28.280 is not required to submit to a criminal background investigation by the chief of police. 
H.  An applicant who qualifies for a downgraded license pursuant to SMC 5.28.285 is not required to submit to a criminal background investigation by the chief of police to obtain the downgraded license. 
(Ord. 1762, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.300.) (Ord. 2423, Amended, 4/13/2009) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.225 - Material change in ownership requires filing of new application and license; temporary license; cash bond; penalties for failure to comply; procedure to change business name. 
A.  Duty to File a New Application and Obtain a New License. If a business holding an alcoholic beverage license undergoes a material change in ownership, an owner or agent of the entity acquiring the majority of the business who qualifies under SMC 5.28.190 shall, within 30 days after the material change in ownership is made, file an application and pay any required investigation and other fees to obtain the appropriate license. The application must be made to the chief licensing officer, the applicant must be investigated (if required) by the chief of police and the premises must be inspected and approved in the manner required for an initial license. The 30-day period described in this subsection is deemed to be the grace period described in SMC 5.12.090. 
B.  Temporary License During Investigation. Upon receiving proof that the owner or agent of the new business described in subsection A has filed an application with the chief licensing officer pursuant to subsection A and has also filed an application for a license investigation (if required) with the chief of police and paid any required investigation fees, and upon receiving from the applicant a $1,000.00 cash bond, the chief licensing officer shall issue a temporary alcoholic beverage license to the applicant which is valid for a period of 90 days. A temporary license allows the new applicant to operate the business pending the investigation by the chief of police. If the chief of police approves the applicant for the required alcoholic beverage license and the chief licensing officer issues such license, the cash bond shall be refunded to the applicant. However, if the investigation or other factors show that the applicant does not qualify for the required license and the chief of police denies the license, the temporary license becomes void immediately upon such a denial and the cash bond is thereupon forfeited to the city by operation of law. 
C.  Temporary License Not Required if No Police Investigation is Required. If the sole owner or entity acquiring the majority of the business is not required to undergo a police background investigation pursuant to SMC 5.28.220, the owner of agent of the entity is not required to obtain a temporary license under subsection B. Such an applicant may operate under the existing license until the application is approved or denied. 
D.  Penalty for Failure of Acquiring Person or Entity to Comply. If an owner or agent of the person or entity acquiring the majority of the business fails to comply with subsections A and B by timely filing a new application with the chief licensing officer and with the chief of police for an investigation (if required), obtaining a temporary license (if required) and paying all required fees within the 30-day grace period, the application shall be deemed delinquent and subject to the same delinquent fees as a failure to renew a license set forth in SMC 5.12.105. 
E.  Change of Name. A business which has changed its name must inform the chief licensing officer and the chief of police of that fact in writing within 15 working days after the change in name is actually made to the business signage. There is no fee for a change in name if the name of the licensee does not change. 
F.  Definition. For purposes of this section, a "material change of ownership" means a transfer of more than 50 percent of ownership interest when compared to the total ownership interest of all persons. 
(Ord. 2446, Add, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.235 - Employee age requirements. 
A.  It is unlawful for a licensee, agent or manager of an alcoholic beverage establishment to employ any person as a bartender who has not attained the age of 21 years. "Bartender" is defined in SMC 5.28.010. 
B.  Except as provided in subsection C, it is unlawful for a licensee, agent or manager of an alcoholic beverage establishment to employ any person who has not attained the age of 18 years in any position in which the employee sells or serves alcoholic beverages. 
C.  A person who has attained the age of 16 years and has not attained the age of 18 years may be employed in a retail food store for the sale or disposition of alcoholic beverages if: 
1.  He is supervised by a person who is 18 years of age or over and who is an employee of the business which sells or disposes of the alcoholic beverages; 
2.  The person 18 years of age or over who is supervising the person under 18 is actually present at the time that the person under 18 sells or disposes of the alcoholic beverages; and 
3.  The alcoholic beverage is in an unopened package or container. 
D.  Pursuant to subsection 3 of NRS 202.020, this section imposes additional and broader restrictions than set forth in the NRS. 
(Ord. 1584 § 2, 1987.) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.240 - Bartenders of an on-premises, cabaret or dining room wine and beer licensee - work permit required. 
A.  An on-premises (including beer), cabaret or dining room wine and beer licensee shall not employ a bartender nor shall any person accept employment as a bartender of such a licensee, unless such person is the holder of a valid work permit issued in conformity with the provisions of Chapter 5.22 and this chapter. 
B.  Each work permit for a bartender shall have clearly imprinted thereon a statement that it is valid for employment by a specific on-premises, cabaret or dining room wine and beer licensee only, and that it is valid at that place of employment for a period of 5 years after the date of issuance. A work permit shall be renewed by issuance of a new permit. 
C.  A work permit for a bartender shall expire 10 days after a change of place of employment, or if the holder thereof is not employed as an employee of an on-premises, cabaret or dining room wine and beer licensee within the city for a period of 90 days or more. 
D.  A bartender shall carry a work permit issued to him pursuant to this section on his person whenever he is engaged in the activity of a bartender at any location within the city. 
(Ord. 1584 § 3, 1987: Ord. 1582 § 2, 1987: 1962 Code § 105.306.) (Ord. 2190, Amended 10/13/2003) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.28.250 - Licenses-Change of agent. 
A.  If a license has been granted to the agent of the owners of a business and the authority of such agent is thereafter revoked by an owner or the agent terminates his status with the owners, and a new agent is appointed, a verified supplemental application shall be filed by the new agent within 30 days after the revocation or termination with the chief licensing officer setting forth all information required by SMC 5.28.200. The supplemental application shall be investigated in the same manner by the chief of police as if it were an original application, except that the business may continue to operate pending approval or denial by the chief of police. In giving any notice, the chief of police may rely on the information in the application and supplemental application. 
B.  No inspection of the premises is required to approve a supplemental application pursuant to this section. (1962 Code § 105.309) (Ord. 2190, Amended 10/13/2003) 
(Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.260 - Licenses-Expiration. 
    Each license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on June 30th of the licensing year during which the license was issued, except amusement park and special events beer licenses. 
(Ord. 1115 § 2, 1977: 1962 Code § 105.312.) 
Section 5.28.270 - Licenses-Display. 
A.  During all of the period of time for which a license has been issued authorizing the sale of alcoholic beverages, the license shall be posted and displayed in a conspicuous place in the room where such business is carried on in order that all persons visiting such place may readily see and read the same. 
B.  It is unlawful for a licensee to fail to so post a license and keep it so posted, or to post the license or permit it to be posted in an establishment other than that licensed, or in an establishment where traffic in alcoholic beverages is carried on or conducted by any person other than the licensee. 
(1962 Code § 105.315.) 
Section 5.28.280 - Licenses-Valid only at location shown on license; adding or changing locations requires new license. 
A.  A license issued pursuant to this chapter is valid only at the location stated on the license. 
B.  A person may not add a new location to an existing license. A new license is required for each new location and must be obtained in the manner provided for an initial license. 
C.  A person possessing a license under this chapter for one location may not use the license for that location to conduct business at a different location. A new license is required for each different location and must be obtained in the manner provided for an initial license. 
D.  An existing alcoholic beverage licensee who has held such a license for a period of three years or less and who applies for a new license for an additional or different location is not required to be investigated by the chief of police. 
(1962 Code § 105.318.) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.285 - Downgrading a license; procedure. 
A.  A person who has held a license issued pursuant to this chapter for a period of three years or less may make a written request to the chief licensing officer to downgrade the existing license to a different license having a lower base license fee set forth in SMC 5.28.380. The existing license and the requested license must be for the same location. 
B.  A request to downgrade a license pursuant to subsection A does not require inspection or a criminal fingerprint investigation by the chief of police. 
C.  If the chief licensing officer finds that the applicant for the requested license has passed all required inspections, has paid all fees incurred under the existing license and has paid the initial license fee for the requested license, the chief licensing officer shall issue the requested license for the next year. 
D.  For purposes of this section, "base license fee" means the fixed annual fee for the license set forth in SMC 5.28.380, exclusive of any fee based on gross receipts. 
(Ord. 2446, Add, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.290 - Operation of businesses by receivers, assignees for the benefit of creditors, guardians and personal representatives. 
A.  If a receiver or assignee for the benefit of creditors is appointed for a licensed business, if a receiver, assignee for the benefit of creditors or guardian of the property of a person holding a license is appointed during the time for which such license was granted, or if a person holding a license dies during the term for which such license was granted, the receiver, assignee, guardian, administrator or executor may continue to carry on the licensed business on the designated premises for the balance of the term for which the license was granted, or for such period as is necessary to approve or deny the supplemental application, with the same rights and subject to the same restrictions and liabilities as if he were the original holder of such license, if permission of the chief of police is first obtained. 
B.  Before continuing such business, the receiver, assignee, guardian, administrator or executor shall file a verified statement with the chief of police, setting forth the facts and circumstances under which he has succeeded to the rights of the original licensee, and his legal qualifications. A supplemental application shall be filed by that successor or his agent within 30 days after the filing of a verified statement and must be investigated and approved or denied in the manner provided for a change of agent. 
(1962 Code § 105.321.) (Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.295 - Access to establishment without warrant. 
A.  The city council hereby finds: 
1.  The city is permitted by statute and city charter to regulate the conduct of alcohol sales businesses within its corporate limits. 
2.  Alcohol sales businesses are part of a closely-regulated industry. 
3.  By virtue of statutes and ordinances, alcoholic beverage licensees are required to conduct their business within particular parameters and are prohibited from permitting or engaging in certain acts and conduct. 
4.  The city has a substantial interest in preserving the public's health, safety, welfare and quality of life through the regulation of businesses selling alcohol beverages. 
5.  Inspection of commercial property on which alcohol is sold, within the bounds of this section, is a necessary component of enforcing alcohol-related ordinances and statutes. 
B.  The city council declares that the provisions contained in this section are enacted for the purpose of securing and promoting the public health, safety and general welfare of persons patronizing or otherwise affected by a business by ensuring that a licensee is conducting a business involving sales of alcoholic beverages in conformance with laws specifically applying to such businesses. 
C.  The chief of police and his officers and authorized designees shall have the authority to enter with or without a search warrant and free of charge, all areas of the licensed business premises. Such authority shall only be exercised within reasonable times when a business establishment is open for the transaction of business. Inspection under this subsection shall be limited to verification that persons doing business on a business premises are properly licensed and have obtained and are displaying all licenses and work permits required under Title 5 of the SMC and verification that the conduct of business is in compliance with this chapter, chapters 9.36, 9.51 and 9.54 of the SMC and any other provision of the SMC or state or federal law pertaining to the sale of alcoholic beverages. Inspection under this subsection shall be limited to visual search of objects in plain view and does not allow the opening of drawers, boxes, closets or similar closed objects, and is further limited to a reasonable length of time on the premises necessary to accomplish the goals of the inspection. These limitations shall not be construed to prohibit action based upon any other constitutionally recognized exception to the warrant requirement. 
D.  Refusal to allow entry pursuant to this subsection constitutes grounds for revocation of an alcoholic beverage license. 
(Ord. 2446, Add, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.300 - Licenses-Revocation-Grounds. 
    Any alcoholic beverage license may be revoked if it appears to the satisfaction of the chief of police that any of the following has occurred: 
A.
