The licensee, his agent, a co-owner or an employee of the licensee has been convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter or chapter 9.36, 9.51 or 9.54 of the SMC, or any other provision of the SMC or any state or federal law regulating or pertaining to the sale of alcoholic beverages; 
B.  The licensee has misrepresented a material fact in obtaining a license; 
C.  Failure to pay any alcoholic beverage license fee, plus delinquent penalties, more than 90 days after the anniversary date of the license; 
D.  The licensee, his agent, a manager or a co-owner has employed a bartender who does not hold a valid work permit as required in SMC 5.28.240. 
E.  The licensee, his agent, a manager, a co-owner or employee has refused to allow police access to the premises in violation of SMC 5.28.295. 
F.  The licensee, his agent, a manager, a co-owner or an employee of the licensee has violated a condition imposed on the license by the chief of police pursuant to SMC 5.28.360. 
G.  A material change in ownership under SMC 5.28.225 has occurred and the owner or agent of the entity acquiring the majority of the business has failed to comply with that section for a period of more than 90 days. Such failure is grounds to revoke the existing license of the holder for the location. 
H.  A change in circumstances has occurred which, having due consideration for the proper protection of the public health, safety and general welfare of the inhabitants of the City, requires the revocation of the license. 
(1962 Code § 105.324.) (Ord. 2423, Amended 4/13/2009) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.310 - Licenses-Denial-Revocation-Procedure. 
A.  An application for an alcoholic beverage license may be denied on the grounds that the applicant is not qualified pursuant to SMC 5.28.090, 5.28.170 or any other law. Denial is effective upon service of a notice of denial upon the applicant by personal service or certified mail directed to the address on the application. 
B.  An alcoholic beverage license may be revoked by the chief of police if the licensee was unqualified under SMC 5.28.170 at the time of filing of an application, if the applicant becomes unqualified for the license under SMC 5.28.170 at any time during the term of the license, or upon the occurrence of any event set forth in SMC 5.28.300. 
C.  Revocation is effective upon service of a notice of revocation upon the licensee by certified mail directed to the licensee's last known address or by personal service. The licensee shall relinquish his or her alcoholic beverage license to the chief of police or his designee within 5 days after being served with such notice. 
D.  Denial or revocation of an alcoholic beverage license may be appealed in the manner set forth in this chapter. 
(1962 Code § 105.327.) (Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.315 - Appeal-Denial, revocation 
A.  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the chief of police to deny an application or revoke a license under this chapter may, within 10 days after the date of receipt of the decision, file a written request with the city clerk for an appeal hearing before the city council. Failure to make timely application for an appeal hearing constitutes a waiver by the applicant of the right to appeal to the city council. 
B.  If a request for an appeal hearing is timely made, the city council shall set a date and time for the hearing within 30 days after the city clerk receives it. The applicant or licensee shall be served with written notice of the hearing in the manner provided in SMC 5.28.310 and shall be given the opportunity to be heard. If an applicant or licensee fails to appear at the place and time designated for the hearing, the city council shall order the license denied or revoked. 
C.  If the applicant or licensee appears at the appeal hearing, the city council shall, within 10 days after the date of the hearing, enter an order either granting or denying the license or an order either revoking or refusing to revoke the license. 
D.  A decision by the City Council on an appeal is a condition precedent to the commencement of any judicial action to contest the denial of an application or revocation of a license. 
E.  An appeal will only be reopened if it appears to the satisfaction of the city council that the failure to appear of the applicant or licensee was due to circumstances beyond his control and not mere negligence. 
(Ord. 2423, Add, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.320 - Licenses-Issuance after revocation. 
    If any license of any licensee is revoked under the provisions of Sections 5.28.300 and 5.28.310, no license shall be granted to the licensee within two years of the date of such revocation. 
(1962 Code § 105.330.) 
Section 5.28.330 - Licenses-Revocation-False complaints. 
    It is unlawful for any person to knowingly file a complaint or report that includes a false statement with the chief of police seeking the denial of an application for a license or the revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(1962 Code § 105.333.) (Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.340 - Licenses-Fee refund not allowed when. 
    If a licensee ceases to operate a licensed business or if the license is revoked, there shall be no refund of the license fee. 
(1962 Code § 105.336.) 
Section 5.28.350 - Excessive noise prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any licensee of an establishment to permit the creation of noises in such establishment by boisterous conduct on the part of individuals, by music or entertainment created by mechanical musical instruments or otherwise, or by dancing or other sources of vibration, which unreasonably disturb any person of ordinary sensibilities in any adjoining room, building or premises. 
(1962 Code § 105.339.) 
Section 5.28.355 - Special event restrictions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision contained in this chapter, at events open to the general public, it is unlawful to sell alcoholic beverages other than manufacturer-prepared beverages with an alcoholic content not exceeding twelve percent (12%) by volume or in glass or metal containers under the following circumstances: 
A.  Under a special event alcoholic beverage license; 
B.  By an on-premises licensee through a walk-up window, or 
C.  In conjunction with a temporary use permit issued pursuant to chapter 20.41 of this code. 
(Ord. 1861, 1995.) (Ord. 2229, Amended, 06/28/2004) 
Section 5.28.360 - Powers and duties of the chief of police. 
    The chief of police: 
A.  Shall investigate the qualifications of all applicants for licenses or employment in licensed establishments and approve or deny each application; 
B.  May impose reasonable conditions on any alcoholic beverage license prior to its issuance or after its issuance; 
C.  May institute, on behalf of the City, proceedings, actions and prosecutions for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter; and; 
D.  May determine whether to revoke an alcoholic beverage license pursuant to SMC 5.28.300. 
(1962 Code § 105.342.) (Ord. 2423, Amended 4/13/2009) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2423, Amended, 04/13/2009) 
Section 5.28.370 - Patrons prohibited from closed or curtained areas. 
A  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no establishment that is required to possess an on-premises or cabaret license shall have closed or curtained booths or rooms, or other places not within view of the main room, for occupancy by any patron. 
B.  This section does not prohibit an establishment possessing a valid on-premises or cabaret license and a valid health permit for food preparation and service issued by the Washoe County Health Department - District Board of Health from having a curtained or closed room in which alcoholic beverages are served only in combination with food prepared on the premises. 
C.  This section does not prohibit restroom facilities in any establishment. 
(1962 Code § 105.345.) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.380 - License fees. 
A.  Alcoholic beverage license fees shall be at the annual rate specified in this section, except where the fee period is specified otherwise: 
1.  Alcoholic beverage manufacturer license ..... $1,000.00 
2.  Alcoholic beverage wholesaler license ..... 1,000.00 
3.  Alcoholic beverage delivery license ..... 800.00 
4.  Alcoholic beverage package license, plus an additional one dollar for each thousand dollars of gross receipts over twenty-five thousand dollars ..... 700.00 
5.  Fraternal club alcoholic beverage license ..... 400.00 
6.  On-premises alcoholic beverage license, plus an additional one dollar for each thousand dollars of gross receipts over fifty thousand dollars ..... 1,000.00 
7.  Cabaret license, plus an additional one dollar for each thousand dollars of gross receipts over fifty thousand dollars ..... 1,300.00 
8.  Beer cabaret license ..... 600.00 
9.  Dining room wine and beer license, plus an additional one dollar for each thousand dollars of gross receipts over twenty-five thousand dollars ..... 500.00 
10.  Beer wholesale license ..... 500.00 
11.  Beer package license, plus an additional one dollar for each thousand dollars of gross receipts over twenty-five thousand dollars ..... 300.00 
12.  Fraternal club beer license ..... 200.00 
13.  On-premises beer license, plus an additional one dollar for each thousand dollars of gross receipts over twenty-five thousand dollars ..... 400.00 
14.  Beer distribution license ..... 500.00 
15.  Incidental beer and wine package license ..... 350.00 
16.  Special event license (per event) ..... 40.00 
B.  Except for a special event license, the licensing year for alcoholic beverage licenses shall commence on July 1st and end on June 30th of each year. 
C.  The annual base fee shall be paid in advance and any licensee issued a license after July 1st of a licensing year shall pay in advance an annual base fee prorated to June 30th of said licensing year. 
D.  Any license fees which are calculated from gross receipts earned during a licensing year shall be paid at the end of said licensing year, except such fees shall become immediately due and payable on the date a licensee ceases conducting the alcoholic beverage business for which he was licensed under this chapter. 
(Ord. 1861, 1995: Ord. 1791, 1993.) 
Section 5.28.385 - License fee-Waiver. 
    The mayor, or his designated representative, upon request by an applicant for a license under this chapter, may waive alcoholic beverage license fees for an applicant which is a nonprofit organization, provided the license is sought for a duration of not more than seven days. 
(Ord. 1170 § 1, 1978: Ord. 1115 § 5, 1977.) 
Section 5.28.386 - Payment of license fee; grace period, delinquent penalty. 
    All annual license fees required under the provisions of this chapter are subject to the 30-day grace period set forth in SMC 5.12.090 and the delinquent fees and penalties set forth in SMC 5.12.105. 
(Ord. 2446, Add, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.387 - Expiration of licenses; unlawful to sell under expired license. 
A.  An alcoholic beverage license issued pursuant to this chapter that is not renewed by the payment of all fees, including delinquent fees, within 90 days after the anniversary date of the license is hereby deemed to have expired for all purposes. 
B.  It is unlawful to sell any alcoholic beverage if the license that would have authorized such sale has expired. 
(Ord. 2446, Add, 11/22/2010) 
Section 5.28.390 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as set forth in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(1962 Code § 105.351.) 
Chapter 5.32 - PAWNBROKERS AND AUTOPAWNS 

Section 5.32.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise: 
A.  "Autopawn" means a pawnbroker who loans money only on the security of any vehicle or other transportation device for which a bill of sale, title or registration can be provided. 
B.  "Pawnbroker" means a person engaged, in whole or in part, in the business of loaning money on the security of pledges, deposits or other secured transactions in personal property. Said personal property must not include vehicles or other transportation devices upon which an autopawn is authorized to loan money. 
C.  "Person" means an individual, partnership, firm, association or corporation. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.540.) 
Section 5.32.020 - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person within the city to engage in or conduct, in or upon any premises in the city, the business of a pawnbroker or autopawn without first having obtained a license as provided in this chapter and chapters 5.12 and 5.16, as applicable. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.543.) 
Section 5.32.030 - License-Application. 
A.  The application for a pawn license shall be filed with the revenue division of the department of finance on a form provided by the revenue division. 
B.  The application shall be referred to the chief of police for investigation and report concerning the applicant's compliance with this chapter and the applicable provisions of this code and of chapter 646 of the Nevada Revised Statutes. 
C.  The applicant shall report to the Sparks Police Department for fingerprinting to facilitate the investigation. 
D.  In the event the applicant is a partnership or association, all persons owning or having an interest therein shall be investigated and fingerprinted. In the case of a corporate applicant, the chief executive officer or local manager and all stockholders owning ten percent or more of the corporation's stock shall be investigated and fingerprinted. 
E.  Each person required to be investigated shall pay to the police department a fee established by resolution. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.546.) 
Section 5.32.040 - Qualifications for license-Employment. 
    The following persons are not qualified to hold any license under the provisions of this chapter: 
A.  A person who has been convicted within the preceding five years of: 
1.  A felony or any crime which under the laws of this state would be a felony; 
2.  Any crime of which fraud or intent to defraud was an element, whether in this state or elsewhere; 
3.  Any crime of moral turpitude, embezzlement or larceny against an employer or business; 
4.  Unlawful possession or distribution of a controlled substance; or 
5.  Violating any law pertaining to the pawn industry. 
B.  A person under the age of eighteen years. 
C.  Any person in the constructive custody of any federal, state or municipal law enforcement authority. 
D.  A person who, by reason of being associated with organized crime, is not a suitable person to receive a license. 
E.  A person who has made a false, misleading or fraudulent statement on his or her application for a license. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.549.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.32.050 - Employees-Work permit required. 
A.  A licensee shall not employ a person to make loans, execute any document required to be prepared pursuant to this chapter or purchase goods or property, nor shall any person accept such employment, unless such person is the holder of a valid work permit issued in conformity with the provisions of the SMC. 
B.  Each work permit shall have clearly imprinted thereon a statement that it is valid for employment in the pawn industry only. Each work permit shall be stamped with the name of the pawnbroker or autopawn for which it is valid. 
C.  A work permit shall expire unless renewed within ten days after a change of place of employment, or if the holder thereof is not employed in the pawn industry within the city for a period of ninety days or more. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.552.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.32.060 - License-Grant or denial. 
    Following his investigation, the chief of police shall report his findings to the city council. The city council shall determine the qualifications of the applicant and grant or deny the application. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.555.) 
Section 5.32.070 - License-Nontransferable. 
A.  Pawn licenses shall not be transferred to any person who has not first been approved by the city council. 
B.  No pawn license shall be transferred to a new location by the holder thereof unless such transfer is first approved by the city council. 
C.  Each pawn license shall be issued to an individual who has successfully passed the investigation conducted by the chief of police and who is responsible for the lawful and orderly management of the pawn business. 
D.  In the event the individual named on the pawn license ceases to be qualified for the license or ceases to be responsible for the management of the business, the owner of the business must submit the name of another individual to be placed upon the license who fully complies with the above-stated qualifications. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.558.) 
Section 5.32.080 - Abandonment of license. 
A.  It is hereby found to be contrary to the public interest for pawn licensees to hold a license merely as an investment while failing to maintain an open pawn business. The hoarding of inoperative pawn licenses will deprive the public of desirable market competition in the pawn industry and may unjustly enrich those who hold such licenses. 
B.  When a pawnbroker or autopawn ceases to maintain an open and operational pawn business at the licensed address for a period of sixty days or more, the license shall be presumed abandoned and shall become null and void. 
C.  A licensee may apply for waiver of the abandonment provisions set forth above by filing a petition for waiver with the office of the city clerk prior to the expiration of sixty days following cessation of pawn business. The petition shall be scheduled for hearing before the city council which has authority to render a decision thereon. Waiver may be granted only upon a showing of good cause therefor. Good cause includes diligent repair or remodeling of the licensed premises but does not include financial hardship or pendency of sale. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.561.) 
Section 5.32.090 - Record of transactions. 
A.  Every pawnbroker or autopawn doing business in the city must maintain in his place of business a book or other permanent record in which must be legibly written in the English language, at the time of each loan or purchase record thereof containing: 
1.  The date and time of the transaction; 
2.  The name or other identification of the person or employee conducting the transaction; 
3.  The name, age, street and house number, the serial number of one piece of positive identification and a general description of the complexion, color of hair and facial appearance of the person with whom the transaction is made; 
4.  A description of the property received; 
5.  The amount loaned or paid; 
6.  The number of any pawn ticket issued therefor. 
B.  The person with whom a transaction is made shall, at the time of the transaction, certify in writing that he has the legal right to pledge or sell the property. 
C.  The record and all goods received must at all times during the ordinary hours of business be open to the inspection of the Sparks Police Department. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.564.) 
Section 5.32.100 - Report of transactions. 
    Every pawn licensee in the city must before the hour of 10:00 a.m. of each and every day except Sunday, make and deliver to the chief of police a full, true and detailed report in writing on computer diskettes or via modem, setting forth an exact description of each and every article or thing pawned or received by such licensee during the twenty-four hours immediately preceding such report. The report made on each Monday shall include all articles or things pawned or received from and after the report made and delivered on the preceding Saturday. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.567.) 
Section 5.32.110 - Computerized recordkeeping. 
A.  Beginning July 1, 1994, pawnbrokers and autopawns shall provide the daily report in an approved format on computer diskettes or via modem at the discretion and direction of the chief of police. 
B.  Daily reports so prepared shall be organized and contain all information required by the chief of police. 
C.  The chief of police shall upon receipt of such reports file and record the same. Said reports shall be confidential and shall be open to inspection only by a police officer or upon the order of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: 1962 Code § 105.570.) 
Section 5.32.120 - Unlawful acts. 
    Every pawn licensee, and every clerk, agent or employee of a licensee, is guilty of a misdemeanor if he or she: 
A.  Fails to make an entry of any material matter in his book or record kept as provided for in this chapter. 
B.  Makes any false entry in his book or record. 
C.  Obliterates, destroys or removes from his place of business the book or record. 
D.  Refuses to allow a police officer to inspect the book or record or any goods in his possession, during the ordinary hours of business. 
E.  Reports any material matter falsely to the chief of police. 
F.  Fails to report forthwith to the chief of police the possession of any property which he may have good cause to believe has been lost or stolen together with the name of the owner, if known, and the date when and the name of the person from whom he received the property. 
G.  Removes or allows to be removed from his place of business, except upon redemption by the owner thereof, any property received within fourteen days after receipt thereof is reported to the chief of police. 
H.  Receives any property from any person under the age of eighteen years, any common drunkard, any habitual user of controlled substances, any habitual criminal, any person in an intoxicated condition, any known thief or receiver of stolen property, or any known associate of a thief or receiver of stolen property, whether the person is acting in his own behalf or as the agent of another. 
I.  Fails to hold personal property for redemption for at least one hundred twenty days after the date of pledge. 
J.  Charge or receive interest at a rate higher than six percent per month for money loaned on the security of personal property, exclusive of an initial charge not to exceed $5.00. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992: Ord. 714 § 1, 1968: 1962 Code § 105.576.) 
Section 5.32.130 - Pawn tickets. 
    Every pawnbroker or autopawn shall furnish to the pledgor a printed pawn ticket, plainly numbered, containing the name of the pledgor, a description of the article or thing pawned or received, date of receipt thereof, the amount loaned thereon, time for redemption, amount to be paid on redemption, and name of the pledgee. The reverse side of the printed pawn ticket must be marked in such a manner that the amounts of principal and interest paid by the pledgor can be clearly designated. Each payment shall be entered upon the reverse side of the receipt and shall designate how much of the payment is being credited to principal and how much to interest, with dates of the payment shown thereon. The licensee shall affix to each article, or thing, a tag upon which shall be inscribed a number of legible characters, which number shall correspond to the number on the pawn ticket and be entered in the records required to be kept by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992.) 
Section 5.32.135 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. To the extent they are not in conflict with this chapter, the provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 2471, § 34, Add, 2/11/2013) 
Section 5.32.140 - Fees. 
A.  Every person engaged in, or proposing to engage in, the business of a pawnbroker in the city shall obtain an annual license therefor and shall pay a license fee of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) and one dollar ($1.00) for each one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in gross receipts (or portion thereof) in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
B.  Every person engaged in, or proposing to engage in, the business of autopawn in the city shall obtain an annual license therefor and shall pay a license fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) and one dollar ($1.00) for each one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in gross receipts (or portion thereof) in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
C.  Except as provided herein, fees and penalties applicable to businesses in general shall apply to pawnbrokers and autopawns. 
(Ord. 1759, 1992.) 
Chapter 5.33 - SECONDHAND JEWELRY AND METALS DEALERS 

Section 5.33.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise: 
A.  "Secondhand jewelry and metals dealers" means every person who engages in or conducts the business of buying, selling or exchanging old gold, old silver, platinum or articles of platinum, silverware, secondhand jewelry or other precious metals, stones, or coins. 
B.  "Person" means an individual, partnership, firm, association or corporation. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.020 - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person within the city to engage in or conduct, in or upon any premises in the city, the business of a secondhand jewelry and metals dealer without first having obtained a license as provided in this chapter and Chapters 5.12 and 5.16, as applicable. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.030 - License-Application-Grant or denial. 
A.  The application for a secondhand jewelry and metals dealer license shall be filed with the license officer and shall specify the name of the true owner of the business and the proposed place of business. 
B.  The application shall be referred to the chief of police for investigation and report, concerning the applicant's compliance with this chapter and other applicable provisions of this code and of Chapter 647 of the Nevada Revised Statutes, and his moral character to conduct such a business. 
C.  The applicant shall report to the Sparks Police Department for fingerprinting to facilitate the investigation. 
D.  In the event the applicant is a partnership or association, all persons owning or having an interest therein shall be investigated and fingerprinted, and in the case of a corporate applicant, all officers and directors and all stockholders owning ten percent or more of the corporation's stock shall be investigated and fingerprinted. 
E.  Each person required to be investigated shall pay to the police department a fee established by resolution. 
(Ord. 1628 § 2, 1988: Ord. 1361 § 2, 1982: Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.040 - Application information. 
    Each applicant for a license herein, and person investigated pursuant to the application, is required to provide the following information to the police department upon request: 
A.  All residential addresses during the past three years; 
B.  The name and address of each business where the applicant was employed, or which the applicant owned during the past three years; 
C.  Whether the applicant has had any business license denied, revoked, or suspended, the reason therefore, and the date and place of such action; 
D.  Any conviction, forfeiture of bond, or plea of nolo contendere upon any criminal violation or municipal ordinance violation (except minor traffic violations) during the past five years; 
E.  Identification sufficient to prove that the applicant is at least eighteen years of age; 
F.  If the applicant is a corporation, a copy of the articles of incorporation shall be submitted, together with the name and residence address of each officer, and director, and of each stockholder owning more than ten percent of the stock of the corporation. If the applicant is a partnership, the applicant shall set forth the name and residence address of each of the partners, including limited partners. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.050 - Qualifications for license-Employment. 
    No person shall hold a license issued pursuant to this chapter who: 
A.  Has been convicted within the preceding five years of: 
1.  Any felony or crime which under the laws of this state would be a felony, 
2.  Any offense involving theft, fraud, dishonesty, or the sale or possession of stolen property; 
B.  Is younger than eighteen years of age; 
C.  Is a person who the city council determines is not a suitable person to receive a license, having due consideration for the protection of the public safety, morals and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city; 
D.  Has made a material misrepresentation of fact on the application for license. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.060 - Applicant bond. 
    The applicant shall, before receiving a license, execute a bond to the city, conditioned that during the continuance of such license, and any renewals thereof, the applicant will comply with the provisions of this chapter and will pay all damages, fines and forfeitures which may be adjudged against him under the ordinances of the city, which bond shall be in the sum of five thousand dollars written by a surety company qualified to do business in the state, and first approved by the city attorney. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.070 - Filing and fee provisions. 
    Each licensee shall report his gross receipts and pay the license fees as required by Section 5.12.100 of this code. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, regulations applicable to general businesses in the city shall apply to businesses regulated by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1762, 1992: Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.080 - License-Nontransferable. 
A.  Licenses shall not be transferred to any person for any reason. 
B.  No license, or operation thereunder, shall be transferred to a new location by the holder thereof, or his agent, unless such transfer as to location is first approved by application. 
C.  No license shall be issued to any person other than the actual proprietor of the business and place of business for which it is issued. 
D.  Upon sale, transfer or relocation of a business regulated by this chapter, the license therefore shall be null and void; provided, however, that upon the death or incapacity of the licensee or any co-licensee, any administrator, executor, or conservator of the licensee's estate may continue the business for a reasonable period of time not to exceed sixty days to allow for an orderly transfer of the license. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.090 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) (Ord. 2471, § 35, Amended, 2/11/2013) 
Section 5.33.100 - Articles to be kept for inspection period. 
A.  Every such dealer in secondhand jewelry and metals must keep without concealment, for a period of ten days after receipt, subject to inspection by any police officer, all articles purchased or received from any person, before selling, shipping or otherwise disposing of the same. During such period, such articles shall be kept intact and identifiable. 
B.  In transactions involving articles purchased or received from persons doing business in the city and licensed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, the period during which articles shall be kept after receipt shall be two business days. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.110 - Purchase books to be kept. 
    Every dealer in secondhand jewelry and metals shall keep in a tightly bound book, not looseleaf, with pages numbered in sequence, in which he shall enter in ink at the time of purchase or receipt, legibly, in the English language: 
A.  A true and accurate description of every article or thing purchased or received by him; 
B.  The name, age, sex and residence of the vendor and subsequent purchaser; 
C.  The amount paid therefor, and estimated value thereof; 
D.  The date and hour of purchase or receipt; and 
E.  The number of the driver's license (or other identification) and vehicle license of the vendor and subsequent purchaser, upon actual inspection of said items by such dealer or his agent. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.120 - Reports to be made to chief of police. 
    Every dealer in secondhand jewelry or metals shall make and deliver to the police department every business day before the hour of twelve noon, a full, true and correct report in writing, on blank forms to be prepared and furnished by the chief of police, setting forth an exact description of each and every article purchased or received by such dealer during the business day immediately preceding such report, and also the name, residence and full description (including age and sex) of the vendor and subsequent purchaser thereof, the number of the driver's license (or other identification) and vehicle license of the vendor and subsequent purchaser, the amount of money paid therefore, together with the date and hour of the receipt of such article or thing. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.130 - Inspection. 
    The premises, records, receipts and purchases of every secondhand jewelry and metals dealer shall be subject to immediate inspection by the police department. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.140 - Sales by minors. 
    No secondhand jewelry and metals dealers or their agents or employees shall purchase any jewelry or metals from any minor without the consent of his parents or guardians. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.33.150 - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided for in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(Ord. 1307 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Chapter 5.34 - ANTIQUE AUTO SWAP MEETS 

Section 5.34.010 - Antique auto swap meets defined. 
    "Antique auto swap meet" means any promotional events whose main purpose is the temporary display, sale and swap of antique automobiles, automobile parts and other articles both directly and indirectly related to antique automobiles. 
(Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Section 5.34.020 - Business unlawful without a license. 
    It is unlawful for any person to conduct an antique auto swap meet within the city without first obtaining a license to do so under the terms and conditions of this chapter. Said license and the payment of the fee set forth in this chapter shall be the responsibility of the person promoting or conducting any antique auto swap meet and providing further that no additional licensing shall be required of any person who, with the consent of the promoter, displays, sells or swaps any article whether or not related directly or indirectly to antique automobiles. 
(Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Section 5.34.030 - License fee. 
    A fee of one hundred seven dollars per day shall be charged for the conducting of an antique auto swap meet. 
(Ord. 1356 § 5, 1982: Ord. 1022 § 1, 1975: Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Chapter 5.36 - SOLICITORS AND PEDDLERS 

Section 5.36.010 - Peddler defined. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, "peddler" means any hawker, vendor or other person who goes from house to house, place to place or in or along the streets within the city selling and making immediate delivery, or offering for sale and immediate delivery, any goods, wares or merchandise, or anything of value in possession of the peddler, to persons other than manufacturers, wholesalers, jobbers or retailers of such commodities. 
(1962 Code § 105.609.) 
Section 5.36.020 - Solicitor defined. 
A.  As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, and except as provided in subsection B of this section, "solicitor" means any agent, canvasser or other person who goes from house to house or place to place and: 
1.  Solicits, takes orders for, canvasses for or makes demonstrations of any goods, wares, merchandise or things of value, or for advertising, subscriptions to periodicals, tickets of admission to entertainments, memberships in any club or services to be performed in the future; 
2.  Solicits, requests or urges persons to ride or become guests of such person or his principal for the purpose of viewing any real estate subdivision or other development, enterprise or project for the purpose of interesting such person in investment therein. 
B.  "Solicitor" does not include persons engaging in any wholesale business who sell to or solicit orders for merchandise from merchants who are engaged in a retail business buying goods, wares, merchandise or other personal property for the purpose of resale. 
(1962 Code § 105.612.) 
Section 5.36.030 - Work permit-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any peddler or solicitor to engage in or transact business in the city for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of any goods, wares or merchandise, or of selling or offering to sell any goods, wares or merchandise, without first having obtained a work permit from the chief of police. 
(1962 Code § 105.615.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.36.040 - Exemption of interstate commerce from licensing-Certificates required. 
A.  Any peddler or solicitor claiming to be entitled to exemption from payment of a work permit fee upon the ground that such fee casts a burden upon his right to engage in commerce with foreign nations or among the several states, or conflicts with federal law respecting interstate commerce, shall file a verified statement with the chief of police disclosing the interstate or other character of his business entitling him to exemption. 
B.  The statement shall include the name and location of the company or firm for which orders are to be solicited or secured, the name and address of the nearest local or state manager, if any, the kinds of goods, wares or merchandise to be delivered, the place from which the same are to be shipped or forwarded, the method of solicitation or taking orders, the location of any warehouse, factory or plant within the state, the method of delivery, the name and location of the residence of the applicant, and any other information necessary to establish the claim of exemption. A copy of the order blank, contract form or other papers used by such person in taking orders shall be attached to the statement. 
C.  If it appears that the applicant is entitled to exemption, he shall be issued, without cost, a certificate in lieu of a work permit. 
(1962 Code § 105.618.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.36.050 - Exemption of disabled veterans from licensing-Certificates required. 
A.  No work permit fee for the purpose of peddling or soliciting shall be required of any honorably discharged or honorably released soldier, sailor or marine of the United States of America exempted from the payment thereof by any law of the state. 
B.  Each such soldier, sailor or marine shall be issued, without cost, a certificate in lieu of a work permit upon application therefor, and upon presentation of a document establishing his honorable discharge or release from the United States Army, Navy, Coast Guard, Air Force or Marine Corps and a certificate of a doctor of medicine licensed to practice under the laws of the state certifying that such veteran is physically unable to obtain a livelihood by manual labor. 
(1962 Code § 105.621.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.36.060 - Exemption of blind persons from payment of fees. 
    No work permit fee for the purpose of peddling or soliciting shall be required of any person having no more than ten percent visual acuity in the better eye with correction. Blindness shall be certified by a physician or optometrist who specializes in diseases of the eye and is licensed to practice in the state, or by the Bureau of Services to the Blind of the State Welfare Department. The exemption shall not be granted until a certificate as to such blindness has been furnished to the chief of police. 
(1962 Code § 105.624.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.36.070 - Exemption of certain salesmen from licensing. 
    No work permit shall be required for any person whose business is limited to the taking of orders for future delivery of goods, wares, merchandise or supplies to businessmen in the city for use or resale by them in the normal course of business. 
(1962 Code § 105.627.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.36.080 - Exemption of growers of agricultural products from payment of fees. 
    Upon application by any person who grows agricultural food products in the state, a work permit to peddle or sell, or peddle and sell, such products shall be issued by the chief of police to the applicant without cost, but such permit shall authorize peddling and selling of such products by the grower only. 
(1962 Code § 105.630.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.36.090 - Work permit-Application; term. 
A.  Any person required to obtain a work permit for peddling or soliciting shall apply to the chief of police for a work permit as provided in Chapter 5.22 of the SMC. A work permit for peddling or soliciting is valid for one year from the date of issuance. 
(Ord. 1628 § 3, 1988: Ord. 1361 § 3, 1982: Ord. 1040 § 1,1975, 1962 Code § 105.633.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.36.120 - Hours for peddling and soliciting. 
A.  Each work permit shall authorize the permitee to make solicitations in the city on all days except Sundays and holidays between the hours of nine a.m. and six-thirty p.m., or sunset, whichever is earlier, only. Solicitation at any other time or on any other day constitutes a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in Section 5.36.150. 
B.  "Sunset," for the purposes of this section, means the legal sunset time for the particular day in Reno, Nevada as listed in the "Sunrise-Sunset Tables" published by the Nevada Department of Wildlife. 
(Ord. 868 § 1 1972: 1962 Code § 105.642.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.36.130 - Peddling or soliciting on posted premises. 
A.  It is unlawful for any peddler or solicitor to contact, accost or approach for the purpose of solicitation or peddling any premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof a sign bearing the words "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or Agents," "No Solicitors or Agents," "No Salesmen" or any similar notice, indicating in any manner that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or to have their right of privacy disturbed. 
B.  It is unlawful for any peddler or solicitor to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any material advertising their wares or any material advertising the cause for which they are soliciting upon any residential premises, if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof a sign bearing the words "No Trespassing," "No Solicitors or Agents," "No Peddlers or Agents", "No Advertisement" or any similar notice indicating in any manner that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested, or to have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any such advertising materials left upon such premises. 
(Ord. 869 § 1 1972: 1962 Code § 105.616.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.36.140 - Permit-Suspension or revocation. 
    In addition to all other grounds for suspension or revocation set forth in Chapter 5.22 of the SMC, a peddler's or solicitor's work permit may be suspended or revoked if the chief of police finds that the peddler or solicitor has: 
A.  Misrepresented his goods; 
B.  Violated any ordinance of the city; 
C.  Conducted himself in a disorderly manner; 
D.  Entered upon the premises of any person without the permission or consent of such person. 
(1962 Code § 105.645.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.36.150 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Violation of any applicable provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided by section 1.12.010 of this code. However, an offense under any provision of this chapter which also constitutes an offense pursuant to state law may be punishable in accordance with the applicable state law. 
(1962 Code § 105.648.) (1975, Amended, 02/23/1998) 
Chapter 5.40 - CHARITABLE AND WELFARE SOLICITATIONS 

Section 5.40.010 - Definitions 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise: 
A.  "Charitable purpose" means philanthropic, religious or other nonprofit objectives, including the benefit of impoverished, refugee or disabled persons; the benefit of any church or religious society, sect, group or order; the benefit of a patriotic, veterans' or other organization purporting to aid the general welfare of the United States or a state or nation or local governmental unit; the benefit of any fraternal, social or civic organization or cause, or the benefit of any educational institution. The term "charitable purpose" shall not be construed to include the direct benefit of the individual making the solicitation. 
B.  "Chief" means the chief of the police department of Sparks or any individual employed by such department that the chief shall designate to perform any of the functions specified in this chapter. 
C.  "Individual" means only a natural person. 
D.  "Person" means and includes any natural person, firm, partnership, corporation or association. 
E.  "Solicit funds" or "solicitation of funds" mean any request for the donation of money, property or anything of value, or the pledge of a future donation of money, property, or anything of value; or the selling or offering for sale of any property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, whether of value or not, including, but not limited to, goods, books, pamphlets, tickets, publications or subscriptions to publications, or brochures, upon the representation, express or implied, that the proceeds of such sale will be used for a charitable purpose as such term is defined herein. Expressly excluded from the meaning of "solicit funds" or "solicitation of funds" are: 
1.  Any offer of membership in any organization; 
2.  Any solicitation of funds for any purpose by a unit of the United States Government or any state or local subdivision thereof; 
3.  Any solicitation of funds for charitable purposes by any organization or association from its members; 
4.  Any solicitation of funds for charitable purposes by a person when such solicitation occurs on premises owned or controlled by the person soliciting funds or with the permission of the person who owns or controls the premises; and 
5.  The issuance of any announcement or advertisement which states that a solicitation as described in subsections (3) and (4) above will occur or which announces or advertises an event at which unannounced solicitation as described in subsections (3) and (4) above occurs. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.020 - Unlawful solicitation by persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, directly or through an agent or employee, to: 
A.  Solicit funds for any charitable purpose within the limits of the City of Sparks unless such person shall have first obtained a certificate of registration from the chief, as hereinafter provided. 
B.  Solicit funds for charitable purposes, within the limits of the City of Sparks, after the expiration of any certificate of registration. 
C.  Represent, in connection with any solicitation of funds, that the issuance of a certificate of registration by the City of Sparks constitutes an endorsement or approval of the purpose of such solicitation of funds by the city or any department, officer or employee thereof. 
D.  Knowingly make a false and material statement of fact on the disclosure statement required by section 5.40.040 of this chapter. 
E.  Solicit funds within the limits of the City of Sparks unless a system of accounting is maintained either on the cash or accrual basis, according to established and customary accounting principles on all such solicited funds. 
F.  Fail to make the written disclosure required by section 5.40.110 of this chapter. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.030 - Unlawful solicitation by individuals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any individual, as the agent or employee of another, to solicit funds for charitable purposes in the City of Sparks unless his principal or employer has received a certificate of registration as hereinafter provided. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.040 - Registration statement. 
    All persons desiring to solicit funds for charitable purposes in the City of Sparks shall file with the chief a registration statement on forms provided by the chief and approved by the city attorney containing the following only: 
A.  The name of the person registering and desiring to solicit funds for charitable purposes. 
B.  Whether the person registering is an individual, partnership, corporation or association, and: 
1.  If an individual, his or her business or residence address and telephone number; or 
2.  If a partnership, corporation or association, the principal business office address and telephone number of such entity, and, if different, the business or residence address and telephone number of the individual completing the aforesaid form on behalf of the entity. 
C.  A listing of all determinations of tax-exempt status under the Internal Revenue Code of the United States and the laws of any state, county or municipality. 
D.  The names of any other cities in Nevada or California in which the person registering has collected funds for charitable purposes within the past five (5) years. If there are more than 25 such cities in California, then the person is only required to list 25 such cities, in addition to all such Nevada cities. 
E.  The names of any officer or any current agent or employee engaging in the solicitation of funds who has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude within the past seven (7) years, the nature of the offense, the state in which the conviction occurred and the year of the conviction. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.050 - Registration fee. 
    Every registration statement shall be accompanied by a registration fee of $20.00 to compensate the City of Sparks for the cost of administering this chapter. Such fee will be nonrefundable irrespective of whether a certificate of registration is issued. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.060 - Issuance of time frames. 
    Within ten (10) working days of the receipt of the registration statement, the chief shall either issue a certificate of registration or notify the person submitting that the registration statement does not comply with the requirements of section 5.40.040 of this chapter, and specifically point out what information has not been furnished that is required before a certificate of registration can be issued. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.070 - Judicial review. 
A.  In the event that any certificate is denied, by reason of failure to provide the required information pursuant to section 5.40.040 of this chapter, or by reason of unusual or emergency conditions, or for other valid reasons, the City of Sparks, acting by and through its city attorney (or the designee thereof), shall within ten (10) working days following such denial apply to either the United States District Court for the District of Nevada or to the Second Judicial District Court for the County of Washoe for a judicial determination as to whether the proposed activities described in the registration statement may be prohibited, naming the registrant as a party defendant. The City of Sparks shall exert every reasonable effort to have this issue heard on its merits without delay and as soon as legally possible. The burden of showing that the proposed activities may be prohibited shall rest on the City of Sparks. In the event that the registrant certifies in the application for a certificate that, due to emergency circumstances, the certificate is required by a specified time in order to be effective, then upon receipt of such certification, the chief shall issue a certificate of registration within the time requested in the registration statement. 
B.  If the issue for judicial determination described in subsection (A) of this section of the chapter is not heard and/or enjoined by the court within twenty (20) working days from the date the complaint is filed, then a ninety (90) day interim permit shall be deemed issued under this chapter. 
    The interim permit shall be deemed renewed after each ninety (90) day period for so long as no judicial determination has been made. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.080 - Financial records review. 
    The chief shall have the right to review the records compiled under section 5.40.020(E) of this chapter for solicited funds received within the City of Sparks for the preceding year. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.090 - Expiration of certificate. 
    Each certificate of registration, unless otherwise reapplied for, shall expire one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.100 - Public disclosure. 
    All registration statements filed with the chief, whether or not a certificate of registration has been issued, shall be public records and shall be available for inspection by members of the public. Copies may be obtained at the fees allowable by law for copies of public records. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.110 - Identification. 
    Every individual who solicits contributions from a prospective contributor within the limits of the City of Sparks shall disclose, in writing, his or her name to each prospective contributor. If the individual is employed by a person who is required to obtain a certificate, pursuant to this chapter, the individual shall disclose the name of the person by whom he or she is employed and the address of his or her employer. The individual shall further disclose, in writing, the fact that a registration form has been filed with the City of Sparks. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Section 5.40.120 - Penalties. 
    Violation of any applicable provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided by section 1.12.010 of this code. However, an offense under any provision of this chapter which also constitutes an offense pursuant to state law may be punishable in accordance with the applicable state law. 
(1976, Added, 02/23/1998) 
Chapter 5.44 - DETECTIVE AND INVESTIGATIVE AGENCIES-GUARDS 

Section 5.44.010 - Person defined. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, "person" means an individual, association, firm, partnership or corporation. 
(1962 Code § 105.393.) 
Section 5.44.020 - Licenses-Required. 
    No person shall, for hire or reward: 
A.  Engage in the business of private detective, or advertise his business to be that of a detective or of conducting a detective agency, without first having obtained a license so to do from the director of finance; 
B.  Engage in the business of furnishing or supplying information as to the personal character of any person, or the character or kind of business or occupation of any person, or own or conduct a bureau or agency for such purpose, without first having obtained a license so to do from the director of finance; 
C.  Engage in the business of furnishing or contracting to furnish watchman or patrol service, or any guard or watchdog or other animal for the purpose of guarding or giving alarm, to any business house or property, or to any private home or individual in the city, without first having obtained a license so to do from the director of finance. 
(Ord. 865 § 1, 1972: 1962 Code § 105.396.) 
Section 5.44.030 - Licenses-Exemptions. 
    Nothing in this chapter applies to: 
A.  The business of obtaining and furnishing information as to the financial rating of persons; or 
B.  Any detective, officer or police officer of the United States, the state, or of any county, city, town or village in the state, appointed or elected pursuant to law. 
(Ord. 865 § 2, 1972: 1962 Code § 105.399.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.44.040 - Licenses-Applications-Investigations. 
A.  Any person who desires to conduct any of the businesses enumerated in Section 5.44.020 shall present to the director of finance a written application for a license stating the age, residence and present and previous occupation of such applicant, where the place of business is to be located, and such other information as will tend to show the good character, competency and integrity of the applicant. 
B.  The director of finance shall refer each application to the chief of police, who shall make an investigation of the character, competency and integrity of the applicant. The application and the report and recommendations of the chief of police shall be referred to the city council. 
(Ord. 865 § 3, 1972: 1962 Code § 105.402.) 
Section 5.44.050 - Licenses-Issuance. 
    The city council, if satisfied that the applicant is a person of good character, competency and integrity, shall direct the director of finance to issue and deliver to the applicant a license to conduct such business upon payment of the license fee and the providing by the applicant, or his representative, of proof satisfactory to the director of finance of the applicant's compliance with all of the provisions of NRS 648.130. 
(Ord. 865 § 4, 1972: 1962 Code § 105.405.) 
Section 5.44.060 - Licenses-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(1962 Code § 105.408.) (Ord. 2471, § 36, Amended, 2/11/2013) 
Section 5.44.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not less than twenty dollars or more than two hundred fifty dollars, or by imprisonment in the city jail for not less than ten days or more than ninety days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(1962 Code § 105.417.) 
Section 5.44.080 - Fees. 
    Guard and detective agency fees shall be as follows: 
    In addition to business license fees, every person engaging in any activities for which a license is required by Section 5.44.020 of this code shall pay for the initial license investigation required under the provisions of this chapter the sum established by resolution for a period of three years. Thereafter, each renewal period of three years shall subject the applicant to an additional fee established by resolution. 
(Ord. 1628 § 4, 1988: Ord. 1361 § 4, 1982: Ord. 1085 § 3, 1976.) 
Chapter 5.48 - PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION VEHICLES 

Section 5.48.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise: 
A.  "Person" means an individual, partnership, firm, association or corporation; 
B.  "Taxicab" means a taxicab, rent service car or other vehicle which is used to carry persons for compensation and does not have a fixed route or definite schedule. 
(Ord. 816 § 6, 1971: 1962 Code § 105.711.) 
Section 5.48.020 - Taxicab-License-Required. 
    Each person who operates a taxicab business shall apply for and secure from the city an annual business license pursuant to the provisions of Section 5.48.040. 
(Ord. 2504, § 1, Amended, 10/27/2014; Ord. 816 § 7, 1971: 1962 Code § 105.714.) 
Section 5.48.030 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2504, § 3, adopted Oct. 27, 2014, repealed former § 5.48.030 in its entirety which pertained to taxicab license applications and derived from § 105.717 of the Code of 1962. 
Section 5.48.040 - Taxicab business license-Fee-Subject to all business license provisions. 
A.  Every person operating a taxicab business in the city shall obtain a city business license therefor and pay a fee of $417.00 per year plus $7.00 per year for each taxicab in the fleet of the business, excepting therefrom the first six such taxicabs. Such fees shall be payable annually on the anniversary date of the license, subject to the 30-day grace period provided for regular business licenses. 
B.  Except as provided in subsection A of this section and SMC 5.48.050, a taxicab business license is subject to all provisions of the Sparks Municipal Code pertaining to business licenses, including but not limited to Chapters 5.04, 5.08, 5.12 and 5.16 of the Sparks Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 2504, § 3, Amended, 10/27/2014; Ord. 1356 § 6, 1982: Ord. 1293 § 9, 1980: Ord. 816 § 5, 1971.) 
Section 5.48.050 - Taxicab business license-Special revocation. 
    A taxicab business license may be revoked by the chief license officer pursuant to Chapter 5.16 of the Sparks Municipal Code for any reason specified in that chapter, and may also be revoked if the holder of the taxicab business license knowingly permits a driver to violate, within the city, any ordinance of the city or any statute of the State of Nevada. 
(Ord. 2504, § 4, Amended, 10/27/2014; Ord. 816 § 8, 1971: 1962 Code § 105.723.) 
Section 5.48.060 - Taxicab stands-Permit-Generally. 
    The city council shall issue permits for taxicab stands or taxi parking spaces, subject to the provisions of this chapter. All such permits shall be revocable at the pleasure of the city council and all applications therefor shall be referred to the city manager for his recommendation. All taxicab stands presently existing in the name of any particular person or company shall remain in the name of such person or company, subject to the payment of fees as provided in this chapter. It is unlawful to park or stand a taxicab at a site designated by the city council for the use of other taxicabs. 
(Ord. 827 § 2, 1971: Ord. 816 § 2, 1971.) 
Section 5.48.070 - Taxicab stands-Permit-Fees. 
    The holder of each permit for a taxicab stand or parking space upon any public street or other public place in the city is required to pay in advance therefor a permit fee of fifty dollars per year for each parking place, space or stand allotted to him by the permit, and twenty-five dollars per year for each parking place, space or stand allotted to him by the permit to be shared with special contract charter buses. The fee for each special contract charter bus space to be shared with a taxicab company shall be seventy-five dollars per year, to be paid by the individual, firm or business to whom such permit is granted. If the stand is shared with two taxicabs, the fee shall be fifty dollars per year to be paid by the taxicab company and fifty dollars per year to be paid by the individual, firm or business to whom the shared bus stand permit is granted. 
(Ord. 816 § 3, 1971.) 
Section 5.48.080 - Bus parking stands-Fees. 
A.  The city council shall regulate the issuance of permits for charter bus parking stands. The permit shall be issued to the individual, firm or business making application for the same, whether the same is a shared stand or a stand solely for the use of charter bus parking. The fee for a charter bus parking stand shall be one hundred dollars per year and shall be paid in advance. 
B.  The city council shall establish all of the terms and conditions to which such permit shall be subject, including limitations as to time. 
C.  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to require the issuance of permits or the payment of fees for any common carrier having a fixed route through or in the city. 
D.  The permit holder shall furnish curbside signs for each taxicab stand or shared bus stand in accordance with specifications established by the public works director. 
(Ord. 816 § 4, 1971.) 
Section 5.48.090 - Taxicab-Soliciting passengers. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person operating a taxicab to: 
1.  Leave the taxicab to solicit passengers; 
2.  Cruise the taxicab on any of the streets of the city for the purpose of soliciting passengers. 
B.  The fact that a taxicab displays a device to indicate that it is not engaged does not constitute soliciting passengers. 
(Ord. 827 § 1, 1971: 1962 Code § 105.724.) 
Secs. 5.48.100-5.48.150 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2504, §§ 5-7, adopted Oct. 27, 2014, repealed former §§ 5.48.100-5.48.120 in their entirety. Subject matter and legistlative history of these former sections follows:

Section 5.48.160 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished as provided in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(Ord. 816 § 13, 1971: 1962 Code § 105.786.) 
Chapter 5.52 - HOTEL, ROOM AND APARTMENT LODGING 

Section 5.52.010 - Required registration system. 
A.  Every person who owns or operates within the limits of the city any hotel, motel, building comprised of former hotel or motel rooms which have been converted into apartments, tenement, boarding or rooming house, recreational vehicle park or other establishment where rooms or spaces for lodging are available to rent or lease on a temporary basis shall keep and maintain a registration system and shall require the name, date of birth and residential addresses, including city or town and state, of every person who rents or occupies a room or space in any such establishment to be written in the register, or upon a registration card, or entered into an electronic registration system. Every such registration shall contain a reference to the day of the year, month and week, and the time of day, the person rents or arranges to occupy such room or space. 
Every person who rents or occupies such a room shall produce a photographic identification card issued by a governmental agency of the United States or a State in the United States. The person's name, date of birth and residential address on the identification card should match the information entered in the registration system. 
If there is a discrepancy between the photographic identification and the information provided by the renter or occupant, the owner or operator of the establishment shall create a unique identifier (e.g., a letter, word or symbol) and place it next to the entry in the registration system. Upon inquiry into a registration system by a peace officer, the owner or operator shall inform the officer that a unique identifier exists for any person entered in the registration system and explain any discrepancy in the registration. 
B.  For purposes of this chapter: 
1.  "Registration system" means a system of registration contained in a registration book, in a card file or in an electronic database. 
2.  "Available to rent or lease on a temporary basis" means a rental or lease which is reasonably expected to have a tenancy of less than six months. An establishment which allows rent or lease payments to be paid on a daily, weekly or bi-weekly (every two weeks) basis is deemed to be for "rent or lease on a temporary basis," regardless of the type of property or the terms of any rental agreement or lease. 
(Ord. 2523, § 1, Amended, 4/25/2016; Ord. 942 § 1 (part), 1973: Ord. 723 § 6, 1968: 1962 Code § 25.605.) 
Section 5.52.020 - False information. 
    It is unlawful for any guest, roomer or lodger in any such establishment to use any name other than his or her true name in so registering, or to give any false or erroneous information as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. 942 § 1 (part), 1973: Ord. 723 § 7, 1968: 1962 Code § 25.610.) 
Section 5.52.030 - Unlawful to occupy room without registering. 
    It is unlawful for any person to occupy a room in any such establishment without entering or causing to be entered his or her true name in the register maintained by such establishment in compliance with the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. 942 § 1 (part), 1973: Ord. 723 § 8, 1968: 1962 Code § 25.615.) 
Section 5.52.040 - Registration systems must be open for inspection; exception-Procedures for objecting to inspection. 
A.  Except as provided in subsection B, every registration system kept in compliance with the provisions of this chapter shall, upon demand, be open for inspection or investigation by the chief of police, or his authorized agent, or for the inspection or investigation of any of the military police or any officer in any of the armed, naval or military services of the United States of America, or any agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, at any and all times. 
B.  Upon receiving a demand for inspection pursuant to subsection A, the owner or operator of an establishment may voluntarily allow inspection of the registration system or may immediately object orally to the inspection. If the owner or operator makes an oral objection or otherwise refuses to allow the inspection, and the law enforcement agency desires to enforce the demand, the officer must make the demand in writing and personally serve it on the owner or operator. The demand must be signed by the officer making the demand. No particular form of the demand is required, but the demand must set forth the name of the establishment, the date and time the demand is served on the establishment and the name of person served. A demand served pursuant to this section shall have attached thereto a form objection letter which may be used by the establishment to object to the demand. 
C.  If the owner or operator of an establishment receives a written demand pursuant to this section and the owner or operator desires to object to the demand, the owner or operator must make a written objection to the demand, with a copy of the demand attached, and personally serve it within 48 hours after receiving the demand. Service of the objection must be made on the officer making the demand or another officer of the same law enforcement agency as the officer who made the demand. No particular form of an objection is required, but the objection must be signed by the owner or operator, and set forth the date and time it is served on the officer or the agency. Failure to timely make and serve a written objection to a demand is a waiver of the establishment's right to seek pre-compliance judicial review of that demand. 
D.  An establishment which makes and serves an objection pursuant to this section may challenge the demand for inspection by filing an action in a court of competent jurisdiction within ten calendar days after the date the objection is served. Failure to timely file such an action is a waiver of the establishment's right to seek pre-compliance judicial review of that demand. 
E.  The owner or operator of an establishment that fails to timely make and serve a written objection, or that makes and serves a timely objection and then fails to timely file an action for pre-compliance judicial review, must open the establishment's registration system for inspection pursuant to subsection A immediately after the lapse of the period of time to make and serve a written objection or to file an action for pre-compliance judicial review, whichever is applicable. 
F.  Nothing in this section prohibits a law enforcement agency from obtaining access to any registration system pursuant to a warrant or ex parte warrant, or if an exception to the warrant requirement applies (e.g., consent or exigent circumstances). 
G.  Nothing in this section prohibits an officer possessing a reasonable, articulable suspicion that a registration system would be altered during pre-compliance review from guarding the registration system pending a decision of the court. 
(Ord. 2523, § 2, Amended, 4/25/2016; Ord. 942 § 1 (part), 1973: Ord. 723 § 9, 1963: 1962 Code § 25.620.) 
Section 5.52.045 - Unlawful to fail or refuse to allow inspection under certain circumstances. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or operator of an establishment required to keep and maintain a registration system pursuant to SMC 5.52.010 to fail or refuse to allow an inspection of that registration system pursuant to SMC 5.52.040 under the following circumstances: 
A.  The law enforcement officer makes an oral demand for such inspection and the owner or operator of the establishment does not object to the demand, but then fails to allow the inspection. 
B.  The owner or operator of the establishment receives an oral demand for inspection and makes an oral objection to such inspection or otherwise refuses to allow the inspection. The law enforcement officer then issues a written demand for inspection pursuant to 5.52.040, but the owner or operator fails to timely make and serve a written objection pursuant to that section and thereafter fails or refuses to allow the inspection. 
C.  The owner or operator of an establishment receives an oral demand for inspection and makes an oral objection or otherwise refuses to allow the inspection. The law enforcement officer then serves a written demand for inspection pursuant to SMC 5.52.040 and the owner or operator timely makes and serves a written objection pursuant to that section, but thereafter fails to timely file an action in a court of competent jurisdiction for pre-compliance review of the police demand for inspection. Following that failure to timely file an action, which is a waiver of the owner's or operator's right to judicial review of the demand, the owner or operator then fails or refuses to allow such inspection. 
D.  The law enforcement officer and the owner or operator of the establishment each act in accordance with SMC 5.52.040 and the establishment files a proper action for pre-compliance judicial review, but the owner or operator is found by the court to have no right to fail or refuse to allow such an inspection, and the owner or operator thereafter fails or refuses to allow the inspection. 
(Ord. 2523, § 3, Add, 4/25/2016) 
Section 5.52.050 - Compliance required-Keeping registration system. 
    It is unlawful for any person who owns or operates within the limits of the city any hotel, motel, building comprised of former hotel or motel rooms which have been converted into apartments, tenement, boarding or rooming house, recreational vehicle park or other establishment where rooms or spaces for lodging are available to rent or lease on a temporary basis to fail, refuse or neglect to comply with the requirements of SMC 5.52.010 and 5.52.040, or to fail, refuse or neglect to keep and maintain a registration system, or to fail, refuse or neglect to keep in possession all registration books, cards or computer entries and related data for a period of at least three years after the date of the last entry therein or thereon. 
(Ord. 2523, § 4, Amended, 4/25/2016; Ord. 942 § 1 (part), 1973: Ord. 723 § 10, 1963: 1962 Code § 25.625.) 
Section 5.52.060 - Reporting minors to police department. 
    It is unlawful for any person who owns or operates within the limits of the city any hotel, motel, building comprised of former hotel or motel rooms which have been converted into apartments, tenement, boarding or rooming house, recreational vehicle park or other establishment where rooms or spaces for lodging are available to rent or lease on a temporary basis to fail to immediately report to the police department the known presence of any and all minors in such rental properties who he has reason to believe to be under the age of eighteen years, unless such minor or minors are accompanied by an adult who he reasonably believes to be a responsible person. 
(Ord. 2523, § 5, Amended, 4/25/2016; Ord. 942 § 1 (part), 1973: Ord. 723 § 11, 1968: 1962 Code § 25.630.) 
Chapter 5.56 - GOING OUT-OF-BUSINESS SALES 

Section 5.56.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases and words shall have the meaning given in this section. 
A.  "Fire and other altered goods sale" is a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale will offer goods damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water or other means. 
B.  "Going-out-of-business sale" is any sale held out or advertised in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand the business will cease and be discontinued, including, but not limited to, the following sales: Adjustor's, adjustment, alteration assignees', bankrupt, benefit-of-creditors, benefit-of-administrator, benefit-of-trustees, building coming down, closing, creditors' committee, creditors', executors', final days, lease expires, liquidation, loss-of-lease, mortgage sale, receivers', trustees', quitting business or other terminology of similar import. 
C.  "Goods" means any goods, wares, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated under this chapter. 
(Ord. 804 § 2, 1970: 1962 Code § 105.870.) 
Section 5.56.020 - Permit-Required. 
    Any person, before selling or offering to sell any goods at a sale advertised or held out by any means whatever to be one of the following kinds: (A) Going-out-of-business sale; or (B) Fire and other altered stock sale, shall first obtain a permit from the chief license officer of the city. 
(Ord. 804 § 3, 1970: 1962 Code § 105.874.) 
Section 5.56.030 - Permit-Application requirements. 
    Any person desiring to conduct a sale regulated by this chapter shall make a written application containing the following information: 
A.  The true name and address of the owner or each of the owners of the goods to be the object of sale; 
B.  The true name and address of the person from whom he purchased the goods to be sold and the price therefor, and if not purchased, the manner of such acquisition, except of property which has been part of the seller's regular stock for sale in the regular course of business for not less than thirty days prior to the date of the application; 
C.  A description of the place where such sale is to be held; 
D.  The nature of the occupancy and the effective date of termination of such occupancy; 
E.  The dates of the period of time during which the sale is to be conducted; 
F.  The means to be employed in advertising such sale, together with the proposed substance content of any advertisement; 
G.  A complete and detailed inventory and original cost of the goods to be sold in such sale, as disclosed by the applicant's records. The inventory shall be attached to and become a part of the required application:
