1.  All goods included in such inventory shall have been purchased by the applicant for resale on bona fide orders without cancellation privileges, and shall not comprise goods purchased on consignment; 
2.  Such inventory shall not include goods ordered in contemplation of conducting a sale regulated under this chapter. Any unusual purchase or additions to the stock of goods of the business affected, within sixty days before the filing of an application hereunder, shall be deemed to be of such character; 
H.  That the applicant has been in business continuously for six months prior to date of application in the city or within its metropolitan area. 
(Ord. 804 § 4, 1970: 1962 Code § 105.879.) 
Section 5.56.040 - Permit-Fee. 
    An application for a permit under this chapter shall be accompanied by a fee of fifty-three dollars. An application for renewal permit under this chapter shall be accompanied by a renewal permit fee of a sum equivalent to one percent of the original inventory filed with the original application. 
(Ord. 1356 § 7, 1982: Ord. 804 § 5, 1970: 1962 Code § 105.882.) 
Section 5.56.050 - Permit-Effect. 
    A permit may be issued under this chapter on the terms set forth in this section. 
A.  The permit shall authorize the sale described in the application for a period of not more than thirty consecutive days, Sundays and legal holidays excluded, following the issuance thereof. The chief license officer may renew a permit for one period of time only, such period to be in addition to the thirty days permitted in the original permit and not to exceed thirty consecutive days, Sundays and holidays excluded, when he finds: That the facts existing justify the permit renewal; that the permittee has filed an application for renewal, wherein a revised inventory showing the items listed on the original inventory remaining unsold, and not listing any goods not included in the original application and inventory, is submitted. 
B.  Nature of Sale. The permit shall authorize only the one type of sale described in the application, at the location named therein. 
C.  Salable Goods. The permit shall authorize only the sale of goods described in the inventory attached to the application. 
D.  Nontransferability. Any permit herein provided for shall not be assignable or transferable. 
E.  Any person who has not been the owner or owners of the business described in the application for a permit under this chapter for a period of at least six months prior to date of the proposed sale shall not be granted a permit. 
(Ord. 804 § 6, 1970: 1962 Code § 105.885.) 
Section 5.56.060 - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect the following persons: 
A.  Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction; 
B.  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials; 
C.  Any publisher of a newspaper, magazine or other publication, or radio or television station, who published in good faith any advertisement, without knowledge of its false, deceptive or misleading character, or without knowledge that the provisions of this chapter have not been complied with. 
(Ord. 804 § 7, 1970: 1962 Code § 105.889.) 
Section 5.56.070 - Permittee's duties. 
    The permittee shall: 
A.  Make no additions whatsoever, during the period provided for under an issued permit under this chapter, to the stock of goods set forth in the inventory attached to the application for permit; 
B.  Refrain from employing any untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising; 
C.  Conduct the permitted sale in strict conformity with any advertising or holding-out incident thereto; 
D.  Keep available at the place of sale a duplicate copy of the inventory submitted with the application, and shall present such duplicate to inspecting officials upon request; 
E.  State prominently the exact closing date of any sale held under this chapter in all advertisements, signs and holding-out of such sale. 
(Ord. 804 § 8, 1970: 1962 Code § 105.892.) 
Section 5.56.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(Ord. 804 § 9, 1970: 1962 Code § 105.895.) (Ord. 2471, § 37, Amended, 2/11/2013) 
Section 5.56.090 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 2471, § 38, Add, 2/11/2013) 
Chapter 5.58 - FLEA MARKET OPERATORS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS 

Section 5.58.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases and words shall have the meaning given in this section. 
A.  "Itinerant merchant" is any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the city or one who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within the city, not licensed under the provisions of Section 5.08.020 of this title, and who, in furtherance of such purposes, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, public room in any hotel, lodging house, apartment, shop, or any street, alley, or any other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction; provided that such definition shall not be construed to include any person, firm, or corporation who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only. 
B.  "Flea market operator" means any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee, or employee, whether a resident of the city, or not, who leases, licenses with or without charge, any premises or portion of any premises, to any itinerant merchant as a normal business activity. Flea market operator shall not include the owner or operator of any hotel or motel whose rooms are used by any itinerant merchant who is principally engaged in the hotel business and does not lease or license such space to itinerant merchants as part of an organized business activity. 
(Ord. 1031 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Section 5.58.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for an itinerant merchant or flea market operator as defined in Section 5.58.010 to engage in business within the city without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this title. 
(Ord. 1031 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Section 5.58.030 - Flea market operator. 
A.  Any person engaged in the business as a flea market operator shall apply for a license to conduct such business in accordance with the provisions of Section 5.12.010 of this title and pay the fees therefor provided in Section 5.12.100. 
B.  Gross receipts as applied to flea market operators shall include: 
1.  All moneys or other consideration derived by the flea market operator from any itinerant merchant for the use of the flea market operator's premises for the sale of any goods, wares or other merchandise, or for the performance of any services. 
2.  Moneys or other consideration received by any itinerant merchant while using the flea market operator's premises for the conduct of the itinerant merchant's business. 
(Ord. 1031 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Section 5.58.040 - Booth fee and certificates of payment. 
A.  The flea market operator shall additionally pay a fee of fifteen dollars per week, or portion of a week, for each individual itinerant merchant occupying or using any space. A week shall begin on Tuesday and end on Monday. 
B.  The flea market operator shall supply each itinerant merchant with a certificate indicating payment of the fee provided in this chapter for the days the itinerant merchant anticipates conducting business at the flea market operator's premises. The flea market operator shall provide the special services department of the Sparks police department with a duplicate of the certificate accompanied by the proper fee. 
C.  If any itinerant merchant remains on the premises of the flea market operator for a greater number of days than anticipated, the flea market operator shall provide the itinerant merchant with an additional certificate for any additional days and pay fees therefor as provided prior to the last day for which the flea market operator has issued a certificate. 
D.  Conducting any business in a flea market operator's premises without a certificate issued by the flea market operator pursuant to subsections A, B and C shall subject the itinerant merchant to punishment for a misdemeanor and shall be grounds for revocation of the flea market operator's license. 
(Ord. 1762, 1992: Ord. 1455 § 1, 1984: Ord. 1031 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Section 5.58.050 - Itinerant merchant's conduct of business within a licensed flea market operator's premises. 
A.  An itinerant merchant is not required to apply for and receive a license as required by Section 5.08.020 when: 
1.  All his business is conducted within the premises of a flea market operator licensed under the provisions of this title; 
2.  He displays a valid certificate issued by the flea market operator as provided in Section 5.58.040. 
(Ord. 1031 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Section 5.58.060 - Unlawful to sell merchandise within a licensed flea market with altered serial number. 
A.  It is unlawful for any itinerant merchant knowingly to sell, attempt to sell, or have in his possession within a licensed flea market, any item of merchandise with an identifying number or serial number that has been obliterated or altered in any manner, unless the manufacturer of the item has obliterated or altered the serial number. 
B.  It is unlawful for any flea market operator to knowingly permit any itinerant merchant to sell or attempt to sell, or have in his possession within a licensed flea market, an item of merchandise with identifying number or serial number that has been obliterated or altered in any manner, unless the manufacturer of the item has obliterated or altered the serial number. 
(Ord. 1031 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Section 5.58.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished as provided in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(Ord. 1031 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Section 5.58.080 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 2471, § 39, Add, 2/11/2013) 
Chapter 5.59 - ROADWAY AND SIDEWALK VENDORS 

Section 5.59.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the words and terms defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section. 
A.  "Food" means any product or substance (including beverages) intended for human consumption. 
B.  "Permittee" means the person, corporation or business entity named on a vending permit issued pursuant to this chapter. 
C.  "Public street or sidewalk" includes all areas legally open to public use as public streets, sidewalks, roadways, highways, parkways, alleys, and any other public way. 
D.  "Roadway vendor" means a vendor who operates vending business while occupying public space in that portion of a street or highway, improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
E.  "Sidewalk vendor" means a vendor who engages in business while occupying that portion of the street other than that used for vehicular travel. 
F.  "Stand" means any newsstand, table, bench, booth, rack handcart, pushcart or any other fixture or device used for the display, storage or transportation of articles or services offered for sale by a vendor. "Stand" does not include newsracks. 
G.  "Vehicle" means any motor vehicle, trailer or bicycle. 
H.  Vendor" means any person, including an employee or agent of another, who sells or offers to sell food, beverages, goods, services or merchandise on any public street or sidewalk from a stand, motor vehicle or from his or her person. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.59.020 - Victorian square vendor permit required; chapter inapplicable to special events and sales of "expressive" merchandise. 
A.  It is unlawful for any vendor to sell, display or offer for sale any food, beverage, goods, services or merchandise on the public streets or sidewalks or other city-owned property within the Victorian Square area described in SMC 5.59.100 without first having obtained a permit in accordance with this chapter. 
B.  Vendors selling ice cream or other products or merchandise from a motor vehicle are not eligible to obtain a permit to operate in Victorian Square in accordance with this Chapter. 
C.  This section does not apply to vendors who are authorized participants in a special event permitted under chapter 9.34 of this code. 
D.  This chapter does not apply to vendors of qualified First Amendment "expressive merchandise," as that term is defined in Chapter 12.26. 
(Ord. 1863, 1995: Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Amended, 09/25/2006) 
Section 5.59.030 - Application. 
    An application for a vendor's permit shall contain all information deemed relevant and necessary to evaluate the proposed vending business including but not limited to: 
A.  Proof of the identity of business address of the applicant; 
B.  A brief description of the nature, character and quality of the food, beverages, goods, services or merchandise to be sold; 
C.  If employed by another, the name and business address of the person, firm, association, organization, company or corporation; 
D.  A description of the vending vehicle, cart, stand or other equipment to be used; 
E.  If a motor vehicle is to be used in the vending business, a description of the vehicle together with the motor vehicle registration number and the license number; 
F.  A description of thg proposed location(s) of the vendinp business and the length of time during which it is proposed that the business shall be conducted; 
G.  Two full-face photographs of the applicant two inches by two inches in size taken within not more than three months prior to the date of applicationo 
H.  A set of fingerprints as required by the chief of police; 
I.  A statement of all arrests and convictions for criminal conduct within the preceding five years except for minor traffic offenses. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.59.040 - Permit fees. 
    Permits may be issued for a period not to exceed three years. Permit fees shall be determined by the city council with due consideration given to the market value of the proposed vending location and the nature and appearance of the proposed vending business. Vending permits are in the nature of a lease and do not relieve permittees from the obligation to pay for and obtain a city business license. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.59.050 - Insurance. 
    No license shall be issued to an applicant unless the applicant furnishes proof to the city of a public liability bond or insurance policy for property damage and injuries, including injury resulting in death, caused by the operation of the vending business. The bond or insurance policy must be in an amount established by the city manager for the type of business to be conducted. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.59.060 - Identification badges and permits-Display. 
A.  Permittee and each employee working at a vending stand or vehicle must obtain identification badges from the Sparks police department. A fee of ten dollars must be paid for each identification badge. Badges must be properly and conspicuously displayed at all times during the operation of the vending business. Such badges shall be deemed to be properly displayed when they are attached to the outer garment of the permittee or employee and clearly visible to the public. If a badge becomes damaged, lost or obscured, the badge must be returned to the police department (unless lost) and another badge will be issued upon payment of a reissuance fee in the amount of five dollars. 
B.  Permits and identification badges shall be used only by the person to whom they were issued and may not be transferred to any other person. 
C.  No person shall fraudulently alter, mutilate, forge or illegally display any badge issued pursuant to these regulations. 
D.  Every permittee or holder of an identification badge issued pursuant to this section shall exhibit the same for examination upon demand by an authorized representative of the city of Sparks. 
E.  A copy of the vending permit must be carried with the vending stand or vehicle and must be surrendered for inspection upon demand by an authorized representative of the city. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.59.070 - Inspection by health department. 
A.  No permit to sell food products for human consumption shall be granted unless the applicant has been issued a health permit by the Washoe County district health department. 
B.  Certificates of health inspection shall be properly and conspicuously displayed at all times during the operation of the vending business. Certificates of health inspection shall be deemed to be properly displayed when they are firmly attached to the vending vehicle or stand and clearly visible to the public. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.59.080 - Bookkeeping requirements. 
    Every vendor shall keep records of sales and receipts as required by the director of finance and shall make such records available for inspection upon request. The vendor shall file with its monthly payment a report of gross receipts as required by the director of finance together with monthly sales tax reports submitted to the Nevada Department of Taxation for the same period. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.59.090 - Notification of change of address or name. 
    Whenever either the name or address provided by the permittee on his application for a permit or inspection certificate changes, the licensee shall notify the revenue division of the department of finance within ten days of such change. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.59.100 - Area where vending business are permitted. 
    Vending is permitted only in the portion of the Victorian Square area bounded by and including the "C" Street right-of-way, 15th Street right-of-way, Nugget Avenue right-of-way and Pyramid Way right-of-way. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2340, Amended, 09/25/2006) 
Section 5.59.110 - Requirements for vending stands and vehicles. 
A.  All vending stands and vehicles shall by design and decoration comply with the Victorian theme of the "B Street Redevelopment Project." The design and decoration of each stand or vehicle must be approved by the redevelopment design review committee in accordance with guidelines contained in the Victorian Design Review Manual. The department of parks and recreation shall not issue a vendor's permit pursuant to this chapter unless the applicant has secured the approval of the redevelopment design review committee. 
B.  All items related to the operation of a vending business shall be kept either on, in, or under a vending vehicle or stand. No such items shall be stored or placed upon any public space adjacent to the vending vehicle or stand. 
C.  Vendors shall keep the sidewalks, roadways and other public space adjoining and adjacent to their locations of business clean and free from paper, peelings, and refuse of any kind generated from the operation of their business. 
D.  Food vendors shall affix to their stands or vehicles a container for litter which shall be maintained and emptied regularly and which shall be marked as being for litter. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2340, Amended, 09/25/2006) 
Section 5.59.120 - Restrictions applicable to sidewalk vendors. 
    Sidewalk vendor stands shall not: 
A.  Impede access to the entrance of any adjacent building or driveway; 
B.  Occupy more than half of the available sidewalk width or four feet of such sidewalk, whichever is less; 
C.  Locate within ten feet of a fire hydrant, fire escape, bus stop, loading zone, or driveway of a fire station, police station or hospital; 
D.  Be leaned against or hung from any building or any other structure, including, but not limited to, structures such as lamp posts, parking meters, mail boxes, traffic signal stanchions, fire hydrants, trees, tree boxes, benches, bus shelters, or traffic barriers which lawfully occupy public space. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.59.130 - Selection of vendors. 
    The object of this chapter is to attract people to certain areas of the city and to promote a festive atmosphere in such areas. This will be accomplished through the selection of a limited number of vendors who will operate vending businesses on public property. The vendors must compete for available permits by demonstrating that their proposed stand or vehicle will complement the architectural and aesthetic theme of the area in which they are to be located and that their goods or services will be of high quality. The selection process shall be as follows: 
A.  The redevelopment design review committee shall study authorized vending areas to determine locations where stands or vehicles are appropriate and to determine the types of goods or services which are best suited to achieve the city's goals in each area. 
B.  Said committee shall establish criteria for selecting the most suitable vendor for each approved location. Said committee shall then solicit applications for vending permits. 
C.  The committee shall recommend appropriate permit fees. The committee may base such a recommendation on competitive bids submitted by applicants. 
D.  The committee shall submit its recommendations concerning appropriate vendors for each proposed location to the department of parks and recreation, which shall select vendors and establish the terms and conditions of vendor permits. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2340, Amended, 09/25/2006) 
Section 5.59.140 - Suspension or revocation of permit. 
A.  Any permit issued under this chapter may be suspended or revoked for any of the following reasons: 
1.  Fraud or misrepresentation in the application for the permit; 
2.  Fraud or misrepresentation in the course of conducting the business of vending; 
3.  Conducting the business of vending contrary to the conditions of the permit; 
4.  Conducting the business of vending in such a manner as to create a public nuisance or constitute a danger to the public health, safety or welfare. 
B.  A permit issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a permit issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2471, § 40, Amended, 2/11/2013) 
Section 5.59.150 - Duties of the permittee. 
    Every permittee authorized to vend under this chapter shall: 
A.  Ascertain and at all times comply with all laws and provisions of this chapter applicable to the operation of a vending business; 
B.  Terminate the vending business after the expiration of his permit and during any period when his permit has been suspended or revoked; and 
C.  Surrender his permit promptly upon its revocation or suspension. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.59.160 - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to the penalties prescribed in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(Ord. 1610 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Chapter 5.60 - HOME SERVICES 

Section 5.60.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the words and terms defined in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
A.  "Home service" means any business or agency which, for a fee, commission, hire or reward, furnishes or offers to furnish persons other than a licensee who provide services to the public in homes, apartments, mobile homes or any other residential dwelling, and who provide the service of residential housekeeping. 
B.  "Residential housekeeping service" means any business or agency which provides persons who clean occupied residences at the request of the owner or occupant. 
(Ord. 1122 § 1, 1977: Ord. 1116 § 2, 1977: Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.60.020 - Policy declaration. 
    It is declared to be the policy of the city that all home service businesses as defined in this chapter while providing such service in the city shall be licensed and controlled in order to protect the public health, safety, morals and good order and the general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Ord. 1133 § 1, 1978: Ord. 1116 § 3, 1977: Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) 
Section 5.60.030 - License required-Fee. 
    No person shall conduct, manage or carry on any home service without a business license issued in accordance with Title 5 of the SMC. No license shall be issued by the council except upon the verified application in writing of the applicant to be in control of the business. Each application must be accompanied by a license fee of eighty dollars plus police investigation fees as follows: 
Individual ..... twenty-seven dollars 
Organization, group or partnership ..... twenty-seven dollars each person 
Corporation ..... twenty-seven dollars each officer 
    The initial license fee and investigation fee shall be payable in advance. Thereafter, each applicant shall report his gross sales and pay the license fees as required by Section 5.12.100 of this code. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, regulations applicable to general businesses in the city shall be applicable to home service businesses. No fees or charges are refundable for any reason. No license under this chapter shall be issued to, or in the name of, any organization, group corporation, partnership, or any other entity than the individual operating the home service business. 
(Ord. 1361 § 6, 1982: Ord. 1356 § 8, 1982: Ord. 1116 § 4, 1977: Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.60.040 - Application for license. 
    The application for a license shall be upon a form furnished by the finance department and shall set forth such information concerning the applicant and the proposed business as may be required by the application. Each application must set out the names and addresses of all employees intended by the applicant to perform home services. 
(Ord. 1116 § 5, 1977: Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.60.050 - Home service employees-Requirement for work permit. 
A.  Prior to employment, every home service employee expected to perform cleaning services shall apply for and obtain a work permit from the chief of police in the manner set forth in Chapter 5.22 of the SMC. 
(Ord. 1628 § 6, 1988: Ord. 1361 § 7, 1982: Ord. 1116 § 6, 1977: Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.60.060 - Persons unqualified for license as a home service business. 
    The following persons are not qualified to hold a home service business license: 
A.  A person who has been convicted within the preceding five years of: 
1.  A felony or of any crime which under the laws of this state would be a felony; 
2.  Any crime of which fraud or intent to defraud was the element, whether in this state or elsewhere; 
3.  Larceny in any degree; 
4.  Buying or receiving stolen property; 
5.  Unlawful entry of a building; 
6.  Unlawful possession or distribution of narcotic drugs; 
7.  Unlawful use, carrying or possession of a pistol or other dangerous weapon; or 
8.  Prostitution; 
B.  A person who the council determines is not a suitable person to receive a license, having due consideration for the proper protection of the public health, safety and the general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Ord. 1116 § 7, 1977: Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.60.070 - Investigation. 
    If the finance department, after investigation by the police department, finds that the applicant for a license is qualified and that the business is to be conducted at a suitable and proper place, and is not calculated or intended to be operated as a subterfuge for the conduct of any unlawful business or practice, then a license shall be granted. Otherwise, the application shall be denied. 
(Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.60.080 - Place of business. 
    The licensee shall conduct the business only at the address shown upon the license. Each additional place of business shall require a separate license. Upon the abandonment of the designated place of business, a change of address may be made upon the payment of a special fee of ten dollars, and the new address shall be endorsed upon the license. 
(Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.60.090 - Maintenance of records. 
    A record shall be kept by the licensee showing every transaction whereby any home service employee is employed, furnished or arranged for on behalf of any patron or customer, hour of the transaction, the name, address and telephone number of the patron or customer, the name of each home service employee involved, the fee charged per hour to the patron, the total fee charged each patron, the amount paid the home service employee, the amount retained by the licensee, and such other information as the chief of police or his designee may reasonably require by rule. Such record shall be available and open to inspection and copying by the police department at any time. 
(Ord. 1116 § 8, 1977: Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.60.100 - Suspension or revocation of licenses-Grounds and procedure. 
    A license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation by the chief of police or his designee for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation, except that the chief of police or his designee is empowered to conduct all proceedings and make all determinations. 
(Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) (Ord. 2471, § 41, Amended, 2/11/2013; Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.60.110 - Submission of employee records. 
    Each licensee shall submit to the chief of police a complete and current list of all employees, their work permit numbers, together with their addresses and telephone numbers at the time the license is first issued and on the first of January and first of June of each year thereafter. Each licensee shall submit to the chief of police the names and addresses of all employees terminated from employment within forty-eight hours after termination. 
(Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.60.120 - License nontransferable. 
    Any license granted hereunder shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. 1064 § 1 (part), 1976.) 
Section 5.60.140 - Bond. 
    Every licensee hereunder shall post a bond in the sum of five thousand dollars, payable to the city, and approved by the city attorney's office, which bond shall be for the protection of the patrons of the licensee against theft or other unlawful acts of the licensee or home service employee. No license shall in any manner advertise their service as licensed and bonded by the city. 
(Ord. 1116 § 10, 1977: Ord. 1064 § 1, 1976.) 
Chapter 5.62 - BABYSITTING AGENCIES 

Sec. 5.62.080 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
Section 5.62.010 - Babysitting agency defined. 
    A "babysitting agency" is an agency which places persons known as babysitters in a place of residence (home, motel or hotel) for the care of children for a fee or otherwise. 
(Ord. 1121 § 1 (part), 1977) 
Section 5.62.020 - Licensing and bonding. 
    Each babysitting agency which places babysitters in the city shall be licensed and bonded by the state and licensed by the city. The division of finance shall require an application to be completed and issue a license to eligible persons. A copy of the state bond shall be deposited with the license division of the city before issuance of the license. The annual license fee shall be eighty dollars ($80.00) per year. Thereafter, each applicant shall report his gross sales and pay the license fees as required by Section 5.12.100 of this Code. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, provisions of the SMC that are applicable to general businesses in the city are applicable to babysitting agencies. 
(Ord. 2471, § 42, Amended, 2/11/2013; Ord. 1356 § 9, 1982: Ord. 1121 § 1 (part), 1977) 
Section 5.62.030 - Investigation fee. 
    Each application for a license under this chapter must be accompanied by a police investigation fee established by resolution. An investigation fee must be paid for each officer of a corporation or other organization and for each partner of a partnership. 
(Ord. 1628 § 7, 1988: Ord. 1361 § 8, 1982: Ord. 1121 § 1 (part), 1977) 
Section 5.62.040 - Standards and regulations applicable to all babysitters placed by an agency. 
A.  A babysitter placed by a babysitting agency: 
1.  Must be eighteen (18) years of age or older. 
2.  Must not be under the influence of alcoholic beverages or stupefying drugs at time of placement or during care of children. Each individual impliedly consents to submit to a breath alcohol analysis administered by the city police department. Failure to submit to such analysis where reasonable belief of intoxication is shown, or an analysis result greater than .05 percent alcohol by weight shall result in the revocation of said individual's right to work as a babysitter under this chapter. 
3.  Must possess and carry a valid work permit issued by the chief of police or his designee pursuant to Chapter 5.22 of the SMC. A person seeking a work permit must meet the qualifications set forth in SMC 5.22.010. 
4.  Must not use corporal punishment on children, whether or not permission has been given by the parent or guardian. 
5.  Must not transport a child from place to place in a private vehicle, except in a medical emergency. 
6.  Shall not babysit while suffering from a communicable disease. 
7.  Shall not smoke on premises of children being cared for, unless given permission a by parent or guardian of each child present. 
(Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003; Ord. 1628 § 8, 1988: Ord. 1361 § 9, 1982: Ord. 1121 § 1 (part), 1977) 
Section 5.62.050 - Records and inspection. 
    Each agency shall keep in its place of business a record of each person placed for the care of children including police work card number and expiration date. Current records of the agency shall be readily available, and must be furnished for inspection upon request to an authorized employee of the city. 
(Ord. 1121 § (part), 1977) 
Section 5.62.060 - Persons unqualified for license. 
    The following persons are not qualified to hold any license under the provisions of this chapter: 
A.  A person who has been convicted within the preceding five (5) years of: 
1.  A felony or any crime which under the laws of this state would be a felony; 
2.  Any crime of which fraud or intent to defraud was an element, whether in this state or elsewhere; 
3.  Larceny in any degree; 
4.  Buying or receiving stolen property; 
5.  Unlawful entry of a building; 
6.  Unlawful possession or distribution of narcotic drugs; 
7.  Unlawful use, carrying or possession of a firearm or other dangerous weapon; 
8.  Prostitution; or 
9.  Any sex crime that would require the person to register under Chapter 179D of NRS. 
B.  A person who the the chief license officer and the chief of police mutually agree is not a suitable person to receive a license, having due consideration for the proper protection of the public health, safety and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Ord. 2502, Amended, 09/08/2014; Ord. 2471, § 43, Amended, 02/11/2013; Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003; Ord. 1121 § 1 (part), 1977) 
Section 5.62.080 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter, for the licensee's failure to remain qualified under SMC 5.62.060, or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 2471, § 44, Add, 02/11/2013) 
Chapter 5.65 - MASSAGE SERVICES 
Article I. - Massage Establishments and Outcall Businesses 

Section 5.65.010 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context otherwise requires, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein: 
A.  "Board" means the board of massage examiners. 
B.  "Colonic irrigation" means a method of hydrotherapy used to cleanse the colon with the aid of a mechanical device and liquid. 
C.  "Director" means the director of finance. 
D.  "Licensee" means the person to whom a business license has been issued to own or operate a massage establishment or outcall business regulated by this chapter. 
E.  "Massage" means the manipulation of the superficial tissues of the human body with the hand, foot, arm or elbow, whether or not such manipulation is aided by hydrotherapy or thermal therapy; any electrical or mechanical device; or the application to the human body of a chemical or herbal preparation. 
F.  "Massage establishment" means any establishment where massage is given or offered for compensation on the premises. 
G.  "Massage patron" means any person who receives a massage under such circumstances that it is reasonably expected that he or she or some third person on his or her behalf will pay money or give any other consideration or any gratuity therefor. 
H.  "Massage technician" means any person who performs massage as defined in this section. 
I.  "Outcall business" means any business enterprise having a source of income or compensation derived from the practice of out-call massage. 
J.  "Outcall massage" means a massage performed at any location other than the premises of a massage establishment or outcall business. 
K.  "Sexual gratification" means sexual conduct as defined in NRS 201.295. 
L.  "Recognized school of massage" means any school or educational institution licensed or approved in the state it is located, whose purpose it is to upgrade the professionalism of massage technicians and which teaches the theory, ethics, practice, profession or work of massage; which requires a resident course of study before the student shall be furnished with a diploma or certificate of graduation from such school or institution of learning following the successful completion of such course of study or learning. Schools offering a correspondence course not requiring actual attendance shall not be deemed a recognized school. 
(Ord. 1650 § 1, 1989: Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988. ) (Ord. 2166, Amended, 02/24/2003) 
Section 5.65.020 - Policy declaration. 
    This chapter regulating the practice of massage has been enacted to insure that massage technicians performing massage within the city have a knowledge of anatomy and physiology and an understanding of the relationship between the structure and the function of the tissues being treated in order to protect the public from potential injury and has been enacted to improve the image of the massage profession as a therapeutic art by regulating deceptive advertising and illegal and unprofessional practices. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.030 - Exemptions from this chapter. 
    This chapter shall not apply to the following individuals while engaged in the personal performance of the duties of their respective professions: 
A.  Physicians, surgeons, chiropractors, osteopaths, psychologists, physical therapists or nurses who are duly licensed to practice their respective professions in this state; 
B.  Barbers and cosmetologists duly licensed by the state and who perform massage of the head, neck and shoulders only. 
C.  Students enrolled and in good standing in a recognized school of massage, as that term is defined by Section 5.65.010(L). 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2166, Amended, 02/24/2003) 
Section 5.65.040 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on, in or upon any premises in the city, the operation of any massage establishment, outcall business or the practice of massage, without first having obtained a business license from the city pursuant to this chapter. Massage technicians working as an independent contractor must first obtain a business license from the city before performing massage on any premises within the city. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.050 - Applications, investigation and license issuance. 
    A business license issued under the provisions of this chapter is a privilege. A license shall not be issued for the operation of a massage establishment or outcall business unless the applicant for such license successfully carries the burden of establishing suitability to receive the license. One license shall be issued for each massage establishment or outcall business. The license fee shall be determined as provided in Section 5.12.100 of this title. 
A.  All persons desiring to obtain a business license to engage in a massage establishment business or outcall business within the city shall first file an application with the finance director on a form provided by his office. 
B.  All applicants shall provide the following information under oath: 
1.  Applicant's height, weight, sex, color of eyes and hair and Social Security number; 
2.  All criminal convictions, both felony and misdemeanor, except minor traffic violations, during the preceding ten years; 
3.  The address of the proposed business location with a copy of the deed, lease or other document pursuant to which applicant occupies such premises; 
4.  The person or persons who will have custody of the business records at the business location; 
5.  Agent for service of process; 
6.  All residential addresses, education and immediate family members during the preceding ten-year period; 
7.  Proof that the applicant is at least eighteen years of age; 
8.  Applicant's business and employment history during the preceding ten years stating whether or not the applicant, or applicant's manager, director, officer, partner or stockholders have had any business license revoked or suspended and stating the details thereof including the reasons therefor; 
9.  Nothing contained herein shall be construed to deny the city the right to take the fingerprints and photographs of the applicant, nor shall anything contained herein be construed to deny the right of the city to confirm the height and weight of the applicant. 
C.  1.  If an applicant is a partnership or limited partnership all application information listed in subsection B of this section shall be provided for all the partners, including, if applicable, limited partners, the same as if each were a sole proprietor and applicant. 
2.  If an applicant is a corporation, all application information listed in subsection B of this section shall be provided for each of the directors officers and shareholders holding ten percent or more of the stock of the corporation the same as if each were a sole proprietor and applicant. 
3.  If applicant is a partnership or limited partnership, it shall provide a certified copy of an agreement or articles of partnership or limited partnership and certificate. 
4.  If applicant is a corporation the application shall be accompanied by: 
a.  A certified copy of the articles of incorporation of such corporation and, if incorporated under the laws of another state, a certificate of qualification to do business in the state; and 
b.  A current annual list of officers, directors and resident agent of such corporation; and 
c.  A list of the stockholders, the last known residence address and telephone number of each, and their respective ownership interests in such corporation certified as being true and correct by the secretary of such corporation; and 
d.  A certified copy of all minutes or resolutions by the board of directors of such corporation authorizing such license application and designating the officer to apply on such application and authorizing his verification thereof. 
5.  If such business is to be conducted under a name other than the legal name of the applicant, the application must be accompanied by a copy of the fictitious name certificate on file with the county clerk. 
6.  All officers directors, shareholders which own directly or constructively ten percent or more of the outstanding stock of the corporation, and the managing agent of the corporation must be investigated for determination of suitability as set forth in this chapter. 
D.  The applicant shall supplement the application by submitting a written plan setting forth the method of operation of the massage establishment, which shall include, but not be limited to: 
1.  The hours that the massage establishment will be open to the public (the hours shall include all hours any massage technicians are with a patron); and 
2.  The methods of promoting the health and safety of massage technicians and protecting them from assault, battery and rape; and 
3.  The methods of supervision of employees to prevent the massage technicians from charging the patron any fee which is in addition to the fee paid to the massage establishment by the patron; and 
4.  The method of supervision which will prevent the massage technicians from engaging in acts of prostitution; and 
5.  The Federal Employer's Identification number and State Industrial Insurance System policy number; and 
6.  The name and the address of the certified public accountant who will certify the gross receipts upon application for renewal license; and 
7.  The applicant shall submit a statement disclosing the names of all persons who have invested in the proposed massage establishment, and who will share in or receive a percentage of the profit or return from the proposed massage establishment. 
E.  The failure to truthfully disclose any of the information required by subsections B, C and D of this section or the failure to make a full disclosure of all facts required shall be grounds for denying the license or, if subsequent to issuance of a license it is discovered that any applicant or person required to be investigated has not been completely truthful or has withheld any facts in answering the above questions, such failure shall be grounds for revoking the license. 
F.  After the filing of a completed application and payment of all fees, and unless the applicant has previously submitted and successfully passed an approved background check in a jurisdiction granting reciprocity to the City of Sparks, the applicant shall be referred to the police department of the city for fingerprinting, investigation and reporting as required in this chapter. 
G.  The result of such investigation shall be given to the director within sixty days or as soon thereafter as possible. 
H.  The director shall deny the license if: 
1.  The license application is incomplete so as to not contain all information required by this chapter; or 
2.  All license and investigation fees are not paid; or 
3.  The applicant or any of its principals have been held liable in a civil action for engaging in fraudulent advertising or sales or trade practices; or 
4.  The applicant fails to meet the requirements for a licensee of a massage establishment or outcall business; or 
5.  The applicant or partner stockholder officer or director has had a massage establishment license previously revoked or denied for any ground set out in this chapter; or 
6.  The proposed business will or has violated provisions of this code, or state or federal law. 
I.  An applicant whose license has been denied by the director may appeal the director s decision to the city council according to the procedure in Section 5.16.010 of this title. The city council shall hear the appeal by examination of: 
1.  The circumstances of the crime or civil action, past business experience, and plans for operation of the proposed massage establishment; and 
2.  The applicant's criminal and civil court history, and business or employment history since such adjudications. 
The city council may sustain the director's denial or grant the license based on the evidence presented. The city council may grant a restricted or conditional license if in its discretion the facts presented merit such license. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2117, Amended, 12/10/2001) 
Section 5.65.060 - Investigation fees. 
    An investigation fee established by resolution shall accompany every application. In addition, applications with more than one person for which a separate background investigation must be conducted shall pay an investigation fee for each person. The investigation of previously licensed resident massage establishment licensees may be waived by the chief of police. 
    The chief of police may require payment of additional investigative fees if he determines that the circumstances so warrant. Every previously unlicensed applicant shall pay the entire cost incurred by the city to complete the investigation required by this chapter whether the application is approved or denied. Such costs are a collectible debt due to the city and must be paid in full prior to final consideration for licensing by the director. 
(Ord. 1762, 1992: Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.070 - Qualifications for license-Employment. 
    No person shall hold a license for a massage establishment or outcall business or a massage technician's certificate issued pursuant to this chapter who: 
A.  Has been convicted within the preceding five years of: 
1.  Any felony or crime which under the laws of this state would be a felony, 
2.  Larceny in any degree, 
3.  Any offense involving sexual misconduct, pandering or prostitution, 
4.  Unlawful possession, manufacture, or distribution of a controlled substance as defined in Chapter 453 of the Nevada Revised Statutes, 
5.  Any violation of a local or state massage law; 
B.  Is younger than eighteen years of age; 
C.  Is a person who the city council determines is not a suitable person to receive a license, having due consideration for the protection of the public health, safety, morals and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city; 
D.  Has made a material misrepresentation of fact on the application for a business license or massage technician's license; 
E.  Has owned, managed or worked for an illegal or unlicensed brothel, or received payment or a portion of profits therefrom. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.080 - Employment of massage technicians with licenses. 
    It is unlawful for any person to employ in a massage establishment or outcall business any massage technician not having a license issued pursuant to this chapter. It shall be unlawful for any massage technicians to perform massages for a massage establishment or outcall business which is not licensed pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.090 - Register of employees. 
    The licensee or person designated by the licensee of a massage establishment or outcall business shall maintain a register of all persons employed at any time as massage technicians and their license numbers. Such register shall be available at the massage establishment or outcall business to any police officer or other authorized representative of the city. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.100 - Inspections. 
    A licensee shall not refuse to permit any police officer or member of the building department, health department, finance department or fire department to inspect the business premises or operations. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.110 - Operating requirements. 
A.  Every portion of a massage establishment or outcall business, including appliances, apparatus and personnel, shall be kept clean and operated in a sanitary condition. 
B.  All employees of massage establishments and outcall businesses shall wear clean, opaque outer garments and underwear at all times. Body stockings, leotards, tights, sleepwear and other garments which cover all or part of the body in a snug, tight-fitting manner (except underwear) may not be worn by a licensee or employee at any massage establishment or during any outcall massage. The underwear of a licensee may not be exposed to any customer of a licensee at any time.. The genitals or breasts of any licensee, massage technician or employee may not be exposed to any customer at any time. 
C.  All massage establishments and outcall businesses shall provide clean, laundered sheets and towels in sufficient quantity to perform the massage pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, and said sheets and towels must be laundered after each use thereof and stored in a sanitary manner. 
D.  Wet and dry heat rooms, shower compartments and toilet rooms shall be thoroughly cleaned each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs shall be thoroughly cleaned after each use. 
E.  No massage establishment or outcall business licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall place, publish, distribute, disseminate or broadcast or cause to be placed, published disseminated or broadcast, any advertising matter or sign which would reasonably suggest to prospective patrons that sexual stimulation or sexual gratification will be provided or otherwise make or imply any other statement which is known or, through the exercise of reasonable care, should be known to be false, deceptive or misleading. 
F.  The licensee of each massage establishment must post in the reception area or other location visible to all prospective customers a list of the massage charges, rates or fees for all of the services provided by the establishment. A massage technician or other employee of each outcall business must provide to each client or customer a list of massage charges, rates or fees for all of the services provided by the outcall business. Each massage establishment and outcall business must file and maintain a current list of massage charges, rates or fees for all massage services with the finance director. It is unlawful to charge a rate or fee in an amount greater than that set forth in the list of fees. 
G.  The genital area of male or female customers and the breasts of female customers must be covered by a sheet, towel or other opaque clothing at all times. It is the responsibility of the licensee to insure that the genitals of the male and female customers and the breasts of female customers remain covered at all times. Should the genitals of male and female customers or the breasts of female customers become intentionally or accidentally uncovered, the physical contact between the licensee and the customer must cease. 
H.  It is unlawful for any person in a massage establishment or during the course of an outcall massage to place his or her hand upon, to touch with any part of his or her body, to fondle in any manner or to massage the genital area or female breasts of any person. 
I.  A licensee or massage employee may not photograph or record in any manner, either visually or audibly, any customer or his or her voice without the prior consent of that customer. A licensee or massage employee may not sell or transfer for any consideration any photograph or recording so made in violation of this section. 
J.  It is unlawful for a massage technician or other employee of a massage establishment or outcall business to refuse to provide their name upon the request of a customer or prospective customer or to give false identity. 
K.  Massage technicians shall not perform colonic irrigation or violate any regulation of the board of massage examiners. 
(Ord. 1650 §§ 2,3, 1989: Ord. 1623 § 1 (part),1988.) 
Section 5.65.120 - Sale, transfer or change of location. 
    Upon sale, transfer or change of location of a business regulated by this chapter, the license therefor shall be null and void; provided, however, that upon the death or incapacity of the licensee or any co-licensee, any administrator, executor or conservator of the licensee's estate may continue the business for a reasonable period of time not to exceed sixty days to allow for an orderly transfer of the license. In the event a massage establishment or outcall business is owned by a partnership or corporation, the license therefore shall be null and void upon the sale or transfer of more than forty-nine percent of the ownership interest in said business. In any event, all the owners of a business regulated by this chapter must meet the qualifications of a licensee as provided herein or the license shall become null and void. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.130 - License fees. 
    An annual license fee in the amount set forth in Section 5.12.100 of this title shall be paid for each massage establishment or outcall business license issued pursuant to this chapter. Said license fee shall be payable at the time and pursuant to the procedures specified in Chapter 5.12 of this code. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.140 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2471, § 45, Amended, 2/11/2013) 
Article II. - Massage Technicians 

Section 5.65.150 - License-required-reciprocity. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, it is unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on, or permit to carry on, upon any premises, within the city, the operation of a massage establishment or business, or the practice of massage without first having obtained a massage technician's license from the city pursuant to this chapter. 
B.  The Board of Massage Examiners shall grant reciprocity to applicants who have not obtained a license by the city to practice massage therapy, provided the applicant seeking licensure holds a current and valid license issued by a jurisdiction that has entered into a reciprocal agreement with the city. 
C.  The city may enter into an agreement with the duly authorized representatives of other jurisdictions, whose licensing and regulatory ordinances contain the same or substantially similar terms, conditions, privileges, responsibilities and mutual reciprocities as provided herein and applicable to massage technicians. Any such agreement shall be made in writing and filed with the city clerk's office. 
D.  Any person issued a massage technician's license pursuant to a reciprocal agreement shall be subject to all other provisions under this chapter required to certify and maintain the applicant's good standing and fitness to engage in the practice of massage, except a person granted licensure pursuant to a reciprocal agreement shall be exempt from any written or practical examination otherwise required. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2107, Amended, 06/25/2001) 
Section 5.65.160 - Certificate-Application. 
A.  Any person who desires to engage in the practice of massage shall file a verified application with the license division upon a form provided by the department. The application for a massage technician certificate shall contain but not be limited to the following: 
1.  Name and residence, addresses of the applicant for the seven years to the date of the application, and all names, nicknames and aliases by which the applicant has been known; 
2.  Driver's license number, if any, and date of birth; 
3.  Applicant's weight, height, sex, color hair and eyes; 
4.  Proof that the applicant is at least eighteen years of age; 
5.  Business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the last seven years immediately preceding the date of application; 
6.  Whether such person has ever been convicted of any crime, except misdemeanor traffic violations; if any person mentioned in this subsection has been so convicted, a statement must be made giving the place and court in which such conviction was had, the specific charge under which the conviction was had, the specific charge under which the conviction was obtained, and the sentence imposed as a result of such conviction; 
7.  An agreement that the city shall have the right to take fingerprints and a photograph of the applicant and the right to confirm the information submitted. 
B.  The holder of a massage technician certificate shall notify the license division of each change in any data required to be furnished by this section within the ten days after such change occurs. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.170 - Certificate-Investigation. 
    Applicants for a massage technician certificate shall pay an investigation fee in the amount set forth in Section 5.65.180 which shall not be refundable. If the license division determines that the application form has been properly and completely filled out, the applicant shall be investigated by the police department. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.180 - Fees. 
    The following fees shall be charged: 
A.  Background investigation: twenty-five dollars. 
B.  Written examination: twenty-five dollars. 
C.  Practical examination: thirty dollars every time the practical examination is taken. 
(Ord. 1650 § 4, 1989: Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2117, Amended, 12/10/2001) 
Section 5.65.190 - Board of massage examiners. 
A.  Creation-Composition. There is created the board of massage examiners to be composed of five members. The members of the board shall consist of at least three massage technicians each of whom must have a minimum of two years of experience practicing massage. The members of the board shall be appointed by the city council for terms of two years each. Two members of the first board shall be appointed to one-year terms so that the board members thereafter shall serve staggered two-year terms. The board shall designate one of its members as chairperson of the board. 
B.  Voting Procedure. All members of the board of massage examiners shall have one vote. 
C.  Examinations. The board of massage examiners shall prepare examinations to test each applicant for a massage technician certificate. 
D.  Conduct and Administration. Examinations shall be conducted at a location to be selected by the board of massage examiners, and shall be administered from time to time as reasonably necessary. 
E.  Meetings. The board shall schedule such meetings during the year as it may determine to be necessary, one of which shall be an annual meeting. The chairperson shall have the authority to call other meetings at his or her discretion. A quorum of the board shall consist of not less than three members. 
F.  Regulations. The board shall promulgate such regulations as are necessary to implement this chapter. 
G.  Compensation. Except as provided herein, the board shall serve without compensation. The two members of the board who observe and grade a practical examination shall each receive one-half of the fee charged for said examination. 
(Ord. 1650 § 5, 1989: Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.200 - Accountability of board members. 
    Each board member shall be held accountable to the city council for the proper performance of all duties and obligations of such board member's office. The city council shall cause to be investigated any complaints or unfavorable reports received concerning the actions of the board or its individual members and shall take appropriate action thereon, which may include removal of any board member for malfeasance, misfeasance, neglect of duty, commission of a felony, incompetency, or permanent inability to perform official duties. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.210 - Qualifications for certificate. 
    An applicant for a massage technician certificate and holders of massage technician certificate must meet the qualifications set forth in Section 5.65.070. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.220 - Examinations. 
A.  The board shall specify by regulation the general areas of competency to be covered by examinations for certification. These rules shall include the relative weight assigned in grading each area, the grading criteria to be used by the examiners, and the score necessary to achieve a passing grade. The board shall ensure that examinations adequately measure both an applicant's competency and his knowledge of related legal requirements. Professional testing services may be utilized to formulate the examinations. 
B.  The board shall ensure that examinations comply with state and federal equal employment opportunities guidelines. 
C.  The city shall, in accordance with regulations established by the board, administer written examinations to applicants for certification under this chapter. The practical examination shall test the applicant's knowledge of hygiene, the theory of massage and ability in the practice of massage. The practical examination shall be administered by at least two members of the board who are massage technicians or state licensed medical professionals. 
D.  Written and practical examinations shall be offered at such times as the board shall deem necessary, but written examinations shall not be offered more often than once per month. 
E.  The board shall adopt regulations providing for re-examinations of applicants who have failed the examination. 
F.  An accurate record of each examination shall be made; and that record, together with all examination papers, shall be filed with the employee services and analysis division and shall be kept for reference and inspection for a period of not less than two years immediately following the examination. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.230 - Approval or denial. 
    The board shall issue a certificate for a massage technician if all applicable application forms have been completed and the applicant meets the qualifications for a certificate hereunder unless: 
A.  The applicant fails to receive a passing grade on the written or practical massage examination. 
B.  The applicant has furnished false information on any application form for a license. 
C.  The applicant's certificate, license or right to practice massage has been revoked by a governmental entity within the preceding five years. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.240 - Display of certificate. 
    Every person issued a massage technician certificate shall display said certificate in a conspicuous place within the massage establishment or shall keep the same at the office of an outcall business. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.250 - Revocation or suspension of certificate. 
    The board of massage examiners may suspend or revoke a massage technician certificate upon the following grounds: 
A.  Attempting to procure a certificate to practice massage by bribery or fraudulent misrepresentation; 
B.  Having a certificate to practice massage revoked, suspended, or otherwise acted against by the licensing authority of another state or local government; 
C.  Failing to meet the qualifications for massage technicians set forth in Section 5.65.070; 
D.  Aiding, assisting, procuring or advertising any noncertified person to practice massage contrary to the provisions of this chapter; 
E.  Making deceptive, untrue, or fraudulent representations in the practice of massage; 
F.  Being unable to practice massage with reasonable skill and safety by reason of illness or use of alcohol, drugs, narcotics, chemicals or any other type of material or as a result of any mental or physical condition. In enforcing this paragraph, the board shall have, upon probable cause, authority to compel a massage technician to submit to a mental or physical examination by physicians designated by the board. Failure of a massage technician to submit to such examination when so directed shall constitute an admission of the allegations against him, unless the failure was due to circumstances beyond his control consequent upon which a default and final order may be entered without the taking of testimony or presentation of evidence. A massage technician affected under this paragraph shall, at reasonable intervals, be afforded an opportunity to demonstrate that he can resume the competent practice of massage with reasonable skill and safety to clients; 
G.  Gross or repeated malpractice or the failure 
H.  Violating any provision of this chapter or any regulation adopted by the board of massage examiners. 
(Ord. 1629 § 1, 1988: Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 5.65.260 - Disciplinary hearings. 
    The following procedure shall apply in actions to suspend or revoke the certificate of a massage technician: 
A.  Notice of intent to discipline shall be served on the technician or mailed to the technician at his last known address. The notice shall specify the grounds for discipline and shall announce the time and place of a hearing before the board on a day not less then ten nor more than thirty days after the date of service or mailing. Said notice shall be sent only upon a majority vote of a quorum of the board. 
B.  The board may appoint a hearing office to conduct or assist in conducting the hearing. The board may delegate to the hearing office such authority as the board deems appropriate. 
C.  Technical rules of evidence do not apply at the hearing. 
D.  The board or hearing office may, upon application of any party to a hearing, issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of witnesses. If a witness refuses to obey a subpoena, the board may file a petition with the district court asking for an order compelling the witness to attend and testify before the board. Witnesses appearing pursuant to a subpoena are entitled to receive fees and mileage as prescribed in NRS 50.225. 
E.  All testimony at a hearing must be recorded or reported by a certified shorthand reporter. The cost of a transcript ordered by the board or a hearing officer must be paid by the city. 
F.  Unless the parties stipulate otherwise, the board or hearing officer shall render a decision in writing, setting forth the reasons therefor, within thirty days after the hearing. 
G.  Any petition for judicial review of the decision of the board or hearing officer must be filed within thirty days after service of the decision. 
(Ord. 1623 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Chapter 5.66 - ESCORT SERVICES 

Section 5.66.010 - Policy declaration. 
    Escort services, because of reputation and past experience in the city and other communities, are recognized as having objectionable characteristics when persons with criminal or immoral tendencies are permitted to own or work in such businesses. Specific reference is made to Chapter 8.32 of the Clark County Code wherein the Clark County Liquor and Gaming Licensing Board found as a result of the persistent illegal activities practiced by escort bureaus and employees in Clark County that the operation of businesses providing escorts was detrimental to the health and safety of the public community and tourist that such businesses were offensive to the public morals and decency, that such businesses were detrimental to the continued economic development of the community and tended to degrade the community as a provider of good entertainment and that such businesses were harmful to the cause of attracting tourists, visitors and conventions to the community. To insure that such businesses are free from criminal and corruptive elements and practices, it is necessary to regulate all persons involved in the operation of such businesses. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.66.020 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context otherwise requires, the following words shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section: 
A.  "Director" means the director of the finance department of the city. 
B.  "Escort" means a person who for monetary consideration in the form of a fee, commission, salary or tip, dates, socializes, visits, consorts with or accompanies or offers to date, consort, socialize, visit or accompany, another or others to or about social affairs, entertainments or places of amusement or within any place of public resort or within any private quarters of a place of public resort. 
1.  A service oriented escort is an escort which: 
a.  Operates from an open office; and 
b.  Does not employ or use an escort runner; and 
c.  Does not advertise either directly or by implication the availability of sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to the customer or work for an escort bureau which so advertises. 
2.  A sexually oriented escort is an escort which: 
a.  Employs or uses an escort bureau runner; or 
b.  Works for, is associated with, or has contracted with a sexually oriented escort bureau; or 
c.  Advertises, either directly or by implication that sexual stimulation or sexual gratification will be provided, or works for, or is associated with, or has contracted with an escort bureau which so advertises; or 
d.  Provides sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to an escort patron. 
C.  "Escort bureau" means a person, as defined in this section, which for a fee, commission, profit, payment or other monetary consideration, furnishes or offers to furnish escorts, or provides or offers to introduce patrons to escorts. 
1.  A service oriented escort bureau is an escort bureau which: 
a.  Maintains an open office at an established place of business: and 
b.  Employs or provides only escorts which possess work identification cards; and 
c.  Does not use an escort bureau runner; and 
d.  Does not advertise either directly or by implication the availability of sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to the customer or that escorts will or may provide such services. 
2.  A sexually oriented escort bureau is an escort bureau which: 
a.  Does not maintain an open office; or 
b.  Uses an escort bureau runner or contracts with third persons for the referral of patrons; or 
c.  Advertises, either directly or by implication that sexual stimulation or sexual gratification will be provided, or that escorts which provide such sexual stimulation or sexual gratification will be provided or introduced to a patron; or 
d.  Provides sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to an escort patron; or 
e.  Employs, contracts with or provides escorts which do not possess work identification cards. 
D.  "Escort bureau runner" means any third person, not an escort, who for a salary, fee, hire, reward or profit, acts in the capacity of an agent for an escort bureau or a patron by contacting or meeting with escort patrons or escort bureaus at any location other than the established open office whether or not the person is employed by such escort bureau or by another business, or is self-employed. 
E.  "Escort patron" means any person who contracts with or employs an escort bureau or escort. 
F.  "Licensee" means a person who is the holder of a valid license under this chapter. Licensee includes an agent, servant, employee or other person acting on behalf of a licensee whenever such licensee is prohibited from doing a certain act under this chapter. 
G.  "Open office" means an office at the licensed escort bureau address from which escort business is transacted and which is open to patrons or prospective patrons during all hours during which escorts are working, which is managed by an employee, officer, director or owner of the escort bureau having authority to bind the bureau to escort and patron contracts, and adjust patron and consumer complaints. 
H.  "Person" means any individual, partnership, limited partnership, firm, corporation or association. 
I.  "Sexual gratification" means sexual conduct as defined in NRS 201.295. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.66.030 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to conduct, manage, operate or maintain an escort bureau business within the city unless licensed pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.66.040 - Unlawful to work as an escort-Exceptions. 
    It is unlawful for any person to work or perform services as an escort in the city unless employed by a licensed escort bureau or licensed as an escort bureau. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.66.050 - Work permit required-Fees. 
A.  All escorts, owners, managers, officers, directors and employees of escort bureaus are required to obtain and possess a current work permit from the police department. Work permits are governed by the provisions of Chapter 5.22 of the SMC. 
B.  A work permit shall expire unless renewed within ten days after a change of place of employment or if the holder thereof is not employed by a business regulated by this chapter for a period of ninety days or more. 
C.  A work permit may be suspended or revoked upon a finding that the permittee has committed one or more of the acts for which an escort services business license may be suspended or revoked as described in SMC 5.66.110. 
D.  In addition to the grounds for denial, suspension or revocation of a work permit contained in SMC 5.22.020 and 5.66.110, a work permit shall be denied, revoked or suspended where the applicant has owned, managed or operated an illegal or unlicensed brothel, or received payment or a portion of profits therefrom; or been convicted of conspiracy, fraud or obtaining money under false pretenses; or has worked as a sexually oriented escort or operated a sexually oriented escort bureau.
