E.  The escort bureau shall keep a current list of all escorts at the licensed business location. Said list shall contain the name and work permit number of each escort and shall be available during all business hours for inspection by licensing officials and agents of the city police department. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.66.060 - Applications, investigation and license issuance. 
    An escort bureau license is a privilege. A license shall not be issued for the operation of an escort bureau unless the applicant for such license successfully carries the burden of establishing suitability to receive the license. One license shall be issued for each escort bureau. The license fee shall be determined as provided in Section 5.12.100 of this title. 
A.  All persons desiring to obtain a business license to engage in an escort bureau business within the city shall first file an application with the finance director on a form provided by his office. 
B.  All applicants shall provide the following information under oath: 
1.  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted by any state or federal court within the past ten years of any misdemeanor or felony other than minor traffic offenses; 
2.  A list of convictions for all pandering, prostitution, soliciting, thefts, fraud, obtaining money under false pretenses, embezzlement or any criminal convictions involving the use of force or violence upon the person of another; or adverse civil action judgments involving allegations pertaining to fraudulent advertising, sales or trade practices, and a detailed explanation of the circumstances; 
3.  The address of the proposed business location with a copy of the deed, lease or other document pursuant to which applicant occupies such premises; 
4.  The person or persons who will have custody of the business records at the business location; 
5.  Agent for service of process; 
6.  Applicant's family, residential, education, military and criminal history background, covering at least a ten-year period immediately preceding the date of filing of the application; 
7.  A complete description of the exact nature of the business to be conducted, including office organization, advertising theme and method, employee qualifications and copies of contracts to be used with escorts and patrons; 
8.  Applicant's business and employment history stating whether or not the applicant, or applicant's manager, director, officer, partner or stockholders have had any business license revoked or suspended and stating the details thereof including the reasons therefor; 
9.  The names, current addresses and written statements of at least five bona fide permanent residents of the United States that the applicant is of good moral character. If the applicant is able, the statement must first be furnished from residents of Washoe County, then the state of Nevada and lastly, from the United States. 
C.  1.  If an applicant is a partnership or limited partnership, all application information listed in subsection B of this section shall be provided for all the partners, including, if applicable, limited partners, the same as if each were a sole proprietor and applicant. 
2.  If an applicant is a corporation, all application information listed in subsection B of this section shall be provided for each of the directors, officers, and shareholders holding ten percent or more of the stock of the corporation the same as if each were a sole proprietor and applicant. 
3.  If applicant is a partnership or limited partnership, it shall provide a certified copy of an agreement or articles of partnership or limited partnership and certificate. 
4.  If applicant is a corporation, the application shall be accompanied by: 
a.  A certified copy of the articles of incorporation of such corporation and, if incorporated under the laws of another state, a certificate of qualification to do business in the state; 
b.  A current annual list of officers, directors, and resident agent of such corporation; and 
c.  A list of the stockholders, the last known residence address and telephone number of each, and their respective ownership interests in such corporation certified as being true and correct by the secretary of such corporation; and 
d.  A certified copy of all minutes or resolutions by the board of directors of such corporation authorizing such license application and designating the officer to apply on such application and authorizing his verification thereof. 
5.  If such business is to be conducted under a name other than the legal name of the applicant, the application must be accompanied by a copy of the fictitious name certificate on file with the county clerk. 
6.  All officers, directors, shareholders which own, directly or constructively ten percent or more of the outstanding stock of the corporation, and the managing agent of the corporation must be investigated for determination of suitability as set forth in this chapter. 
D.  The applicant shall supplement the application by submitting a written plan setting forth the method of operation of the escort bureau, which shall include, but not be limited to: 
1.  The hours that the escort bureau will be open to the public (the hours shall include all hours any escorts are with a patron); and 
2.  The methods of promoting the health and safety of escorts and protecting them from assault, battery and rape; and 
3.  The methods of supervision of employees to prevent the escort from charging the patron any fee which is in addition to the fee paid to the escort bureau by the patron; and 
4.  The methods of supervision which will prevent the escorts from engaging in acts of prostitution; and 
5.  The Federal Employer's Identification number and Nevada Industrial Commission policy number; and 
6.  The name and the address of the certified public accountant who will certify the gross receipts upon application for renewal license; and 
7.  The applicant shall submit a statement disclosing the names of all persons who have invested in the proposed escort bureau, and who will share in or receive a percentage of the profit or return from the proposed escort bureau. 
E.  The failure to truthfully disclose any of the information required by subsections B, C and D of this section or the failure to make a full disclosure of all facts required shall be grounds for denying the license or, if subsequent to issuance of a license it is discovered that any applicant or person required to be investigated has not been completely truthful or has withheld any facts in answering the above questions, such failure shall be grounds for revoking the license. 
F.  After the filing of a completed application and payment of all fees, the applicant shall be referred to the police department of the city for fingerprinting, investigation and reporting as required in this chapter. 
G.  The result of such investigation shall be given to the director within sixty days or as soon thereafter as possible. 
H.  The director shall deny the license if: 
1.  The license application is incomplete so as to not contain all information required by this chapter; or 
2.  All license and investigation fees are not paid; or 
3.  The applicant or any of its principals has been convicted of a crime listed in subsection B (2) of this section or has been enjoined in an adjudicated civil action from engaging in fraudulent advertising or sales or trade practices; or 
4.  The applicant, based upon the content of his application, and his activities since the enactment of these regulations, intends to operate a sexually oriented escort bureau; or 
5.  The applicant or partner, stockholder, officer or director, has had an escort license previously revoked or denied for any ground set out in this chapter; or 
6.  The applicant, its partners, officers or directors, do not qualify for, or have not obtained work identification cards as required in Section 5.66.050 of this chapter. 
I.  An applicant whose license has been denied by the director pursuant to Subsections 3, 4 or 5 of subsection H of this section may appeal the director's decision to the city council according to the procedure in Section 5.16.010 of this title. The city council shall hear the appeal by examination of: 
1.  The circumstances of the crime or civil action, past business experience, and plans for operation of the proposed escort business; and 
2.  The applicant's criminal and civil court history, and business or employment history since the adjudication; or sexually oriented escort bureau operations since the enactment of these regulations; and 
3.  The written recommendations of five or more residents of the county. 
The city council may sustain the director's denial or grant the license based on the evidence presented that the applicant does not present, and is not likely to present in the future, a threat to city safety, morals and welfare, and will not operate a sexually oriented escort bureau as defined in this chapter. The city council may grant a restricted or conditional license if in its discretion the facts presented merit such license. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.66.070 - Investigation fees. 
    An investigation fee of one hundred seventy-five dollars shall accompany every application. In addition, applications with more than one person for which a separate background investigation must be conducted shall pay an investigation fee deposit of one hundred seventy-five dollars per person. The investigation of previously licensed resident escort bureau licensees may be waived by the city council; however, in any event, the previously licensed escort bureau owners shall not be required to pay in excess of the one hundred seventy-five dollar investigation fee. The director may require prepayment of additional investigative fees if the determines that the circumstances so warrant. 
    Every previously unlicensed applicant shall pay the entire cost incurred by the city to complete the investigations required by this chapter whether the application is approved or denied. Such costs are a collectible debt due to the city and must be paid in full prior to final consideration for licensing by the director. 
    If the applicant withdraws his application prior to beginning the investigation, investigative fees paid shall be refunded to the applicant. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.66.080 - License renewal. 
    The escort bureau license terminates at the end of each annual period and for renewal thereof the licensee must reapply by filing with the director an update of the original application to reflect any changes therein since the last licensing period. The director shall determine if there has been any material changes in applicant's compliance with the conditions of Section 5.66.060 of this chapter prior to renewing the license and shall deny such renewal if the licensee is in violation of any of the conditions of this code or would not be suitable for licensing upon an original application for a license. The licensee may appeal a denial pursuant to Section 5.16.010 of this title. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.66.090 - Escort bureau duties. 
A.  The escort service shall provide to each patron a written contract and receipt of payment for services. The contract shall clearly state the type of services to be performed, the length of time such services shall be performed, the total amount of money such services shall cost the patron, and any special terms or conditions relating to the services to be performed. 
B.  The escort bureau shall maintain an open office at the licensed location during all hours escorts are working. The address of that office shall be included in all patron contracts and published advertisements. Private room or booths where the patron may meet with the escort shall not be provided at the open office or at any other location by the escort bureau. Violation of this provision shall be grounds for license revocation. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.66.100 - Advertising-Implying services other than service oriented escorts. 
A.  Any publication, dissemination, display, whether by hire, contract or otherwise, by any escort, escort bureau, or owner, manager or employee of an escort bureau within the scope of this chapter directly or indirectly in any newspaper, magazine, or other publication, by any radio, television, telephone or pictorial display, publication or other advertising media which contains any statement which is known or through the exercise of reasonable care would suggest to a reasonable, prudent person that any service other than that of service oriented escorts is provided by the escort bureau is prohibited. 
B.  Any word, phrase or combination of words used in any advertisement which implies a service other than that of service oriented escorts, or which gives the public a basis to believe that sexual stimulation or sexual gratification, or any form of sex service is provided is prohibited within the intent of this section. The following terms and words may, depending upon the context used, be deemed by the licensing board to convey that sexual stimulation or sexual gratification is offered: 
"The Utmost in discretion", "All our escorts have health certificates", "All our models have health certificates", "Bodies beautiful and girls galore", "Call us and make your point", "Call us we come to you", "Climax", "Models", "Couples and swingers", "Desires", "Direct to your room," "Do you want a swinger", "Dominance," "Double delight", "Erotic encounters", "Erotic", "Exciter", "Fantasies", "Fetishes", "For adults only", "Fox hunting", "Fulfill", "Girls to go", "Hard core", "Hot", "It's legal in Nevada", "Love", "Maid", "maids" or "maid service", "Make your point", "Massages", "Models, girls, or escorts in the privacy of your hotel or motel room", "Models, girls, or escorts to act out your fantasies", "No need to leave your hotel room", "No need to leave your hotel", "Nude models", "Open 24 hours for your desires," "Open 24 hours for your pleasure", "Outcall", "Rooms provided", "Satisfy", "Seductive", "Sensuous", "Sexy", "Showers", "Showgirls", "models", "actresses", "Showguys", "So good", "Someone to enjoy", "Special services", "Spend some time with me", "Spice or spicy", "Submit to pleasure", "Swingers and couples", "Swinging", "Tantalizing", "The pleasure is yours", "Two for one", "Warm", "We come direct to you", "We deliver", "We deliver the goods", "We go out", "We have a model, escort or girl for your every need", "We respond immediately", "You always win", "You won't be disappointed". 
C.  It is unlawful to advertise or hold out to the public the availability of an escort or escort bureau without obtaining a license therefor as provided in this chapter, whether the actual business of escorts or escort bureau as defined in this chapter is performed or not. 
D.  Any photograph, picture, drawing, sketch, pictorial representation, verbal or written description, used in any escort or escort bureau advertisement, in any of the advertising media showing or depicting an escort, or representation of an escort in an unclothed state, or attired in clothing which shows the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a full opaque covering, or the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any portion thereof below the top of the nipple, or the depiction of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, is prohibited and shall be presumed to be advertising the availability of sexual stimulation or sexual gratification. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.66.110 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license may be suspended or revoked after notice and hearing as provided in SMC 5.16.020 upon a finding that the licensee has committed one or more following acts: 
A.  Committed or been convicted in any court subsequent to the filing of the application for a license of a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude, fraud, deception, false pretenses, misrepresentations, or concealed material facts in an application for a business license; 
B.  Made intentional misrepresentations, or concealed material facts in an application for a business license; 
C.  Been convicted of, committed, or been enjoined in a civil action of any of the offenses provided in SMC 5.66.060 B(2); 
D.  Used or employed escort bureau runners; 
E.  If a partnership, limited partnership or corporation, failed to remove any partner, officer, director or stockholder convicted of any offense as described in SMC 5.66.060 B(2) immediately upon learning of the conviction; 
F.  Failed to keep accounting records capable of audit and certification of gross receipts by a certified public accountant, or refused to provide access to such for audit by business license investigators; 
G.  Failed to update its license application as required in this chapter; 
H.  Failed to pay any license fees due under this chapter; 
I.  Failed to maintain an open office at all hours escorts are working; 
J.  Advertised that services other than service oriented escorts are available; 
K.  Published advertisements which contain phone numbers of the escort service or escort bureau without giving the address of that business; 
L.  Advertised, either directly or by implication, that sexual stimulation or sexual gratification is available; 
M.  Continued to employ or use an escort who has been convicted of prostitution after notification by the police department or licensing officials; such notice shall be sent by mail to the licensee at its principal place of business and to the officer manager thereof (if any) of record at his/her home address; 
N.  Operated the escort service in a fraudulent or dishonest manner as defined in NRS 207.170 through 207.171 inclusive; 
O.  Conducted or advertised business under an unlicensed fictitious name; 
P.  Maintained the business in a structure or building which is structurally unsafe, or not provided with adequate egress, or which constitutes a fire hazard, or which is otherwise dangerous to human life or safety, or which in relation to existing use constitutes a hazard to safety or health, or public welfare; 
Q.  Maintained the business in a manner detrimental to the peace or morals of the community; or 
R.  Otherwise violated any provision of this chapter. 
If the city manager or his designee finds that after notice and hearing the licensee is guilty of a violation which is grounds for revocation, he may suspend the license, suspend the license but allow continued operation upon compliance with specific conditions or revoke the license. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) (Ord. 2471, § 46, Amended, 2/11/2013) 
Section 5.66.120 - Exemptions. 
    All professions, employments, and businesses which are licensed by the state or city pursuant to a specific statute or ordinance, and all employees employed by a business so licensed, and which perform an escort or escort bureau function as a service merely incidental to the primary function of such profession, employment or business and which do not hold themselves out to the public as an escort or escort bureau, are exempt from licensing pursuant to this chapter. Any employment agency, licensed by the state, which provides escorts as defined in this chapter, must, however, obtain a license as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.66.130 - Bond. 
    Every licensee under this chapter shall post a bond in the sum of five thousand dollars payable to the city and approved by the city attorney's office. No licensee shall in any manner advertise its service as licensed and bonded by the city. 
(Ord. 1478 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Chapter 5.68 - CARNIVALS AND CIRCUSES 

Section 5.68.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise the words and terms defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section. 
A.  "Carnival" includes any traveling business providing commercial entertainment consisting of side shows, concessions, rides, games of chance and other amusements. 
B.  "Circus" includes any traveling business providing commercial performances by acrobats, trained animals, clowns, jugglers and others within a tent or arena. 
(Ord. 1333 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.68.020 - License required-Fee. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct or carry on, in or upon any premises in the city, the operation of a circus or carnival without first having obtained a business license from the city. 
B.  Every applicant for a license required by this chapter shall file an application with the license officer of the city, and shall pay the license fee prescribed by Section 5.12.100 of this title. 
C.  A business license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid only during the period of time the carnival or circus is operating within the city, not to exceed thirty days. 
(Ord. 1333 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.68.030 - Work permit required. 
    Any person who desires to work as an employee at a carnival or circus in the city must apply for and receive a police work permit from the chief of police before engaging in such employment. Application for the work permit may be made to the chief of police in compliance with Chapter 5.22 of the SMC. An applicant must qualify for a work permit under SMC 5.22.010. If the applicant is a minor under the age of fourteen years, the application must be accompanied by the fee and written permission for such employment signed by a juvenile master, referee or probation officer authorized to grant such permission by a judge of the District Court. 
(Ord. 1333 § 1 (part), 1981.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.68.040 - Application process. 
A.  Upon receipt of the completed application and, when required, written permission to work as a carnival or circus employee, the chief of police shall process the application in the manner provided in Chapter 5.22 of the SMC. 
(Ord. 1333 § 1 (part), 1981.) (Ord. 2190, Amended, 10/13/2003) 
Section 5.68.060 - Term of work permit. 
    A work permit issued by the chief of police entitles the person to whom it is issued to work as an employee at a carnival or circus for the period of time that the carnival or circus is in operation in the city, or for a period of thirty days, whichever period of time is the shorter. At the end of that period of time, the permit expires and a new application must be submitted. 
(Ord. 1333 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.68.070 - Employment of persons without work permit prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to employ any other person at a carnival or circus unless the employee possesses a valid work permit issued by the chief of police. 
(Ord. 1333 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.68.080 - Performing work without work permit prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to work at a carnival or circus without a valid work permit issued by the chief of police. 
(Ord. 1333 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.68.090 - Information to be furnished to chief of police by owners or operators of carnivals or circuses. 
    In addition to information required to be furnished to the chief of police by employees at a carnival or circus, the owner or operator of the carnival or circus must submit to the chief of police a schedule of the locations where, and dates on which, the carnival or circus has appeared during the preceding six month period and will be appearing during the next six months following its performance in the city. That information and information furnished by the carnival or circus employees shall be maintained in a confidential manner by the chief of police for use when needed in any judicial proceeding, or when the chief of police deems it necessary to communicate with the owner or operator of the carnival or circus when that person is outside the boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. 1333 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.68.110 - Fraudulent concessions. 
    It is unlawful for any person who owns or operates any game or concession open to the public and operated for a profit to fraudulently obtain money, or tokens purchased with money, from another by means of any hidden mechanical device, obstruction, or other fraudulent means, with intent to diminish the chance of any patron to win a prize. 
(Ord. 1333 § 1 (part), 1981.) 
Section 5.68.120 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.20. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 2471, § 47, Add, 2/11/2013) 
Chapter 5.70 - CHILD CARE FACILITIES 

Section 5.70.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise: 
    "Child care facility" shall have the meaning ascribed to said term in Chapter 432A of NRS. 
(Ord. 1869, 1995: Ord. 1483 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.70.020 - Child care facility-License required. 
    No person may engage in or conduct the business of a child care facility for seven or more children without first obtaining a business license under the terms and conditions of this title applicable to general businesses. 
(Ord. 1869, 1995: Ord. 1483 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.70.030 - License fees. 
    Child care facilities required to be licensed by this chapter must pay the annual license fee established for general businesses in Chapter 5.12 of this code. 
(Ord. 1869, 1995: Ord. 1483 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Section 5.70.040 - Licensing agency designated. 
    The Washoe County Department of Social Services is designated as the child care licensing agency of the city pursuant to Chapters 277 and 432A of NRS. 
(Ord. 1869, 1995: Ord. 1483 § 1 (part), 1985.) 
Chapter 5.72 - PRIVATE VIEWING BOOTHS 

Section 5.72.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to regulate commercial establishments which offer private viewing of movies, tapes, slides, pictures or live performances of any kind. This chapter is intended to control the transmission of communicable disease and to discourage the unsanitary practice of sexual acts in viewing booths. For purposes of this chapter a viewing booth is one designed for or generally used by five (5) or fewer persons at any one time. 
(Ord. 1792, 1993.) 
Section 5.72.020 - Booth access. 
    Each booth shall be totally accessible to and from aisles and public areas of the establishment. Access to a booth shall be unobstructed by doors, locks or other controlling devices. 
(Ord. 1792, 1993.) 
Section 5.72.030 - Booth construction. 
    Any booth used to view a movie, tape, slide, picture or live performance of any kind must be so constructed as to discourage sexual activity and the spread of communicable disease by including, but not being limited to the following requirements: 
A.  Every booth shall be separated from adjacent booths and any nonpublic areas by a wall. 
B.  Every booth shall have at least one side totally open to a public, lighted aisle so that there is an unobstructed view at all times of anyone occupying the booth. 
C.  All walls shall: 
1.  Be solid, without any openings; 
2.  Extend from the floor to a height of not less than six (6) feet; 
3.  Be light colored, nonabsorbent, smooth-textured and easily cleanable. 
D.  The floor must be light colored, nonabsorbent, smooth textured and easily cleanable. 
E.  The lighting level of each booth when not in use shall be a minimum of ten (10) foot candles at all times. 
(Ord. 1792, 1993.) 
Section 5.72.040 - Booth occupants/occupancy. 
A.  Only one individual shall occupy a booth at any time. 
B.  No individual occupying a booth shall, at any time, engage in any type of sexual activity or cause any bodily discharge or litter associated with sexual activity while in the booth. 
C.  No individual shall damage or deface any portion of the booth. 
D.  No alcoholic beverages may be possessed or consumed in the booth. 
(Ord. 1792, 1993.) (Ord. 2099, Amended, 04/23/2001) 
Section 5.72.050 - Operator responsibility. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner, operator, licensee and employees of the establishment to: 
A.  Maintain the premises in a clean and sanitary manner at all times. 
B.  Maintain at least ten (10) foot candles of light in the public portion of the establishment, including aisles, at all times. 
C.  Ensure compliance of the establishment and its patrons with the provisions of this section. 
D.  Post the regulations concerning booth occupancy on signs, with lettering at least one (1) inch high, that are placed in conspicuous areas of the establishment and in each of the viewing booths. 
(Ord. 1792, 1993.) 
Section 5.72.060 - Enforcement. 
A.  Both the health department and the police department may inspect the premises during operating hours and may enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  A license issued pursuant to this title which allows private viewing booths is subject to suspension, revocation or non-renewal for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of such a license and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
C.  Violation of any provision of this chapter constitutes a public nuisance. 
(Ord. 1792, 1993.) (Ord. 2471, § 48, Amended, 2/11/2013) 
Chapter 5.75 - TEENAGE DANCES, TEENAGE DANCE HALLS AND TEENAGE NIGHTCLUBS 

Section 5.75.010 - Findings of fact. 
    The City Council finds that the businesses conducting teenage dances and operating teenage dance halls and teenage nightclubs seriously affect the social and moral well being of the City and its residents, and that the establishments at which such businesses are conducted or operated must be strictly regulated for the welfare of the public and of the patrons of such establishments. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms that are defined in Subsections A through H of this Section shall have the meanings that are ascribed to them in those sections. 
A.  "Church" means a religious society that is incorporated, organized or established in the State of Nevada and has a common belief, members of which meet together to worship under the direction of an ordained or licensed minister, priest, bishop or rabbi. 
B.  "Licensee" means any individual to whom a license has been issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
C.  "Responsible person" means any person who is required by SMC Section 5.75.030(B) to be approved for suitability to be the on-premises supervisor of the location. 
D.  "Teenager" or "teenage person" means a minor person who is between the ages of thirteen years and nineteen years. 
E.  "Teenage dance" means any public dance to which primarily teenagers are invited, whether admission thereto is by a set admission charge, by the donation of money or is at no charge. 
F.  "Teenage dance hall" means place in which dances that are attended primarily be teenage persons are regularly held or conducted, whether admission thereto is by a set admission charge, by the donation of money or is at no charge. 
G.  "Teenage entertainment location" or "location" means any place at which a teenage dance is conducted or a teenage dance hall or a teenage nightclub is operated and for which a license is required by SMC Section 5.75.030(A) and includes without limitation any parking area that is required by SMC Section 5.75.120. 
H.  "Teenage nightclub" means any establishment in which primarily teenage persons regularly gather, either to participate in dancing or to observe live entertainment, whether admission is by a set admission charge, by the donation of money or is at no charge. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.030 - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person within the city to: 
A.  Commence, carry on or engage in the business of holding or conducting teenage dances operating a teenage dance hall or a teenage nightclub without first having procured a license so to do in accordance with this Chapter; or 
B.  Act as the responsible person for any teenage entertainment location without first having been approved for suitability so to do in accordance with SMC 5.75.050. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.040 - License-Application. 
    The application for the license that is required by SMC Section 5.75.030(A) shall be made on forms that are suitable to the chief of police and filed with the police department. The application shall set forth the following information: 
A.  The name and address of the applicant; 
B.  The date and time when the dance will be conducted, if the application is for an individual dance; 
C.  A description of the location to be licensed, including without limitation the dimensions of the interior of the location, the dimensions of the dance floor, the seating arrangements, the location of the dance floor within the location and the dimensions of the parking area; 
D.  The provisions that have been made by the applicant for security and the names and addresses of the persons who will supervise the license location; 
E.  The manner in which admission will be permitted, and, if admission will be by a set admission charge or the donation of money, the amount of the charge or the donation that will be required; and 
F.  Such other information as the chief of police may reasonably require with respect to the security and conduct of the dance, dance hall or nightclub. 
G.  The application must be submitted at least thirty days in advance of the dance or opening of the location. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.050 - License-Application for responsible person. 
    An application for suitability that is required by SMC Section 5.75.030(B) shall be made on forms that are suitable to the chief of police and filed with the police department. The application shall set forth the following information: 
A.  The name and address of the applicant; 
B.  Such other information as the chief of police may reasonably require. 
C.  After the investigation of an applicant, the chief of police shall determine if the applicant shall be granted a permit to be a responsible person. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.060 - Appeal to the city council. 
    An applicant for suitability aggrieved by the decision of the chief of police may, within ten days after notification of the decision, file a written request with the city clerk for a hearing before the city council. Failure to make timely applications for hearing before the city council shall constitute a waiver by the applicant of his right to appeal. The city council will only determine whether the appellant is qualified in accordance with Section 5.75.080. The city council will not waive a qualification listed in Section 5.75.080. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.070 - Filing and fee provisions. 
    The initial license fee shall be eighty dollars, payable in advance. Thereafter, each licensee shall report his gross receipts and pay the license fees as required by Section 5.12.100 of this code. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, regulations applicable to general businesses in the city shall apply to businesses regulated by this chapter. 
    Each licensee and responsible person required to submit to a background investigation must pay a nonrefundable fee in advance in the same amount established for the investigation of applicants for alcoholic beverage work permits. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.080 - Persons unqualified to hold a license or to be a responsible person. 
    The following persons are not qualified to hold a license or to be a responsible person under the provisions of this chapter: 
A.  A person who has been convicted, released from jail, prison, probation, or parole within the preceding five years on any of the following charges: 
1.  A felony or of any crime which under the laws of this state would be a felony, 
2.  Any crime of which fraud or intent to defraud was an element, whether in this state or elsewhere, 
3.  Larceny in any degree, 
4.  Buying or receiving stolen property, 
5.  Unlawful entry of a building, 
6.  Unlawful possession or distribution of a controlled substance, 
7.  Unlawful use, carrying or possession of a pistol or other dangerous weapon; 
8.  Any crime against a minor including contributing to the delinquency of a minor. 
B.  A person under the age of twenty-one years; 
C.  A person who has a notorious or unsavory reputation which would adversely affect public confidence and trust that licensed teenage entertainment locations are free from criminal or corruptive elements. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.090 - License-Investigation and consideration. 
    After the investigation of an applicant for a business license has been completed by the Sparks police department, it shall be submitted to the city clerk, who shall complete the processing of the application and place it before the city council for its action thereon. The applicant shall appear in person at the meeting of the city council at which his application is scheduled to be considered and shall be required to answer any and all questions that pertain to such application or to the fitness of any person who is connected as an owner, officer, responsible person or manager of the proposed teenage entertainment location that any member of the city council deems is necessary or appropriate. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.100 - Maximum occupancy and interior requirements. 
    The maximum occupancy of each teenage entertainment location shall be determined by the Sparks Fire Department. The occupancy load for each location must be posted above each door through which patrons may be admitted to the location. It shall be unlawful to admit persons in excess of the posted occupancy load. The business shall maintain an accurate count of the persons present and submit said count on request to any member of the Fire or Police Departments. Seating shall be provided in an area which adjoins the dance floor and must accommodate at least one-fourth of the maximum occupancy. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.110 - Interior lighting. 
    At all times during which a teenage entertainment location is open for business, the interior lighting therein shall be sufficient to make the appearance and conduct of all patrons and other persons who are in the portion of the location in which dancing is conducted or in which entertainment is offered easily discernible immediately upon entering the main entrance to the location. In no event, whenever patrons or other persons are sitting or standing within the location, shall the interior lighting be of less intensity than one foot-candle, when the same is measured at a height of thirty inches above the floor. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.120 - Parking. 
    Each teenage establishment location shall provide and maintain parking spaces in the number that is determined by the planning director to be sufficient for that location in accordance with SMC Chapter 20.49. The parking area shall be surfaced with a concrete or asphaltic paving and shall be electrically illuminated with a light that provides, at ground level, an intensity of not less than .25 foot-candle power. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.130 - Supervision and security. 
A.  During all hours that a teenage entertainment location is open to the public, at least one licensee or one responsible person shall be present to supervise the business. 
B.  Each teenage entertainment location shall provide, for each function thereat at least one uniformed security guard, who is licensed pursuant to SMC Chapter 5.44, for each one hundred, or portion thereof, persons who are anticipated to attend such function. Such security guards shall patrol and maintain order in and about the location and shall supervise the clean up of the trash and litter in the parking lot area that is required by SMC Section 5.75.120. 
C.  In no event shall a teenage entertainment location be open for business without having at least one such guard inside the location and at least one such guard in the parking area that is required by SMC Section 5.75.120. This requirement shall not prevent security guards from temporarily assisting security guards elsewhere in or about the location, if the circumstances require such assistance. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.140 - Entrance restrictions. 
    No entrance through which patrons may be admitted to a teenage entertainment location shall be permitted within a distance of five hundred feet from the closest customer entrance to any establishment that is described in SMC Chapter 20.51 or from the closest customer entrance to any tavern or other establishment in which any beer, wine or other alcoholic beverage is served, sold or given away, and no teenage entertainment location shall be permitted within a structure or building that has a roof in common with any of such establishments. At the request of the applicant for a license pursuant to this chapter, the city council, in its discretion, may waive the separation between the proposed teenage entertainment location and an establishment which dispenses alcoholic beverages that is required by this section, based upon a consideration of the nature and the character of the businesses within the surrounding neighborhood. Notice of the time and place of the city council's consideration of the request for such a waiver shall be published at least once in at least one newspaper of general circulation within the city not less than five days nor more than ten days prior to the date of such consideration. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.150 - Age restrictions. 
    No teenage entertainment location shall admit any person who is under the age of thirteen years unless such person is accompanied by at least one of his or her parents or his or her legal guardian. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.160 - Live entertainment. 
    If a teenage entertainment location provides, at any function thereat,live music through musicians who personally appear and perform at that location, the responsible party shall provide the chief of police with at least five days' advance written notice thereof, which notice shall include the date of, and the hours during which such function is to be held, the name and size of each group that will perform at such function and a description of the type of music and other entertainment that will be presented by each group. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.170 - Unlawful acts designated. 
    It is unlawful for the responsible person, or any licensee, manager, or employee of any teenage entertainment location to allow or permit any person: 
A.  Who is under the age of eighteen years to remain at that location in violation of SMC Section 9.60.010; or 
B.  To be in possession of any alcoholic beverage or controlled substance at that location, including without limitation the parking area that is required by SMC Section 5.75.120. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.180 - Exceptions to chapter provisions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to activities that are sponsored by a governmental entity or a school or to activities that are conducted upon the property of any church under the active supervision of officials or members of the congregation of that church. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.190 - License-Nontransferable. 
A.  Licenses shall not be transferred to any person for any reason. 
B.  No license, or operation thereunder, shall be transferred to a new location by the holder thereof, or his agent, unless such transfer as to location is first approved by application. 
C.  No license shall be issued to any person other than the actual proprietor of the business and place of business for which it is issued. 
D.  Upon sale, transfer or relocation of a business regulated by this chapter, the license therefor shall be null and void; provided, however, that upon the death or incapacity of the licensee or any co-licensee, any administrator, executor, or conservator of the licensee's estate may continue the business for a reasonable period of time not to exceed sixty days to allow for an orderly transfer of the license. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Section 5.75.200 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) (Ord. 2471, § 49, Amended, 2/11/2013) 
Section 5.75.210 - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided for in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(Ord. 1720, 1992.) 
Chapter 5.77 - SIDEWALK CAFES 

Section 5.77.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the regulations and standards in this chapter is to allow increased business and pedestrian traffic by providing safe and visually appealing opportunities for outdoor services at the discretion of the Sparks City Manager or his or her designee. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) (Ord. 2231, Amended, 07/12/2004) 
Section 5.77.020 - Definitions. 
    "Outdoor services" means the use of sidewalks and public rights-of-way for the consumption of food and/or beverages. 
    "Restaurant" means a business licensed to serve food and/or beverages for on-premises consumption and/or which uses a kitchen on the premises for food preparation with a minimum floor area of 200 square feet. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) (Ord. 2231, Amended, 07/12/2004) 
Section 5.77.030 - Outdoor services permit/encroachment permit required. 
    Outdoor services are not allowed without an outdoor services permit and an encroachment permit as set forth in Section 5.77.100. This chapter does not apply to outdoor services authorized by a special event permit issued pursuant to Chapter 9.34 of this code. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) (Ord. 2231, Amended, 07/12/2004) 
Section 5.77.040 - Outdoor services in public rights-of-way permitted. 
    Outdoor services are not permitted where the speed, volume or nearness of vehicular traffic is not compatible with sidewalk services. All outdoor service areas must be adjacent to and incidental to the operation of an indoor restaurant. Use of the sidewalk must be confined to the actual sidewalk and public right-of-way frontage of the indoor restaurant building. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) (Ord. 2231, Amended, 07/12/2004) 
Section 5.77.050 - Required sidewalk width. 
    Outdoor services are permitted only where the sidewalk is wide enough to adequately accommodate both the usual pedestrian traffic in the area and the operation of the proposed activity. The outdoor service area shall leave not less than six consecutive feet of sidewalk width at every point which is clear and unimpeded for pedestrian traffic. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) (Ord. 2231, Amended, 07/12/2004) 
Section 5.77.060 - Alcoholic beverage restrictions. 
    The service of alcoholic beverages shall be restricted solely to on-premise consumption by customers within the outdoor service area. Each of the following standards apply to service of alcoholic beverages: 
A.  The outdoor service area must be immediately adjacent to and abutting the indoor restaurant which provides it with food and/or beverage service; 
B.  The outdoor service area must be clearly separated from pedestrian traffic; 
C.  The operator shall post a written notice to customers that the drinking or carrying of an open container of alcoholic beverage is prohibited and unlawful outside the outdoor service area; 
D.  The outdoor service operation must maintain a valid alcoholic beverage license. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) (Ord. 2231, Amended, 07/12/2004) 
Section 5.77.070 - Health standards. 
    The operator shall not permit the following outside the building: tables preset with utensils, glasses, napkins, condiments, busing service stations, or trash and garbage storage. Outdoor food preparation is not allowed except in compliance with conditions of an outdoor services permit. All exterior surfaces within the outdoor service area shall be easily cleanable and shall be kept clean at all times by the permittee. Rest rooms sufficient for indoor and outdoor services shall be provided in the adjoining indoor restaurant. The permittee shall be responsible for maintaining the outdoor service area, including the sidewalk surface and furniture and adjacent areas in a clean and safe condition. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) (Ord. 2231, Amended, 07/12/2004) 
Section 5.77.080 - Hours of operation. 
    Outdoor cafes may only operate between seven a.m. and eleven p.m. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) 
Section 5.77.090 - Special closures. 
    Outdoor services are a privilege. The city shall have the right and power, acting through the city manager and his/her designee, to prohibit the operation of an outdoor service area at any time because of anticipated or actual problems and conflicts in the use of the sidewalk area. Such problems and conflicts may arise from, but are not limited to, scheduled festivals and similar events or parades or marches, or repairs to the street or sidewalk, or from demonstrations or emergencies occurring in the area. To the extent possible, the permittee shall be given prior written notice of any time period during which the operation of the outdoor service area will be prohibited by the city. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) (Ord. 2231, Amended, 07/12/2004) 
Section 5.77.100 - Permit issuance. 
    The city council may issue an outdoor service permit upon such terms, conditions and fees as it deems appropriate. The design and signage of the proposed outdoor service area must meet the minimum standards set by the Sparks Redevelopment Agency Design Review Committee. 
    The director of public works is authorized to issue the necessary encroachment permit. The director of public works shall condition the permit on: 
A.  Execution of a hold harmless agreement in a form acceptable to the city attorney; 
B.  Insurance meeting the requirements contained in the city's administrative policy entitled "Policy Processing Contracts/Agreements for the City of Sparks"; 
C.  Such other conditions as are necessary for public safety or to protect public improvements; 
D.  Conditions necessary to restore the appearance of the sidewalk on termination of use. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) (Ord. 2231, Amended, 07/12/2004) 
Section 5.77.110 - Permit-Suspension or revocation. 
    An outdoor service permit may be suspended or revoked by the city council following notice to the permitee and a noticed public meeting. The permit may be suspended or revoked if the city council finds that one or more conditions of the permit or of this chapter have been violated or that the outdoor service area is being operated in a manner which constitutes a nuisance, or that the operation of the sidewalk café unduly impedes or restricts the movement of pedestrians past the outdoor service area. 
(Ord. 1816, 1994.) (Ord. 2471, § 50, Amended, 2/11/2013; Ord. 2231, Amended, 07/12/2004) 
Chapter 5.78 - BOOTING 

Section 5.78.010 - Declaration of public policy. 
    It is declared to be the policy of the city council that the licensing and regulation of vehicle immobilization booting services is necessary because said services are neither licensed, regulated nor controlled by the State of Nevada. It is further declared that the booting of motor vehicles by private businesses should be regulated in order to alleviate some of the problems motorists have experienced, namely that their vehicles had been legally parked when booted, no signs had been posted indicating that their vehicles would be booted if improperly parked, that booting personnel were unresponsive and that booting charges were excessive when combined with subsequent towing charges. Since the immobilization of vehicles by booting is currently an unlicensed business activity, the city has been unable to address or prevent perceived abuses associated with the immobilization of vehicles by booting. The booting of vehicles can result in serious damage to vehicles and it is the intent of the city to protect motorists within the city from abusive booting business practices and unwarranted vehicular damage. This chapter will provide for the licensing of vehicle immobilization booting businesses, establish certain standards governing the booting of vehicles and thereby help to ensure that licensed booting companies do not wrongfully boot motor vehicles or engage in booting practices in such a manner as to endanger the public safety. The city council further finds that the licensing of vehicle immobilization booting companies will help to protect both the public and those companies from undue inconvenience and damage. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the words and terms defined in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. 
A.  "Authorized agent of owner" means an individual or person who has written authorization from the owner of private property to engage the services of a licensee to boot motor vehicles located upon that private property. 
B.  "Boot" or "booting" means the act of placing on a parked motor vehicle a locking mechanical device which is designed to be attached to the wheel or tire or other part of a motor vehicle so as to immobilize such vehicle and prevent anyone but the holder of a key or other unlocking mechanism from removing the device. 
C.  "Dispatch telephone" means a licensee's twenty-four (24) hour telephone service that is used to facilitate the dispatch of personnel responsible for removing the locking boot device from an immobilized vehicle. The dispatch telephone must not be subject to a "busy signal" and must be equipped with an answering service or device capable of documenting the date and time of each call received by the licensee. 
D.  "Individual" means a human being. 
E.  "Licensee" means any person that applied for and received a business license to engage in vehicle immobilization booting services in the City of Sparks and who, at the request of a private property owner, engages in the act of booting vehicles that are situated or remain within a private street, lot or garage without permission or without payment of a parking fee. "Licensee" includes the holder of a provisional license. 
F.  "Person" means any individual, partnership, corporation, limited liability company, association, firm or other business entity. 
G.  "Printed order form" means a printed or typewritten document setting forth the name, physical business location and business telephone number of the licensee as well as the legible handwritten name of the individual or person requesting the vehicular immobilization booting service, the name of any business or property owner that such individual represents, the date and time the service was requested, the name of the individual installing the boot, a description of the vehicle to be immobilized including the model, make, VIN, number of the license plate, state of registration, year of manufacture and a certification signed by the owner of the property, or the authorized agent of the owner, that he or she authorized the booting and was physically present when the boot was installed. 
H.  "Private street, lot or garage" means every way, structure or place in private ownership that is used for vehicular travel and/or parking by the owner and those persons having express or implied permission from the owner to use such way or place for vehicular travel or parking. 
I.  "Vehicle owner" means the registered owner, and the registered owner's authorized agent, representative, or permissive user exercising control over any vehicle that has been booted. For purposes of this section, any keyholder of the booted vehicle shall be presumed to be the vehicle owner. 
J.  "Warning decal" means a blaze orange placard, sticker or decal no smaller than forty-seven (47) inches square in size which must be securely affixed to the center of the driver's side window or to the front windshield directly in front of the steering wheel of an immobilized booted vehicle, and which must clearly and legibly state that a locking device has been installed on the vehicle, that attempting to move the vehicle will cause serious damage to the vehicle. A warning decal must display the date and time the vehicle was booted, the licensee's Sparks business license number, the name, physical business address, business telephone number, and dispatch telephone number of the licensee. A release or waiver of any kind appearing on a warning decal purporting to limit or avoid liability for damages to a vehicle that has been booted is not valid. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.030 - Licensing of businesses engaged in the immobilization of motor vehicles by booting. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to boot a motor vehicle within the city unless that person is engaged in the business of immobilization of vehicles by booting. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of immobilization of vehicles by booting within the city without possessing a provisional license pursuant to SMC 5.78.040 or a Sparks vehicular immobilization business license at the time of the booting. 
C.  For purposes of this section, a person shall be deemed to be engaged in the business of immobilization of vehicles by booting if the person boots a motor vehicle and seeks or requires monetary compensation or any other consideration for unlocking or otherwise releasing the boot from the motor vehicle. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.040 - Provisional licenses for existing booting companies; duty to apply for special booting license under Chapter 5.78. 
A.  Any person possessing a general business license issued by the City of Sparks who is engaged in the business of booting motor vehicles in the city on the effective date of this ordinance shall be deemed to possess a provisional license to engage in the business of immobilization of vehicles by booting. The provisional license shall expire on the date the person's general business license expires. 
B.  At least 30 days before the expiration of a provisional license, the person possessing such a license shall apply for a license to engage in the business of immobilization of vehicles as provided in this chapter. 
C.  A person possessing a provisional license under this section shall comply with all provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.050 - Application for license to immobilize motor vehicles by booting; contents of application. 
    Every person required to have a license under the provisions of this title shall apply for such a license to the chief license officer of the city, and upon approval and payment of the prescribed license fee, the chief license officer may issue a license containing a business license number. Approval is subject to all provisions of the SMC and receipt and verification of the following: 
A.  The name of the person to whom the license is to be issued. If the license is to be issued to a firm, association, corporation, or other business entity, the entity who shall provide the name of an individual who is personally responsible for the orderly conduct of business. 
B.  The business telephone number and physical address of the location of the business, plus the telephone number and physical address of the individual responsible for the orderly conduct of business. 
C.  A description, including the model, make, VIN, number of the license plate, state of registration and year of manufacture of each vehicle owned, leased or otherwise used by the applicant to conduct vehicle immobilization services within the city. 
D.  Proof of insurance naming the applicant as the covered person or entity responsible for property damage caused to booted vehicles. Insurance coverage shall be maintained for the duration of the licensee's business license in an amount not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
E.  The proposed date of issuance and the expiration date of the business license. 
F.  Payment of the business license fee. 
G.  A copy of the printed order form that the applicant intends to use prior to the booting of any vehicle. 
H.  A sample warning decal that the applicant intends to place upon a vehicle that has been immobilized by booting. 
I.  A current list of all private streets, lots and garages where the applicant has been authorized to perform vehicle immobilization by booting services. This list must be accompanied by a certificate signed by the owner, or the owner's authorized agent, of the private street, lot or garage which authorizes the applicant to perform immobilization by booting services upon that privately owned street, lot or garage. If the owner's agent signs a certificate, the certificate must be accompanied by a copy of the written authorization by the owner granting the agent the authority to allow a licensee to boot vehicles on the property. 
J.  Proof that the applicant is capable of accepting payment of service fees by major credit cards, including, but not limited to, VISA and Mastercharge. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.060 - Monthly list of booting locations required. 
    A licensee under this chapter shall, on or before the fifteenth day of each month, submit a revised, updated list of places where the licensee has been authorized to perform booting services. The updated list must be accompanied by current certificates and authorizations in the manner set forth in subsection I of SMC 5.78.050. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.070 - Renewal of business license. 
    Upon the first renewal and every subsequent renewal thereafter, a licensee shall, in addition to the provisions set forth in chapter 5.12 of this Code, provide the chief licensing officer with: 
A.  A legible and complete copy of every printed order form which resulted in the immobilization of a vehicle by booting within the city during the preceding year in which the licensee conducted business within the city. 
B.  A legible and complete copy of every signed receipt provided to a vehicle owner whose vehicle was booted and thereafter unlocked or otherwise released by the licensee during the preceding year in which the licensee conducted business within the city. 
C.  A legible and complete copy of a chronological log or record of the vehicles that the licensee immobilized by booting within the city during the preceding year in which the licensee conducted business within the city. The log must contain the name of the vehicle owner, a description of the vehicle, including the model, make, VIN, number of the license plate, state of registration and year of manufacture, the location where the immobilization occurred, the date and time the immobilization occurred, the date and time that the vehicle owner requested release of their vehicle and the date and time the vehicle was unlocked by the licensee. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.080 - Order form required prior to booting; log required. 
A.  A licensee must possess an original, fully completed and signed printed order form applicable to the vehicle to be booted prior to the booting of such motor vehicle. The original form for each booting must be maintained by a licensee for a period of seven (7) years after the date of booting of a motor vehicle and must be presented for inspection and copying upon demand of any peace officer or the owner of a vehicle booted by the licensee. 
B.  A licensee must maintain a chronological log or record of all vehicles that the licensee immobilized within the city. The log shall contain the information set forth in subsection C of SMC 5.78.070. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.090 - Unlawful booting of vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for any licensee to immobilize a vehicle by booting that is parked upon a private street, lot or garage: 
A.  Without first securing a written contract with an owner or authorized agent of the owner of the private property upon which an unauthorized vehicle is parked, setting forth that the owner is liable for any damage to booted vehicles as well as any civil judgment against the licensee or its employees or agents for any violation of this title pertaining to a vehicle that the owner or his agent authorized to be booted. 
B.  Without first installing and maintaining a dispatch telephone. 
C.  Without first securing a completed and signed printed order form. 
D.  Without first ensuring that a sufficient number of signs are posted which comply SMC 5.78.110. 
E.  While operating a motor vehicle which does not have a light bar containing at least two (2) flashing or strobe amber lights atop the vehicle or which does not prominently and conspicuously display on both sides of the vehicle the licensee's business name, physical address, business telephone number, dispatch telephone number and the business license number issued by the city to the licensee. 
F.  Without first providing oral notice to local law enforcement at least fifteen (15) minutes before a vehicle is booted, indicating: 
a)  The time the vehicle will be booted. 
b)  The location of the vehicle. 
c)  The description of the vehicle including the model, make, VIN, number of the license plate, state of registration and year of manufacture. 
d)  Whether the licensee or its agent or employee has any reason to believe the vehicle may be stolen. 
G.  Without operating the flashing amber lights atop the licensee's vehicle for at least fifteen (15) minutes before booting a vehicle and at all times while booting a vehicle. During such time, the licensee's vehicle must be no more than twenty (20) feet from the vehicle to be booted. 
H.  While outside of the presence of the owner or the authorized agent of the owner who has requested and authorized the licensee to boot a motor vehicle. 
I.  That is reclaimed by the vehicle owner during the fifteen (15) minutes required by subsection G of this section. 
J.  That is lawfully parked. 
K.  That is occupied by any person licensed to operate a motor vehicle. 
L.  That is parked upon the roadway side of another vehicle that is already stopped, standing or parked at the curb. 
M.  That is parked in a fire lane or a handicapped or disabled parking space as defined in SMC 10.48.240 and 20.49.010(F) or in front of or immediately adjacent to a fire hydrant, fire connection or building emergency exit, or any other area where such booting could cause a hazard to the public health, safety or welfare. 
N.  That is an ambulance, police, fire or any other emergency vehicle as that term is defined by NRS 484.787 and 484.789. 
O.  That exhibit special license plates, stickers or placards issued pursuant to NRS 482.384 (disabled persons) or NRS 482.377 (disabled veterans and ex-POWs) and are parked in accordance with NRS 484.407. 
P.  That is parked upon public property within the limits of the city. 
Q.  That is parked in the vehicular entrance to, or exit from, a theatre, hotel or school. 
R.  That has been identified by the licensee or its agent or employee, as the result of parking lot patrols, unless all provisions of subsections A to I, inclusive, of this section have been satisfied. 
S.  That has remained in a parking lot or garage less than twenty-four (24) hours after the expiration of a parking fee or charge. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.100 - Retrieval of booted vehicles. 
    Subsequent to the booting of a vehicle, a licensee or its agent or employee shall: 
A.  Immediately affix a warning decal meeting the requirements of subsection J of SMC 5.78.020. 
B.  Within thirty (30) minutes after receiving a telephonic call to a licensee's dispatch telephone or after receiving an in-person request made by the owner of a booted vehicle, unlock or otherwise release the vehicle upon the payment of the service fee prescribed in this chapter. 
C.  Before unlocking the boot, afford the vehicle owner the opportunity to inspect and inventory the vehicle to detect damage to or theft of property while the vehicle was booted. If damage or theft is detected, the licensee shall: 
a)  Resolve the complaint to the satisfaction of the claimant; or 
b)  Identify the licensee's insurance carrier and provide a written insurance claim form to the vehicle owner; and 
c)  Provide the owner of the booted vehicle a copy of the written contract between the licensee and the property owner described in SMC 5.78.090, a copy of the printed order form required by SMC 5.78.080 and, if the property owner's agent authorized the booting, a copy of the written authorization of the owner giving the agent the authority to engage a licensee to boot a vehicle. 
D.  Personally accept at the place where the vehicle was immobilized by booting, payment of the service fee by cash, certified check, money order or major credit card in accordance with the generally accepted business practices of the community. 
E.  Provide to the vehicle owner a legible, written receipt setting forth the licensee's name, the licensee's business address and business telephone number, the licensee's business license number, the name(s) of the property owner, the owner's agent and the licensee's employees, agents or representatives present during the booting and unbooting of the vehicle, the date and time the vehicle was booted, the date and time the vehicle was unlocked, the name of the individual who requested and authorized booting the vehicle, the relationship of such individual to the owner of the property, a description of the booted vehicle setting forth the model, make, VIN, number of the license plate, state of registration and year of manufacture, and all charges paid by the vehicle owner to the licensee. 
F.  Immediately unlock and release without charge, any vehicle that has been disabled or booted by the licensee to which the licensee did not respond to within thirty (30) minutes after the vehicle owner's request. 
G.  Immediately unlock and release without charge, any vehicle that has been immobilized by booting in violation of any provision of this title. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.110 - Signage. 
    No licensee may immobilize a vehicle by booting unless the private street, lot or garage has a sufficient number of signs conspicuously displayed on the property in accordance with NRS 487.038, this Code and any applicable county ordinances. The signs shall be maintained by the property owner and must contain in a clear and legible fashion, the following information and conform to the following dimensions: 
A.  The word "warning" shall be in letters not less than five (5) inches high and each part of each letter must not be less than three-fourths of an inch wide, and shall be in the color red. 
B.  Lettering of no less than three (3) inches high providing the hours during which and the circumstances under which vehicles are prohibited from parking on such property and that such vehicles are subject to immobilization by booting. 
C.  Lettering of no less than one (1) inch high providing the name, business address, business telephone number and business license number of each licensee authorized to immobilize vehicles by booting on the property, and the fees charged for booting. 
D.  Lettering of no less than one (1) inch high providing the licensee's dispatch telephone number which the motorist may call in order to facilitate the unbooting or release of their vehicle. 
E.  Lettering of no less than one (1) inch high informing the motorist that the licensee must respond to a motorist's request for the unbooting or release of their vehicle within thirty (30) minutes, otherwise no booting fees may be charged. 
F.  Be visible at night by reflective lettering or well-illuminated by direct or indirect lighting. 
G.  Be maintained, repaired or replaced at least twenty-four (24) hours before any vehicle is immobilized by booting. 
H.  In lieu of placing signs throughout the private street, lot or garage, a private property owner will be deemed in compliance with this section if signs containing the information and format required by this section are conspicuously posted and maintained by the owner of a private street, lot or garage at each entrance and exit of the private street, garage or lot intersects a public street, so long as the signs are situated in such a manner as to be readily visible and readable by the operator of a motor vehicle traveling from the public street onto or within the private street, lot or garage. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.120 - Service fees. 
    The licensee of a vehicle immobilization by booting business is entitled to collect only the following service fees for each booting: 
A.  Fifty dollars ($50.00) or seventy-five (75) of the contractual amount currently charged by towing companies for the towing of vehicles for the Sparks Police Department, whichever is greater. 
B.  A licensee of a vehicle immobilization by booting business may not charge or collect, attempt to charge or collect, a service fee if a vehicle is subsequently towed by a licensed towing company or business. 
C.  A licensee may not charge or collect, or attempt to charge or collect, any fees, costs or charges related to a booting except the service fee specified in this section. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.130 - Civil liability of owner of private property. 
    If the owner of private property or his agent authorizes a booting by signing a printed order form, the owner of the property is liable to the registered owner of the booted motor vehicle for: 
A.  Any damage or loss to the booted vehicle or its contents while it is booted, including damage resulting from attempting to drive a booted vehicle that does not have the required warning decal securely affixed thereto. 
B.  Any civil judgment incurred by the licensee or its employees or agents for any violation of this chapter pertaining to the booted vehicle. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.140 - License-Suspension or revocation. 
    A license or provisional license issued pursuant to this chapter is subject to suspension or revocation for any violation of the provisions of this chapter or for any ground for suspension or revocation set forth in SMC 5.16.020. The provisions of Chapter 5.16 of the SMC govern the suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter and any administrative or judicial appeal of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 2471, § 51, Amended, 2/11/2013; Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Section 5.78.150 - Violation-Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter may be punished as provided in Section 1.12.010 of this Code. 
(Ord. 2155, Add, 11/25/2002) 
Chapter 5.80 - LICENSING OF MARIJUANA ESTABLISHMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Retitled from "Licensing of Medical Marijuana Establishments" by Ord. 2537, adopted July 10, 2017. 

Section 5.80.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the words and terms defined in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. 
A.  "Community facility" means: 
1.  A facility licensed by Washoe County to provide day care to children. 
2.  A public park. 
3.  A playground. 
4.  A public swimming pool as defined in NRS 444.065. 
5.  A center or facility, the primary purpose of which is to provide recreational opportunities or services to children or adolescents. 
6.  A church, synagogue or other building, structure or place used for religious worship or other religious purpose. 
B.  "Cultivation facility" means a business that: 
1.  Is licensed by the State of Nevada; and 
2.  Acquires, possesses, cultivates, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies or sells marijuana and related supplies to any other marijuana establishment. 
C.  "Facility for the production of edible marijuana products or marijuana-infused products" means a business that: 
1.  Is licensed by the State of Nevada; and 
2.  Acquires, possess, manufactures, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies or sells edible marijuana projects or marijuana-infused products to any other marijuana establishment. 
D.  "Independent testing laboratory" means a facility certified by the State of Nevada to operate as an independent testing laboratory to test marijuana, edible marijuana products and marijuana-infused products that are sold in the State of Nevada pursuant to state law. 
E  "Marijuana" means: 
1.  The dried leaves and flowers of any plant of the genus Cannabis, and any mixture or preparation thereof that are appropriate for the use of marijuana; or the seeds of a plant of the genus Cannabis; or 
2.  The resin extracted from any part of the plant; or 
3.  Every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of the plant, its seeds or resin; or 
4.  "Marijuana" does not include the mature stems of the plant, fiber produced from the stems, oil or cake made from the seeds of the plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of the mature stems (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination. 
F.  "Medical marijuana" means any marijuana or marijuana-infused products acquired, possessed, cultivated, delivered, transferred, transported, supplied or sold pursuant to a license issued by the State of Nevada under the authority of Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 453A. 
G.  "Marijuana-infused products" means products that: 
1.  Are infused with marijuana or an extract thereof; and 
2.  Are intended for use or consumption by humans through means other than inhalation or oral ingestion. 
3.  The term includes, without limitation, topical products, ointments, oils and tinctures. 
H.  "Medical marijuana dispensary" means a business that: 
1.  Is licensed by the State of Nevada; and 
2.  Acquires, possesses, delivers, transfers, supplies, sells or dispenses marijuana or related supplies and educational materials to the holder of a valid registry identification card, or at retail as authorized by state law. 
I.  "Marijuana distributor" means a business that: 
1.  Is licensed by the State of Nevada; and 
2.  Transports marijuana or marijuana-infused products from one marijuana establishment to another marijuana establishment. 
J.  "Marijuana establishment" means: 
1.  An independent testing laboratory; 
2.  A cultivation facility;
