4.  The applicant demonstrates an inability or unwillingness to conduct an event pursuant to the terms and conditions of this division. 
5.  The event will require the exclusive use of a park area in a manner which will adversely impact upon the reasonable use or access to those areas by the general public; or 
6.  The applicant has failed to provide an adequate first aid or emergency medical services plan based on event risk factors. 
D.  The city manager or his designee may deny a special event permit to an applicant who has failed to comply with any terms of this division, or with any condition of a special event permit previously issued to the applicant. 
E.  An aggrieved applicant or permittee may appeal a decision or order of the city manager or his designee to the city council by filing a petition with the city clerk within ten days of issuance of such decision or order. The petition shall be scheduled for a public hearing before the city council which may affirm, modify or overrule such decision or order. Notice of hearing shall be provided to a petitioner not less than five days prior to the hearing. 
(Ord. 1742, 1992: Ord. 1618 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2439, Amended, 06/28/2010) 
Section 9.34.070 - Indemnification and insurance. 
A.  Each permit shall expressly provide that the permittee agrees to defend, protect, indemnify and hold the city, its officers, employees and agents free and harmless from and against any and all claims, damages, expenses, loss or liability of any kind or nature whatsoever arising out of or resulting from, the alleged acts or omissions of permittee, its officers, agents or employees in connection with the permitted event or activity; and the permit shall expressly provide that the permittee shall, at permittee's own cost, risk and expense, defend any and all claims or legal actions that may be commenced or filed against the city, its officers, agents or employees, and that permittee shall pay any settlement entered into and shall satisfy any judgment that may be rendered against the city, its officers, agents or employees as a result of the alleged acts or omissions of permittee or permittee's officers, agents or employees in connection with the uses, events or activities under the permit. 
B.  Concurrent with the issuance of a permit under this chapter, and as a condition precedent to the effectiveness of the permit, the permittee shall procure and maintain in full force and effect during the term of the permit a policy of insurance from a reliable insurance company authorized to do business in the state, which policy includes the city, its boards, officers, agents and employees as named insureds or additional named insureds and which provides the coverage that the city manager or his designee determines to be necessary and adequate under the circumstances, and proof of insurance shall be submitted to the city at least ten days prior to the event. Said insurance policy must provide liability coverage for the activities of vendors and entertainers participating in the special event. In the event coverage is excluded for any vendor or entertainer, proof of adequate insurance for said vendor or entertainer must be provided through additional insurance policies. 
C.  Except as provided in Section 9.34.070(D), comprehensive general liability insurance coverage shall be required in a combined single limit of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000). 
D.  If the special event is of a demonstrated high or low risk category, according to recognized insurance and risk management standards, the city manager or his designee may authorize a greater or lesser amount of coverage than required above, or may require a particular type of insurance coverage different from that specified above. 
E.  If the city manager or his designee determines that a particular use, event or activity does not present a substantial or significant public liability or property damage exposure for the city or its officers, agents and employees, the city manager or his designee may give a written waiver of the insurance requirements of this section. 
(Ord. 1860, 1995: Ord. 1742, 1992: Ord. 1618 § 1 (part), 1988.) (Ord. 2439, Amended, 06/28/2010) 
Section 9.34.072 - City manager or his designee's action on special event permit application. 
A.  Except as provided in this section, the city manager or his designee shall take final action upon a completed application for a special event permit as soon as practicable. 
B.  The city manager or his designee is not required to take final action upon any special event permit application prior to one hundred-eighty (180) calendar days before the event. 
C.  The city manager or his designee is not required to take final action on an incomplete or untimely special event permit application. 
D.  The city manager or his designee is not required to process more than one (1) application for a special event permit per applicant during any two-week period. 
E.  The city manager or his designee is not required to take final action upon two (2) or more special event permit applications submitted by the same applicant unless two (2) or more weeks shall have elapsed between the respective dates of submission of each. 
F.  Final action on a completed special event permit application shall consist of one (1) of the following: 
1.  Issuance of a special event permit in accordance with the terms of the application; or 
2.  Issuance of a special event permit in accordance with the terms of the application, as modified by mutual agreement between the city manager or his designee and the applicant; or 
3.  Denial of the special event permit application by the city manager or his designee. 
(Ord. 2439, Add, 06/28/2010) 
Section 9.34.075 - Free speech areas to remain open during special events. 
A.  Each permit for a special event occurring at Victorian Square or any city park must specifically provide that the permit is subordinate to designated "free speech" areas and the rights of persons utilizing such areas. 
B.  Each permit described in subsection A shall also prohibit the permittee from taking any action to terminate or seriously impair any First Amendment activity occurring in a designated "free speech" area. 
(Ord. 2439, Amended, 06/28/2010; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.34.080 - Charges and fees. 
A.  The city committee shall provide estimates for parks and recreation maintenance, public works duties and police and fire costs to permittee twenty-one (21) days prior to start of event upon presentation of estimated department service charges. Once final costs are determined after the event has concluded, a comprehensive invoice shall be furnished to permittee, who will be afforded thirty (30) days to reimburse city for the invoiced city service charges. If payment is not received in full within thirty (30) days, city may decline future event/permit applications for subsequent year(s). 
(Ord. 2439, Amended, 06/28/2010; Ord. 1618 § 1 (part), 1988) 
Section 9.34.081 - Deligation of city manager's authority; city manager authorized to adopt rules and regulations. 
A.  Delegation of city manager's authority. The city manager may delegate any or all of his or her functions under this section to his or her designee, deputies or subordinates. 
B.  City manager or his designee authorized to adopt rules and regulations. The city manager or his designee is authorized to promulgate additional rules and regulations that are consistent with and that further the terms and requirements set forth within this division and the provisions of law that pertain to the conduct and operation of a special event or demonstration. 
(Ord. 2439, Add, 06/28/2010) 
Section 9.34.082 - Enforcement authority. 
    The city manager or his designee is authorized to administer and enforce the provisions of this section. The city manager and his or her designated enforcement official may exercise any enforcement powers as set forth in this section and the Sparks Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 2439, Add, 06/28/2010) 
Section 9.34.083 - Authorized special event vendors. 
A.  The issuance of a special event permit confers upon the event permit holder or event organizer the right to control and regulate the sale of goods, food and beverages by vendors within the special event venue in accordance with the terms and conditions of the special event permit. 
B.  At least forty-five (45) days prior to the event, the event permit holder or event organizer shall inform the city of the number and location of the anticipated vendors participating in the event by filing a site plan map with the parks and recreation department showing the location and number of the vendor booths. 
C.  At least fifteen (15) days in advance of the special event, the permit holder or event organizer shall submit a final site plan, the name of each participating vendor, and payment in full to the city for all participating vendors. The event producer shall pay to the city fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each authorized vendor except for vendors preparing or cooking food on event site for sale and for those food vendors the event producer shall pay fifty-five dollars ($55.00) for each permit. The temporary vendor permit is valid for the duration of the event only. The event producer is not required to pay the vendor fee for those vendors who possess a valid Sparks business license or who are otherwise exempt under Title 5 of the Sparks Municipal Code with proof shown to the city representative. 
D.  Upon receipt of the site plan and full required permit payments, and if all other city requirements are met, the city may issue temporary special event vendor permits to the special event permit holder or the event organizer for distribution to the vendors. 
E.  Notwithstanding issuance of the temporary vendor permit by the city, authorized vendors must comply with all other permitting and licensing requirements imposed by local, state, and federal laws. 
F.  Failure of the permit holder or event producer to file the site plan map indicating the location and number of vendors in a timely manner as required by paragraphs B and C above, may be grounds for denial of all vendor permits or, at the city manager's discretion, a ten (10) percent penalty of the total for vendor permits may be imposed against the event permit holder or the event producer. 
G.  Vendors authorized by the event organizer to sell goods, food or beverages in the special event venue shall display their authorization in the manner required by the city manager or his designee. Only vendors displaying the required authorization shall be allowed to sell goods, food or beverages in the special event venue. 
(Ord. 2495, Amended, 06/23/2014; Ord. 2439, Add, 06/28/2010) 
Section 9.34.100 - Interfering with activity prohibited. 
    No person shall knowingly join or participate in any parade, special event or filming activity conducted under permit from the city in violation of any of the terms of the permit, nor knowingly join or participate in any permitted parade, special event or filming activity without the consent and over the objection of the permittee, nor in any manner interfere with the progress or orderly conduct of any such parade, special event or filming activity. 
(Ord. 2439, Amended, 06/28/2010; Ord. 1618 § 1 (part), 1988) 
Section 9.34.105 - Loitering in public areas of victorian square prohibited after special event closes; purpose of prohibition is to protect persons from injury or death during clean-up of victorian square and take-down of vendor stands. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to loiter in Victorian Square in any public area owned by and under the control of the city or another governmental entity or agency: 
1.  Within twenty-four (24) hours prior to the opening of a special event; or 
2.  Between the time a special event closes and the time the police department deems it safe to allow members of the public to return to such public areas. 
B.  To constitute a violation of this section, a person loitering in a public area during the period of time described in subsection A must first be orally warned that he or she cannot loiter in the public area and must either move to premises owned or operated by a private business in Victorian Square or leave the public areas in Victorian Square. Any person who, being so warned, fails or refuses to promptly move into such a private business, or who fails or refuses to promptly leave such public areas in Victorian Square, commits a trespass and violates SMC 9.45.050, a misdemeanor. 
C.  For purposes of this section, "loiter" means to be in a public area for no obvious reason, but does not include temporary traveling across a public area to reach any private site or a public site outside of Victorian Square. 
D.  For purposes of this section "promptly" means within two (2) minutes after receiving a warning. 
E.  For purposes of this section, "public area" means any street, alley, sidewalk, plaza, park, memorial park, parking garage, parking lot, driveway, transportation facility or other area owned by and under control of the city or any other governmental entity or agency. 
F.  For purposes of this section, "Victorian Square" means that area bounded by the southern right-of-way of Nugget Avenue, the western right-of-way of 15th Street, the northern right-of-way of D Street and the eastern right-of-way of Pyramid Way. 
G.  The prohibition in subsection A does not apply to: 
1.  Vendors with a permit to sell at the special event or their employees, independent contractors or volunteers, while actively engaged in work related to their business as a vendor. 
2.  Merchants having fixed premises located within Victorian Square or their employees, independent contractors or volunteers, while actively engaged in work related to the business at such premises. 
3.  Persons who are lawfully occupying a "free speech" site in compliance with the rules and regulations of the department of parks and recreation. 
4.  Employees, independent contractors or volunteers of the city actively engaged in clean-up, law enforcement or other activities related to the special event. 
5.  Private patrolmen who are licensed pursuant to Chapter 648 of NRS or who possess a valid work card issued by the Sheriff of Washoe County. 
H.  This section is enacted to protect and enhance the health, welfare and safety of persons present within Victorian Square during hours of clean-up and vendor stand set-up preceding a special event and take-down following the daily closure of a special event. During those hours, maintenance trucks, garbage trucks, street sweepers and other vehicles, as well as power equipment such as pressure washers, pose a danger to persons loitering on public areas in Victorian Square. 
(Ord. 2439, Amended, 06/28/2010; Ord. 2364, Add, 06/11/2007) 
Section 9.34.110 - Animals prohibited. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to bring an animal into the area designated for a special event occurring at Victorian Square. 
B.  This section shall not apply to animals authorized by the permittee or to guide dogs, hearing dogs and helping dogs assisting a person with a disability as provided in NRS Chapter 426. The permittee must notify the city of such authorization for animals in writing at the time of application. 
(Ord. 2439, Amended, 06/28/2010; Ord. 1742, 1992) 
Section 9.34.115 - Inflatables prohibited without a permit. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to set up, inflate or offer for use any inflatable on public property in Sparks without a permit. 
B.  The director of the department of parks and recreation or designee may issue a permit for one or more inflatables for use by attendees during a special event in Victorian Square, Golden Eagle Regional Park, Shadow Mountain Park, or Sparks Marina Park upon such terms and conditions as the director or designee may deem advisable. No fees shall be required for such a permit. Each such permit shall carry an expiration date and shall be specific with respect to the number and type(s) of inflatables allowed and the location(s), date(s) and time(s) allowed. The city manager or designee will be responsible for determining whether an inflatable complies with the terms of the permit. Any inflatable(s) shall not be used or offered for use prior to passing an inspection by the chief of the fire department or designee, which inspection shall be paid for by the permittee. 
(Ord. 2544, Add, 10/23/2017) 
Section 9.34.120 - Certain containers prohibited. 
    Within the area designated for a special event occurring at Victorian Square, it shall be unlawful for any person to use or possess: 
A.  a glass beverage container; or 
B.  a metal container of an alcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. 2439, Amended, 06/28/2010; Ord. 2228, Amended, 06/28/2004; Ord. 1742, 1992) 
Section 9.34.125 - Other permits and licenses. 
A.  The issuance of a special event permit does not relieve any person from the obligation to obtain any other permit or license pursuant to this Code. 
B.  The issuance of any other permit or license issued pursuant to this Code does not relieve any person from the obligation to obtain a special event permit pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. 2439, Add, 06/28/2010) 
Chapter 9.35 - EXEMPT SPECIAL EVENTS 

Section 9.35.005 - Scope and operation of Chapters 9.34 and 9.35. 
    Chapter 9.34 of the SMC governs the regulation of general gatherings of people in parades and special events, concerning promotional, athletic, musical, historical or other celebrations, observances and activities that do not constitute expressive speech under the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. 
    This chapter 9.35 of the SMC governs the regulation of organized gatherings of people in parades and special events, such as rallies and demonstrations, that constitute expressive speech under the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. 
    The standards for determining whether a parade or special event is "expressive" under the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States are set forth in this chapter 9.35. See, SMC 9.35.035. 
(Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the words and terms defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to them herein. 
A.  "Department" means the Department of Parks and Recreation. 
B.  "Departmental service charge" means certain delineated actual costs incurred by the City in connection with the direct activities of a permittee. 
C.  "Director" means the Director of the Department of Parks and Recreation. 
D.  "Expressive" means the exhibition, dissemination or communication by verbal, visual, literary, auditory or other means of opinions, views, ideas, concepts or emotions. 
E.  "Expressive Parade" means and includes an expressive parade, procession, march, run or assembly which is conducted on or upon any portion of any public sidewalk, park path, street or way so as to impede, obstruct, impair or interfere with the free use of such public passageway; or in a manner that does not comply with normal or usual traffic regulations or controls. 
F.  "Expressive Special Event" means any expressive planned gathering of persons which occupies any part of a city street, park, Victorian Square or other city property and which hinders the general public in the ordinary and usual use of such street or property. 
G.  "Person" means and includes any individual, firm, organization, club, partnership, corporation, municipality or governmental entity. 
H.  "Victorian Square" means that area bounded by the southern right-of-way of Nugget Avenue, the western right-of-way of 15th Street, the northern right-of-way of D Street and the eastern right-of-way of 6th Street. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 9/25/2006) (Ord. 2430, Amended, 10/26/2009; Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.020 - Permit required for large expressive parade or large expressive special event; exceptions; notice to police department of smaller expressive parades . 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall conduct or cause to be conducted an expressive parade or expressive special event involving 150 or more participants on or upon any city street, sidewalk, alley, park, way, public place or public property which is owned or controlled by the city without first having obtained a written permit from the director or his designee. 
B.  Except as otherwise provided in this section, in order to assure the safety of participants, no person shall conduct or cause to be conducted an expressive parade involving fewer than 150 participants upon any city street, alley or way in a manner likely to interfere with vehicular traffic or violate laws applicable to vehicles or pedestrians without first notifying the director or the Police Department of the activity at least 24 hours prior to the commencement of the activity. The notice must include the date, time, route and an estimate of the number of participants. 
C.  Sidewalk Parade "Safe Harbor" Exception. An expressive parade is deemed to not interfere with the free use by others of a public sidewalk or public park path and is not required to obtain a permit if the total group consists of 500 or fewer participants and if all participants: 
1.  Assemble, march, walk or run in groups of less than 50, 2 abreast (to allow others to pass on the sidewalk or path), and give way to others they encounter on the public way; 
2.  Do not obstruct traffic flow; 
3.  Obey all laws applicable to pedestrians; and 
4.  Obey all park regulations. 
An expressive "safe harbor" parade under this section may be alone or in combination with a "spontaneous event" exception. 
D.  Spontaneous Events; Exception. Neither notice or a permit is required under this section for a spontaneous expressive event which is occasioned by news or affairs coming into public knowledge within 5 days prior to the spontaneous event, if such events are conducted: 
1.  In off-street public areas in Victorian Square; 
2.  In designated "free speech" areas at Sparks City Hall; 
3.  In any city park, including the Sparks Marina, but excepting city ballfields, children's playgrounds and swimming areas; or 
4.  On public sidewalks. 
If a spontaneous event is to occur on a public street or right-of-way in a manner likely to interfere with vehicular traffic or violate laws applicable to vehicles or pedestrians, notice of the date, time, route and estimated number of participants must be given to the director or the Police Department no less than 24 hours prior to commencement of the event. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006.) (Ord. 2430, Amended, 10/26/2009; Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.030 - Application for permit; no fee for processing application. 
A.  The application for a permit under this chapter to conduct or engage in any expressive parade or expressive special event which involves the use of city streets, alleys, sidewalks, parks, ways or other public property owned or controlled by the city shall be filed at the department with the director or his designee. On Saturdays and Sundays and holidays, the application must be filed with the front desk of the Sparks Police Department. Such applications shall be filed at least 48 hours prior to the date that the permit is to become effective. There is no fee for a permit for a parade or special event which qualifies under this chapter as "expressive". Any permit issued under this chapter may not be for a period of more than three consecutive days. There is no limit on the number of permits an applicant may seek. 
B.  Applications must be upon a form which is furnished by the department. Each application must contain full, complete and detailed information including, but not limited to, the following: 
1.  A detailed description of the proposed use, event or activity; 
2.  A brief explanation of why the proposed use, event or activity falls within the definition of "expressive" in SMC 9.35.101. 
3.  The street, park or other public property and the specific area or areas thereof which are proposed to be utilized in connection with the proposed use, event or activity; 
4.  The manner in which the public property is proposed to be utilized; 
5.  The date or dates and the specific times thereof that the public property is proposed to be utilized for the described use, event or activity; 
6.  The name, address and telephone number of each person, entity or organization sponsoring, conducting or coordinating the proposed use, event or activity; and 
7.  A preliminary estimate of the number of persons, vehicles and equipment, together with a brief description of any oversized (wider than 8 feet or longer than 25 feet) vehicle or piece of equipment expected to participate in the expressive parade or expressive special event. 
Once completed and submitted, an application may be reused to renew a permit after it expires if the information on the application is still true and correct. 
C.  The director or his designee shall issue a permit to an "expressive parade" or "expressive special event" if the following criteria have been met: 
1.  The application for the permit is fully completed, the estimated amount of departmental service charges, unless waived, is deposited, and all conditions precedent to the issuance of the permit are met. 
2.  The proposed use is not prohibited by any other permit procedures provided elsewhere in this code or by other applicable laws, rules or regulations; 
3.  The proposed use is not on the same date and at the same place as a previously-approved parade, special event, expressive parade, expressive special event, group activity or group event; 
4.  The preparation for or the conduct of the proposed use, event or activity will not unduly impede or obstruct the operation of emergency vehicles or equipment in or through the particular permit area, or prevent the city from performing essential municipal functions or furnishing essential city services to affected parts of the city; 
5.  Safety or traffic hazards will be mitigated to the extent the public and the event participants are not placed at undue risk; and 
6.  The proposed use, event or activity will not have a significant adverse environmental impact. 
D.  In addition to the requirements of this code or other applicable laws or rules or regulations, including the Regulations for "Free Speech" and "Expressive Activities" in City Parks and Victorian Square, the director or his designee, after receiving the approval of the City Attorney or his designee, may impose reasonable restrictions regarding the time, place and manner of utilizing the city streets, parks or other public property which are necessary and appropriate to the proposed activity. Any such restriction must further a substantial governmental interest, including but not limited to those set forth in SMC 12.26.010, and must not unreasonably restrict expressive activity. 
E.  In fashioning additional reasonable restrictions regarding the time, place and manner of utilizing public property, the director or his designee shall give no consideration to the message of the event, the content of likely speech, the identity of associational relationships of the applicant or to any assumptions or predictions as to the amount of hostility which may be aroused in the public by the content of speech or the message conveyed by the event. 
F.  If any additional restrictions are placed on the time, place and manner of the activity, the director or his designee must notify the applicant in writing of the restrictions and the reasons for the restrictions. Reasonable time, place or manner restrictions may be imposed on the permit at any time prior to 4 hours before the proposed commencement of the activity and, if unforeseen or emergency circumstances necessitate, at any time during the activity. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended 10/27/08; Ord. 2340, Add, 9/25/2006) (Ord. 2430, Amended, 10/26/2009; Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.035 - Qualification of parade or special event as "expressive". 
A.  A proposed parade or special event qualifies as "expressive" for purposes of this chapter if it expresses the opinions, views, ideas, concepts or emotions of its participants, and if it is an activity that is not defined as a special event in SMC 9.34.010. The determination whether a parade or special event qualifies as "expressive" must be made by the director or his designee with the approval of the City Attorney or his designee within 24 hours after the application is submitted to the director. 
B.  If, under the circumstances a reasonable person would have no reasonable doubt that the purpose of the parade or special event is "expressive," the special event must be deemed "expressive" by the director or his designee without first obtaining the concurrence of the City Attorney or his designee. 
C.  If, upon viewing the application and other relevant facts, a reasonable person would have a reasonable doubt that the purpose of the parade or special event is "expressive," the director or his designee and the City Attorney or his designee shall make further inquiry of the applicant to obtain more facts relating to the event and how the event relates to the applicant. The applicant must cooperate and promptly provide answers in any inquiry. Failure to promptly provide answers to questions which are capable of being answered promptly is grounds to deny the application. If after that inquiry there is a reasonable, articulable doubt that the parade or special event is "expressive," , the special event shall be deemed "not expressive." 
D.  If a parade or special event is found to be "not expressive" pursuant to this section, the director or his designee shall promptly notify the applicant of that finding, the reasons for that finding and of the necessity to seek a special event permit pursuant to Chapter 9.34 of the SMC. 
E.  The determination that a parade or special event is not expressive may be appealed within 5 days to the city manager, who shall make a decision on the question within 5 days after receipt of the appeal. If the sponsor of the parade or event is dissatisfied with the city manager's decision, an appeal may be taken to a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended 10/27/08; Ord. 2340, Add, 9/25/2006) (Ord. 2430, Amended, 10/26/2009; Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.040 - Police and parks departmental service charges; deposit. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in this section, by this code or other applicable law, rule or regulation, as a condition precedent to receiving a permit the director or his designee shall require the applicant to deposit the estimated amount of city departmental service charges for police traffic control and department clean-up fees likely to occur by virtue of the permittee's actions during the requested activity. The total amount of fees due for the entire permit period must be paid to the department at least 4 hours before the date and time on which the applicant requests the permit to become effective. At the conclusion of the activity, the respective city departments shall calculate the actual cost of police traffic control and departmental clean-up and said sums must be deducted from the estimated amounts deposited by the permittee. Any difference must be timely refunded to the permittee. If the actual cost exceeds the estimated costs, the permittee shall pay the deficiency to the director or his designee within five days after demand therefore. 
B.  "Actual Costs" must be calculated by including the wages of support personnel (including fringe benefits), vehicle expenses (including a base hourly charge), equipment, materials and supplies. "Actual Costs" shall not include costs of clean up caused by persons not associated with the permittee (e.g., bystanders, onlookers, hecklers, etc.). 
C.  The estimated service charges for police traffic control and departmental clean-up must be calculated by the Chief of Police and the Director, or their designee, in conformance with the definition of "actual costs" contained in subsection B and must be based only upon the number of expected participants in the expressive parade or expressive special event and the impact the proposed activity will have on traffic flow and parking. The Chief of Police or his designee shall not consider any cost of police protection to the participants or to the public as a result of the activity, nor base any portion of the departmental service charge on the message of the applicant, the content of speech, the identity or associational relationships of the applicant, or upon any assumptions or predictions as to the amount of hostility which may be aroused in the public by the context of speech or the message conveyed by the activity or to the potential for violence occasioned by the activity. 
D.  The estimated departmental service charge for clean-up shall be calculated by the director of the department of parks and recreation or his designee in conformance with the definition of "actual costs" contained in subsection B, and must be based only upon the expected number of participants in the expressive parade or expressive special event and the relative difficulty of cleaning up the areas they will occupy during the event. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.050 - Permittee must provide insurance, agree to hold harmless, defend and indemnify the city or agree to act to reduce risk and exposure. 
    As a condition precedent to obtaining a permit for an expressive parade or an expressive special event, the permittee shall, at the permittee's option: 
A.  Procure and maintain a policy of insurance in full force and effect during the term of the permit. The policy must insure against willful or negligent acts or omissions of permittee, its officers, agents, employees or members (but not the acts or omissions of persons not associated with the permittee) in connection with the permitted event or activity, and be of a type and in an amount to be determined by the City's insurance advisors; 
B.  Agree to defend, protect, indemnify and hold the City, its officers, employees, agents, and volunteers free and harmless from and against any and all claims, damages, expenses, loss and liability of any kind or nature whatsoever resulting from the alleged willful or negligent acts or omissions of permittee, its officers, agents, employees or members in connection with the permitted event or activity; or 
C.  Agree to, and actually undertake to, redesign or reschedule the permitted activity to respond to specific risks, hazards and dangers to the public health and safety identified by the city manager as being reasonably foreseeable consequences of the expressive parade or expressive special event. 
D.  The city manager may waive the requirement of this section if he and the city attorney agree that the proposed conduct of the permittee and its officers, agents, employees or members during the expressive parade or expressive special event poses no significant increase in the potential for harm to the general public and does not significantly increase the City's exposure to liability. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended 10/27/08; Ord. 2340, Add, 9/25/2006) (Ord. 2430, Amended, 10/26/2009; Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.060 - Permit; denial, revocation. 
A.  The director or his designee may deny any application for a permit or revoke any permit if the director or his designee determines, and the city attorney concurs, that the applicant therefor or permittee thereof, or any agent, employee, associate or member of any such applicant or permittee, has made any false statement of material fact in an application, has not met the conditions precedent for a permit or has violated any relevant provision of this chapter. If an application is denied, the director or his designee shall immediately notify the applicant of the reasons for denial. The applicant may appeal the denial to the city council by serving a Notice of Appeal on the City Manager within 5 working days after the denial. The appeal must be placed on the agenda of the next meeting of the city council in compliance with the Open Meeting Law. Judicial review may be taken from a denial by the city council. 
B.  Any permit issued under this chapter may be summarily revoked by the City Manager or his designee if the activity evolves into a clear and present danger to the safety of persons or property. If an expressive parade or expressive special event is in progress when any such revocation occurs, the city manager or his designee may direct the police department to disassemble such gathering. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.080 - Petition for indigency waiver of departmental service charges. 
A.  An applicant may petition the director or his designee for an indigency waiver of the city departmental service charges. Such a petition for waiver of charges must be submitted at the time of filing the application and must include such relevant information and documentation as is necessary to establish the indigency criteria set forth in subsection B for each person named on the application as being responsible for sponsoring or conducting the special event. Failure to submit complete financial information for each such person is deemed an incomplete request for waiver and the petition must be denied. 
B.  A waiver of the city departmental service charges must be granted if the applicant proves indigency by showing the following to the department: 
1.  For individuals: 
(a)  Receipt of benefits under Supplemental Security Income (SSI) and the State Supplemental Payments (SSP); 
(b)  Receipt of food stamps under the Food Stamps Program (7.U.S.C. § 2011, et seq.) or a similar State program; 
(c)  Monthly income of less than 125 percent of the current monthly poverty line annually established by the Secretary of Health and Human Services pursuant to the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1981, as amended; or 
(d)  Lack of money necessary to post the deposit for estimated departmental service charges. 
2.  For organizations: 
(a)  That a majority of its members meet the criteria for individual indigent status set forth in paragraph 1; or 
(b)  That the organization does not possess funds equal to or greater than the deposit for estimated departmental service. 
C.  The decision to grant or deny a waiver of departmental service charges shall be rendered within 24 hours after receipt of an application and petition for waiver of charges. 
D.  An applicant who submits a petition for waiver of charges and complete financial information as required in subsection A and is denied a waiver of the city departmental service charges because the director or his designee finds that the applicant does not qualify for an indigency waiver under subsection B, and who nonetheless claims an inability to pay the deposit for such service charges, must be allowed to proceed with the requested expressive parade or expressive special event without paying the deposit if the subject matter of the activity involves a matter of immediate public concern or a public controversy that may lose its importance with the passage of time. 
E.  If an expressive parade or expressive special event is allowed pursuant to subsection D, and the City later discovers that the applicant falsely claimed an inability to pay the deposit for service charges, the city attorney may seek approval of the city council to institute legal action against the applicant and the persons named on the application as sponsoring or conducting the special event to compel the payment of the actual chargeable departmental service charges incurred by the city for the activity, plus costs and attorney's fees. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.090 - Refunds. 
A.  A permittee who determines to cancel an expressive parade or an expressive special event must notify the director or his designee of that determination at least 24 hours before the activity is to commence pursuant to the terms of the permit. 
B.  If the permittee provides the 24-hour notice required in subsection A and submits a written request for the refund of the deposit for departmental services charges to the director within 30 days after the date that the activity was to have commenced, the city manager shall authorize the refund of that deposit. 
C.  If the permittee fails to provide the 24-hour notice required in subsection A and submits a written request for the refund of the deposit for departmental service charges to the director within 30 days after the date that the activity was to have commenced, the city manager may authorize a full or partial refund of that deposit. The amount to be refunded is the amount of the deposit, less charges for all compensable time spent by employees and all costs incurred by the City in preparation for the expressive parade or expressive special event. 
D.  Requests for refunds made more than 30 days after the date the activity was scheduled to commence must be considered by the director on a case-by-case basis, based on the amount of notice and formula set forth in subsections B and C. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) (Ord. 2430, Amended, 10/26/2009; Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.100 - Unlawful obstruction of participants in expressive parade or expressive special event. 
    It is unlawful for a person to knowingly engage in any physical activity which purposefully obstructs the free flow of persons in an expressive parade or limits the free movement of persons in any expressive special event. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.110 - Animals prohibited; exceptions. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided herein, it is unlawful for any person to bring an animal into the area designated for an expressive parade or expressive special event occurring at Victorian Square. 
B.  This section does not apply to animals authorized by the permit, or to police dogs, guide dogs, hearing dogs and helping dogs assisting a handicapped person as provided in NRS chapter 426. 
C.  The permittee must request the city to authorize designated animals in writing at the time of application. 
(Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.115 - Alcoholic beverages. 
    It is unlawful for a permittee or any participant in an expressive parade or expressive special event to sell or serve alcoholic beverages in conjunction with the activity. 
(Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.120 - Certain containers prohibited. 
    Within the area utilized for an expressive parade or expressive special event, it shall be unlawful for any person to use or possess: 
A.  A glass beverage container; or 
B.  A metal container of an alcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.35.130 - Violation - penalty. 
    Any person who intentionally violates a provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in SMC 1.12.010. 
(Ord. 2415, Add, 10/27/2008) 
Chapter 9.36 - INTOXICATION-ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 
Sections: 

Section 9.36.010 - Consumption of alcoholic beverages in public place unlawful; exceptions. 
A.  Except as provided in subsection B, it is unlawful for any person to consume or drink an alcoholic beverage or possess an open container of any alcoholic beverage in or upon any public park, street, sidewalk, alley or public parking lot. 
B.  The consumption of alcoholic beverages on public property when authorized by a park use waiver, a special event alcoholic beverage license or a temporary alcohol permit, which are issued pursuant to SMC 5.28.155, does not constitute a violation of this section. 
(Ord. 1669, 1990: Ord. 921 § 1, 1973: 1962 Code § 25.120.) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010) 
Section 9.36.020 - Supplying alcoholic beverages to intoxicated persons and military personnel. 
    It is unlawful for any person to deliver, give, sell or offer to sell any alcoholic beverage to: 
A.  Any person actually and apparently under the influence of alcoholic beverages; 
B.  An person wearing a uniform of any of the armed services of the United States if such act is contrary to an order issued by the commanding officer of the area which includes the city and such order has been made public in the city. 
(1962 Code § 25.215.) 
Chapter 9.39 - DISORDERLY CONDUCT 
Sections: 

Section 9.39.010 - Disorderly conduct. 
A.  It is unlawful to: 
1.  Offer or agree to engage in lewd or dissolute conduct in any public place or in any place open to the public or exposed to public view; 
2.  Offer or agree to engage in, engage in or aid and abet any act of prostitution; 
3.  Be a pimp, panderer or procurer or live in or about houses or prostitution; 
4.  Seek admission to a house upon frivolous pretexts for no other apparent motive than to see who may be therein, or to gain an insight of the premises; 
5.  Keep a place where lost or stolen property is concealed; 
6.  Loiter in or about any toilet open to the public for the purpose of engaging in or soliciting any lewd or lascivious or any unlawful act; 
7.  Lodge in any building, structure or place, whether public or private, without the permission of the owner or person entitled to the possession or in control thereof. 
B.  A person who violates a provision of subsection A shall be punished; 
1.  For the first violation of paragraph (1), (2) or (3) of subsection A and for each subsequent violation of the same paragraph occurring more than 3 years after the first violation, for a misdemeanor; 
2.  For the second violation of paragraph (1), (2) or (3) of subsection 3 within 3 years after the first violation of the same paragraph, by imprisonment in the county jail for not less than 30 days nor more than 6 months and by a fine of not less than $250.00 nor more than $1,000.00; 
3.  For the third or subsequent violation of paragraph (1), (2) or (3) of subsection A within 3 years after the first violation of the same paragraph, by imprisonment in the county jail for 6 months and by a fine of not less than $250.00 nor more han $1,000.00; 
4.  For a violation of any provision of a paragraphs (4) to (7), inclusive, of subsection A, for a misdemeanor. 
C.  The terms of imprisonment prescribed by subsection B must be imposed to run consecutively. 
(Ord. 1467 § 2, 1984: Ord. 921 § 2, 1973: Ord. 701 § 1, 1967: 1962 Code § 25.220.) (1961, Amended, 12/08/1997) 
Chapter 9.40 - SOLICITATION 
Sections: 

Section 9.40.010 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the words and terms defined herein shall have the meanings ascribed to them. 
A.  "Coercion" means to willfully and knowingly: 
1.  Approach or speak to a person in such a manner as would cause a reasonable person to believe that the person is being threatened with: 
a.  imminent bodily injury; or 
b.  the commission of a criminal act upon the person or another person, or upon property in the person's immediate possession; 
2.  Persist in a solicitation after the person solicited has given a negative response; 
3.  Block, either individually or as part of a group of persons, the passage of a solicited person; or 
4.  Engage in conduct that would reasonably be construed as intended to compel or force a solicited person to accede to demands. 
B.  "Employment" means and includes services, industry or labor performed by a person for wages or other compensation or under any contract of hire, written, oral, express or implied. 
C.  "Obstruct vehicular traffic" means to knowingly block, hinder, hamper or interfere with the passage of a vehicle upon a public street or highway or to knowingly require a driver of a vehicle upon a public street or of the public street or highway to take evasive action to avoid physical contact. 
D.  "Public street or highway" means that paved portion of the public right of way actually used for lawful vehicular purposes, including any divider and median strip thereof. 
E.  "Solicitation" means any in-person verbal request or offer for immediate employment, the immediate sale of goods or services, or a request for an immediate donation of money or other property. (Ord. 1865, 1995.) 
(Ord. 2111, Amended, 10/22/2001; Ord. 2075, Amended, 07/10/2000) 
Section 9.40.020 - Coercion. 
    Any person who commits solicitation by coercion is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 1865, 1995.) 
Section 9.40.040 - Solicitation of persons in vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct vehicular traffic while standing in or upon any public street or highway. 
(Ord. 1865, 1995.) (Ord. 2111, Amended, 10/22/2001; Ord. 2075, Amended, 07/10/2000) 
Section 9.40.041 - Solicitation of persons from vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any occupant of a motor vehicle while unlawfully stopped or unlawfully parked upon any portion of a public street or highway to obstruct vehicular traffic while providing a gift, donation, contribution, or while engaging in a solicitation with another person who is standing in, upon or adjacent to a public street or highway. 
(Ord. 2111, Amended, 10/22/2001; Ord. 2075, Add, 07/10/2000) 
Section 9.40.050 - Private owner or operator. 
    If the property where the solicitation occurs is owned or controlled by a private owner or operator, nothing in this chapter shall be construed as applying to the conduct or activity of a person on said property acting under the authorization or permission of the owner or operator of the property. 
(Ord. 1865, 1995.) 
Chapter 9.42 - SOUND-AMPLIFYING EQUIPMENT 
Sections: 

Section 9.42.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  "Commercial purpose" means and includes the use, operation, or maintenance of any sound amplifying equipment for the purpose of advertising any business or any goods, or any services or for the purpose of attracting the attention of the public to or advertising for, or soliciting patronage or customers to or for any performance, show, entertainment, exhibition, or event, or for the purpose of demonstrating any such sound equipment. 
B.  "Noncommercial purpose" means the use, operation, or maintenance of any sound equipment for other than a commercial purpose. Noncommercial purpose means and includes, but shall not be limited to, philanthropic, political, patriotic, and charitable purposes. 
C.  "Sound-amplifying equipment" means any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice, music, or any other sound. Sound-amplifying equipment shall not include standard automobile radios when used and heard only by the occupants of the vehicle in which the automobile radio is installed. Sound-amplifying equipment, as used in this chapter shall not include warning devices or authorized emergency vehicles or horns or other warning devices on any vehicle used only for traffic safety purposes. 
D.  "Sound truck" means any motor vehicle, or any other vehicle regardless of motive power, whether in motion or stationary, having mounted thereon, or attached thereto, any sound-amplifying equipment. 
E.  "Victorian Square" means that area bounded by the southern right-of-way of Nugget Avenue, the western right-of-way of 15th Street, the northern right-of-way of D Street and the eastern right-of-way of 6th Street. 
(Ord. 1639 § 1 (part), 1989.) (Ord. 2511, § 1, 5/11/2015) 
Section 9.42.020 - Registration-Required. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person, other than personnel of law enforcement or governmental agencies, to install, use, or operate within the city a loudspeaker or sound amplifying equipment in a fixed or movable position or mounted upon any sound truck for the purposes of giving instructions, directions, talks, addresses, lectures, or transmitting music to any persons or assemblages of persons in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, park, place, or public property without first filing a registration statement and obtaining approval thereof as set forth in this article. 
B.  This chapter shall not apply to the operation of sound amplifying equipment in compliance with the terms of a special events permit issued pursuant to Chapter 9.34 of this code. 
(Ord. 1639 § 1 (part), 1989.) 
Section 9.42.030 - Registration statements-Filing. 
    Every user of sound-amplifying equipment shall file a registration statement with the chief of police five days prior to the date on which the sound-amplifying equipment is intended to be used, which statement shall contain the following information: 
A.  The name, address and telephone number of both the owner and user of the sound amplifying equipment; 
B.  The maximum sound-producing power of the sound-amplifying equipment which shall include the wattage to be used, the volume in decibels of sound which will be produced, and the approximate distance for which sound will be audible from the sound amplifying equipment; 
C.  The license and motor number if a sound truck is to be used; 
D.  A general description of the sound-amplifying equipment which is to be used; 
E.  Whether the sound-amplifying equipment will be used for commercial or noncommercial purposes; 
F.  The date and place or places where the sound-amplifying equipment is to be operated; and 
G.  Such other information as may be prescribed. 
(Ord. 1639 § 1 (part), 1989.) 
Section 9.42.040 - Registration statements-Approval. 
    The chief of police shall return to the applicant an approved certified copy of the registration statement unless he finds that: 
A.  The conditions of the motor vehicle movement are such that use of the equipment would constitute a detriment to traffic safety; or 
B.  The conditions of pedestrian movement are such that use of the equipment would constitute a detriment to traffic safety; or 
C.  The registration statement reveals that the applicant would not be able to comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1639 § 1 (part), 1989.) 
Section 9.42.050 - Registration statements-Disapproval. 
    In the event the registration statement is disapproved, the chief of police shall endorse upon the statement his reasons for disapproval and return it forthwith to applicant. 
(Ord. 1639 § 1 (part), 1989.) 
Section 9.42.060 - Fees. 
    Prior to the issuance of the registration statement, a fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars per day, or any portion thereof, shall be paid to the city, if the loudspeaker or sound amplifying equipment is to be used for commercial purposes. No fee shall be required for the operation of a loudspeaker or sound amplifying equipment for noncommercial purposes. 
(Ord. 1639 § 1 (part), 1989.) 
Section 9.42.070 - Regulations. 
    The commercial and noncommercial use of sound-amplifying equipment shall be subject to the following regulations: 
A.  The only sounds permitted shall be either music or human speech, or both. 
B.  The operation of sound-amplifying equipment shall only occur between the hours of eight a.m. and eight p.m. each day except on Sundays and legal holidays. No operation of sound-amplifying equipment for commercial purposes shall be permitted on Sundays or legal holidays. The operation of sound-amplifying equipment for noncommercial purposes on Sundays and legal holidays shall only occur between the hours of ten a.m. and eight p.m. The sound-amplifying equipment shall be operated only on the date(s) and place(s) specified in the approved registration statement. 
1.  For sound permits approved within Special Event permits located in Victorian Square, the commercial operation of sound-amplifying equipment shall only occur between the hours of eight a.m. and ten p.m. or at the discretion of the city manager or his designee. The sound-amplifying equipment shall be operated only on the date(s) and place(s) specified in the approved permit. 
C.  No sound emanating from sound-amplifying equipment shall exceed fifteen dbA above the ambient as measured at any property line. 
D.  It is unlawful to operate any sound-amplifying equipment within three hundred feet of churches, schools, hospitals, or city or county buildings. 
E.  In any event, the volume of sound shall be so controlled that it will not be unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing, or a nuisance to reasonable persons of normal sensitiveness within the area of audibility. 
F.  The speech or music amplified shall not be profane, lewd, obscene or slanderous. 
(Ord. 1639 § 1 (part), 1989.) (Ord. 2511, § 2, 5/11/2015) 
Chapter 9.45 - PROPERTY DESTRUCTION OR DEFACEMENT OR TRESPASS 
Sections: 

Section 9.45.010 - Destruction of barrier. 
    Any person who willfully breaks down, removes, injures or destroys any barrier or obstruction erected or placed in or upon any road or highway by the authorities in charge thereof or by any authorized contractor engaged in the construction or maintenance thereof, or who tears down, defaces, removes or destroys any warnings, notices or directional signs erected, placed or posted in, upon or adjacent to any road or highway, or who extinguishes, removes, injures or destroys any warning light or lantern or reflectorized warning or directional sign erected, placed or maintained by any such authority in, upon or adjacent to any such road or highway is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 931 § 1 (part), 1973: Ord. 646 § 2, 1966: 1962 Code § 25.058.) 
Section 9.45.020 - Destruction of property generally. 
    It is unlawful for any person within the city willfully, unlawfully and maliciously to destroy, burn, cut or otherwise injure any goods, chattels or property of any description whatever belonging to another. 
(1962 Code § 25.060.) 
Section 9.45.040 - Destruction of public and other notices. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person without proper authority to tear down or deface any ordinance, resolution, bill, notice, advertisement or other paper of a business or other legitimate character lawfully posted within the limits of the city, at any time before the object of such notice, paper or document has been accomplished. 
B.  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in SMC 1.12.010. 
(1962 Code § 25.070.) (Ord. 2340, Amended, 09/25/2006) 
Section 9.45.050 - Trespass on land, in building of another after warning-Warning by posting, fencing. 
A.  Every person who shall go upon the land or into any building of another with intent to vex or annoy the owner or occupant thereof, or to commit any unlawful act, or shall willfully go or remain upon any land or in any building after having been warned by the owner or occupant thereof not to trespass, is guilty of a misdemeanor. The meaning of this subsection is not limited by paragraphs B and D of this section. 
B.  Every owner or other occupant of any land shall be deemed to have given a sufficient warning against trespassing, within the meaning of this section, who posts in a conspicuous manner on each side thereof, upon or near the boundary, at intervals of not more than seven hundred feet, signs, legibly printed or painted in the English language, warning persons not to trespass, or fences the area. 
C.  It is prima facie evidence of trespass for any person to be found on private or public property which is posted or fenced as provided in subsection B of this section without lawful business with the owner or occupant of the property. 
D.  An entryman on land under the laws of the United States shall be an owner within the meaning of this section. 
E.  As used in this section, "fence" means a barrier sufficient to indicate an intent to restrict the area to human ingress, including, but not limited to, a wall, hedge or chain-link or wire-mesh fence. 
(Ord. 1193 § 1, 1978: Ord. 1001 § 1, 1975.) 
Chapter 9.48 - CAMPING PROHIBITED ON PUBLIC PROPERTY IN THE TRUCKEE RIVER CORRIDOR 
Sections: 

Section 9.48.010 - Preamble. 
A.  The Truckee River runs from the outlet of Lake Tahoe, through Truckee, City of Reno and through Sparks on its way to Pyramid Lake, and is an important natural resource shared by our city and surrounding communities. 
B.  The Truckee River watershed includes all of the land draining into the river, either directly, through our urban storm water system, or into creeks which feed the Truckee River. 
C.  Once a thriving, wild waterway, the Truckee has been highly degraded over the past century. 
D.  Proper management of the Truckee River, which provides 85 percent of the water delivered in the Truckee Meadows, is vital to sustaining a healthy community. 
E.  Unregulated camping in and around the Truckee River threatens to pollute the area's primary source of drinking water, and detracts from the scenic beauty of the river. 
F.  Limited regulation of camping within the Truckee River Corridor is reasonably necessary to protect and enhance water quality or water resources of the Truckee River and appropriately balances the public interest and individual rights. 
(Ord. 2522, § 1, Add, 3/28/2016) 
Section 9.48.020 - Definitions. 
A.  The following words, terms and phrases, whenever used in this code, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section unless from the context a different meaning is intended or unless a different meaning is specifically defined for such words, terms or phrases. 
1.  "To camp" or "camping" means to use real property of the city for overnight living accommodation purposes. 
2.  "Overnight" is defined as the period from one-half hour after sunset to sunrise. 
(Ord. 2522, § 2, Add, 3/28/2016) 
Section 9.48.030 - Unlawful to camp on public property-General provisions. 
A.  Unless a permit is obtained in accordance with an applicable provision of the Sparks Municipal Code, it shall be unlawful to camp on public property within 350 feet of the shore of the Truckee River within city limits (the "Truckee River Corridor"). For purposes of this section, camping shall include: 
1.  Sleeping activities or making preparations to sleep including the laying down of bedding for the purpose of sleeping; 
2.  Storing personal belongings; 
3.  Making any fire, other than in a fire or barbeque pit provided by the city or an area designated for such use by the city; 
4.  Using any tent, shelter, other structure or vehicle for sleeping; or 
5.  Cooking, other than in a fire or barbeque pit provided by the city or an area designated for such use by the city. 
B.  The above listed activities constitute camping when it reasonably appears in light of all the circumstances that the participant, in conducting these activities is in fact using the area for overnight living accommodation purposes, regardless of the intent of the participant or the nature of any other activities in which they may also be engaging. 
C.  The prohibition in subsection (b) shall not apply to any person: 
1.  Sitting or lying down on public property due to a medical emergency; 
2.  Operating or patronizing a commercial establishment conducted on the public property pursuant to an applicable permit; 
3.  Participating in or attending a parade, festival, performance, rally, demonstration, meeting, or similar event conducted on public property pursuant to an applicable permit. 
D.  No person shall be charged with a violation of this section unless the person engages in conduct prohibited by this section after having been notified by a law enforcement officer that the conduct violates this section. 
E.  The provisions of this section are declared to be separate and severable. The invalidity of any clause, sentence, paragraph, subdivision, section or portion of this section, or the invalidity of the application thereof to any person or circumstance shall not affect the validity of the remainder of this section, or the validity of its application to other persons or circumstances. 
F.  Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 2522, § 3, Add, 3/28/2016) 
Chapter 9.51 - USE OR POSSESSION OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES BY MINORS 
Sections: 

Section 9.51.005 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  "Alcoholic beverage" has the meaning ascribed to it in Section 5.28.010. 
B.  "In a public place" includes: 
1.  In, upon or about a motor vehicle while on or about any highway, street, road, trail or other area to which the public has access. 
2.  In any place open to the public. 
3.  In any private business establishment which is in effect open to the public. 
C.  "Impaired" or "Impairment" is defined as exhibiting observable signs or symptoms commonly associated with the consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
D.  "Motor vehicle" means every vehicle which is self-propelled, except devices which are moved by human power or operated exclusively on stationary rails. 
(Ord. 2103, Add, 05/29/2001) 
Section 9.51.010 - Unlawful possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages; unlawful impairment. 
A.  Except as provided in subsection B: 
1.  It is unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to consume or have any alcoholic beverage in his custody or possession in a public place. 
2.  It is unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to be in a public place while impaired to any degree by the use of an alcoholic beverage. 
B.  Unlawful possession or consumption does not include: 
1.  Possession or reasonable consumption for an established religious purpose. 
2.  Possession or reasonable consumption in the presence of the person's parents, spouse or legal guardian who is at least 21 years of age or older, when not in a public place. 
3.  Possession or consumption in accordance with a prescription issued by a person statutorily authorized to issue prescriptions. 
4.  The selling, handling, serving or transporting of alcoholic beverages by a person in the course of his lawful employment by a licensed manufacturer, wholesaler or retailer of alcoholic beverages. 
(1962 Code § 25.125.) (Ord. 2103, Amended, 05/29/2001) 
Section 9.51.020 - Supplying alcoholic beverages to minors prohibited-exceptions. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person, other than a parent, guardian or physician, to sell, deliver, give away or otherwise furnish any alcoholic beverage to any person under the age of 21 years, or to leave or deposit any such alcoholic beverage in any place with the intent that the same shall be procured by any person under the age of 21 years. 
B.  It is unlawful for any parent, guardian or other person having legal care, custody and control of any person under the age of 21 years to allow any such underaged person to have in his possession in any public place any alcoholic beverage. 
C.  Except as provided in subsection D, in any criminal prosecution based upon the violation of subsection A, proof that the defendant demanded and was shown, immediately before furnishing any alcoholic beverage to a person under the age of 21 years, bona fide documentary evidence of the age and identity of the person issued by a federal, state, county or municipal government, or subdivision or agency thereof, including, but not limited to, an operator's license for a motor vehicle, a registration certificate issued under the Federal Selective Service Act, or an identification card issued to a member of the Armed Forces, is a defense to the prosecution. 
D.  Proof of being shown documentary evidence of the age and identity of a person under the age of 21 pursuant to subsection C is not a defense to a criminal prosecution for a violation of subsection A if: 
1.  The document which was shown to the person who sold, gave or otherwise furnished the alcoholic beverage was counterfeit, forged or altered, or was issued to a person other than the person to whom the alcoholic beverage was sold, given or otherwise furnished; and 
2.  Under the circumstances, a reasonable person would have known that the document was counterfeit, forged or altered, or was issued to a person other than the person to whom the alcoholic beverage was sold, given or otherwise furnished. 
(Ord. 1616 § 1, 1988: 1962 Code § 25.130.) (Ord. 2429, Amended, 08/24/2009; Ord. 2103, Amended, 05/29/2001) 
Section 9.51.030 - Purchase or consumption of alcoholic beverages in licensed establishments. 
    It is unlawful: 
A.  For any person under the age of twenty-one years to purchase or consume any alcoholic beverage in any establishment licensed under the provisions of Chapter 5.28 of this code; 
B.  For any parent or guardian of a person under the age of twenty-one years to permit such person to purchase or consume any alcoholic beverage in any establishment licensed under the provisions of such sections. 
(1962 Code § 25.135.) 
Section 9.51.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(Ord. 2103, Add, 05/29/2001) 
Chapter 9.54 - CERTAIN PLACES OR ACTIVITIES PROHIBITED TO MINORS 
Sections: 

Section 9.54.005 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. 
    "Dining area" means a place which is regularly and in a bona fide manner used and kept open for the serving of food to guests for compensation: 
A.  Which has suitable kitchen facilities connected therewith which are authorized by a permit issued by the Washoe County Health Department - District Board of Health; 
B.  In which alcoholic beverages and food prepared on the premises are served at separate tables or booths and are not served over a bar or counter; and 
C.  In which alcoholic beverages and food prepared on the premises are served separately or in combination. 
(Ord. 2446, Add, 11/22/2010) 
Section 9.54.010 - Underage persons; unlawful to be in establishments that serve alcoholic beverages; exceptions. 
A.  Bars with no dining area. Any person under 21 years of age who is found within an establishment that serves alcoholic beverages but does not have a dining area is guilty of a misdemeanor. This subsection does not apply to persons lawfully employed by the establishment to sell or serve alcoholic beverages. 
B.  Bars having a dining area. Any person under 21 years of age who is found within six feet of any bar on the premises of any establishment that serves alcoholic beverages and has a dining area is guilty of a misdemeanor. This subsection does not apply to persons employed by the establishment to sell or serve alcoholic beverages. 
C.  Use of dining area by underaged persons. Persons under 21 years of age may be present within a dining area of an establishment wherein alcoholic beverages and food are served separately or in combination and where dining tables or booths are provided and separated from every bar by no less than six feet; 
D.  Grocery stores and drugstores. Persons under 21 years of age may be present in any grocery store or drugstore where alcoholic beverages are not sold by the drink for consumption on the premises. 
(Ord. 1, 630 § 1, 1966: 1962 Code § 25.136.) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010) 
Section 9.54.015 - Unlawful for licensee, agents or employees to allow underaged persons to be present in an establishment where alcoholic beverages are sold or served; exceptions. 
A.  Bars with no dining area. It is unlawful for any licensee, agent or employee of an establishment where alcoholic beverages are sold or served that does not have a dining area to allow or permit any person under the age of 21 years to remain on the premises. Nothing in this subsection prohibits the presence of persons under the age of 21 years of age who are employed by the establishment to sell or serve alcoholic beverages. 
B.  Bars having a dining area. It is unlawful for any licensee, agent or employee of an establishment where alcoholic beverages are sold or served that has a dining area to allow or permit any person under the age of 21 years to be within six feet of any bar on the premises. Nothing in this subsection prohibits persons employed by the establishment to sell or serve alcoholic beverages from being within six feet of any bar on the premises. 
C.  Use of dining area by underaged persons. Persons under 21 years of age may be present within a dining area of an establishment wherein alcoholic beverages are served separately or in combination with food and where dining tables or booths are provided and separated from every bar by no less than six feet. 
D.  Grocery stores and drugstores. Persons under 21 years of age may be present in any grocery store or drugstore where alcoholic beverages are not sold by the drink for consumption on the premises. 
(Ord. 1127 § 1, 1977.) (Ord. 2446, Amended, 11/22/2010) 
Section 9.54.020 - Billiard and pool rooms. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person owning or conducting a licensed billiard or pool room to allow any person under the age of fifteen years to visit, frequent or remain in or about such room, or to play at billiards or pool therein, without having written consent of the parent or guardian of such minor. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person under the age of fifteen years, for the purpose of resorting to or frequenting any licensed billiard or pool room, to represent himself to be fifteen years of age or over. 
(Ord. 705 § 1, 1968: 1962 Code § 25.140.) 
Section 9.54.030 - Unlawful gambling. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one years to play any gambling game or device, as defined in Section 5.24.010 of this code, or any slot machine, or to loiter about any gambling game, excluding slot machines. 
B.  It is unlawful for any parent, guardian or other person having the charge, care, custody or control of any person under the age of twenty-one years to allow such person to play any gambling game or device, as defined in Section 5.24.010, or any slot machine, or to loiter about any room or premises where any such game or device, excluding slot machines, is operated or conducted. 
(1962 Code § 25.150.) 
Chapter 9.55 - GRAFFITI 
Sections: 

Section 9.55.010 - Legislative findings and declaration. 
    The City Council hereby makes the following findings and declares as a matter of public policy: 
A.  The increasing incidents of the defacement of public and private property through the application of graffiti upon walls, rocks, bridges, buildings, fences, gates, other structures, trees and other real and personal property within the corporate boundaries of the City promotes the organization of gangs and constitutes a blight on this community, and, in the interests of the health, safety and general welfare of the residents and taxpayers of the City, immediate steps must be taken to halt the spread of this blight. 
B.  The Sparks Police Department is aware of reports that such defacement of property is most often committed by persons under the age of 18 years using aerosol containers of spray paint and broad-tipped indelible markers. 
C.  When any such person has a legitimate need for such aerosol containers and markers, the same may be obtained and furnished by a parent or guardian. 
D.  Such aerosol containers and markers are frequently stolen from retail stores by minors. 
E.  The sale of such aerosol containers and broad-tipped markers to minors should therefore be prohibited, and persons who are engaged in the retail sale of such aerosol containers and markers should be required to take reasonable steps to prevent the theft of such aerosol containers and markers. 
F.  When appropriate, the court should require those who commit acts of defacement of public or private property through the application of graffiti to restore the property so defaced, damaged or destroyed. 
G.  Obtaining convictions for the application of graffiti is difficult due to the fact that the offense can be committed quickly and secretively, and that witnesses to the act are frequently nonexistent. 
H.  Members of the public should be encouraged, through the promise of a reward, to cooperate in the elimination of graffiti by reporting to the proper authorities any incidents of the application of graffiti which they observe. 
(Ord. 2199, Add, 11/24/2003) 
Section 9.55.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and terms have the following meanings: 
A.  "Broad-tipped marker" means any indelibile marker or similar implement with a tip which, at its broadest width, is greater than 1/4 inch. 
B.  "Graffiti" means any unauthorized markings, such as initials, slogans, inscriptions, figures, marks or drawings, whether written, spray-painted, etched or sketched, placed on any sidewalk, wall, building, fence, sign, or any other public or private property. 
C.  "Graffiti materials" means an aerosol paint container, a broad-tipped marker, gum label, paint stick or graffiti stick, etching equipment, brush, adhesive label, and engraving device or any other device capable of leaving a visible mark on a natural or man-made surface. 
D.  "Minor" means a person under 18 years of age. 
E.  "Paint stick" means a device containing a solid form of paint, chalk, wax, epoxy, or other similar non-water soluble substance, which is capable of being applied to a surface by pressure, and upon application, can leave a mark of at least one-fourth of an inch in width. 
F.  "Responsible adult" means a parent, legal guardian or person having custody and control of a minor. 
(Ord. 2199, Add, 11/24/2003) 
Section 9.55.030 - Unlawful to place graffiti on public or private property. 
    It is unlawful for any person to apply graffiti to any building, fence, wall, rock, bridge, gate, tree or landscaping, or other real or personal property, either publicly or privately owned, without the permission of the owner or operator of such property. 
(Ord. 2199, Add, 11/24/2003) 
Section 9.55.040 - Unlawful for minor to possess graffiti materials; exception. 
    It is unlawful for any minor to possess any graffiti materials, unless: 
A.  A responsible adult has first consented; or 
B.  Possession is necessary for school-related purposes on property used by a school, school district, community college or university. 
(Ord. 2199, Add, 11/24/2003) 
Section 9.55.050 - Unlawful for adults and minors to possess graffiti materials with the intent to place graffiti on public or private property. 
    It is unlawful for any adult or minor to possess graffiti materials with the intent to place graffiti on public or private property while in, upon or in close proximity to such property, unless authorized by the City or the owner of the property. 
(Ord. 2199, Add, 11/24/2003) 
Section 9.55.060 - Unlawful to sell or otherwise furnish graffiti materials to minor; exception.
