A.  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
B.  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
C.  The provisions of this section do not apply under the conditions provided in Section 10.32.060 when pedestrians are prohibited from crossing at certain designated places. 
D.  No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. 
(Ord. 1468 § 5, 1984: Ord. 713 § 122, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.376.) 
Section 10.32.060 - Prohibited crossings. 
    Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk. 
(Ord. 713 § 123, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.380.) 
Section 10.32.070 - Walking along roadways. 
A.  Where sidewalks are provided, it is unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
B.  Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction. 
(Ord. 713 § 124, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.382.) 
Section 10.32.090 - Driver to exercise due care. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of this title, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Ord. 713 § 126, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.386.) 
Chapter 10.36 - TURNING MOVEMENTS-STARTING-SIGNALS 
Sections: 

Section 10.36.010 - Required position and method of turning at intersections. 
    The driver of a vehicle intending to turn at an intersection shall do so as follows: 
A.  Right Turns. both the approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as close as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway. 
B.  Left Turns on Two-way Roadways. At any intersection where traffic is permitted to move in both directions on each roadway entering the intersection, an approach for a left turn shall be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the centerline thereof and by passing to the right of such centerline where it enters the Intersection and after entering the intersection the left turn shall be made so as to leave the intersection to the right of the centerline of the roadway being entered. Whenever practicable the left turn shall be made in that portion of the intersection to the left of the center of the intersection. 
C.  Left Turns on Other Than Two-way Roadways. At any intersection where traffic is restricted to one direction on one or more of the roadways, the driver of a vehicle intending to turn left at any such intersection shall approach the intersection in the extreme left-hand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the direction of travel of such vehicle, and after entering the intersection, the left turn shall be made so as to leave the intersection, as nearly as practicable, in the left-hand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in such direction upon the roadway being entered. 
(Ord. 713 § 87, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.268.) 
Section 10.36.020 - Authority to place and obedience to turning markers. 
A.  The public works director may place markers, buttons or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections, and such course to be traveled as so indicated may conform to or be other than as prescribed by law or ordinance. 
B.  When authorized markers, buttons or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle may disobey the directions of such indications. 
(Ord. 713 § 88, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.272.) 
Section 10.36.030 - Signals on starting, stopping or turning. 
A.  The driver of any vehicle upon a highway before starting, stopping or turning from a direct line shall first see that such movement can be made in safety, and if any pedestrian may be affected by such movement shall give a clearly audible signal by sounding the horn, and whenever the operation of any other vehicle may be affected by such movement shall give a signal as required in Section 10.36.040, plainly visible to the driver of such other vehicle of the intention to make such a movement. 
B.  The signal required in Section 10.36.040 shall be given either by means of the hand and arm in the manner therein specified or by an approved mechanical or electrical signal device, except that when a vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent the hand and arm signal from being visible both to the front and rear, the signal shall be given by a device of a type which has been approved by the department. 
(Ord. 713 § 89, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.275.) 
Section 10.36.040 - Method of giving signals. 
A.  All signals herein required given by hand and arm shall be given from the left side of a vehicle in the following manner and such signals shall indicate as follows: 
1.  Left Turn. Hand and arm extended horizontally beyond the side of the vehicle; 
2.  Right Turn. Hand and arm extended upward beyond the side of the vehicle; 
3.  Stop or Sudden Decrease of Speed Signal. Hand and arm extended downward beyond the side of the vehicle. 
B.  If it is a closed vehicle, the signals must be given by a proper signaling device indicating the same signals as required by the hand and arm, or by signal lamps of an approved type. 
C.  Any signal of intention to turn right or left shall be given continuously during the last one hundred feet traveled by the vehicle before turning. 
(Ord. 766 § 1, 1969: Ord. 713 § 90, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.278.) 
Section 10.36.050 - U-turns and certain left turns. 
A.  The driver of a vehicle shall not make a U-turn upon any street in a business district except where permitted by an official traffic-control device. 
B.  The driver of a vehicle shall not make a U-turn at any intersection controlled by an official traffic-control device except where permitted by an official traffic-control device. 
C.  A U-turn may be made on any street where such turn can be made with safety, except as prohibited by this section or any other provision of this title. An unsafe U-turn shall be unlawful. 
D.  Whenever any street has been divided by an intervening space, a physical barrier or other dividing indicator: every vehicle shall be driven to the right of such divider and shall not be driven over or within any such divider; and no vehicle shall make any left turn, semicircular turn, or U-turn except through an official opening or crossover to such divider or at an intersection, as permitted by this section, or this title, or an official traffic-control device. 
(Ord. 1468 § 6, 1984: Ord. 149 § 2, 1979: Ord. 713 § 91, 1968: 1962, Code § 35.283.) 
Chapter 10.40 - SPEED RESTRICTIONS 
Sections: 

Section 10.40.010 - Speed restrictions. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate a vehicle of any kind or character at a rate of speed greater than that posted by a public authority for the particular portion of street or highway being traversed. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate a vehicle of any kind or character at a rate of speed greater than Twenty-Five (25) Miles per hour upon any street or highway except as otherwise provided in this title. 
C.  It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate a vehicle of any kind or character at a rate of speed greater than posted by a public authority in a designated school zone that has been clearly marked as such. 
D.  It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate a vehicle of any kind or character at a rate of speed greater than Fifteen (15) Miles per hour in any public park within the City. 
E.  It is unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle upon a street or highway in the City at such a slow speed as to impede or block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic, except when reduced speed is necessary for safe operation or because the vehicle is traveling upon a grade. 
(Ord. 1270 § 1, 1980: Ord. 1104 § 1, 1977: Ord. 781 § 1, 1969: Ord. 713 § 82, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.251.) (Ord. 2443, Repealed and Replaced, 09/27/2010) 
Section 10.40.040 - When speed limit not applicable. 
    The speed limits set forth in this title do not apply to authorized emergency vehicles when driven in response to an emergency call or in pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law, and the drivers thereof sound audible signal by bell, siren or exhaust whistle. This section does not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of persons using the street, nor shall it protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequence of a reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Ord. 713 § 85, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.260.) 
Section 10.40.050 - Regulation of speed by traffic signals. 
    The public works director is authorized to regulate the timing of traffic signals so as to permit the movement of traffic in an orderly and safe manner at speeds slightly at variance from the speeds otherwise applicable within the city or at intersections and shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(Ord. 713 § 86, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.263.) 
Section 10.40.060 - Duty of driver to decrease speed under certain circumstances. 
    The fact that the speed of a vehicle is lower than the prescribed limits does not relieve a driver from the duty to decrease speed when approaching and crossing an intersection, when approaching and going around a curve, when approaching a hill crest, when traveling upon any narrow or winding highway, or when special hazards exist or may exist with respect to pedestrians or other traffic, or by reason of weather or other highway conditions, and speed shall be decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding with or endangering any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering a highway in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(Ord. 1249 § 3, 1979.) 
Chapter 10.44 - RECKLESS AND CARELESS DRIVING-DRIVING WHILE INTOXICATED 
Sections: 

Section 10.44.040 - Reckless driving. 
    It is unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle on a street, highway, alley, or premises to which the public has access within the city in willful or wanton disregard of the safety of persons or property. 
(Ord. 1409 § 8, 1983: Ord. 713 § 112, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.353.) 
Section 10.44.050 - Careless driving. 
    It is unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle on a street, highway, alley or premises to which the public has access in the city in a careless manner; or in other than a careful and prudent manner; or at a rate of speed greater than is reasonable and proper, having due regard for the traffic on and the surface and width of the street or highway; or at such a rate of speed as to endanger the life, limb or property of any person; provided, that the speed of vehicle shall not exceed that provided for in this title; and provided further that the mere fact that a vehicle is operated within the speed restriction contained in this title will not constitute prima facie evidence that the vehicle was operated in a lawful manner. 
(Ord. 1409 § 9, 1983: Ord. 713 § 113, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.355.) 
Chapter 10.48 - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[5] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- For statutory provisions authorizing local authorities to restrict the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles on highways controlled by them, see NRS 484.399, 484.403, 484.441. 

Section 10.48.010 - Application of title. 
A.  The provisions of this title prohibiting the stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times herein specified, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
B.  The provisions of this title imposing a time limit on standing or parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions of this title or of any other ordinance of the city or statute of the state prohibiting or limiting the standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Ord. 713 § 127, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.389.) 
Section 10.48.020 - General prohibitions. 
    It is unlawful for the driver of a vehicle or for the owner of a vehicle to permit the driver thereof to stop, stand or park such vehicle, whether attended or unattended, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control signal, in any of the following places: 
A.  Within an intersection; 
B.  On a crosswalk; 
C.  On a sidewalk; 
D.  Within fifteen feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station; 
E.  Within fifteen feet of a fire hydrant; 
F.  In front of a private driveway; 
G.  Alongside or opposite any street or highway excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
H.  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of any street or highway; 
I.  In any line of traffic so as to obstruct such traffic; 
J.  Between the curb or edge of roadway and property line; 
K.  Within five feet of an intersection of two streets; 
L.  Within three feet of an intersection of a street and an alley; 
M.  At any curb which is marked by signs or red paint; 
N.  Alongside any portion of a curb return or that curved section of a curb on a corner which connects the curb lines of intersecting streets. 
(Ord. 1464 § 1, 1984: Ord. 751 § 1, 1969: Ord. 713 § 128, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.391.) 
Section 10.48.030 - Parking of oversized vehicles. 
A.  Within areas designated as commercial or residential districts by the city council, it is unlawful for the owner or driver of any vehicle, trailer or vehicle and trailer having an overall length of more than twenty-four feet to stand or park the same at any time on any public street, highway or alley, except immediately in front of the property of the owner or driver thereof, while goods or passengers are being loaded or discharged. In the case of recreational vehicles, trailers and boats, a forty-eight hour period will be allowed for loading and unloading provided all vehicle and traffic regulations are otherwise complied with. 
B.  It is unlawful for the owner or an agent of the owner of any commercial trailer or semi-trailer, which is not attached to a tractor or other motor vehicle, to cause or allow the same to be parked on a public street, highway, alley or parking lot. 
(Ord. 1691, 1991: Ord. 1457 § 1, 1984: Ord 713 § 129, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.392.) 
Section 10.48.035 - Parking of trucks or commercial vehicles in residential districts. 
    It is unlawful for any person to stand or park any truck or commercial vehicle in excess of four thousand pounds per axle unladen weight, to a maximum of twelve thousand pounds, unladen weight, in any residential district except when actually and expeditiously engaged in the loading or unloading of merchandise or when such vehicle is being used in conjunction with the performance of service, repair, construction or similar essential use within the immediate area. 
(Ord. 1646 § 1, 1989: Ord. 1617 § 1,1988.) 
Section 10.48.040 - Parking gasoline trucks. 
    It is unlawful for the driver of any vehicle or of any vehicle and trailer or semitrailer containing more than two thousand gallons of gasoline to stop, stand or park such vehicle, trailer or semitrailer on any street, highway or alley for any purpose except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control signal. 
(Ord. 713 § 130, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.394.) 
Section 10.48.050 - Parking to load gasoline. 
    It is unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to stand or park the same upon any street, highway or alley for the purpose of introducing gasoline or other petroleum product into such vehicle and it is unlawful for any person to introduce gasoline or other petroleum product into any vehicle while the same is standing or parked upon any street, highway or alley; provided, however, that it is lawful to so introduce gasoline or other fuel into a vehicle from a container not exceeding one gallon in capacity if the fuel supply in such vehicle has become exhausted. 
(Ord. 713 § 131, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.395.) 
Section 10.48.060 - Use of public parking lots. 
A.  For purposes of this section the term "public parking lot" means off-street parking spaces available for use by the general public and owned by the city, county, Redevelopment Agency of the city, Regional Transportation Commission or Reno-Sparks Convention Authority. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to dwell or sleep in a vehicle or otherwise on a public parking lot. 
C.  It is unlawful for any person to stand or park a vehicle on a public parking lot in an area not designated by striping or an official traffic control device as a parking space or so as to be on or overlap any line or stripe designating a parking space. 
(Ord. 1464 § 2, 1984: Ord. 855 § 1, 1971: Ord. 713 § 132, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.397.) 
Section 10.48.070 - Overtime parking. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to park a vehicle or non-commercial trailer on a street, highway or alley for a period longer than forty-eight hours or longer than is designated by an official traffic control device regulating the area. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to park a vehicle or non-commercial trailer on a public parking lot for a period longer than twenty-four hours or longer than is designated by an official traffic control device regulating the area. 
(Ord. 1691, 1991: Ord. 1464 § 3, 1984: Ord. 713 § 133, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.398.) 
Section 10.48.080 - Method of parking. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of traffic and with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle within eighteen inches of the curb line or edge of the roadway, except on one-way streets where the wheels of either side of the vehicle shall be within eighteen inches of the curb line or edge of the roadway. 
B.  It is unlawful to park any vehicle so as to be on or overlap any parking line which is marked upon the surface of any street or highway for the purpose of designating a parking space; provided, however, that it is lawful to back a vehicle to the curb only for such time as shall be necessary to load or unload merchandise or material and then only if ample space is left in the roadway for one lane of traffic to pass such a vehicle. 
(Ord. 713 § 134, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.400.) 
Section 10.48.090 - Parking in alleys. 
    No person shall: 
A.  Park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic; 
B.  Stop, stand or park a vehicle within any alley in such position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property; 
C.  Park on the left side of any designated one-way traffic movement alley. 
(Ord. 713 § 135, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.401.) 
Section 10.48.100 - No parking areas. 
    It is unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park a vehicle in an area designated as a fire or no parking zone either by red paint placed and maintained upon the entire curb surface or by an official traffic control device, except that a bus may stop in such a no parking zone when the same has been authorized to be and has been marked or signed as a bus stop. 
(Ord. 1464 § 4, 1984: Ord. 713 § 136, 1968: 1962 § 35.403.) 
Section 10.48.110 - Stopping for loading or unloading only. 
    When an area is regulated by an official traffic control device designating the area as a loading zone or marked by yellow paint placed and maintained upon the entire curb surface, it is unlawful for any person to stop or stand a vehicle except for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or materials; provided that the loading or unloading of passengers shall not consume more than three minutes and that the unloading or loading of materials shall not consume more than twenty minutes, unless permission is obtained from the department authorizing the standing of a vehicle for a longer period while unloading or loading materials: provided, however, that where a proper sign is erected in front of a hotel or motel, the time for loading or unloading of passengers and their luggage shall not consume more than ten minutes. 
    The loading or unloading of materials applies only to commercial deliveries and to the delivery or pickup of express and parcel post packages and United States mail. The loading or unloading of passengers shall include the loading or unloading of personal baggage. 
(Ord. 1464 § 5, 1984: Ord. 713 § 137, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.406.) 
Section 10.48.120 - Where angle parking is permitted. 
A.  The chief of police and the public works director, subject to the approval of the city council, shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted and cause such streets to be marked or signed. 
B.  Angle parking shall not be permitted upon any federal-aid or state highway unless the State Department of Highways approves by written notice. 
C.  Angle parking shall not be permitted at any place where passing traffic would thereby be required to drive upon the left side of the street. 
D.  Upon streets which have been signed or marked for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the Angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs markings. 
(Ord. 713 § 138, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.409.) 
Section 10.48.130 - Parking on the left side of the street. 
    No person riding, driving, propelling or in charge of any vehicle shall stop the same upon any street of this city with the left side of such vehicle toward or along the curb, except on one-way streets. 
(Ord. 713 § 139, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.412.) 
Section 10.48.140 - Limited and regulated parking areas. 
    It is unlawful for any person to park, stand or stop a vehicle on any street, highway, alley or public parking lot in violation of an official traffic control device regulating the method or hours of parking. 
(Ord. 1464 § 6, 1984: Ord. 713 § 140, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.415.) 
Section 10.48.150 - Public carrier stands. 
A.  The city council shall establish bus stops, taxicab stands and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets and in such places and number as it determines to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public. Every such bus stop, taxicab stand or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
B.  No driver of a bus or taxicab shall park upon any street in any business or other district at any place other than at a bus stop or taxicab stand, respectively, except for temporary stops in accordance with other stopping and parking regulations while engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
C.  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may stop therein while engaged in loading or unloading passengers if such stop does not interfere with any bus or taxicab entering such zone. 
(Ord. 713 § 141, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.418.) 
Section 10.48.160 - Municipal vehicle parking. 
    The city council may designate a space to be reserved for the parking of municipal vehicles, and it is unlawful to park any vehicle other than a municipal vehicle in such space. 
(Ord. 713 § 142, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.421.) 
Section 10.48.170 - Presumption of unlawful standing or parking. 
    In any prosecution charging a violation of any provision of this title governing the standing or parking of vehicles, proof that the vehicle described in the complaint was standing or parked in violation of any such provision and that the defendant named in the complaint was, at the time of such standing or parking, the registered owner of such vehicle, creates a rebuttable presumption that the defendant was the person who parked or placed the vehicle where and for the time during which the violation occurred. 
(Ord. 713 § 143, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.424.) 
Section 10.48.180 - Locking persons in parked vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for any person to leave standing or parked any vehicle when the doors of the same are locked in which there is a person or persons who cannot readily escape therefrom. 
(Ord. 713 § 144, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.427.) 
Section 10.48.190 - Parking peddlers' or vendors' vehicles. 
A.  No person may stand or park any vehicle, wagon or pushcart from which goods, wares, merchandise, fruits, vegetables or foodstuffs are sold, displayed, solicited or offered for sale or bartered or exchanged, or any lunch wagon or eating car or vehicle, on any portion of any street, highway or alley within the city without permission from the city council. The provisions of this subsection do not apply to persons delivering such articles from a store or other fixed place of business or distribution upon order of, or by agreement with, a customer. 
B.  In the event that the city council grants a permit to stand or park a vehicle, wagon or pushcart from which goods, wares, merchandise, fruits, vegetables or foodstuffs are sold, displayed, solicited or offered for sale or bartered or exchanged, such permission shall designate the specific location in which a cart or vehicle shall stand and the period of time during which it may stand. 
(Ord. 713 § 145, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.430.) 
Section 10.48.200 - Emergency parking signs. 
A.  Whenever the public works director determines that an emergency traffic congestion is likely to result from the holding of public or private assemblages, gatherings or functions, or for other reasons, including construction and maintenance operations which interfere with normal flow of traffic, the public works director may order temporary signs to be erected or posted indicating that the operation, parking or standing of vehicles is prohibited on such streets, highways or alleys as the public works director shall direct during any time such temporary signs are in place. Such signs shall remain in place during the existence of such emergency and the public works director shall cause such signs to be removed promptly thereafter. 
B.  When signs authorized by the provisions of this section are in place, it is unlawful for any person to operate, park or stand any vehicle contrary to the directions and provisions of such signs. 
(Ord. 713 § 147, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.439.) 
Section 10.48.210 - Preferential parking rights. 
    Whenever a space is vacant next to a curb, sufficient only for the parking of one vehicle, and any vehicle has been stopped in the line of traffic for the purpose of backing into the space, such vehicle shall have the preferential right to such parking space over any following vehicle. 
(Ord. 713 § 148, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.442.) 
Section 10.48.220 - Lamps on parked vehicles. 
A.  Whenever a vehicle is lawfully parked upon a street or highway during the hours between a half hour after sunset and a half hour before sunrise and in the event there is sufficient light to reveal any person or object within a distance of five hundred feet upon such street or highway, no lights need be displayed upon such parked vehicle. 
B.  Whenever a vehicle is parked or stopped upon a roadway or shoulder adjacent thereto, whether attended or unattended during the hours between a half hour after sunset and a half hour before sunrise and there is not sufficient light to reveal any person or object within a distance of five hundred feet upon such highway, such vehicle so parked or stopped shall be equipped with one or more lamps meeting the following requirements: At least one lamp shall display a white or amber light visible from a distance of five hundred feet to the front of the vehicle, and the same lamp or at least one other lamp shall display a red light visible from a distance of five hundred feet to the rear of the vehicle, and the location of the lamp or lamps shall always be such that at least one lamp or combination of lamps meeting the requirements of this section is installed as near as practicable to the side of the vehicle which is closest to passing traffic. The foregoing provisions shall not apply to a motor-driven cycle. 
C.  Any lighted headlamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or dimmed. 
(Ord. 713 § 149, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.445.) 
Section 10.48.230 - Standing or parking on one-way roadways. 
    If a street or highway includes two or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction upon any such roadway, no person may stand or park a vehicle upon the left-hand side of such one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. The public works director may determine when standing or parking is permitted upon the left-hand side of any such one-way roadway and may erect signs giving notice thereof. 
(Ord. 713 § 150, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.448.) 
Section 10.48.240 - Handicapped parking spaces. 
A.  Any parking space designated for the handicapped must be indicated by a sign: 
1.  Bearing the international symbol of accessibility with or without the word "Parking," "Handicapped Parking," "Handicapped Parking Only, " or "Reserved for the Handicapped," or any other word or combination of words indicating that the space is designated for the handicapped; and 
2.  Stating "Minimum Fine of $250 for use by others" or equivalent words. 
3.  The bottom of which must not be less than seven feet above the ground. 
B.  A person shall not park a vehicle in a space designated for the handicapped by a sign that meets the requirements of subsection A, whether on public or privately owned property, unless he is eligible to do so and the vehicle displays: 
1.  Special license plates issued pursuant to NRS 482.384; 
2.  A special or temporary parking placard issued pursuant to NRS 482.384; 
3.  Special license plates or a special or temporary parking placard displaying the international symbol of access issued by another state or foreign country; or 
4.  Special license plates for a disabled veteran and a special parking placard issued pursuant to NRS 482.384. 
C.  A person shall not use such a plate, permit or emblem for a vehicle for the purpose of parking unless he is a person with a disability which limits or impairs the ability to walk, a disabled veteran or is the driver of a vehicle in which such person is a passenger. 
D.  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be punished: 
1.  Upon the first offense, by a fine of $250; 
2.  Upon the second offense, by a fine of $250, and not less than 8 hours, but not more than 50 hours, of community service; 
3.  Upon the third or subsequent offense, by a fine of not less than $500 but not more than $1,000, and not less than 25 hours, but not more than 100 hours, of community service. 
(Ord. 1529 § 1, 1985: Ord. 1351 § 1, 1982.) (Ord. 2356, Amended, 01/22/2007; 1962, Amended, 12/08/1997) 
Chapter 10.50 - SNOW ROUTES 
Sections: 

Section 10.50.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: 
    "Snow emergency" means actual or forecasted weather conditions which require the absence of parked vehicles and other obstructions on snow routes to facilitate plowing and traffic flow. 
    "Snow routes" means those streets generally traversing the entire city or a major part thereof, and are considered essential to the rapid movement of emergency vehicles and normally carry the heaviest traffic volumes. 
    "Snow route priority" means a numerical system for ranking designated snow routes in two service levels: Primary and secondary access routes. 
(Ord. 1804, 1993: Ord. 1684, 1991.) (Ord. 2411, Amended, 10/13/2008) 
Section 10.50.020 - Declaration of snow emergency. 
A.  Whenever the director of public works finds, on the basis of falling snow, sleet or freezing rain, or on the basis of a forecast by the United States Weather Bureau or other meteorological data indicating the threat of snow, sleet or freezing rain, that weather conditions could severely impede vehicular traffic in the city, the director of public works shall declare a snow emergency. 
B.  A snow emergency shall automatically go into effect on any part of any snow route on which there has been an accumulation of snow or ice of six inches or more. 
C.  The public works director shall cause each declaration of a snow emergency to be publicly announced by means of broadcasts or telecasts from stations with a normal operating range covering the city, and may cause such declaration to be further announced in newspapers of general circulation when feasible. 
(Ord. 1684, 1991.) 
Section 10.50.030 - Parking on snow routes. 
A.  While a snow emergency is in effect, owners and operators of vehicles are encouraged not to park vehicles on snow routes and to remove any vehicle or other obstruction from a snow route. 
B.  Once in effect, a snow emergency under this section shall remain in effect until terminated by announcement of the director of public works, except that any street area which has become substantially clear of snow and ice from curb to curb for the length of the entire block shall be automatically excluded therefrom. 
(Ord. 1684, 1991.) 
Section 10.50.040 - Removal of vehicles. 
A.  During a snow emergency, a police officer or other government employee whose duty is to clear snow routes is authorized to order the immediate removal of any vehicle which is parked or disabled in a position which obstructs a travel lane or impedes the safe and expeditious clearing of snow on a snow route. If the owner or operator of such vehicle fails or refuses to comply immediately with such order, the vehicle may be immediately removed from the snow route to the nearest place where the vehicle will not obstruct a snow route. 
B.  The owner or operator of a vehicle removed from a snow route pursuant to this section shall be responsible for all costs incurred as a result of the removal of the vehicle. 
(Ord. 1684, 1991.) 
Section 10.50.050 - Snow route priorities and route designations. 
A.  Due to the specialized equipment, logistics, timing and limited resources available for snow removal operations only certain city streets are designated as snow routes. To further improve our efficiency each snow route is assigned a snow removal priority. Snow removal priority classifications are established to guide city snow removal operations on designated streets as referenced on the City of Sparks snow route map. Maps are available at www.cityofsparks.us or the Public Works Department. Streets with the highest numerical priority shall have the first priority for service and on-going efforts will be maintained to keep higher priority streets open to the maximum extent possible. The following roadways are hereby established as snow routes and assigned a snow removal priority. 
1.  Priority 1 Roadways are designated as primary snow routes. This designation indicates that the roadway will be plowed to maintain continuous all-weather access within the maximum capabilities of the city. 
2.  Priority 2 Roadways are designated as secondary snow routes. This designation indicates that the road will be plowed to provide reasonable all-weather access as time, available funds and human resources permit. 
B.  All streets not referenced on the City of Sparks snow route map as Priority 1 or Priority 2 roadways included in section A are designated as non-snow routes. The City of Sparks snow removal operations are limited to Priority 1 or Priority 2 roadways referenced in section A, unless the public works director determines that emergency access or other special snow and ice conditions are present which require the utilization of city snow removal operations. 
(Ord. 1851, 1995: Ord. 1804, 1993: Ord. 1684, 1991.) (Ord. 2411, Amended, 10/13/2008) 
Section 10.50.060 - Regional emergency snow removal operations. 
    The public works director is hereby authorized to direct the use of city resources in cooperation and coordination with the City of Reno and Washoe County to improve regional snow removal operations on major streets and to participate in emergency snow removal operations as needed to achieve regional emergency vehicle access. 
(Ord. 1804, 1993.) 
Chapter 10.52 - TRUCK ROUTES[6] 
Sections:

Section 10.52.010 - Designated. 
    Except as provided in Section 10.52.020, it is unlawful for the operator of any truck or commercial vehicle in excess of four thousand pounds per axle unladen weight, to a maximum of twelve thousand pounds unladen weight, to drive such truck or commercial vehicle through the city over any street or roadway other than: 
A.  11th Street from "B" Street to Nugget Avenue; 
B.  12th Street from "B" Street southward to dead end; 
C.  14th Street from "B" Street to Nugget Avenue;

I.  Nichols Boulevard from McCarran Boulevard to Howard Drive; 
J.  North Truckee Lane from Baring Boulevard to Spanish Springs Road; 
K.  Oddie Boulevard;

O.  South Rock Boulevard;

6.  Pittman Avenue, 
7.  Shaber Avenue, 
8.  South 15th Street,

10.  South 18th Street, 
11.  South 19th Street. 
U.  Any street or roadway situated east of Sparks Boulevard and south of East Prater Way. 
(Ord. 1646 § 2, 1989: Ord. 1271 § 1, 1980: Ord. 1037 § 1,1975: Ord. 844 § 1 (part), 1971: Ord. 732 § 1 (part), 1968: Ord. 713 § 151 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.451(l).) 
Section 10.52.020 - Streets other than designated routes-Use requirements. 
    The operator of any such truck or commercial vehicle, when required to use any of the streets of the city other than those named in Section 10.52.010 for the purpose of delivering or pickup of merchandise or persons, may use the feasible route from such streets to the point of delivery or pickup, and may return there from one of such streets by the most direct route upon completion of the pickup or delivery. 
(Ord. 1271 § 2, 1980: Ord. 844 § 1 (part), 1971: Ord. 732 § 1 (part), 1968: Ord. 713 § 151 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.451(2).) 
Chapter 10.56 - ONE-WAY STREETS AND ALLEYS[7] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- For statutory provisions authorizing local authorities to designate particular highways within their jurisdictions as one-way, see NRS 484.779. 

Section 10.56.010 - Signing. 
    Whenever any street or alley is designated as a one-way street or alley, the public works director shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and no such designation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Ord. 713 § 99, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.322.) 
Section 10.56.020 - Compliance required. 
    Vehicular traffic may move only in the indicated direction upon those streets and alleyways described in Section 10.56.010 when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Ord. 713 § 100, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.326.) 
Section 10.56.030 - Authority to restrict direction of movement on streets during certain periods. 
A.  The public works director may, with the approval of the city council, determine and designate streets, parts of streets or specific lanes thereon upon which vehicular traffic shall proceed in one direction during one period and the opposite direction during another period of the day and shall place and maintain appropriate markings, signs, barriers or other devices to give notice thereof. The public works director may erect signs temporarily designating lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction, regardless of the centerline of the roadway. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle in violation of such markings, signs, barriers or other devices so placed in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 713 § 101, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.331.) 
Chapter 10.60 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES 
Sections: 

Section 10.60.010 - Speed contests. 
    No person shall: 
A.  Engage in any motor vehicle speed contest exhibitor of speed on any street or highway or aid or abet such contest or exhibition; 
B.  Drive or permit to be driven any vehicle by the side of another vehicle on any street or highway for a time longer than is necessary to pass such other vehicle, except on designated one-way or multiple-lane streets or highways. 
(Ord. 713 § 114, 1986: 1962 Code § 35.361.) 
Section 10.60.020 - Sidewalk use restrictions. 
    It is unlawful for any person to ride or drive, or cause to be ridden or driven, any horse or other animal, or to ride or drive, or cause to be driven, any motor vehicle upon or along any sidewalk. 
(Ord. 1202 § 1, 1978: Ord. 713 § 115,1968: 1962 Code § 35.362.) 
Section 10.60.030 - Unlawful riding. 
A.  No person shall ride, and no person driving a motor vehicle shall knowingly permit any person to ride, on any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designated or intended for the use of passengers. 
B.  The provisions of this section do not apply to employees engaged in the necessary discharge of their duties or to persons riding within or upon vehicle bodies in spaces designed to carry loads on such vehicles. 
(Ord. 713 § 116, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.364.) 
Section 10.60.040 - Displaying a vehicle for sale. 
    No person may stand or park a vehicle upon any street, highway or alley for the purpose of displaying such vehicle for sale by sign or otherwise. 
(Ord. 713 § 146, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.433.) 
Section 10.60.050 - Interference with driver or mechanism of vehicle. 
    No person shall wilfully interfere with the driver of a vehicle or with the mechanism thereof in such manner as to affect the driver's control of the vehicle. 
(Ord. 713 § 164, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.478.) 
Section 10.60.060 - Opening and closing vehicle doors. 
    No person shall open the door of a motor vehicle on the side nearer to moving traffic unless it is reasonably safe to do so, or leave such door open longer than necessary to load or unload passengers. 
(Ord. 713 § 165, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.479.) 
Section 10.60.070 - Boarding or alighting from moving vehicles. 
    No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion. 
(Ord. 713 § 166,1968: 1962 Code § 35.481.) 
Section 10.60.080 - Attaching to moving vehicles. 
    No person riding upon any motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates, skis or any toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to any moving vehicle upon any street or highway. 
(Ord. 713 § 167, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.482.) 
Section 10.60.090 - Damage or tampering with vehicles. 
    No person shall: 
A.  Wilfully damage or tamper with any vehicle or the contents thereof or break or remove any part or parts of or from a vehicle without the consent of the owner; 
B.  With intent to commit any malicious mischief, injury or other crime, climb into or upon a vehicle whether it is in motion or at rest; 
C.  Attempt to manipulate any of the levers, starting mechanism, brakes or other mechanism of an unattended vehicle; 
D.  Set in motion any vehicle while the same is at rest and unattended. 
(Ord. 713 § 168, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.484.) 
Section 10.60.100 - Throwing any substance at or from a vehicle. 
A.  No person shall throw any substance at a vehicle or any occupant thereof on any street or highway. 
B.  No occupant of any vehicle shall throw any substance at any pedestrian walking or standing upon any street, highway or sidewalk. 
(Ord. 713 § 169, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.485.) 
Section 10.60.110 - Ignition keys in unattended vehicle. 
A.  No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to remain unattended on any public street, highway or alley, or in any public parking lot, or in any place readily accessible to the public, without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing the ignition key from the vehicle, effectively setting the brake thereon and, when upon any grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the street or highway. 
B.  Whenever any police officer finds a motor vehicle unattended with the ignition key in the vehicle, in violation of this section, such police officer may remove such key from such vehicle and deliver it to the police station. 
C.  The registered owner of a vehicle found in violation of this section shall be held prima facie responsible for any such violation. 
(Ord. 713 § 170, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.487.) 
Section 10.60.120 - Vehicle left unattended-Brakes to be set and engine stopped. 
    No person having control or charge of a motor vehicle shall allow such vehicle to stand on any street or highway unattended without first effectively setting the brakes thereon and stopping the motor of the vehicle, and when standing upon any perceptible grade without turning the front wheels of such vehicle to the curb or right-hand side of the highway or street. 
(Ord. 713 § 171, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.488.) 
Section 10.60.130 - Obstruction to driver's view of driving mechanism. 
A.  It is unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive the same when such vehicle is so loaded, or when there are in the front seat of such vehicle such number of persons, as to obstruct the view of the driver to the front or sides or to interfere with the driver's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle, or when any person is riding on the outside of any vehicle. 
B.  It is unlawful for any passenger in a vehicle to ride in such a position as to interfere with the driver's or operator's view ahead or to the sides. 
C.  It is unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive the same when the view of the driver to the front or to the sides is restricted or impaired by reason of the accumulation of frost, snow, ice, moisture or other matter. 
(Ord. 713 § 172, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.490.) 
Section 10.60.140 - Following fire apparatus prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for the driver of any vehicle other than one on official business to follow any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm closer than six hundred feet or to drive into or park such vehicle within the block where fire apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire alarm or within six hundred feet of any fire where the fire department is engaged in fighting the same. 
(Ord. 713 § 173, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.491.) 
Section 10.60.150 - Fire lines established-Crossing fire hose. 
A.  Any member or members of the fire department or the police department in the city may, at any fire or alarm of fire, establish fire lines by the use of rope or other appropriate designation, and when any such fire line has been so established, no person shall cross the same without first receiving permission so to do from the member of the fire department or police department in charge of such line. 
B.  No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected hose of the fire department when laid down on any street, private driveway or elsewhere, to be used at any fire or alarm of fire, without first securing the consent of the fire department official in command. 
(Ord. 713 § 174, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.493.) 
Section 10.60.157 - Driving without valid license. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle on a street, highway, alley or premises to which the public has access in the city without being the holder of a valid driver's license. 
B.  The court must require any person convicted of violating this section to obtain a valid driver's license or produce a notice of disqualifIcation from the Department of Motor Vehicles. 
(Ord. 1409 § 11, 1983.) 
Section 10.60.159 - License to be carried and surrendered on demand. 
    Every licensee shall have his driver's license in his immediate possession at all times when driving a motor vehicle and shall manually surrender the license for examination, upon demand, to a municipal court judge, a peace officer, or a deputy of the Department of Motor Vehicles. However, no person charged with violating this section shall be convicted if he produces in court or the office of the arresting officer a driver's license theretofore issued to him and valid at the time of the demand. 
(Ord. 1432 § 1, 1984.) 
Section 10.60.160 - Unlawful uses of licenses. 
    It is unlawful for any person to: 
A.  Display or cause or permit to be displayed, or have in his possession, any cancelled, revoked, suspended, fictitious, fraudulently obtained or fraudulently altered driver's license or chauffeur'spermit; 
B.  Alter, forge, substitute, counterfeit or use an unvalidated driver's license or chauffeur's permit; 
C.  Lend his driver's license or chauffeur's permit to any other person, or knowingly permit the use thereof by another; 
D.  Display or represent as one's own any driver's license or chauffeur's permit not issued to him; 
E.  Fail or refuse to surrender to a peace officer or a court upon lawful demand any driver's license or chauffeur's permit which has been suspended, revoked or cancelled; 
F.  Permit any unlawful use of a driver's license or chauffeur's permit issued to him; 
G.  Drive a motor vehicle in any manner in violation of the restrictions imposed in a driver's license or chauffeur's permit issued to him. 
H.  Photograph, photostat, duplicate, or in any way reproduce any driver's license or chauffeur's permit or facsimile thereof in such a manner that it could be mistaken for a valid license or permit, or to display or possess any such photograph, photostat, duplicate, reproduction or facsimile unless authorized by Nevada law. 
(Ord. 1154 § 1, 1978: Ord. 728 § 1, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.494.1.) (1951, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.60.170 - Permitting unauthorized person to drive. 
A.  No person shall cause or knowingly permit his child or ward under the age of eighteen years to drive a motor vehicle in the city when such minor does not hold a valid operator's or chauffeur's license. 
B.  No person shall authorize or knowingly permit a motor vehicle owned by him or under his control to be driven in the city by any person who is not the holder of a valid operator's or chauffeur's license. 
(Ord. 741 § 1, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.494.2.) 
Section 10.60.175 - Registration of vehicles. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to operate, or for the owner thereof knowingly to permit the operation of, any motor vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer upon any street or highway or alley within the city, unless the same has been registered, and has attached thereto and conspicuously displayed thereon the number of plate or plates currently assigned thereto by the motor vehicle department of the state, unless such vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer is exempted from such registration by the laws of the state. 
B.  It is unlawful to park any vehicle of any kind or description whatever on any street, highway or alley within the city unless the same has a valid current registration placed in the vehicle, and has attached and conspicuously displayed on the vehicle the number of plate or plates currently assigned thereto by the Motor Vehicle Department of the state or any other state of the United States. 
(Ord. 1093 § 2, 1976.) 
Section 10.60.176 - Fictitious registration/plates. 
    It is unlawful for any person to commit any of the following acts: 
A.  To display, cause or permit to be displayed or to have in possession any certificate of registration, license plate, certificate of ownership or other document of title knowing it to be fictitious or to have been cancelled, revoked, suspended or altered. 
B.  To lend to or knowingly permit the use of by one not entitled thereto any registration card or plate issued to the person so lending or permitting the use thereof. 
C.  Knowingly to operate a vehicle which: 
1.  Has an altered vehicle identification number, serial number, motor number, or other distinguishing number or identification mark required for registration; or 
2.  Contains a part which has an altered identification number or other distinguishing number or identification mark which was placed or stamped on the part by the manufacturer pursuant to federal law or regulation. 
(Ord. 1468 § 7, 1984.) (1955, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.60.180 - Zones of quiet. 
A.  Every street or highway within two hundred feet of a hospital building is declared to be a "Zone of Quiet" and the chief of police is authorized to declare any portion of a street, highway or alley within two hundred feet of a sick chamber a "Zone of Quiet" for temporary purposes. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to sound gongs, whistles, horns, sirens or to make unnecessary noise or itinerant music in any such "Zone of Quiet." 
(Ord. 713 § 177, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.497.) 
Section 10.60.190 - Sports in streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in any sport, amusement or occupation likely to impede the passage of vehicles upon any street or highway. 
(Ord. 713 § 178, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.499.) 
Section 10.60.200 - Mufflers on motor vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for any person to ride, drive or propel, or to cause or permit to be ridden, driven or propelled, any motor vehicle in, upon or along any street or highway, or to operate or cause or permit to be operated the motor in any such vehicle in any street or other public place, if such motor vehicle or the motor in such vehicle is not provided with a good and sufficient muffler properly attached thereto, or if the exhaust from the motor in such vehicle is ejected otherwise than through such muffler, or if such exhaust is ejected toward the surface of the street or ground. 
(Ord. 713 § 179, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.500.) 
Section 10.60.210 - Loud noises from mufflers. 
    It is unlawful for any person operating a self-propelled vehicle upon the streets to permit the pipes, mufflers or other devices to emit the sound of exhaust in a loud and annoying manner, it being the intention of this section to compel the operation of such self-propelled vehicle in as noiseless a manner as possible. 
(Ord. 713 § 180, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.502.) 
Section 10.60.215 - Excessive amplified sounds from motor vehicles prohibited. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person, while parked or operating a motor vehicle on a highway, street or alley, to create or allow noise to emanate from an electronic amplification device within or upon the motor vehicle which is plainly audible by a person having normal hearing at a distance of 25 feet or more from the source. 
B.  For purposes of this section, "Electronic Amplification Device" means a radio, stereo, audiotape, CD, DVD, or any other device for electronically amplifying pre-recorded music, voices, words or data. 
C.  For purposes of this section, "noise" means music, words or other sounds, or sounds that cause a person to be aware of vibration or concussion accompanying the sound. 
D.  This section does not apply to authorized emergency vehicles or noise created by emergency alarms or anti-theft alarms. 
(Ord. 2442, Add, 09/13/2010) 
Section 10.60.220 - Machinery in motion on motor vehicles at a standstill. 
    It is unlawful for any person to leave unattended upon any public street, highway or alley any motor vehicle while any part of its machinery is running, or is in motion, except for the purpose of operating refrigeration equipment on the vehicle or a trailer or semitrailer connected therewith. 
(Ord. 713 § 181, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.503.) 
Section 10.60.230 - Draining gasoline and oil. 
    It is unlawful for any person owning or operating any vehicle or any machinery or apparatus using gasoline, or other product of petroleum, to drain or to permit the same to drip or run from the crank or gear case, or from any other part of vehicle or machinery, any gasoline, oil or other petroleum product in or upon any street, highway, public parking lot or other publicly-owned property. 
(Ord. 1669, 1990: Ord. 713 § 182, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.505.) 
Section 10.60.240 - Repairing on streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person to construct or cause to be repaired any vehicle in or upon any street, highway, alley or public parking lot. 
(Ord. 1669, 1990: Ord. 713 § 183, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.506.) 
Section 10.60.250 - Changing from side to side of street. 
    No person driving, riding, propelling or in charge of any vehicle proceeding correctly along the right side of any street or highway shall cross over to the left side in the center or middle of a block, but shall proceed to the nearest street intersection and make a complete turn, keeping at all times to the right side of the street in the channel of traffic; provided, however, that under the meaning and intent of this section an alley shall not be construed to be a street. 
(Ord. 713 § 184, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.508.) 
Section 10.60.260 - Limitations on backing. 
    The driver of a vehicle: 
A.  Shall not back the vehicle unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic; and 
B.  Shall not back into an intersection, on or over a crosswalk, or around a street corner; and 
C.  Shall in every case yield the right-of-way to moving traffic and pedestrians when backing. 
(Ord. 1202 § 2, 1978: Ord. 713 § 185, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.509.) 
Section 10.60.270 - Warning on backing. 
    Before backing, ample warning shall be given by blowing the horn of the vehicle, and while backing unceasing vigilance shall be exercised so as not to injure or damage those behind, and in all events the approaching car shall have the right-of-way. 
(Ord. 713 § 186, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.511.) 
Section 10.60.280 - Throwing tacks or material liable to injure tires. 
    It is unlawful for any person to throw, deposit or place in or upon any public street any nails, tacks, crockery, scrap iron, tin, wire, bottles, glass, thorns or thorny clippings, or thorny branches of trees or bushes, or any other articles or things likely to puncture or injure the tire of any vehicle. 
(Ord. 713 § 187, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.512.) 
Section 10.60.290 - Funeral processions. 
    No vehicle shall be driven or propelled through or across any funeral procession passing through the streets of the city, but any such vehicle, upon meeting any funeral procession, shall come to a full stop until the funeral procession has fully and completely passed the vehicle; provided, that the provisions of this section shall not appertain or apply to vehicles of the fire or police departments or other authorized emergency vehicles. 
(Ord. 713 § 188, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.514.) 
Section 10.60.300 - Drivers in a procession. 
    Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practicable and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. 
(Ord. 713 § 189, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.515.) 
Section 10.60.310 - Driving within sidewalk areas. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Ord. 713 § 190, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.520.) 
Section 10.60.320 - Controlled access. 
    No person shall drive a vehicle onto or from any controlled access roadway except at such entrances and exits as are established by public authority. 
(Ord. 713 § 191, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.521.) 
Section 10.60.330 - Tires on traction engines. 
    It is unlawful for any person to drive or cause or permit to be driven along or upon any paved street any vehicle to any tire or wheel of which is attached cleats or spikes or uneven surfaces, or any device that will cause damage to the pavement of such street. 
(Ord. 713 § 192, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.523.) 
Section 10.60.340 - Driving on new pavements prohibited. 
    No person shall ride or drive any horse or vehicle over or across any pavement newly laid or repaired across or around which there has been placed a barrier, or at or near which there is a person or a sign warning persons against riding or driving over such pavement, or a sign stating that the street or highway is closed. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the persons actually engaged in the paving or repair of such street or highway. 
(Ord. 713 § 193, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.524.) 
Section 10.60.350 - Sifting or leaking loads. 
    It is unlawful for any person to drive or move any vehicle on any street or highway unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent its contents from dropping, sifting, leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom. 
(Ord. 713 § 194, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.526.) 
Section 10.60.360 - Exhaust systems and products. 
A.  It is unlawful to operate any vehicle powered with a diesel engine within the city, unless the extreme end of the exhaust pipe therefrom terminates at a point above the top of the cab of such vehicle. Diesel-powered vehicles used primarily for the transportation of persons are specifically exempted from the provisions of this subsection. 
B.  It is unlawful to operate any motor vehicle within the city in such manner as to result in the escape of excessive smoke, flame, gas, oil or fuel residue. 
(Ord. 713 § 195, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.527.) 
Section 10.60.370 - Transferring loads. 
    It is unlawful to transfer merchandise from one vehicle to another upon any street unless one such vehicle has been damaged or has become disabled and cannot be removed from the street with safety until the same has been unloaded. 
(Ord. 713 § 196, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.530.) 
Section 10.60.380 - Illegally parked or abandoned vehicles. 
A.  lmpounding Vehicles. Any vehicle of any kind or description whatever found parked at a place or in a manner prohibited or declared to be unlawful by this title, or in violation of the restrictions on stopping, standing or parking imposed by this title or other sections of this code, or any vehicle of any kind or description whatever found to be abandoned or inoperative for a period longer than twenty-four hours, on any street, highway, alley, or other public property within the city, is a nuisance and may be impounded by any police officer and shall only be surrendered to the duly identified owner or to the duly authorized agent of such owner upon the payment of all fees and charges properly assessed against such vehicle, including impound fees, towing charges and storage charges. 
B.  All vehicles impounded under this section may be sold in accordance with the provisions of state law. 
(Ord. 1267 § 1, 1980: Ord. 713 § 198, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.533.) 
Section 10.60.390 - Towing and repossessing vehicles-Notice. 
    Any person who repossesses or tows any vehicle from any location in the city without the knowledge of the registered owner thereof shall immediately report such repossession or towage by oral communication to the police department of the city. The oral communication shall include the description of the vehicle, identification number, license number, the time of such repossession or towage, and the location from which and to which the vehicle has been repossessed or towed. 
(Ord. 1298 § 1, 1981: Ord. 1202 § 3, 1978.) 
Section 10.60.400 - Child restraining devices. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection E of this section, any person who is transporting a child under five years of age or who weighs less than forty pounds in a motor vehicle operated in this city which is equipped to carry passengers shall secure him in a device for restraining a child which has been approved by the United States Department of Transportation. 
B.  Any person who violates the provisions of subsection A of this section shall be punished by a fine of not less than thirty-five dollars nor more than one hundred dollars unless, within fourteen days after the issuance of the citation for such a violation, the person presents to the court specified in the citation proof of his purchase or rental of such a restraining device. Upon presentation of such proof, the court shall void the citation. 
C.  For the purposes of NRS 483.470, a violation of this section is not a moving traffic violation. 
D.  A violation of this section may not be considered: 
1.  Negligence in any civil action; or 
2.  Negligence or reckless driving for the purposes of Section 10.44.040. 
E.  This section does not apply: 
1.  To a person who is transporting a child in a means of public transportation, including a taxi, school bus or emergency vehicle, or in a rented vehicle; 
2.  When a physician determines that the use of such a restraining device or safety belt for the particular child would be impractical or dangerous because of such factors as the child's weight, physical unfitness or medical condition. In this case, the person transporting the child shall carry in the vehicle the signed statement of the physician to that effect; 
3.  To a person who is transporting a child if: 
a.  All seating positions in the motor vehicle which are equipped with safety belts are occupied by other passengers using the safety belts, 
b.  Preference for the use of the safety belts is given to children, and 
c.  All unrestrained children under five years of age are in the rear seat of the motor vehicle. 
(Ord. 1408 § 1, 1983.) (1963, Amended, 12/08/1997) 
Section 10.60.410 - Post-storage hearing. 
A.  Whenever an authorized city employee directs the storage of a vehicle, as permitted by law, or upon the storage of any vehicle as permitted by law, the department or person directing the storage shall provide the vehicle's registered owners of record, or their agents, with the opportunity for a post- storage hearing to determine the validity of the storage. 
B.  A notice of such storage shall be mailed or personally delivered to the registered owners within forty-eight hours, excluding weekends and holidays, and shall include the following information: 
1.  The name, address and telephone number of the department providing the notice; 
2.  The location of the place of storage and description of the vehicle which shall include, if available, the name or make, the manufacturer and the license plate number; 
3.  The authority and purpose for the removal of the vehicle. 
Such notification shall also specify that, in order to receive their post-storage hearing, such owners, or their agents, must request the hearing in person, writing or by telephone within ten days of the date appearing on the notice. Any such hearing shall be conducted within forty-eight hours of the request, excluding weekends and holidays. The city manager shall authorize a city officer or employee to conduct the hearing, so long as such hearing officer is not the same person who directed the storage of the vehicle. 
C.  Failure of the registered owners, or their agents, to request or to attend a scheduled hearing shall satisfy the post-storage validity hearing requirement of this section. 
The city shall be responsible for the costs incurred for towing and storage if it is determined in the hearing that probable cause for the storage cannot be established. 
D.  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the removal of vehicles impounded for investigation of involvement in a hit-and-run accident, so long as the vehicle is released within forty-eight hours after such impoundment, excluding weekends and holidays. The city shall be responsible for the costs incurred for towing and storage in such investigatory impoundments. 
E.  The provisions of this section shall not apply to a seizure authorized by warrant. 
(Ord. 1469 § 1, 1984: Ord. 1431 § 1, 1984.) 
Chapter 10.64 - VEHICLE EQUIPMENT 
Sections: 

Section 10.64.010 - Required lighting equipment. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle upon any street, highway or alley that is not equipped with lighting equipment required by the laws of the state, and it is unlawful for any person driving or in charge of a vehicle to fail to display lights in compliance with the laws of the state, and it is unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle upon any street or highway that is equipped with lighting equipment that is not in conformity with the requirements of the laws of the state. 
(Ord. 713 § 152, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.454.) 
Section 10.64.020 - Brakes. 
A.  Every motor vehicle, other than a motorcycle, when operated within the city, shall be equipped with brakes adequate to control the movement of and to stop and hold such vehicle, including means which shall be effective to apply the brakes to at least two wheels. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle within the city which is not capable at all times and under all conditions of loading of being stopped on a dry, smooth, level street free from loose material, upon application of the service brake, of being decelerated at such a sustained rate as is specified by the statutes of the state. 
(Ord. 713 § 153, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.455.) 
Section 10.64.030 - Horns and warning devices. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle upon the streets, highways or alleys of the city which is not equipped with a horn in good working order and capable of emitting sound audible under normal conditions from a distance of not less than two hundred feet; but no horn shall emit an unreasonably loud or harsh sound or a whistle. Every person operating a vehicle shall, when reasonably necessary to insure safe operation, give audible warning with his horn and it is unlawful to otherwise use such horn. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to use upon a vehicle any siren, whistle, bell or red light, except on emergency equipment of the city or other governmental agency or other emergency equipment authorized by the state. 
(Ord. 713 § 154, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.457.) 
Section 10.64.040 - Windows. 
    It is unlawful to operate any motor vehicle upon any street when the windshield, rear window or other windows are in such a condition as to impair the driver's vision. 
(Ord. 713 § 155, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.458.) 
Section 10.64.050 - Flag or light at end of load 
    Whenever the load of any vehicle extends more than four feet beyond the rear of the bed or body thereof, there shall be displayed at the end of such load in such position as to be clearly visible at all times from the rear of such load a red flag not less than twelve inches both in length and width, except that between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise there shall be displayed at the end of any such load a yellow or red light plainly visible under normal atmospheric conditions at least two hundred feet from the rear of such vehicle. 
(Ord. 713 § 156, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.460.) 
Section 10.64.060 - Inspections and tests of equipment. 
A.  Any member of the police department having reasonable grounds to believe that any equipment upon a vehicle fails to comply with the requirements of this title may require the driver of such vehicle to stop and submit to an inspection or test of the equipment. 
B.  It is unlawful to refuse to submit to such an inspection or test of equipment. 
(Ord. 713 § 157, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.461.) 
Section 10.64.070 - Unlawful to operate vehicle without required equipment or in unsafe condition. 
    It is unlawful to operate on any street, highway or alley any vehicle or combination of vehicles which is not equipped as required by the provisions of this title or which is in an unsafe condition. 
(Ord. 713 § 158, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.463.) 
Chapter 10.68 - MOTORCYCLES AND SIMILAR VEHICLES 
Sections: 

Section 10.68.010 - Handlebars. 
    Handlebars on motorcycles and mopeds extend above the uppermost portion of the driver's shoulder when the driver sits on the seat and the seat is depressed by the weight of the driver. 
(Ord. 713 § 159, 1968: 1962 Code 35.466.) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.020 - Driving regulations. 
A.  No rider of a motorcycle ormoped shall hold to any moving vehicle for the purpose of being propelled. No driver of a motorcycle ormoped other than a police officer in the performance of his duty shall drive their vehicle between moving or stationary vehicles occupying adjacent traffic lanes. 
B.  Except as provided in subsection C, a person shall not drive a motorcycle or moped abreast of or overtake or pass another vehicle within the same traffic lane. 
C.  Motorcycles and mopeds may, with the consent of the drivers, be operated no more than two abreast in a single traffic lane. 
(Ord. 713 § 160, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.469.) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.030 - Equipment-Generally. 
    All motorcycles and all mopeds operated within the city limits shall be equipped in the manner set forth in Sections 10.68.040 through 10.68.110. 
(Ord. 713 § 161 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.470 (part).) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.040 - Rear view mirrors. 
    All motorcycles and mopeds covered under this chapter shall be equipped with two mirrors, containing a reflection surface of not less than three inches in diameter, mounted one on each handlebar of the vehicle and positioned so as to enable the operator to clearly view the roadway for a distance of two hundred feet to the rear of his vehicle. 
(Ord. 713 § 161 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.470(l).) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.050 - Windshield. 
    All motorcycles and mopeds covered under this chapter shall be equipped with atransparent windscreen meeting those standards adopted by the Nevada Department of Motor Vehicles, except that in lieu of such transparent windscreen the operator shall wear glasses, goggles or face shield of material and design to protect him from foreign objects as approved by the Nevada Department of Motor Vehicles. 
(Ord. 713 § 161 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.470(2).) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.060 - Brakes. 
    All motorcycles and mopeds covered under this chapter shall be equipped with brakes adequate to control the movement of same to stop and hold such vehicles, including two separate means of applying the brakes, one means shall be effective to apply the brakes to the front wheel and one means shall be effective to apply the brakes to the rear wheels. All such vehicles shall be equipped with a stop lamp on the rear of the vehicle which shall display a red or amber light, or any shade of color between red and amber, visible from a distance of not less than one hundred feet to the rear in normal sunlight, and which shall be actuated upon application of the rear service brakes. 
(Ord. 713 § 161 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.470(3).) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.070 - Speedometer. 
    All motorcycles and mopeds shall be equipped with a properly operating speedometer capable of registering at least the maximum legal speed limit for that vehicle. 
(Ord. 713 § 161 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.470(4).) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.080 - Fenders. 
    All motorcycles and mopeds shall be equipped with a fender over each wheel. which shall be of sufficient size and design to prevent the throwing of rocks, dirt, water or other substances to the rear. 
(Ord. 713 § 161 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.4705).) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.090 - Lights. 
    All motorcycles and mopeds shall carry at least one lighted headlamp capable of showing a white light visible at least three hundred feet in the direction in which the same are proceeding, and one tail lamp mounted on the rear which, when lighted, shall emit a red light plainly visible from at least three hundred feet to the rear, and such lights required by this section shall be burning whenever such vehicles are in motion during the period from one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise and at any other time when, due to insufficient light or unfavorable atmospheric conditions, persons and vehicles on the streets are not clearly discernible at a distance of at least five hundred feet ahead. 
(Ord. 713 § 161 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.470(6).) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.100 - Protective headgear. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in this section, where any motorcycle is operated on a highway, street, or within the city limits, the driver and passenger shall wear protective headgear. Protective headgear shall be of a type approved by the Department of Motor Vehicles and shall be securely fastened on the head. 
B.  Drivers and passengers of a moped as defined in Section 10.68.050 are not required to comply with the provisions of this section. 
C.  When a motorcycle or moped is being driven in a parade authorized by the city council, the driver and passenger are not required to wear protective headgear and are not required to comply with Section 10.68.050. 
D.  When a three-wheel motorcycle, on which the driver and passengers ride within an enclosed cab, is being driven on a highway, street or alley, the driver and passengers are not required to wear protective headgear and are not required to comply with Section 10.68.050. 
(Ord. 1129 § 1, 1977: Ord. 713 § 161 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.470(7).) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.110 - Operator-Shoes. 
    No person shall operate or ride upon any vehicle covered under this chapter unless such person is wearing protective foot covering. Sandals, thongs and open-toed shoes are not considered protective foot covering. 
(Ord. 713 § 161 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.470(8).) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.120 - Equipment-Exception. 
    Sections 10.68.040 through 10.68.110 shall not apply to operators or passengers of three-wheeled vehicles which have an enclosed passenger compartment. 
(Ord. 713 § 161 (part), 1968: 1962 Code § 35.470(9).) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.130 - Passengers. 
    It is unlawful for an operator of a motorcycle to carry any other person thereon, except on a seat securely fastened to the machine in the rear of the operator and provided with footrests and handgrips, or in a sidecar attached to the motorcycle and designed for the purpose of carrying a passenger. 
(Ord. 713 § 162, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.473.) (1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Section 10.68.140 - Riding restrictions.
