    A person operating a motorcycle or moped shall ride only upon the permanent and regular seat attached thereto, and such operator shall not carry any other person nor shall any other person ride on a motorcycle or moped unless it is designed to carry more than one person, in which event a passenger may ride upon the permanent and regular seat if designed for two persons. (Ord. 713 § 163, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.475.) 
(1957, Amended, 11/24/1997) 
Chapter 10.72 - BICYCLES 
Sections: 

Section 10.72.010 - License-Required. 
A.  No person who resides within the city shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street, or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, unless such bicycle has been licensed and a license plate is attached thereto. 
B.  No rental agency shall rent or offer for rent any bicycle unless the bicycle is licensed and a license plate is attached thereto. 
(1962 Code § 35.546.) 
Section 10.72.020 - License-Application and fee. 
A.  Applications for bicycle licenses and license plates shall be made to the chief of the police department upon forms provided by the city. 
B.  A license fee of one dollar shall be paid before any license is issued. 
(Ord. 1477 § 1, 1985: Ord. 950 § 1 (part), 1973; 1962 Code § 35.549.) 
Section 10.72.030 - License-Issuance. 
A.  The chief of the police department, upon receiving proper application therefor, may issue a bicycle license. 
B.  The chief of the police department shall not issue a license for any bicycle if he knows or has reasonable ground to believe that the applicant is not the owner or entitled to the possession of a bicycle. 
(Ord. 1477 § 2, 1985: 1962 Code § 35.552.) 
Section 10.72.040 - License-Records. 
    The chief of police shall keep a record of the number of each license, the date issued, the name and address of the person to whom issued, the number on the frame of the bicycle for which issued and all bicycle license fees collected. 
(1962 Code § 35.555.) 
Section 10.72.050 - License plate issuance, attachment and removal. 
A.  The chief of the police department, upon issuing a bicycle license, shall issue a license plate bearing the license number assigned to the bicycle and the name of the city, and cause such plate to be firmly attached to the rear mudguard or frame of the bicycle for which issued in such position as to be plainly visible from the rear. 
B.  No person shall remove a license plate from a bicycle during the period for which issued, except upon a transfer of ownership or when the bicycle is dismantled and no longer operated in the city. 
(Ord. 1477 § 3, 1985: 1962 Code § 35.558.) 
Section 10.72.060 - Inspection. 
    The chief of the police department shall inspect each bicycle before licensing the same and refuse a license for any bicycle which he determines is in unsafe mechanical condition. 
(Ord. 1477 § 4, 1985: 1962 Code § 35.561.) 
Section 10.72.070 - Loss of license or plate. 
    Upon satisfactory proof to the chief of the police department that any license or license plate has been lost or stolen, he may issue a new license or plate in lieu thereof upon payment of a fee of fifty cents. 
(Ord. 1477 § 5, 1985: 1962 Code § 35.564.) 
Section 10.72.080 - Transfer of ownership. 
    Upon the sale or other transfer of a licensed bicycle, the licensee shall remove the license plate and shall either surrender the same to the chief of police or may, upon proper application and without payment of an additional fee, have the plate assigned to another bicycle owned by the applicant. 
(1962 Code § 35.567.) 
Section 10.72.090 - Application of traffic laws to bicycles. 
A.  Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as otherwise provided in this chapter, and except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. 
B.  Every person walking or pushing a bicycle upon a sidewalk or crosswalk shall be subject to all the rights and all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(Ord. 1477 § 6, 1984: Ord. 713 § 203, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.570.) 
Section 10.72.100 - Riding on bicycles. 
A.  A person operating a bicycle shall not ride other than upon or astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. 
B.  No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Ord. 1477 § 7, 1984: 1962 Code § 35.573.) 
Section 10.72.110 - Bicycle paths. 
    Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders proceeding at a speed less than the normal speed of vehicular traffic shall use such path and not the roadway. 
(Ord. 1477 § 8, 1984: 1962 Code § 35.576.) 
Section 10.72.120 - Riding on the right. 
    Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right-hand side of the roadway as practicable and exercise due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(1962 Code § 35.579.) 
Section 10.72.130 - Riding on sidewalks. 
A.  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district. 
B.  No person fifteen years of age or older shall ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk in any district. 
C.  The chief of police may erect signs on any sidewalk or roadway prohibiting the riding of bicycles thereon by any person, and when such signs are in place no person shall disobey the signs. 
D.  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, he shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and give an audible signal before overtaking and passing any pedestrian. 
(1962 Code § 35.582.) 
Section 10.72.140 - Emerging from alley or driveway. 
    The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk or sidewalk area, and, upon entering the roadway, shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the roadway. 
(1962 Code § 35.585.) 
Section 10.72.150 - Bicycle racing. 
A.  Bicycle racing on the roadways is prohibited except when a racing event has been approved by state or local authorities on any highway under their respective jurisdictions. 
B.  By agreement with the approving authority, participants in a bicycle racing event may be exempted from compliance with any traffic laws otherwise applicable provided that traffic control is adequate to assure the safety of all highway users. 
(Ord. 1477 § 9, 1984: 1962, Code § 35.588.) 
Section 10.72.160 - Attaching to vehicles. 
    No person riding upon any bicycle shall attach the same or himself to any streetcar or vehicle upon a roadway. 
(1962 Code § 35.591.) 
Section 10.72.170 - Riding in a group. 
    Persons operating bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two abreast. 
(Ord. 1477 § 10, 1985: 1962 Code § 35.594.) 
Section 10.72.180 - Carrying articles. 
    No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon the handlebar. 
(1962 Code § 35.597.) 
Section 10.72.190 - Parking. 
    Bicycles shall be parked only upon a roadway against the curb, upon the sidewalk in a rack, against a building or in such other manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(1962 Code § 35.600.) 
Section 10.72.210 - Equipment required 
A.  No person who resides within the city shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street, or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, unless the bicycle is equipped as required by the provisions of Sections 10.72.220 through 10.72.240. 
B.  No rental agency shall rent or offer for rent any bicycle unless the bicycle is equipped as required by the provisions of Sections 10.72.220 through 10.72.240. 
(1962 Code § 35.606.) 
Section 10.72.220 - Lamps and reflectors. 
A.  Every bicycle when in use at night shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which emits a white light visible from a distance of at least five hundred feet to the front, and with a red reflector on the rear visible from all distances from fifty to three hundred feet to the rear when directly in front of the lawful upper beams of the headlamps on a motor vehicle. 
B.  A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of five hundred feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(1962 Code § 35.609.) 
Section 10.72.240 - Brakes. 
    Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on a dry, level, clean pavement. 
(1962 Code § 35.615.) 
Section 10.72.250 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars, or by imprisonment in the city jail for not more than fifty days, or by impounding of such person's bicycle for not more than sixty days, or by removal and detention of the license plate of such persons for not more than one hundred eighty days, or by any combination of such penalties. 
B.  Any parent or guardian who knowingly permits his child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars or by imprisonment in the city jail for not more than fifty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(1962 Code § 35.618.) 
Chapter 10.74 - SKATEBOARDS AND ROLLER SKATES 
Sections: 

Section 10.74.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the words and terms defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to them herein. 
A.  "Business district" means that area bounded by the "C" Street right-of-way, the 15th Street right-of-way, the Nugget Avenue right-of-way and the Pyramid Way right-of-way. 
B.  "Skateboard" means a device with wheels for riding upon, usually standing, including without limitation, skateboards and roller skates. 
(Ord. 1612 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 10.74.020 - Skateboarding on a street. 
    No person shall operate a skateboard on a public street or alley in the city if there is a sidewalk adjacent or parallel to such street or alley. If no such sidewalk exists, street riding shall be done as far to the right side of the road as possible, and in the same direction as traffic. 
(Ord. 1612 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 10.74.030 - Clinging to a vehicle. 
    No person operating a skateboard shall attach himself or herself to any vehicle upon a roadway. 
(Ord. 1612 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 10.74.040 - Skateboarding on business property. 
A.  No person shall operate a skateboard on the premises of any business in violation of a sign complying with this section. 
B.  Areas in which skateboarding is prohibited must be indicated by one or more signs which are positioned to provide actual or constructive notice and which contain the words "No Skateboarding" or any other word or combination of words indicating that skateboarding is prohibited. Such sign must also contain the words "SMC 10.74.040" or "City Code 10.74.040." 
Letters must be clearly legible. 
(Ord. 1612 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 10.74.050 - Skateboarding on public property. 
A.  No person shall operate a skateboard in, upon, or on the grounds of Sparks City Hall, Sparks Municipal Court or any city-owned parking structure. 
B.  No person shall operate a skateboard in violation of a sign erected by the city or other governmental entity prohibiting or regulating skateboarding. 
(Ord. 1612 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 10.74.060 - Yield right-of-way. 
    Any person operating a skateboard must yield right-of-way to any pedestrian. 
(Ord 1612 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 10.74.070 - Skateboarding in the business district. 
    No person shall operate a skateboard within the business district of the city. 
(Ord. 1612 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 10.74.080 - Damaging city property. 
    No person shall operate a skateboard on or against any city-owned table, bench, structure, tennis court, swimming pool or other improvement which may suffer damage by such use. 
(Ord. 1612 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Section 10.74.090 - Skateboard ramps. 
    No person shall use or place a ramp, jump, or any other device used to force a skateboard off the pavement on the grounds of any city- owned parking lot or park. 
(Ord. 1612 § 1 (part), 1988.) 
Chapter 10.76 - PROCEDURE-PENALTIES[8] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- For statutory provisions regarding the issuance and form of traffic citations, see NRS 484.799 to 484.817. 

Section 10.76.010 - Presumption in reference to violations. 
    In any proceeding for the violation of any of the provisions of this title, or of any of the restrictions imposed by this title, the registration plate or number thereon displayed on the vehicle involved shall be received as prima facie evidence that the registered owner of such vehicle was then operating the same. If at any hearing or proceedings the registered owner of the vehicle testifies, under oath, that he was not operating the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation of this title and submits himself to an examination as to who, at that time, was operating such vehicle and reveals the name of the person, or shows that the vehicle was stolen, then the prima facie evidence arising from the registration plate or number thereon shall be overcome and the burden of proof shifted. 
(Ord. 713 § 199, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.534.) 
Section 10.76.020 - Reports on convictions. 
A.  The chief of police shall cause to be kept a full report of every case in which a person is charged with violations of any provisions of this title, and in the event that such person is convicted or that his bail is forfeited, an abstract of such report shall be sent by the police judge to the Department of Motor Vehicles of the state. 
B.  Abstracts required by this section shall be made upon forms prepared by and shall contain such detail as may be requested by the Department of Motor Vehicles of the state. 
(Ord. 713 § 200, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.536.) 
Section 10.76.030 - Arrests and summonses. 
A.  If any person is arrested without warrant for violation of any provisions of Chapters 10.04 through 10.68, unless such person demands to be taken before the municipal judge, the arresting officer may take the name and address of such person and the number of his motor vehicle and operator's license, if any, and notify him in writing to appear before the municipal judge at a time and place to be specified in such writing within three days subsequent to the date of such notice, and upon serving such summons in writing the officer may release such person from custody. 
B.  If the violator is not present at the time an officer views a violation, the summons may be given by attaching to the vehicle used in connection with the offense, in a conspicuous place thereon or therein, a ticket or tag in such form as may be prescribed by the chief of police. 
C.  It is unlawful: 
1.  Wilfully to fail to comply with a summons issued pursuant to this section; 
2.  For any person to remove a ticket or tag attached to a vehicle pursuant to subsection B, unless he is the operator or owner of the vehicle; 
3.  For any person to destroy a tag or ticket attached to a vehicle pursuant to the provisions of subsection B until after the appearance of the person to whom it is addressed before the municipal judge. 
(Ord. 713 § 201, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.538.) 
Section 10.76.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provisions of this title for which another penalty has not been provided shall be punished as provided in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(Ord. 713 § 202, 1968: 1962 Code § 35.539.) 
Title 12 - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - OBSTRUCTIONS TO STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 
Sections: 

Section 12.04.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise: 
A.  "Person" means an individual, partnership, firm, association or corporation; 
B.  "Street" or "alley" means all of the area between property lines where a street or alley is located, including sidewalks as well as roadbeds. 
(1962 Code § 50.010.) 
Section 12.04.020 - Unlawful obstructions generally. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to obstruct completely any street or alley in the city for any time, or to place any obstruction therein, without first having obtained permission so to do from the city engineer. 
B.  At no time shall any house or other object being moved across or through any street or alley be allowed to stand therein, or to obstruct or hinder traffic therein, longer than five minutes at any one time without permission of the city engineer. 
(1962 Code § 50.020.) 
Section 12.04.030 - Vending stands prohibited on streets, alleys, sidewalks; exception. 
A.  Except as provided in Chapter 5.59, no person shall occupy any part of any street or alley, including any sidewalk, for the purpose of keeping or maintaining any table, cart, booth or stand for the commercial sale of goods or merchandise. 
B.  This section does not prohibit the non-commercial First Amendment sales of "expressive merchandise" on sidewalks pursuant to Chapter 12.26. 
C.  This section does not prohibit the commercial sale of newspapers, printed materials or other media protected as speech under the First Amendment on sidewalks pursuant to Chapter 12.26. 
(1962 Code § 50.030.) (Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Amended, 09/25/2006) 
Section 12.04.040 - Seats. 
    No person shall place any permanent seat on any street or alley. The chief of police shall summarily cause the removal of any such obstruction. 
(1962 Code § 50.040.) 
Section 12.04.050 - Street games. 
    It is unlawful for any person to play baseball, cricket, football or any other game in a street or alley which tends to interrupt the free or safe use of such street or alley. 
(1962 Code § 50.050.) 
Section 12.04.060 - Reasonable use of streets and alleys by merchants and house holders. 
    Merchants and householders may make such reasonable use of the streets and alleys as the necessities of their businesses may require, but at no time shall any person be permitted to place or to leave any obstruction on any sidewalk or in any street or alley for a time longer than is absolutely necessary, and any obstruction shall be at once removed on the order of the chief of police. 
(1962 Code § 50.060.) 
Section 12.04.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in SMC 1.12.010. 
(1962 Code § 50.070 (part).) (Ord. 2340, Amended, 09/25/2006) 
Chapter 12.08 - CLOSING OF STREETS AND ALLEYS 
Sections: 

Section 12.08.010 - Closing streets and alleys. 
    The city council or the city engineer may: 
A.  Declare closed any street or alley in the city in whole or in part and exclude travel or entry thereon during the time improvements or repairs are being made, or during any time it is deemed travel or entry thereon is unsafe from any cause; 
B.  Place obstructions on or across any street or alley, or any portion thereof, and give notice of the closing of such street, alley or portion thereof by posting notice of such closing. 
(1962 Code § 50.080.) 
Section 12.08.020 - Unlawful entry upon closed streets and alleys-Penalties. 
A.  All persons and travel are prohibited from entering in or upon a closed street, alley or portion thereof. 
B.  Any person who enters upon, travels over or commits any trespass whatsoever in, across or upon any closed street, alley or portion thereof, who breaks, injures or removes any obstruction, or who defaces, covers up, destroys or removes any notice posted under the provisions of Section 12.08.010 is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars or more than one hundred fifty dollars, or by imprisonment in the city jail for not less than five days or more than seventy-five days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(1962 Code § 50.090.) 
Chapter 12.10 - STREET NAME APPROVAL 
Sections: 

Section 12.10.010 - Prerequisite to subdivision map approval. 
    Prior to the approval of any final subdivision map under the provisions of Title 17 of this code, the subdivider shall secure from the street naming committee of Reno, Sparks and Washoe County approval of all street names. 
(Ord. 1326 § 1, 1981: Ord. 952 § 1(1), 1973.) 
Section 12.10.020 - Required-Presentation to street naming committee. 
    Any person desiring to name any other public or private street in the city shall present the proposed street name to the street naming committee of Reno, Sparks and Washoe County for their approval. The street naming committee may disapprove any street name they find duplicated in the county or which may be confused with any other street name. 
(Ord. 1326 § 2, 1981: Ord. 952, § 1 (2), 1973.) 
Chapter 12.12 - EXCAVATIONS 
Sections: 

Section 12.12.010 - Permits-General provisions. 
A.  An excavation permit shall be secured from the department of public works of the city before any person, partnership, corporation, association or other, hereinafter sometimes referred to as the excavating contractor, makes any excavation in any public street or alley within the city limits; with the exception, however, that permits shall not be required for excavations in new subdivisions under development in which the streets or alleys have not been brought to final grade. 
B.  Permits must be secured at least twenty-four hours prior to the beginning of the excavation; provided however, that if an emergency arises, necessitating an immediate excavation during the hours that the department of public works' office is not open for business, the person making such excavation shall notify the police and fire departments of the city, giving the location of the excavation, the time the same will be made and the extent thereof. A permit shall be secured from the department of public works on the next succeeding business day, whether the emergency work has been completed or not. Failure to notify the proper authorities will result in payment of double the normal fee for performing this work. The contractor shall confine work to the standard work week which shall consist of five, eight-hour workdays, Monday through Friday. The contractor shall be responsible for inspection and testing expenses incurred by the city which result from contractor activity in excess of the standard work week. The city reserves the right to deduct these costs from monies owed the contractor. 
C.  Every permit issued by the public works department shall expire and become null and void if the excavation is not commenced within fourteen calendar days from the date of such permit, unless otherwise extended in writing by the public works director. 
(Ord. 1772, 1993: Ord. 650 § 1, 1966.) 
Section 12.12.020 - Requirements. 
    All excavations, including pavement cutting, excavating, backfilling, and temporary patching shall be done in accordance with the technical specifications set forth in the current edition of Standard Specifications for Public Works Construction adopted by the City of Sparks. It is the responsibility of the excavating contractor to maintain the temporary patch for a period not to exceed ninety days. All permanent asphaltic concrete patches shall be constructed by the department of public works unless special permission is given by the public works director allowing the permittee to construct the permanent patch. The excavating contractor shall be responsible for replacing material equal in quality and depth to that existing prior to excavation in all gravel surfaced streets or alleys. All Portland cement concrete structures, such as curbs, gutters, sidewalks and valley gutters, or other public facilities damaged or removed, shall be replaced to the nearest construction joints on either side of the curb cut by the excavating contractor without cost to the city. 
(Ord. 1772, 1993: Ord. 650 § 3, 1966.) 
Section 12.12.030 - Excavation permit fees. 
    A minimum excavation permit fee is required for any work which involves excavation, filling and/or replacement of asphalt, concrete or other materials in any City of Sparks dedicated right-of-way or easement. 
Permanent patch fees: 
A.  Standard 4" depth patch 500 square feet or less. Street cut contract square foot cost for the year x 1.6 = applicant cost. 
B.  Standard 4" depth patch over 500 square feet. Street cut contract square foot cost for the year x 1.3 = applicant cost. 
The fee for an excavation permit shall be increased by a per square foot surcharge for any street which has been constructed or reconstructed within the last five years. 
For the purpose of establishing fees for excavation permits, road surfaces shall be classified as follows: 
A.  Class A: Streets or alleys which are surfaced with asphaltic concrete pavement; 
B.  Class B: Streets or alleys having gravel surfaces. 
Fees for excavation permits and surcharges for any street which has been constructed or reconstructed within the last five years are set by resolution of the City Council. Schedules of these fees are available from the City Clerk and are posted wherever permits are obtained and fees paid. 
(Ord. 1772, 1993.) (Ord. 2022, Amended, 05/24/1999; 1991, Amended, 05/26/1998; 1986, Amended, 04/13/1998) 
Section 12.12.040 - Basis for area determination. 
    For the purpose of computing the area of the excavation on paved surfaces, field measurements shall be made by the public works department at the time of construction. The area shall be computed from the linear measurement of the length and width of the trench, each such measurement increased a minimum of one and three-tenths feet; provided however, if excessive sloughing of trench banks or if breakage of pavement occurs, the measurements shall be adjusted to cover the area of street to be restored. 
(Ord. 1772, 1993: Ord. 650 § 6, 1966.) 
Section 12.12.050 - Protection of excavation. 
A.  Excavations in the city's rights-of-way shall be properly protected by barricade methods as provided for in the current edition of Standard Specifications for Public Works Construction adopted by the City of Sparks. 
B.  Any person maintaining improper barricades within the street right-of-way which require the placing of additional barricades, warning lights or signs by the city in the interest of public safety shall be charged time and materials (two hour minimum) for each occasion in which the city finds it necessary to place such barricades, warning lights or signs. 
(Ord. 1772, 1993: Ord. 650 § 7, 1966.) 
Section 12.12.060 - Procedure for waiving requirements. 
    The city council may, for good cause shown, by resolution adopted by no less than a four-fifths majority, waive or dispense with any of the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1772, 1993: Ord. 650 § 8, 1966.) 
Section 12.12.070 - Bond and certificate of insurance. 
A.  Any person obtaining a permit under this article shall before renewing or in any manner changing the surface of the sidewalk, curb, gutter, street, highway, avenue or alley, provide to the city, a bond to be approved by the city attorney, in such sum as shall be designated by the public works director as necessary for the proper protection of the city, conditioned that the obligor of the bond will pay to the city the amount of the bond, should the person obtaining such permit fail, neglect or refuse to complete the excavating or filling in, the sidewalk, curb, gutter, public street, highway, avenue or alley in proper condition to the satisfaction of the public works director after the work provided for in the permit has been finished; provided, however, that instead of special bonds to cover particular work, any person intending to make excavations in sidewalks, curbs, gutter, public streets, alleys or any public property in the city may make and maintain current with the city, a general bond in the sum of twenty-five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), which general bond shall be conditioned and used for the same purpose as the special bond hereinbefore described in this section, covering all work to be done instead of any particular piece of work. 
B.  Before a permit shall be issued under this article, any applicant, with the exception of public utilities under the jurisdiction of the state public service commission, shall file with the city clerk, upon review and approval by the city attorney, a certificate of insurance for a minimum combined single limit insurance policy of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00), such policy to include but not be limited to collapse and underground damage. 
The certificate of insurance must meet the following requirements: 
1.  Coverage must include broad form property damage liability, automobile liability including non-owned and hired automobiles (with the contractual liability exclusion deleted), contractual liability, products and completed operations liability, personal injury and advertising liability and stop gap/employer's liability. 
2.  The City of Sparks must be named as an additional insured by endorsement. The endorsement must be filed with the City Clerk as soon as practicable. 
3.  The City of Sparks must be notified of the insurance company's intent to cancel the policy not less than ten (10) days in advance of cancellation for non-payment of premium or not less than thirty (30) days in advance of cancellation for any other cause. 
C.  An applicant must provide and maintain proof of worker's compensation insurance in compliance with State law. 
(Ord. 1772, 1993.) 
Section 12.12.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, partnership, corporation, association or others violating any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in Section 1.12.010 of this code. Each day of such violation constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. 650 § 9, 1966.) 
Chapter 12.16 - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 
Sections: 

Section 12.16.010 - Requirements in general. 
    In the Tourist/Commercial (TC) district, lots shall have concrete sidewalks a minimum of five feet in width. In all other zoning districts, sidewalks shall be of concrete four feet in width. The inner line of sidewalks must be laid one foot from the property line, but wherever any sidewalk has been constructed under authority of any former ordinance of the city in any manner other than in accordance with the lines established in this section, sidewalks for the remaining properties in the same block shall be so constructed that uniformity of lines may be maintained. 
(Ord. 1772, 1993: 1962 Code § 50.290(2).) 
Section 12.16.020 - Sidewalks ordered built by the city council-Liens for costs. 
    Any sidewalk ordered built by the city council shall be paid for by the owner of the property which abuts upon the sidewalk. If the owner fails to pay the cost, the cost and all expense entailed by the city in building the sidewalk and collecting of the cost of the same shall be a lien against the property. The lien shall be enforced as other liens under the laws of the state. 
(1962 Code § 50.320.) 
Section 12.16.030 - Property owners to keep sidewalks in repair. 
    Property owners shall be responsible for the repair and reconstruction of a sidewalk in the public right-of-way that abuts the property of the owner if the owner caused the need for such repair or reconstruction. 
(1962 Code § 50.330.) (Ord. 2187, Amended, 09/08/2003) 
Section 12.16.035 - Maintenance of sidewalks. 
A.  Property Owners shall be responsible for the general maintenance of a sidewalk in the public right-of-way that abuts the property of the owner, including, without limitation, sweeping, removal of snow, ice and weeds, and maintenance preventing any grass, shrubs or trees from encroaching upon the sidewalk . 
B.  In the event snow and ice on a sidewalk become so hard that it cannot be removed without likelihood of damage to the sidewalk, the person or entity charged with its removal shall cause enough sand or other abrasive to be put on the sidewalk to make travel thereon reasonably safe. 
(Ord. 1349 § 1, 1982.) (Ord. 2187, Amended, 09/08/2003) 
Chapter 12.20 - PARTICULAR SIDEWALK AREAS 
Sections: 

Section 12.20.010 - Areas between property lines and curbs. 
    The widths of areas between property lines and curbs along all streets in the city are established as follows: 
A.  On B Street from Stanford Way to 15th Street, on A Street from 9th Street westerly to 15th Street and on all properties abutting on Prater Way, the width shall be twelve feet; 
B.  On all thirty or forty foot streets, the width shall be six feet; 
C.  On 15th Street from A Street to Prater Way, the width shall be twenty feet; 
D.  On 6th Street from B Street to Prater Way, the width shall be twenty-four feet; 
E.  On all seventy foot streets, the width shall be seventeen feet; 
F.  On Pyramid Way from B Street to the north city limits, the width shall be twelve feet; 
G.  After May 1, 1936, in the residential districts where the streets are of varying widths, the widths are established so that when curbs are laid and completed the streets shall be thirty-six feet wide for vehicular traffic. 
(1962 Code § 50.280.) 
Section 12.20.020 - Certain sidewalks on b street. 
    All sidewalks constructed on the north side of B Street from 6th Street to 15th Street shall be of cement entirely filling the space from property line to curb. 
(1962 Code § 50.290(1).) 
Section 12.20.030 - Certain sidewalks on prater way. 
    Sidewalks constructed on the north side of Prater Way between Pyramid Way and 12th Street shall be as follows: 
A.  The inner line of the sidewalks shall be located two feet from the property line as they existed on November 12, 1940; 
B.  The sidewalks shall be of uniform width and in accordance with the provisions of Section 12.20.010; 
C.  The curb and gutter line on Prater Way shall be established to make the street uniform throughout its length. 
(1962 Code § 50.300.) 
Section 12.20.040 - Sidewalks in subdivisions. 
A.  Any sidewalk constructed in the Lincoln Park Subdivision, the Huyck Subdivision, the Greenbrae Subdivision, the Barnard Subdivision, the Northmore Subdivision, the Strobel Subdivision and any new subdivision annexed by the city shall be of cement four feet in width and constructed contiguous to the curb line. 
B.  Any sidewalk constructed in the following locations in the Newtown Tract shall be four feet in width and constructed contiguous to the curb line: 
1.  Both sides of I Street from 15th Street to Sullivan Lane; 
2.  The north side of H Street from 17th Street to Sullivan Lane; 
3.  The south side of H Street from 19th Street to Sullivan Lane; 
4.  Both sides of G Street from 15th Street to 16th Street; 
5.  Both sides of G Street from 18th Street to 19th Street; 
6.  The north side of G Street from 19th Street to Sullivan Lane; 
7.  The south side of G Street from 20th Street to Sullivan Lane; 
8.  Both sides of F Street from 15th Street to 16th Street; 
9.  The south side of F Street from 16th Street to 17th Street; 
10.  Both sides of F Street from 17th Street to 19th Street; 
11.  The north side of F Street from 20th Street to Sullivan Lane; 
12.  Both sides of E Street from 18th Street to 19th Street; 
13.  The east side of Sullivan Lane from Prater Way to the north boundary of Frederick Addition; 
14.  Both sides of 20th Street from F Street north to the north boundary of Newtown Tract; 
15.  Both sides of 19th Street from F Street north to the north boundary of the Newtown Tract; 
16.  The east side of 19th Street from Prater Way north to F Street; 
17.  Both sides of 18th Street from Prater Way north to the north boundary of the Newtown Tract; 
18.  The east side of 16th Street from Prater Way north to the north boundary of the Newtown Tract; 
19.  Both sides of 15th Street from Prater Way north to the north boundary of the Newtown Tract. 
C.  In all other portions of the Newtown Tract, sidewalks shall be five feet in width and shall conform to lines of walks previously installed. 
(1962 Code § 50.310.) 
Section 12.20.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of Sections 12.20.010, 12.20.020 or 12.20.040 is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not less than two dollars or more than fifty dollars. 
(1962 Code § 50.370 (part).) 
Chapter 12.22 - CURBS 
Sections: 

Section 12.22.010 - Curb numbering. 
    No curb shall be lettered or numbered in any way except that residential street address numbers may be painted on curbs in front of residential street addresses. Curb numbering must conform to the following standards: 
A.  Numbers must be black on white background; 
B.  Numbering must be in block print, four inches in height, three-fourths-inch stroke, and there must be a space of at least one-fourth inch and no more than one inch in between numbers; 
C.  No numbers may be painted in restricted zones, that is, where curbs are painted yellow or red or where parking is restricted; 
D.  Numbers must be placed at the end of the curb return on the street on which the residence is addressed and which is closest to the residence entrance, or, if no such curb return exists, then the numbers must be placed, insofar as possible, in direct line with the entrance of the residence. 
(Ord. 1777, 1993.) 
Section 12.22.020 - Unsolicited curb numbering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or agency to paint numbering on curbs in front of any residence without first securing the approval of the person living at such address or the owner of the premises and without first making arrangements with the owner or person who resides at the given address if and how payment is to be made for the lettering. Any person who paints numbers on curbs in violation of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 1777, 1993.) 
Section 12.22.030 - House numbers on residence. 
    The curb numbering as provided for herein is not in lieu of house numbers to be affixed to the residence as provided for in Section 14.04.060 of the Sparks Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 1777, 1993.) 
Chapter 12.24 - PARKS 
Sections: 

Section 12.24.010 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, unless the context requires otherwise: 
A.  "City park" means any area designated by the city council as a public park, playground or recreation facility. 
B.  "Park ranger" means a person employed by the Parks and Recreation Department whose primary responsibility is to enforce rules in city parks. 
C.  "Inflatable" means a structure that is intended to be or capable of being inflated with air and used for commercial displays or laying, sitting, standing, riding, bouncing, running, swimming or other physical activities by a person or persons. "Inflatable" includes, without limitation, slides, bounce houses, obstacle courses, boxing/jousting rings, ball pits, pools, race arches and displays. "Inflatable" does not include inner tubes, swim tubes, paddle boards, rafts, or similar devices intended for flotation; or balloons that are smaller than 18 inches in diameter when inflated. 
D.  "Smoking" means the action of inhaling and exhaling the smoke of tobacco or a controlled substance, including, but not limited, to marijuana and its derivatives, by any means, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, cigarillos, pipes, and hookahs. 
E.  "Vaping" means the action of inhaling and exhaling the vapor of tobacco or a controlled substance, including, but not limited to, marijuana and its derivatives, by use of any vapor product. 
F.  "Vapor product" means any noncombustible product that employs a heating element, power source, electronic circuit or other electronic, chemical, or mechanical means, regardless of the shape or size thereof, that can be used to produce vapor from any substance placed in or on the vapor product for the purpose of human consumption. "Vapor product" includes, but is not limited to, any electronic cigarette, cigar, cigarillo, pipe, or a substantially similar device. "Vapor product" does not include any product regulated by the United States Food and Drug Administration pursuant to Subchapter V of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. §§ 351 et seq. 
(Ord. 1855, 1995: Ord. 1669, 1990: Ord. 1383 § 1 (part), 1983.) (Ord. 2555, § 2, Amended, 6/25/2018; Ord. 2545, § 1, Amended, 12/23/2017; Ord. 2464, § 2, Amended, 07/09/2012; Ord. 2339, Amended, 09/11/2006; Ord. 2069, Amended, 04/24/2000) 
Section 12.24.020 - Motor vehicles in parks. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to drive or cause to be driven any motor vehicle in any city park without first having obtained a permit from the director of the department of parks and recreation or his designee. 
B.  Permits to drive motor vehicles in the city parks may be issued by the director of the department of parks and recreation or his designee upon such terms and conditions as the director may deem advisable. No fees shall be required for such a permit. Each such permit shall carry an expiration date and shall be specific with respect to the number and types of vehicles allowed and the dates and time allowed. 
C.  The permit must be kept in the possession of the permittee at all times when operating a motor vehicle in a city park. A copy of each permit shall be transmitted to the police department upon issuance. 
(Ord. 1383 § 1 (part), 1983: Ord. 1227 § 1, 1979: Ord. 775 § 1, 1969: 1962 Code § 50.059.) (Ord. 2339, Amended, 09/11/2006) 
Section 12.24.030 - Times when parks open. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, city parks shall be closed to the public between the hours of ten p.m. and six a.m., every day. Shadow Mountain and Golden Eagle Regional Park shall be closed to the public between the hours of twelve a.m. and six a.m., every day. It is unlawful for any person to be present within a city park during any period when said park is closed to the public, except that authorized employees of the department of parks and recreation and peace officers may be within the city parks during such periods. 
(Ord. 1669, 1990: Ord. 1383 § 1 (part), 1983: Ord. 1227 § 2, 1979: 1962 Code § 50.070 (part).) (Ord. 2464, § 3, Amended, 07/09/2012; Ord. 2339, Amended, 09/11/2006; Ord. 2318, Amended, 04/10/2006) 
Section 12.24.040 - Overnight camping. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to camp in any city park. ., 
B.  For purposes of this section, "camp" means living accommodation activities such as sleeping, making preparations to sleep (including the laying down of bedding for the purposes of sleeping), storing personal belongings, making any fire not permitted by the SMC or park rule or regulation, doing any digging or earth breaking or carrying on routine or repetitive cooking activities. The above-listed activities constitute "camping" when it reasonably appears, in light of all the circumstances, that the participants, in conducting these activities, are in fact using the area as a living accommodation regardless of the stated intent of the participants or the nature of any other activities in which they may also be engaging. 
C.  Recreational vehicles and temporary structures, including but not limited to motorhomes, travel trailers, truck campers, tent trailers, tents and canopies, may not be used for living accommodation activities in any city park. 
D.  It is unlawful for any person to sleep in any city park between the hours of ten p.m. and six a.m. on any day. 
(Ord. 1669, 1990: Ord. 1383 § 1 (part), 1983: Ord. 1227 § 3, 1979.) (Ord. 2339, Amended, 09/11/2006) 
Section 12.24.050 - Fires. 
A.  No person may light, use or maintain a fire within any city park except in a stove, pit, or fireplace provided and maintained for that purpose, or in a portable camp stove or device designed for cooking. 
B.  No person shall leave a city park before extinguishing any fire which the person has built, lighted or maintained, nor shall any person allow a fire to be left unattended within any city park. Children under the age of ten years are not qualified to tend a fire. 
(Ord. 1383 § 1 (part), 1983.) 
Section 12.24.055 - Inflatables prohibited on public property. 
    It is unlawful for any person to set up, inflate or offer for use any inflatable on public property in the City of Sparks except as otherwise authorized by Section 9.34.115. 
(Ord. 2545, § 2, Add, 10/23/2017) 
Section 12.24.056 - Smoking and vaping prohibited in city parks. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided by this section, smoking and vaping in a city park is prohibited. 
B.  No person shall be charged with a violation of this section unless the person continues to engage in conduct prohibited by this section after having been notified by a city employee or officer or any law enforcement officer that the conduct violates this section. 
C.  This section does not apply within the Victorian Square special event venue as defined in Section 9.42.010.E. 
D.  This section does not apply to chewing tobacco. 
(Ord. 2555, § 2, Amended, 6/25/2018) 
Section 12.24.060 - Archery prohibited without a permit. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to shoot any archery device in a city park except by authority granted by the police department of the city. 
B.  Permits to perform archery in a city park may be issued by the city police chief or designee upon such terms and conditions as the chief may deem advisable. No fees shall be required for such a permit. Each such permit shall carry an expiration date and shall specifically state the number of persons or teams to which the permit applies, type of sport and the location(s), date(s) and time(s) such sport is allowed. Any person or group of persons shooting archery devices in a city park pursuant to such a permit shall present said permit at the request of a sheriff, deputy sheriff, police officer or other peace officer acting in the course and scope of his or her duties. 
(Ord. 2545, § 3, Add, 10/23/2017) 
Section 12.24.065 - Golfing prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to golf in a city park. 
(Ord. 2545, § 4, Add, 10/23/2017) 
Section 12.24.070 - Organized sports prohibited without a permit. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person or persons to conduct organized sports, youth or adult, in any city park without first having obtained a permit from the director of the department of parks and recreation or designee. 
B.  Permits to conduct organized sports in a city park may be issued by the director of the department of parks and recreation or designee upon such terms and conditions as the director may deem advisable. Each such permit shall carry an expiration date and shall specifically state the number of teams and type of sport allowed and the location(s), date(s) and time(s) allowed. 
(Ord. 2545, § 5, Add, 10/23/2017) 
Section 12.24.075 - Metal detectors prohibited without a permit. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to possess or operate a metal detector within any city park without first having obtained a permit from the director of the department of parks and recreation or designee. 
B.  A permit to possess or operate a metal detector in a city park may be issued by the director of the department of parks and recreation or designee upon such terms and conditions as the director may deem advisable. Each such permit shall carry an expiration date and shall specifically state the location(s), date(s) and time(s) such possession or operation is allowed. 
(Ord. 2545, § 6, Add, 10/23/2017) 
Section 12.24.080 - Excessive noise prohibited. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided for First Amendment activities, no person shall operate machinery, electrical equipment, or otherwise engage in noise-producing conduct which disturbs the peace of others at the park or persons residing near the park without first obtaining the written permission of the director of the department of parks and recreation to engage in the noise-producing conduct. Such written permission must be kept in the possession of the recipient at all times when the noise-producing conduct exists. 
B.  For purposes of this section, "noise producing" conduct" means any conduct which produces sound exceeding 70 decibels when measured ten feet or more from the source. 
(Ord. 1383 § 1 (part), 1983.) (Ord. 2339, Amended, 09/11/2006) 
Section 12.24.085 - Priority of use of city parks. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to fail to observe or respect written permits issued pursuant to this Code. Any person using any city park, or any portion thereof, which may be reserved by obtaining a permit, but who has not obtained such a permit, shall vacate said area when the holder(s) of a valid permit present themselves. When no permit has been issued, the use of such areas shall be on a first come, first served basis consistent and compatible with their intended use. 
B.  The city further reserves the right to restrict use of all areas when conflicts arise with scheduling, maintenance, public safety or for other reasons. 
(Ord. 2545, § 7, Add, 10/23/2017) 
Section 12.24.090 - Park rules. 
    The director of the department of parks and recreation shall, after consultation with the park and recreation commission and following approval by the city manager, adopt, amend or repeal such rules, consistent with the policies, objects and purposes of the city council, as he or she may deem necessary or desirable in the public interest in regulating the safe, enjoyable and equitable use of city parks. Rules pertaining to specific activity areas shall be displayed in a prominent and public location in or near such area or shall be communicated orally or in writing to program participants as circumstances require. Principal rules pertaining to an entire park shall be publicly and prominently displayed at the entrance to the city park. 
(Ord. 2464, § 4, Amended, 07/09/2012; Ord. 2339, Amended, 09/11/2006) 
Chapter 12.26 - FIRST AMENDMENT RIGHTS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY 
Sections: 

Section 12.26.010 - Findings and declarations of city council. 
    The City Council finds and declares: 
A.  The City has a compelling interest in preserving the health, safety and welfare of pedestrians, in maintaining the free flow of pedestrians across its sidewalks and preventing vendors and others from obstructing sidewalks in the City. 
B.  The City has a compelling interest in controlling the flow of vehicular and pedestrian traffic in a manner that protects pedestrians from harm. 
C.  The City has a compelling interest in controlling the flow of vehicular and pedestrian traffic to assure it will not obstruct or impede the operation of emergency vehicles or equipment. 
D.  The City has a compelling interest in assuring the preservation of public property and public places by preventing dangerous, unlawful or impermissible uses. 
E.  The City has a compelling interest in protecting the safety of persons and property, including protecting their health by requiring large groups using public areas to assure there are adequate sanitary facilities for human and other waste. 
F.  The City has a compelling interest in cleaning up and restoring its parks and public areas following an event or other public use. 
G.  The City has a compelling interest in preserving the City's parks' aesthetic beauty and serenity by keeping them open, attractive, free from commercial sales of merchandise and free from excessively loud noise. H. The City has a compelling interest in protecting the safety and convenience of persons using the City's parks and Victorian Square. 
I.  The City has a compelling interest in regulating competing uses of the City's parks and Victorian Square . 
J.  The City has a compelling interest in managing pedestrian congestion in the City's parks, Victorian Square and other public areas, and finds that very heavy congestion is present during special events in Victorian Square. 
K.  The City finds that there is a lack of uncongested areas during special events in Victorian Square, and that the City has a compelling interest to restrict non-commercial vendors and others who want to set up tables and chairs to exercise their First Amendment rights to designated "Free Speech Areas" during such special events to prevent further congestion of the special event. 
L.  The City has a compelling interest in preserving Victorian Square's aesthetic Victorian-era theme and in maintaining its open, attractive and visually pleasing squares and walkways. 
M.  The City has a compelling interest in protecting local merchants from unfair competition by outdoor vendors who have negligible overhead costs and who can undercut the prices local merchants must charge. 
N.  The City has a compelling interest in collecting appropriate fees from event sponsors to defray the expenses of policing traffic laws during an activity and cleaning up at the conclusion of an activity. 
O.  The City has a compelling interest in preventing the disruption of the work of public employees and further finds that the "Free Speech" rights of individuals are satisfied by allowing First Amendment activities in areas outside of public buildings. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) (Ord. 2430, Amended, 10/26/2009; Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 12.26.020 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following terms have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, unless the context otherwise requires: 
A.  "Department" means the Department of Parks and Recreation. 
B.  "Display stand" means any object used to display merchandise, and includes, without limitation, flower stands, artist's easels and similar objects. 
C.  "Expressive merchandise" means merchandise that: 
1.  Is created by hand, offered for sale by its maker, and may express any idea, belief, concept, philosophy or emotion of its maker. The maker's original product and copies thereof both qualify as "expressive merchandise." Examples include, but are not limited to, original paintings or drawings (regardless of the medium used or object on which painted or drawn), sculptures, carvings or artistic fabrications (regardless of the type of material sculpted, carved or used in fabrication). 
2.  Is communicative of any political, religious, philosophical or ideological doctrine, concept, belief or idea. Examples include, but are not limited to, a Bible, a religious brochure , a "vote for me" pamphlet, a "Save the Second Amendment" bumper sticker, a T-shirt with printing stating "Earth Now!" and a "Peace, not War" button. 
3.  Is common, mass-produced merchandise that lacks inherent expressive value but becomes expressive from being intrinsically intertwined with pure speech carrying a religious, political, philosophical or ideological message. Examples include, but are not limited to, a toy stuffed whale with a "Greenpeace" logo or tag affixed so that it is intended to convey a philosophical message of "Save the Whales;" an unlabeled toy doll of an emaciated child, with no apparent connection to any organization, distributed to donors by "Save the Children" during pure speech intended to procure donations. 
4.  Does more than propose a commercial transaction and is therefore not mere commercial speech. 
5.  Is otherwise protected "speech" or "expression" under the First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. 
D.  "Merchandise" means personal property, commodities or goods. 
E.  "Park" means all parks located in the city and includes the Sparks Marina. 
F.  "Victorian Square" means the the downtown area bounded by and including the "D" Street right-of-way, 15th Street right-of-way, Nugget Avenue right-of-way and 6th Street right-of-way. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 12.26.030 - Free speech areas in parks, Victorian Square to be designated. 
A.  The department shall designate at least one "Free Speech" area in each of the three most popular parks within the City and shall designate at least seven "Free Speech" areas in Victorian Square. The areas must be described in maps which must be made available by the department for public inspection and copying. Within each "Free Speech" area the department shall designate multiple "free speech" sites not measuring less than 10 feet by 10 feet. 
B.  In the three parks, each "Free Speech" area must contain at least four "Free Speech" sites and shall be delineated by signage stating "Free Speech Area Behind This Sign" or "Free Speech Area." . 
C.  In Victorian Square, each "Free Speech" area shall contain at least five "Free Speech" sites and shall be delineated by signage stating "Free Speech Area Behind This Sign" or "Free Speech Area." 
D.  When possible, "Free Speech" areas must be located near access points commonly used by the public for ingress and egress and shall not isolate speakers from other users. The City Attorney's office must approve the size and location of the "Free Speech" area in the parks and in Victorian Square. The size of the "Free Speech" area must be determined based on expected usage and, with approval of the City Attorney, can be increased or reduced based on actual usage. If additional "Free Speech" sites are necessary to accommodate all persons desiring to exercise their First Amendment rights, the department shall create sufficient temporary "Free Speech" sites to meet the demand therefore. 
E.  "Free Speech" activities must be allowed when a special event is occurring in a park or in Victorian Square. The area assigned for "free speech" activities may be modified to accommodate the special event but speakers must not be isolated from contact with people entering or leaving the special event. Every special event permit must contain language acknowledging that the designated "Free Speech" areas will remain open for public speech during the special event. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 12.26.040 - City council to adopt regulations for First Amendment activities in parks and Victorian Square. 
    The City Council shall adopt regulations which impose reasonable time, place and manner restrictions on the exercise of First Amendment rights in the City's parks and Victorian Square as are reasonably necessary to protect or promote the City's interests set forth in SMC 12.26.010 and the general health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Sparks and visitors to special events in Sparks. The regulations must be first approved by the City Attorney. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 12.26.060 - Commercial sale of merchandise unlawful in parks and Victorian Square; expressive merchandise exception. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in this section, it is unlawful for any person to use or employ any portion of any public street, lane, alley, park, mall, plaza (including Victorian Square) or any other public property for the conducting or transaction of any private commercial business or activity. 
B.  The sale of commercial merchandise is permitted on public property in Victorian Square pursuant to Chapter 5.59 of the SMC (Roadway and Sidewalk Vendors), Chapter 9.34 of the SMC (Special Events), and Chapter 20.53 of the SMC (Outdoor Sales). 
C.  This section does not apply to concessions granted by the City or Redevelopment Agency or to public lands, licensed, rented or leased by the City or the Redevelopment Agency to private businesses for the conducting or transaction of private commercial business or activity. 
D.  The display, offering for sale or barter, or sale or barter of expressive merchandise, or the acceptance of donations in exchange for expressive merchandise, is non-commercial expression and is not the "conducting or transaction of any private commercial business or activity" as that term is used in subsection A. 
(Ord. 2415, Amended, 10/27/2008; Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 12.26.065 - Alcoholic beverages. 
    It is unlawful for any proponent or occupant of a "free speech" site to sell or serve any alcoholic beverage in conjunction with any use of the site. 
(Ord. 2415, Add, 10/27/2008) 
Section 12.26.073 - Unlawful to place or erect tables or display stands during special events; exceptions. 
    In order to prevent over-congestion and significant interference with pedestrian traffic flow, when a permitted special event (as defined in SMC Chapter 9.34) or an expressive special event (as defined in SMC Chapter 9.35) is occupying a park or Victorian Square, it is unlawful for a person to place or erect a table or display stand on public property within those occupied portions of the park or Victorian Square, except that tables or display stands are permitted: 
A.  In a booth or space rented from the sponsor or operator of the special event or expressive special event. 
B.  In a designated "Free Speech" site within a Free Speech Area. 
C.  To be placed or erected by a person who is a party to a concession agreement with the City or Redevelopment Agency, to the extent permitted in the agreement. 
D.  To be placed or erected by the private licensee, lessee or tenant of public property that has been licensed, leased or rented by the City or Redevelopment Agency, to the extent permitted in the license, lease or rental agreement. 
For purposes of this section, a permitted special event or expressive special event shall be deemed to be occupying portions of the park or Victorian Square designated in the permit from the date and time the permitted use commences until the date and time the permitted use terminates, as set forth in the permit. 
(Ord. 2415, Add, 10/27/2008) 
Section 12.26.075 - Certain containers prohibited. 
    Within a "free speech area," including all "free speech sites" in the area, it is unlawful for any person to use or possess: 
A.  A glass beverage container; or 
B.  A metal container of an alcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. 2415, Add, 10/27/2008) 
Section 12.26.077 - Internal combustion engines prohibited; generators or alternators prohibited. 
    Within a "free speech area," including all "free speech sites," it is unlawful for any person to operate an internal combustion engine, including one used to power a generator or alternator. 
(Ord. 2415, Add, 10/27/2008) 
Section 12.26.080 - Interior portion of building used for official city business or activities is not a public forum; permitted locations for free speech activities near such buildings. 
A.  The interior portions of any building owned, leased or rented by the city and used for official business or any governmental activity is not a public forum. However, the City Council may adopt its own rules and rules for all City boards, commissions and committees to allow individuals to engage in temporary "free speech" activities before, after or during public meetings in specific locations within a building used by the city for official business. 
B.  First Amendment activities are permitted at the exterior of public entrances of buildings used for official city business. For fire and safety reasons, a person engaged in such activities shall not obstruct, or cause an obstruction of, any walkway or passageway to an entrance of such a building and shall not engage in such activities closer than 20 feet from the entrance. 
C.  For safety reasons, First Amendment activities are not permitted within 15 feet of any staircase or stairway leading to an entrance of a building or within 50 feet of any fire hydrant or emergency water supply pipe. 
D.  The permission to use public property for First Amendment activities granted by this section is not intended to, and shall not be construed to, designate a public forum inside or outside of any public building. 
E.  For purposes of this subsection, a walkway or passageway is "obstructed" if there is less than 15 feet in passable width remaining when First Amendment users and their personal property (such as tables and chairs) are located on the walkway or passageway. However, a walkway or passageway is not "obstructed" if all of the original width remains passable when First Amendment users and their personal property are located adjacent to (but not on) the walkway or passageway. 
(Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 12.26.090 - Designation of areas around certain public buildings for gathering signatures for petitions; annual reports to be filed. 
A.  The city officer or employee who is in control of the operation of an occupied city building that is open to the general public shall: 
1.  Designate an outdoor area near the primary public entrance to the building for use by any person to gather signatures on a petition for a constitutional amendment or a statewide measure proposed by initiative or referendum. The designated area must be located on concrete or asphalt if the maintenance of turf would be disrupted, and the designated area must conform with the restrictions contained in SMC 12.26.080. 
2.  On an annual basis, submit to the Secretary of State and to the Clerk of Washoe County a notice of the area at the building which is designated for the gathering of signatures on a petition. 
B.  A person is not required to notify the City of his or her intent to use a designated area to gather signatures on a petition. However, the City will not be liable for damage to the person's property (e.g., water damage from automatic lawn sprinklers) caused by the person's failure to provide the department with sufficient advance notice of his or her intention to occupy. 
C.  No person may be denied the right to use a designated area for its intended purpose, i.e., gathering signatures for a petition. 
D.  Every person using a designated area for gathering signatures must comply with all laws and regulations applicable to the designated area. 
E.  The designation of an area to gather signatures on a petition made pursuant to this section is required by state statute (NRS 293.127565) and is not intended to designate or create a public forum. 
(Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Section 12.26.100 - Use of sidewalks for first amendment activities; newspaper vending machines, newsracks permitted; obstructing sidewalks is prohibited. 
A.  Sidewalks in the City may be used for First Amendment activities if they are of sufficient width to accommodate the activity and pedestrian traffic. The City Council finds that a sidewalk must be at least four feet wide to allow two average sized persons to comfortably pass each other. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to obstruct a public sidewalk during the exercise of a First Amendment activity. 
C.  Newspaper vending machines, newsracks and similar displays of speech which are protected by the First Amendment may be placed on a public sidewalk. It is unlawful for any person to place or maintain a newspaper vending machine, newsrack or similar display in a manner which obstructs a public sidewalk. 
D.  For purposes of this section, "obstruct" means: 
1.  Placing individuals or personal property on a sidewalk to the extent that less than four feet in width remains open for pedestrians; or 
2.  Placing individuals or personal property on a sidewalk to the extent that pedestrians are forced to detour into a street or roadway to circumvent the blockade. 
A sidewalk is not "obstructed" if all of the original width remains passable when First Amendment users and their personal property are located adjacent to (but not on) the sidewalk. 
(Ord. 2340, Add, 09/25/2006) 
Chapter 12.28 - URBAN FORESTRY 
Sections: 

Section 12.28.010 - Purpose and intent. 
A.  Establish and maintain the maximum amount of tree cover on public lands in the city. 
B.  Maintain public trees in a healthy and nonhazardous condition through approved arboricultural practices. 
C.  Establish and maintain appropriate diversity in tree species and age classes to provide a stable and suitable urban forest. 
(Ord. 1881, 1995.) 
Section 12.28.020 - Definitions. 
A.  Public tree - All trees located on City of Sparks property, to include those located in all parks, in the medians, along the Truckee River and in the parkways. 
B.  Parkway - That portion of public right-of-way situated between the curbline of any street and the property line abutting and adjoining any street. In the absence of a curb, the curbline of a street shall be deemed to be the edge of that portion of public right-of-way maintained and open to the use of the public for the purpose of vehicular travel. 
C.  Urban forester - That person who shall have such duties and perform such functions as shall be prescribed herein and who shall be subject to the direction of the parks and recreation director. 
D.  Tree committee - A committee consisting of the members of the Parks and Recreation Commission. The committee's responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the study of and the dissemination of news and information regarding the protection, maintenance, removal and planting of trees on public lands, and to make such recommendations as necessary to the city council as to desirable legislation concerning the tree program and activities for the city. 
(Ord. 1881, 1995.) 
Section 12.28.030 - Injuring trees and shrubbery. 
    It is unlawful for any person to harm, deface or mutilate any ornamental tree or shrubbery of any kind or to tie, hitch or fasten any notice, rope, wire or animal to any ornamental tree or shrubbery on any public street, parkway, alley or public park or grounds within the city without first obtaining written consent from the city. 
(Ord. 1881, 1995: 1962 Code § 25.490.) 
Section 12.28.040 - Tree care. 
A.  The owner of any tree which disturbs, lifts, or interferes in any way with any sidewalk, curb, gutter, sewer, storm drain or other public improvement shall cause such tree, or the branches or roots thereof, to be removed and the improvement to be repaired and restored as originally constructed at such owner's own cost and expense. 
B.  All owners of trees shall care for, trim and prune the same when necessary for the preservation of a tree or for public safety. A property owner must trim tree limbs, shrubs and other vegetation so that any official traffic control device is not hidden or obscured from motorist view, the area above any sidewalk is clear of obstruction to a height of ten feet, and the area above street or alley pavement is clear of obstruction to a height of fifteen feet. No plants or other landscape items shall block free access to a fire hyrdant. 
(Ord. 1881, 1995: Ord. 1180 § 3, 1978: 1962 Code § 25.465.) 
Section 12.28.050 - Interference with planting, maintenance and removal. 
A.  No person, firm or corporation shall interfere with the parks and recreation director or persons acting under his/her authority while engaged in planting, mulching, pruning or removing any tree, shrub or plant in any street or public place within the city. 
B.  Nothing contained in this chapter shall preclude the removal or alteration of any tree, plant or landscaping material for construction, maintenance or operation of any public right-of-way at the direction and approval of the director of public works. 
(Ord. 1881, 1995.) 
Section 12.28.060 - Appeals. 
    Any action or intent of action may be appealed to and heard by the tree committee. An appeal shall be filed within ten (10) days after the notification of action by the city. The appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the parks and recreation director for placement on the tree committee's agenda. The appeal shall clearly specify the reasons for which a hearing is requested. After a hearing the recommendations of the tree committee will be subject to appeal and review by the city council. 
(Ord. 1881, 1995.) 
Section 12.28.070 - Administrative responsibilities. 
A.  The parks and recreation director shall, by use of city employees, the urban forester or contractors, plant, maintain and otherwise care for, or if necessary, remove trees in any public place in the city. The responsibilities of the parks and recreation director shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
1.  Recommend to the tree committee changes or additions to a Master Street Tree Plan; 
2.  Make determination of tree removals in public places; 
3.  Review all landscaping plans as they affect trees in public places; 
4.  Act as advisor to the planning commission, redevelopment agency and engineering department in tree-related issues; 
5.  Seek funding from state, federal, and other granting agencies; 
6.  Conduct community outreach and education programs; and 
7.  Enforce this chapter. 
(Ord. 1881, 1995.) 
Section 12.28.090 - Prohibited trees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to plant any and all species of genera Ulmus (elm), Salix (willow) or the following species of Populus (cottonwood): Acuminata (lanceleaf), Angustifolia (narrowleaf) Fremontii (western) and Trichocarpa (black) anywhere in the city. 
(Ord. 1881, 1995: Ord. 1180 § 2, 1978: 1962 Code § 25.455.) 
Section 12.28.100 - Penalty for violation. 
A.  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
B.  A violation of any provision of this chapter constitutes the maintenance of a public nuisance. 
C.  Upon determination that a public nuisance exists, the parks and recreation director or his/her designated representative shall serve written notice upon the owner or occupant of the premises where the tree is located to abate the nuisance. Said notice may be personally served or mailed by certified mail to the premises or last known address of the owner. 
D.  If the nuisance is not abated within ten (10) days of personal service or mailing of the notice, the parks and recreation director may summarily abate the nuisance and charge the costs thereof to the owner. If the costs thus incurred are not paid within thirty (30) days after demand, such costs shall become a lien upon the premises and may be collected and the lien enforced in the manner provided in Section 2.120 of the City Charter and the laws of the State of Nevada. 
E.  No action taken by the city to abate a nuisance shall be deemed to prevent misdemeanor prosecution of violations of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1881, 1995: Ord. 1180 § 8, 1978: 1962 § 25.495.) 
Chapter 12.32 - REMOVAL OF IMPROVEMENTS FROM FORMER CITY PROPERTY 
Sections: 

Section 12.32.010 - Generally. 
A.  When any real property situated within the limits of the city is or may be withdrawn or excluded from the city, or when any real property which is within the limits of the city of which the city has control, possession or use and occupation which does or may pass from the city, the chief of police shall withdraw, take up and remove, at the request of the city council, any improvements belonging to, made by or put upon such real property by the city. 
B.  The chief of police shall use all due diligence and, with the consent of the city council, employ all necessary assistance to comply with any special instructions that may be given him by the city council in carrying out the provisions of this section. 
(1962 Code § 50.380.) 
Chapter 12.36 - RAILROAD RIGHTS-OF-WAY 
Sections: 

Section 12.36.010 - Grant. 
    The Southern Pacific Company, a corporation, and the Central Pacific Railway Company, a corporation, are authorized to construct, operate and maintain railroad tracks across certain blocks, streets, avenues and alleys in the city, such blocks, streets, avenues and alleys being shown upon the official map of the city entitled "Plat of the Town of Sparks, County of Washoe, Nevada, formerly known as New Wadsworth and Harriman as filed and of record in the office of the County Recorder of Washoe County, State of Nevada, on April 23rd, 1904." 
(1962 Code § 40.010.) 
Section 12.36.020 - Descriptions. 
    The center lines of the tracks referred to in Section 12.36.010 are more particularly described as follows: 
A.  South Wadsworth Avenue. 
1.  Track No. 1. Beginning at a point in the northerly line of South Wadsworth Avenue, distant easterly thereon sixty-six feet, more or less, from the easterly line of Beach Street produced northerly, thence southeasterly a distance of one hundred twenty-five feet, more or less, to a point in the southerly line of South Wadsworth Avenue, distant easterly thereon one hundred ninety feet, more or less, from the easterly line of Beach Street. 
2.  Track No. 2. Beginning at a point in the northerly line of South Wadsworth Avenue, distant easterly thereon four feet, more or less, from the easterly line of Beach Street produced northerly, thence southeasterly on a curve to the right a distance of one hundred sixty-five feet, more or less, to a point in the southerly line of South Wadsworth Avenue, distant easterly thereon one hundred fifty-eight feet, more or less, from the easterly line of Beach Street. 
3.  Track No. 3. Beginning at a point in the northerly line of South Wadsworth Avenue at or near the intersection with the easterly line of Beach Street produced northerly, thence southeasterly on a curve concave to the right a distance of one hundred thirty-three feet, more or less, to a point in the southerly line of South Wadsworth Avenue, distant easterly thereon one hundred twenty-five feet, more or less, from the easterly line of Beach Street. 
B.  Cedar Street and Alley in Block 15. 
1.  Track No. 1. Beginning at a point in the westerly line of Cedar Street, distant northerly thereon forty-three feet, more or less, from the north line of the alley through Block 16, thence southeasterly a distance of sixty-five feet, more or less, to a point in the easterly line of Cedar Street, distant northerly thereon fifteen feet, more or less, from the north line of the alley through Block 15, thence continuing across private property to a point in the north line of the alley through Block 15, such point being distant easterly measured along such north line of the alley thirty-five feet, more or less, from the easterly line of Cedar Street, thence continuing southeasterly a distance of forty-five feet, more or less, to a point in the south line of the alley, distant easterly thereon eighty feet, more or less, from the easterly line of Cedar Street. 
2.  Track No. 2. Beginning at a point in the westerly line of Cedar Street, distant northerly thereon twenty-eight feet, more or less, from the northerly line of the alley through Block 16, thence southeasterly a distance of sixty-five feet, more or less, to a point in the easterly line of Cedar Street at or near its intersection with the northerly line of the alley through Block 15, thence continuing southeasterly a distance of forty-five feet, more or less, to a point in the south line of the alley, distant easterly thereon forty-five feet, more or less, from the easterly line of Cedar Street. 
3.  Track No. 3.
