Beginning at a point in the westerly line of Cedar Street, distant northerly thereon fourteen feet, more or less, from the north line of the alley through Block 16, thence southeasterly across Cedar Street and the alley through Block 15, a distance of eighty-five feet, more or less, to a point in the southerly line of the alley, distant thereon fifteen feet, more or less, from the easterly line of Cedar Street. 
C.  Frazer Avenue and Deal Street. 
1.  Track No. 1. Beginning at a point in the westerly line of Deal Street, distant thereon six feet, more or less, from the northerly line of Frazer Avenue, thence southeasterly on a curve to the left a distance of one hundred ninety feet, more or less, to a point, thence easterly, tangent to such curve, parallel to and distant fifteen and five-tenths feet, more or less, southerly at right angles from the northerly line of Frazer Avenue a distance of eight hundred feet, more or less, to a point, thence on a curve to the left, the tangent to such curve being the last described course, a distance of eighty-eight feet, more or less, to a point, thence easterly, tangent to such curve a distance of fifty-five feet, more or less, to a point in the west property line of the Central Pacific Railway Company, distant southerly thereon five feet, more or less, from the northerly line of Frazer Avenue. 
2.  Track No. 2. Beginning at a point in the northerly line of Frazer Avenue, distant westerly thereon thirty-five feet, more or less, from the westerly line of Deal Street, thence southeasterly on a curve to the left a distance of two hundred thirty-three feet, more or less, to a point, thence easterly, tangent to such curve, parallel to and distant thirty-three and five-tenths feet, more or less, southerly at right angles from the northerly line of Frazer Avenue a distance of seven hundred sixty-five feet, more or less, to a point, thence easterly on a curve to the left, the tangent to such curve being the last described course, a distance of eighty-six feet, more or less, to a point, thence easterly tangent to such curve, a distance of eighty-eight feet, more or less, to a point in the west property line of the Central Pacific Railway Company, distant southerly thereon nineteen feet, more or less, from the northerly line of Frazer Avenue. 
3.  Track No. 3. Beginning at a point in the northerly line of Frazer Avenue, distant westerly thereon eighty-one feet, more or less, from the westerly line of Deal Street, thence southeasterly on a curve to the left a distance of two hundred seventy-six feet, more or less, to a point, thence easterly tangent to such curve, parallel to and distant fifty-one and five tenths feet, more or less, southerly at right angles from the northerly line of Frazer Avenue a distance of seven hundred thirty feet, more or less, to a point, thence easterly on a curve to the left, the tangent to such curve being the last described course, a distance of eighty-eight feet, more or less, to a point, thence easterly tangent to such curve a distance of one hundred thirty-six feet, more or less, to a point in the west property line of the Central Pacific Railway Company, distant thereon thirty-two feet, more or less, from the northerly line of Frazer Avenue. 
(1962 Code § 40.020.) 
Section 12.36.030 - Streets not to be obstructed. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to authorize the Southern Pacific Company and the Central Pacific Railway Company, or either of them, from so using such tracks that such use obstructs the use of the streets, avenues and alleys as public highways. 
(1962 Code § 40.030.) 
Section 12.36.040 - Maintenance of tracks. 
    The Southern Pacific Company and Central Pacific Railway Company shall at all times maintain the tracks on or across the streets, avenues and alleys in a good and serviceable condition for vehicle and pedestrian travel. 
(1962 Code § 40.040.) 
Section 12.36.050 - Application of other laws. 
    The rights granted under this chapter are subject to all rules, regulations, ordinances and statutes of the city and the state now in effect or which may hereafter be adopted or enacted for the benefit or protection of the users of the streets, avenues and alleys authorized by the provisions of this chapter to be used by the Southern Pacific Company and Central Pacific Railway Company. 
(1962 Code § 40.050.) 
Chapter 12.42 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND VIDEO SERVICES 
Sections: 

Section 12.42.010 - Telecommunications and video service. 
A.  Every business entity providing telecommunications service within the city must obtain and pay for an annual business license. Every business entity providing video service within the city as defined by NRS 711.141 must obtain a certificate of authority issued by the Secretary of State pursuant to NRS Chapter 711. The fee for such license, or franchise fee for such certificate of authority, is payable to the city not later than 30 calendar days after the end of each calendar quarter and shall be five percent of the total gross receipts. 
B.  "Total gross receipts" means: 
1.  Revenue received from customers located within the city for local or intrastate telecommunications service; 
2.  In the case of "commercial mobile radio service" as defined in Part 20 of Title 47 of the Code of Federal Regulations, revenue received from the first $15.00 charged monthly for each line of access for each of its customers located within the city; or 
3.  In the case of a "video service provider", "gross revenue" as defined by NRS 711.066, as amended. 
C.  A license or franchise fee not received or postmarked within 30 calendar days after the end of each calendar quarter shall be delinquent and the business entity that is subject to this ordinance shall pay, in addition to the fee, a penalty of two percent per month of the delinquent amount. 
D.  Each telecommunications company which derives or intends to derive revenue from customers located within the city shall, not later than 60 calendar days after the effective date of this ordinance or 30 calendar days before the company begins to provide telecommunications service to those customers, whichever occurs later, provide to the city: 
1.  An acknowledgment that the company is operating or intends to operate within the city; and 
2.  The date that the company began or intends to begin to derive revenue from customers located within the city. 
E.  A business entity that is subject to this ordinance shall, not later than 30 calendar days after the end of each calendar quarter, provide to the city a statement of the amount of revenue the public utility derived during that calendar quarter from the sale of a telecommunication or video service to each of its customers located within the city. 
F.  Rights-of-way. 
1.  Construction or installation in the public ways shall be subject to the provisions contained in Chapter 12.12 of the Sparks Municipal Code, the latest adoption edition of the Standard Specifications for Public Works Construction, the Standard Details for Public Works Construction, the City of Sparks Public Works Design Manual and the City of Sparks Standard Details. Such publications shall be available for public inspection and review at the office of the city engineer. 
2.  A business entity that is subject to this ordinance shall submit construction drawings for city approval prior to performing any construction or installation in the public way. In the case of excavations in the public way, the business entity shall reimburse the city for related administrative costs, costs of asphalt replacement and the cost of full-time inspection of the construction or installation. 
3.  Upon completion of any construction or installation in the public way, the business entity must provide the city with "as built" construction drawings within 30 days of the completion of the work. 
4.  When directed by the city, in writing, and within the time limits set forth by the City, a business entity that is subject to this ordinance shall, at its own expense, perform any necessary alterations, repairs, maintenance or relocation of its property installed or located in the public way. If the business entity fails to perform the necessary alterations, maintenance, repairs or relocation as directed by the city, at its option the city may perform the necessary operations at the business entitles expense. 
5.  All excavations and other construction in the public ways shall be carried on to interfere as little as practicable with the use of public and private property and in accordance with any direction given by the city under the police and regulatory powers of the city. 
G.  A business entity that is subject to this ordinance shall maintain in full force and effect commercial general liability insurance with an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Nevada. 
1.  Limits of liability shall be at least $3000,000.00 combined single limit per occurrence. Any deductibles or self-insured retentions must be approved by the city. 
2.  The city, its officers, agents, and employees must be named as additional insureds and the policy must contain a provision for 30 days notice to the city of cancellation, non-renewal, or material change. 
(Ord. 2440, Add, 06/28/2010) 
Chapter 12.44 - REGIONAL ROAD IMPACT FEE 
Sections: 

Section 12.44.010 - Regional road impact fee program. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Regional Road Impact Fee" (hereinafter "RRIF") chapter. The City Council of the City of Sparks has the authority to adopt this chapter pursuant to the Nevada Constitution, Sparks City Charter Secs. 2.060 and 2.090(6), and Nevada Revised Statutes Chapter 278, Sections 278B.010 to 278B.330, inclusive, and Sections 277.080 to 277.180, inclusive. It shall apply to all lands within the boundaries of the City of Sparks. Pursuant to the Regional Road Impact Fee Ordinance Interlocal Cooperative Agreement (hereinafter "RRIF Interlocal Cooperative Agreement"), it shall also apply to all other lands within unincorporated Washoe County that are within the Service Area and all other lands within the boundaries of the City of Reno. 
(Ord. 2025, Repealed and Replaced, 05/24/1999) 
Section 12.44.020 - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish a Regionwide Impact Fee Program by the establishment of a comprehensive and Regionwide system for the imposition of road impact fees to assure that new development contributes its proportionate share of the cost of providing, and benefits from the provision of, the road capital improvements identified as needed to be built in the RRIF CIP which has been adopted as the City of Sparks Local CIP, and the Local CIP of the other two (2) Participating Local Governments. It is intended to implement and be consistent with the Regional Road Impact Fee System Capital Improvements Plan (hereinafter "RRIF CIP"), the City of Sparks Road Capital Improvements Plan (hereinafter "Local CIP") and Master Plan, and the Local CIPs and Master Plans of the other two (2) Participating Local Governments. 
(Ord. 2418, Amended, 12/15/2008; Ord. 2025, Repealed and Replaced, 05/24/1999) 
Section 12.44.030 - Adoption and amendment of the RRIF System General Administrative Manual. 
    The Regional Road Impact Fee System General Administrative Manual (hereinafter "RRIF Manual") approved by the Regional Transportation Commission of Washoe County on August 18, 1995, attached to the original adopting ordinance and last amended by the Regional Transportation Commission of Washoe County on September 19, 2014, is hereby adopted. A copy of the Amended RRIF Manual is attached hereto as Exhibit "1" and incorporated herein by reference. The RRIF Manual shall contain appropriate definitions, an independent fee calculation study, exemptions, credits, appeals and review sections for the effective administration of the program. It may subsequently be amended by a resolution approved by the Regional Transportation Commission Board and the Governing Bodies of each Participating Local Government. 
(Ord. 2508, § 1, Amended, 01/26/2015; Ord. 2444, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2418, Amended, 12/15/2008; Ord. 2379, Amended, 10/22/2007; Ord. 2171, Repealed and Replaced, 05/27/2003; Ord. 2025, Repealed and Replaced, 05/24/1999) 
Section 12.44.040 - Adoption of the Regional Road Impact Fee System Capital Improvement Plan ("RRIF CIP"). 
    The Regional Road Improvement Fee System Capital Improvement Plan ("RRIF CIP") adopted by the Regional Transportation Commission of Washoe County on August 18, 1995, attached to the original adopting ordinance as and last amended by the Regional Transportation Commission of Washoe County on September 19, 2014 is hereby adopted. A copy of the Amended RRIF CIP is attached hereto as Exhibit "2" and Exhibit "3" and incorporated by reference. It may be amended only by subsequent ordinance. 
(Ord. 2508, § 1, Amended 1/12/2015; Ord. 2444, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2418, Amended, 12/15/2008; Ord. 2379, Amended, 10/22/2007; Ord. 2171, Repealed and Replaced, 05/27/2003; Ord. 2025, Repealed and Replaced, 05/24/1999) 
Section 12.44.050 - Service areas. 
    There are hereby established two service areas for the imposition of regional road impact fees and the collection and expenditure of funds under the provisions of this section. The Service Areas are identified in Exhibit B of the RRIF General Administrative Manual, referred to in Section 12.44.040 of this chapter and is defined as: 
A.  North Service Area. Starting at the southwest corner of the district at the California-Nevada state line and Interstate 80, follow the state line north to the northern boundary of the Washoe County North Valleys planning area (i.e. northern boundary of the Red Rock Hydrographic Basin boundary), then east along the northern boundary of the North Valleys planning area (i.e. northern boundary of the Red Rock and Bedell Flat Hydrographic Basin boundary) then north to the northwest corner of the Warm Springs planning area, then southeast and south along the boundary of the Warm Springs planning area, then west along the southern boundary of the Warm Springs planning area to the eastern edge of the Washoe County Spanish Springs planning area and the Washoe County Truckee Canyon planning area, then southwest along the westen edge of the Truckee Canyon planning area to Interstate 80, then west along Interstate 80 to the California- Nevada state line. 
B.  South Service Area. Starting at the northwest corner of the district at the California-Nevada state line and Interstate 80, follow Interstate 80 east to the western edge of the Washoe County Truckee Canyon planning area, then south along the Washoe County-Storey County line to the Washoe County-Carson City line, then west along the Washoe County-Carson City line to the southern jurisdictional line of the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency and the Washoe County Tahoe planning area, then north along the California-Nevada state line to Interstate 80. 
(Ord. 2508, § 1, Amended, 01/26/2015; Ord. 2444, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2418, Amended, 12/15/2008; Ord. 2025, Repealed and Replaced, 05/24/1999) 
Section 12.44.060 - Impact fees. 
    The amount of the impact fees shall be determined by the Local RRIF Administrator in accordance with the applicable provisions of the RRIF Manual adopted by the Regional Transportation Commission of Washoe County on September 19, 2014 or as subsequently amended by resolution as provided herein and the application of the fee schedule identified as Exhibit D of the RRIF General Administrative Manual referenced in 12.44.030. Said fee schedule may only be modified by subsequent ordinance. 
(Ord. 2508, § 1, Amended, 01/26/2015; Ord. 2444, Amended, 11/22/2010; Ord. 2418, Amended, 12/15/2008; Ord. 2379, Amended, 10/22/2007; Ord. 2171, Repealed and Replaced, 05/27/2003; Ord. 2025, Repealed and Replaced, 05/24/1999) 
Section 12.44.070 - Establishment of trust fund. 
    There is hereby established the City of Sparks Regional Road Impact Fee Trust Fund (hereinafter "City of Sparks RRIF Trust Fund") and the RTC Regional Road Impact Fee Trust Fund (hereinafter "RTC RRIF Trust Fund") for the purpose of ensuring that feepayers receive sufficient benefit for regional road impact fees paid. 
(Ord. 2025, Repealed and Replaced, 05/24/1999) 
Section 12.44.080 - General requirements for trust fund. 
A.  All regional road impact fees collected by City of Sparks' RRIF Administrator pursuant to this section shall be immediately deposited in the City of Sparks RRIF Trust Fund. 
B.  Any proceeds in the City of Sparks RRIF Trust Fund not immediately necessary for expenditure shall be invested in an interest-bearing account. All income derived from these investments shall be retained in the City of Sparks RRIF Trust Fund until transferred to the RTC RRIF Trust Fund. Record of the City of Sparks RRIF Trust Fund accounts shall be available for public inspection in the Local Government RRIF Administrator's Office, during normal business hours. 
C.  No less frequently than quarterly, and pursuant to the RRIF Interlocal Cooperative Agreement, the City of Sparks RRIF Administrator shall transfer the impact fee funds in the City of Sparks RRIF Trust Fund to the RTC RRIF Administrator, who shall deposit these funds in the RTC RRIF Trust Fund. All proceeds in the RTC RRIF Trust Fund not immediately necessary for expenditure shall be invested in an interest bearing account. Records of the RTC RRIF Trust Fund accounts shall be available for public inspection in the RTC RRIF Administrator's Office, during normal business hours. 
(Ord. 2025, Repealed and Replaced, 05/24/1999) 
Section 12.44.090 - Limitations on expenditures. 
A.  Impact fee monies shall only be expended from funds drawn from the RTC RRIF Trust Fund. 
B.  Funds shall only be expended on those projects selected by the RTC Board and approved by the RTC Board and the Participating Local Governments in the RRIF Interlocal Cooperative Agreement. 
C.  The expenditure of impcat fee funds shall be limited to those road capital improvement projects included in the RRIF CIP. 
D.  For the purposes of determining whether impact fee funds have been spent or encumbered, the first fees collected shall be considered the first monies spent or encumbered. 
E.  If impact fee funds transferred to the RTC RRIF Trust Fund are required to be refunded pursuant to Section VIII of the RRIF Manual, they shall be returned by the RTC RRIF Administrator to the Local RRIF Administrator for refund. 
(Ord. 2025, Repealed and Replaced, 05/24/1999) 
Section 12.44.100 - Service Area Expenditure of Fees. 
    Impact fee funds shall be spent within the Service Area from which the traffic generating land development activity paying the fee is located, except that: 
A.  Where a road on the RRIF Network as identified in the RRIF CIP is used to define Service Area boundaries, the road demarcating the boundary shall be considered as part of both Benefit Districts that it bounds, the impact fees from both Benefit Districts may be used to fund road capital improvements for that road including freeway ramps that provide access to a boundary road. 
B.  Impact fee funds may be used to fund a road capital improvement on the RRIF CIP outside the Service Area from which the fees are collected if it is demonstrated by competent substantial evidence that the feepayers from the Service Area from which the fees come will receive sufficient benefit from the road capital improvement as provided in the RIFF General Administrative Manual. 
(Ord. 2508, Amended, 01/26/2015; Ord. 2025, Repealed and Replaced, 05/24/1999) 
Chapter 12.46 - NATURAL GAS FRANCHISE AGREEMENT 
Sections: 

Section 12.46.010 - Natural gas franchise agreement. 
    The City of Sparks and the Sierra Pacific Power Company have entered into a Natural Gas Franchise Agreement, to be effective on April 26, 2006. A copy of said agreement is available from the office of the City Clerk, City of Sparks, Nevada. The fees collected in excess of two percent of the franchisee's gross revenues as defined in the agreement shall be distributed between a fund designated for street maintenance and/or improvements (including, but not limited to, sidewalks, curb and gutter systems) and utility relocations and a fund designated for park maintenance and/or improvements in such proportions as the City Council may direct from time to time. 
(Ord. 2540, § 1, Amended, 09/11/2017; Ord. 2315, Add, 03/27/2006) 
Chapter 12.48 - ELECTRICAL SYSTEM FRANCHISE AGREEMENT 
Sections: 

Section 12.48.010 - Electrical system franchise agreement. 
    The City of Sparks and the Sierra Pacific Power Company have entered into an Electrical System Franchise Agreement, to be effective on April 26, 2006. A copy of said agreement is available from the office of the City Clerk, City of Sparks, Nevada. The fees collected in excess of two percent of the franchisee's gross revenues as defined in the agreement shall be distributed between a fund designated for street maintenance and/or improvements (including, but not limited to, sidewalks, curb and gutter systems) and utility relocations and a fund designated for park maintenance and/or improvements in such proportions as the City Council may direct from time to time. 
(Ord. 2539, § 1, Amended, 09/11/2017; Ord. 2316, Add, 03/27/2006) 
Chapter 12.50 - RIGHTS-OF-WAY AGREEMENT 
Sections: 

Section 12.50.010 - Rights-of-way agreement 
    The City of Sparks and AT&T have entered into a Rights-of-Way Agreement to be effective on February 26, 2007. During the term of this agreement, AT&T agrees as compensation for the use of the City's rights-of-way to pay the City a fee of five percent (5%) of gross revenues starting after the effective date of this agremeent. The fee amount shall be calculated based on the amount of gross revenues received by AT&T for provision of IP Video Services to subscribers located within the City of Sparks. A copy of said agreement is available from the Office of the City Clerk, City of Sparks, Nevada. 
(2359, Added, 02/26/2007)

Section 13.03.341 - Interference.

Interval residential would include motel and concominium units that are normally rented out on a weekly basis.

Section 13.03.470 - NDEP.

Section 13.03.480 - New source. 
    "New source" means any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which is commenced after the publication of proposed regulations prescribing a Section 307(c) (33 U.S.C. 1317) categorical pretreatment standard which will be applicable to such source, if such standard is thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: 
A.  The construction is at the site at which no other source is located; or 
B.  The construction totally replaces an existing source; or 
C.  The production or wastewater generating processes of the construction are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source, should be considered. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; Ord. 1283 § 2 (part), 1980)

Section 13.03.550 - Pollutant. 
    "Pollutant" means substances including, but not limited to: 
A.  Commercial and industrial waste (such as fuels, solvents, chemicals, detergents, plastic pellets, hazardous materials or substances, hazardous wastes, fertilizers, pesticides, soot, slag, ash, and sludge); 
B.  Metals (such as cadmium, lead, zinc, copper, silver, nickel, chromium and arsenic) and nonmetals (such as carbon, chlorine, fluorine, phosphorous, sand and sulfur; 
C.  Petroleum hydrocarbons (such as fuels, oils, lubricants, surfactants, waste oils, solvents, coolants, and grease); 
D.  Eroded soils, sediment, and particulate materials in amounts which may adversely affect the beneficial use of the receiving waters, flora, or fauna of the state; 
E.  Animal waste (such as discharges from confinement facilities, kennels, pens, recreational facilities, stables, and show facilities; 
F.  Substances having acidic or corrosive characteristics such as a pH of less than 5.5 or greater than 10.0 units; 
G.  Substances having unusual coloration or turbidity, levels of fecal coliform, fecal streptococcus, or enterococcus, which may adversely affect the beneficial use of the receiving waters, flora, or fauna of the state. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2186, Amended, 08/25/2003; Ord. 2043, Added, 11/22/1999) 
Section 13.03.560 - POTW. 
    "POTW" means publicly owned treatment works. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 1686, 1991) 
Section 13.03.570 - Premises. 
    "Premises" means a parcel of real estate or portion thereof including any improvements thereon which is determined by the city to be a single user for purposes of receiving, using, and paying for sewage and storm drain collection, treatment and disposal service. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 1283 § 2 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.03.580 - Pretreatment or treatment. 
    "Pretreatment or treatment" means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to or in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into a POTW. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, or process changes by other means, except as prohibited by 40 CFR Section 403.6(d). 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2043, Added, 11/22/1999)

Section 13.03.710 - Secondary containment. 
    "Secondary containment" means a level of containment that is external to and separate from primary containment (e.g., concrete dike, wall, barrier, berm, bin, drum or tank). 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2186, Amended, 08/25/2003; Ord. 2043, Added, 11/22/1999) 
Section 13.03.720 - Single-family dwelling or residential unit. 
    "Single-family dwelling or residential unit" means a building containing one (1) kitchen, designed and/or used to house not more than one (1) family, including necessary employees of each such family. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2043, Added, 11/22/1999) 
Section 13.03.725 - Significant industrial user. 
    "Significant industrial user" means: (1) all industrial users subject to categorical pretreatment standards under 40 CFR 403.6 and 40 CFR chapter I, subpart N; and (2) any other industrial user that discharges an average of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons per day or more of process wastewater to the POTW (excluding sanitary, non-contact cooling, and boiler blowdown wastewater), contributes a process wastestream which makes up five (5) percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plant, or is designated as such by the POTW on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard, or requirement (in accordance with 40 CFR 403.8(f)(6). 
(Ord. 2503, Add, 09/08/2014) 
Section 13.03.730 - Significant violation. 
    "Significant violation" means a violation which remains uncorrected forty-five (45) days after notification of noncompliance; which is part of a pattern of noncompliance over a twelve-month period; which involves a failure to accurately report noncompliance; or which resulted in the POTW exercising its emergency authority under 40 CFR 403.8(f)(1)(vi)(B). 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 1686, 1991) 
Section 13.03.740 - Standard methods. 
    "Standard methods" refers to the most current edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," prepared by American Public Health Association, American Water Works Association and Water Pollution Control Federation. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 1283 § 2 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.03.750 - Storm drain facilities, or storm drain, or storm sewer. 
    "Storm drain facilities", "storm drain", or "storm sewer" means the public facilities that are used to convey storm water, including, but not limited to, catch basins, drop inlets, drains, gutters, piping, ditches and combined sewers and other facilities designed to remove storm water. 
(Ord. 2503, Amended, 09/08/2014; Ord. 2420, Add, 01/26/2009) 
Section 13.03.760 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. 2503, § 23, adopted Sept. 8, 2014, repealed § 13.03.760, entitled "Storm sewer", which derived from: Ord. 2420, adopted Jan. 26, 2009. 
Section 13.03.770 - Storm water. 
    "Storm water" is a type of waste water that originates during precipitation events and includes water that originates with snowmelt or runoff water from overwatering. Storm water is water that does not soak into the ground or is channeled into the storm drain. 
(Ord. 2420, Add, 01/26/2009) 
Section 13.03.780 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. 2503, § 24, adopted Sept. 8, 2014, repealed § 13.03.780, entitled "Total suspended solids", which derived from: Ord. 1283, adopted 1980; Ord. 2043, adopted Nov. 22, 1999; and Ord. 2420, adopted Jan. 26, 2009. 
Section 13.03.790 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. 2503, § 25, adopted Sept. 8, 2014, repealed § 13.03.790, entitled "TDS or total dissolved solid", which derived from: Ord. 1686, 1991; and Ord. 2420, adopted Jan. 26, 2009. 
Section 13.03.800 - Toxic pollutant. 
    "Toxic pollutant" means any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency under the provisions of Section 307(a) of the Act or other Acts. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2043, Added, 11/22/1999) 
Section 13.03.810 - Recreational vehicle park. 
    "Recreational vehicle park" means a parcel or tract of land, having as its principal use the transient rental or occupancy of space by two (2) or more recreational vehicles, including accessory buildings, structures, or uses customarily incidental thereto. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 1283 § 2 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.03.820 - Waste. 
    "Waste" includes sewage and all other waste substances, liquid, solid, gaseous, or radioactive, associated with human habitation, or of human or animal origin, or from producing, manufacturing, or processing operation of whatever nature, including such waste placed within containers of whatever nature prior to, and for the purposes of, disposal. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 1283 § 2 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.03.830 - Wastewater 
    "Wastewater" means waste and water, whether treated or untreated, discharged to the city's wastewater facilities. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 1283 § 2 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.03.840 - Wastewater facilities. 
    "Wastewater facilities" includes the public sewer, storm drain and reclaimed water facilities. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; Ord. 1283 § 2 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.03.850 - USC. 
    "USC means the United States Code. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2043, Added, 11/22/1999) 
Section 13.03.860 - User charge. 
    "User charge" means the sewer and storm drain service charge to users of the "wastewater facilities" which is based on wastewater flow and wastewater BOD, suspended solids, total nitrogen and total phosphorus concentrations. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; Ord. 1283 § 2 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.03.870 - Units of service. 
    "Units of service" is a method of comparing or equating industrial/commercial users to a "residential unit" for the purposes of sewer user charge and connection fees. One (1) residential unit of service is equal to 21.65 weighted fixture units. 
(Ord. 2420, Renumbered, 01/26/2009; Ord. 1283 § 2 (part), 1980) 
Chapter 13.04 - RAW LAND DEVELOPMENT 

Section 13.04.010 - Sewer and storm drain line extensions-Policy declaration. 
    In order to provide for the orderly development of sanitary sewer lines and storm drain facilities throughout the city limits, it is declared to be a policy of the city to provide for extensions of existing sanitary sewer lines and storm drain lines to serve those areas of the city which are in the planning stages of development, or those areas which have been developed without the benefit of such facilities in such a manner as to allow the cost of such extensions to be paid out of funds readily available to the city and to be charged against the recorded owner of the land being developed on a prorated basis prior to final acceptance of such development by the proper officials of the city. 
(Ord. 628 § 2, 1965) 
Section 13.04.020 - Sewer and storm drain line extensions-Procedures. 
A.  When it is deemed necessary to provide an extension of existing sanitary sewer lines or existing storm drains to serve a contemplated subdivision or other development in the city, the public works department shall prepare a detailed plan and estimate of construction costs, engineering costs, right-of-way acquisition costs and all other incidental costs connected with any such extension and shall determine the area that may be served by such extension. 
B.  Upon completion of such detailed plan and estimate and determination of area, it shall be submitted to the city council for study. 
C.  The city council, after reviewing such plan, estimate and determination of area, may, by ordinance, approve such plans, estimates and determinations of area and approve a cost per unit of area to be served by any such extension, and all land subdividers, land developers and property owners shall receive notice of the hearing of each ordinance by mail, postage prepaid, to the address of record shown on the records of the Washoe County Assessor's office. 
D.  Prior to connection, any such land developer, subdivider or property owner within the area to be served by any such extension shall enter into a written agreement with the city to pay his proportionate share of the entire cost of such extension on a prorated area basis: 
1.  In the case of an existing development, prior to any connection being made to any such extension of the sanitary sewer system or the storm drain system; 
2.  In the case of a new development, prior to the approval of a final subdivision map or the issuance of a building permit. 
E.  Nothing contained herein shall require the city council to approve or the city to share in any of the costs of any such extensions to any area within the city. 
F.  All funds received by the city pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be deposited in the sewer capital improvement fund and are to be used for the same purposes as other moneys in the fund are used. 
(Ord. 628 § 3, 1965) 
Chapter 13.06 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Section 13.06.010 - Mandatory connections. 
    Each owner of houses, buildings, or other properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, commercial, industrial, or other like purposes, situated within the incorporated areas of the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is located a public sanitary sewer, shall connect to such sewer within ninety (90) days after such sewer is available for use wherever such public sewer line is within three hundred (300) feet of any building discharging sanitary or process waste. 
(Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; Ord. 1283 § 3 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.06.020 - Notice to director of finance required. 
A.  If any person, firm or corporation transfers, conveys or sells the title to any property which is connected to the sewer system, the person, firm or corporation to whom the property is transferred, conveyed or sold shall report such transfer, conveyance, or sale to the office of the director of finance within fifteen (15) days thereof, advising the director of finance of the name and mailing address of the person, firm or corporation to which the title to such property has been transferred, conveyed, or sold, together with the date of such transfer. 
B.  Upon completion of construction of a new or additional dwelling or commercial unit on any property within the city, the owner of such property must notify the director of finance within fifteen (15) days advising the director of finance of the name and mailing address of the owner of the property, the number and address of new or additional units, the name and address of a commercial tenant or lessee, if any, and the date of completion or issuance of certificate of occupancy. 
(Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; 2014, Amended, 12/14/1998; Ord. 1630 § 1, 1988: Ord. 1283 § 3 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.06.030 - Septic tank use. 
A.  If any property which is hereafter annexed to the city is using a sewer septic tank which has been and is approved by and acceptable to the Washoe County District Health Department, such property may continue to use such septic tank in the city so long as such tank is acceptable to the state board of health. 
B.  In the event any such septic tank becomes unusable for any reason whatsoever, or is not accepted by the Washoe County District Health Department, then the property being serviced by such septic tank shall become connected to the Sparks municipal sewer system within thirty (30) days thereafter. 
(Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 1283 § 3 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.06.040 - Sewer service charge regulations. 
    The purpose of these sewer service charge regulations is to provide a system of user charges and connection fees for the proportional distribution of costs to existing and future users of the wastewater facilities based on the user's wastewater volume, strength, flowrate characteristics, and cost of wastewater facilities and storm water conveyance system. Revenues derived from the application hereof shall be used to defray the city's cost of operating and maintaining an adequate storm water conveyance system and wastewater collection, treatment and disposal system and to provide sufficient funds for capital outlay, bond service costs, capital improvements and depreciation. Wastewater facilities construction requirements are also included in Chapters 13.30 and 13.85. Charges, fees and limitations shall be reviewed at least once every two years by the Public Works Director. The Public Works Director shall recommend and/or effect changes as necessary for the proper collection, treatment and disposal of wastewater. 
(Ord. 1421 § 5, 1983: Ord. 1283 § 3 (part), 1980.) (Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2390, Amended, 02/25/2008; Ord. 2186, Amended, 08/25/2003; Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999) 
Section 13.06.050 - Scope. 
    These provisions shall apply to all direct or indirect discharges to the wastewater facilities of the city. The provisions regulate sewer service user charges, connection fees and wastewater facilities construction. 
(Ord. 1421 § 6, 1983: Ord. 1283 § 3 (part), 1980.) (Ord. 2390, Amended, 02/25/2008; Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999) 
Section 13.06.060 - Administration. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this title, the Public Works Director shall administer, implement and enforce the provisions herein. Any powers granted or duties imposed upon the Public Works Director may be delegated to persons acting in the beneficial interest of, or in the employment of, the city. 
(Ord. 1283 § 3 (part), 1980.) (Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2186, Amended, 08/25/2003; Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999) 
Section 13.06.070 - Discharges subject to these regulations. 
    All wastewater discharges to the city's wastewater facilities, whether within or outside the city limits, are equally subject to the sewer user charges and construction requirements. 
(Ord. 1421 § 7, 1983: Ord. 1283 § 3 (part), 1980.) (Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999) 
Section 13.06.080 - Dischargers outside the city limits. 
    The city shall accept wastewater from dischargers located outside the city limits. Those dischargers not located within a sanitary district or sewer utility district may be incorporated into the city limits, upon the city's agreement. The city will bill all discharges outside the city limits through the sanitary district, sewer utility district, or Washoe County, in accordance with the charges prescribed in this title. 
(Ord. 1283 § 3 (part), 1980.) 
Chapter 13.09 - SEWER, STORM AND RIVER FLOOD USER CHARGES 

Section 13.09.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the sewer and storm drains user charge is to recover administration, collection, treatment and disposal, operation, rehabilitation and maintenance costs related to the sanitary sewer and storm drain facilities and it is distributed based on volume and equivalent domestic strength wastewater. The portion of the operation and maintenance costs which are fixed costs such as billing of user charges will be distributed to the users as a monthly service charge. The purpose of the river flood protection user rate is to fund the North Truckee Drain Realignment Project and subsequent infrastructure projects that will protect the city from river flooding events. 
(Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2390, Amended, 02/25/2008; Ord. 1284 § 2 (part), 1980)

Section 13.09.025 - Sewer rebate program. 
    If you live in a dwelling or residence in the City of Sparks and are enrolled in: (1) the State of Nevada Welfare Division Energy Assistance Program (EAP); (2) the Federal Supplemental Security Income (SSI) Program; (3) Social Security Disability (SSD); or (4) or another equivalent low-income program you may be eligible to receive a sewer rebate up to one quarter's sewer, storm drains, and river flood user charge per the applicable fiscal year, provided you can demonstrate your eligibility. Any rebate granted may be prorated based on the amount of time the applicant has lived within the City of Sparks during the prior fiscal year. No more than one rebate per fiscal year may be given. However, you may apply once a fiscal year as long as the program is in effect. Applications and additional information may be obtained from the customer service department. All applications shall be subject to review and income verification. 
(Ord. 2571, § 2, Amended, 12/10/2018; Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2390, Amended, 02/25/2008; Ord. 2156, Amended, 12/09/2002; 2055, Added, 12/27/1999)

Section 13.09.031 - Industrial/commercial, federal, state, county and school district dischargers with water meters. 
    Effective December 31, 2002, the public works director will no longer allow private water meters to be used to determine irrigation credits. Instead, industrial/commercial dischargers will be required to have an additional public utility meter installed to separately measure water that is used for irrigation and is not discharged to the sewer. An administrative fee will be assessed for periodic reading of previously allowed separate private water meters and for processing. 
(Ord. 2503, Amended, 09/08/2014; Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2186, Amended, 08/25/2003; Ord. 2043, Added, 11/22/1999)

    Subject to approval by the city council, an industrial/commercial discharger may apply to the public works director for a special user charge if the discharger can demonstrate that the rates specified in this title are inequitable or unfair because its fees are higher than the fees assessed to industrial/commercial dischargers requiring comparable treatment. 
(Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2186, Amended, 08/25/2003; Ord. 2056, Added, 12/27/1999)

Section 13.09.050 - Residential septage. 
    Residential septage discharged to the municipal wastewater system is only dischargeable at TMWRF. It must have compatible pollutants and must conform to the requirements of this title. It may not exceed the mass loads for constituents using the limitations in Section 13.36.090, or actual residential concentrations, whichever is lower. Fees for residential septage shall be calculated based on sampled and analyzed waste strengths of compatible pollutants using septic waste strengths defined in the handbook of Septage Treatment and Disposal, United States EPA, Document No. 625/6-84-009. In addition to the unit cost of compatible treatment, a flat fee of $0.06/gallon shall be assessed to cover the special costs of providing septic waste services. 
(Ord. 2053, Amended, 12/27/1999; Ord. 1686, 1991) 
Section 13.09.055 - Industrial/commercial waste transported by vehicle. 
    Facilities generating industrial/commercial waste who transport that waste by vehicle to TMWRF for disposal must be issued an environmental control permit as outlined in Chapter 13.39 of this title, notwithstanding anything to the contrary in Chapter 13.39, prior to disposal and must otherwise comply with the requirements of this title. Wastes transported by truck do not qualify for exemption under the solid waste requirements of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act ("RCRA") under the domestic sewage exclusion of 40 CFR 261.4(a)(1). A flat fee of $0.075/gallon shall be assessed to cover special costs of providing waste services. 
(Ord. 2503, Amended, 09/08/2014; Ord. 2186, Amended, 08/25/2003; Ord. 2054, Added, 12/27/1999) 
Section 13.09.060 - Portable toilet waste discharge fees. 
    The public works director shall establish conditions for the discharge of portable toilet waste. Dischargers of portable toilet waste will be considered industrial/commercial dischargers for the purposes of billing. 
(Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2186, Amended, 08/25/2003; Ord. 2043, Added, 11/22/1999) 
Chapter 13.24 - CONNECTION FEES 

Section 13.24.010 - Connection fee payment. 
    Except as otherwise provided in a sewer service agreement between Sparks and Sun Valley General Improvement District or Washoe County, the connection fees set forth in this chapter apply to all new construction. The connection fee will be paid when the building permit is issued or the payment of the connection fee can be deferred until prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy or for twelve (12) months, whichever comes first. If the applicant chooses to defer the payment of connection fees, no temporary certificate of occupancy will be issued until such time as the connection fees are paid. If a connection is made to the wastewater facility without a building permit and payment of connection fees, the discharger will be subject to a connection fee which is twice the applicable connection fee. 
(Ord. 2493, Amended, 06/23/2014; Ord. 1283 § 4 (part), 1980.) (Ord. 2390, Amended, 02/25/2008; Ord. 2156, Amended, 12/09/2002) 
Section 13.24.020 - Dwelling or residential unit. 
    The sewer connection fee is at a flat rate for each residential unit and shall be in accordance with the following schedule: 
Type of Unit Connection Fee effective January 1, 2019 Single-family residential $7,332.54/unit Multiple-family residential and mobile home $7,332.54/unit Interval residential $7,332.54/unit Roominghouse $7,332.54 plus $3,666.27/rental room  
    Effective January 1, 2020, connection fees shall be adjusted annually based on the Engineering News Record Construction Cost Index. The measurement period shall end with the published index for November of each year and the resulting increases shall be implemented January of each year. Calculation of the change in the index is made by dividing the current index for November by the preceding index for November and subtracting one. 
    A supplemental river flood protection connection fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) will be charged to each dwelling or residential unit to which this ordinance applies, effective April 1, 2008. 
(Ord. 2571, § 5, Amended, 12/10/2018; Ord. 2391, Amended, 02/25/2008; Ord. 2390, Amended, 02/25/2008; Ord. 2156, Amended, 12/09/2002; Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; 1949, Amended, 11/24/1997; Ord. 1368 § 1, 1982: Ord. 1292 § 3, 1980: Ord. 1283 § 4 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.24.030 - Industrial/commercial discharger. 
    On January 1, 2019, the sewer connection fees will be based on the number of weighted fixture units which are being connected, times three hundred forty-four dollars and thirty-three cents ($344.33) per weighted fixture unit. Effective January 1, 2020, connection fees shall be adjusted annually based on the Engineering News Record Construction Cost Index. The measurement period shall end with the published index for November of each year and the resulting increases shall be implemented January of each year. Calculation of the change in the index is made by dividing the current index for November by the preceding index for November and subtracting one. 
    If the wastewater discharge contains BOD, suspended solids, total phosphorus or total nitrogen concentrations more than three times higher than for the discharger categories listed in Section 13.09.030, the public works director may adjust the sewer connection fee to cover any additional capital costs required for treating and disposing of the wastewater. The public works director's decision may be appealed to the city council. 
    A supplemental river flood protection connection fee of nine dollars and twenty-four cents ($9.24) per weighted fixture unit will be charged to each industrial/commercial discharger to which this ordinance applies, effective April 1, 2008. 
(Ord. 2571, § 6, Amended, 12/10/2018; Ord. 2503, Amended, 09/08/2014; Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2391, Amended, 02/25/2008; Ord. 2390, Amended, 02/25/2008; Ord. 2186, Amended, 08/25/2003; Ord. 2156, Amended, 12/09/2002; Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; Ord. 1949, Amended, 11/24/1997; Ord. 1374 § 1, 1982: Ord. 1368 § 2, 1982: Ord. 1283 § 4 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.24.040 - Abandonment of sewer connections. 
    There shall be no refunds granted for abandoning fixtures that connect to sewer facilities. However, the city may provide documentation of a weighted fixture unit credit per the schedule in Section 13.09.040 at the time of abandonment. Credit for abandonment of residential uses shall be per equivalent residential unit (ERU). If fixtures are added in excess of the abandonment credit, connection fees shall be required for weighted fixture units that exceed the abandonment credit at the rates in effect at the time of permit applications. To obtain a weighted fixture unit credit, the owner, discharger, or account holder must provide sufficient documentation of the credit previously granted by the city. Fixture credits shall be applied on a per parcel basis and are not transferable to another parcel. 
(Ord. 2503, Amended, 09/08/2014; Ord. 2390, Add, 02/25/2008) 
Section 13.24.050 - Change in use. 
A.  Connection fees associated with a change in use from an industrial/commercial discharge to a residential discharge, or vice versa, are subject to a credit in the number of weighted fixture units for an industrial/commercial discharge, or the number of dwelling units for a residential discharge, upon which the connection fee was originally based. 
B.  Connection fees associated with a change of use to a new use will be determined in accordance with the type of use as outlined in this chapter. 
(Ord. 2390, Add, 02/25/2008) 
Chapter 13.27 - BILLING, COLLECTION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Section 13.27.010 - Charges payable by owner. 
    The city shall bill the owner of the premises connected to the wastewater facilities for payment of sewer and storm drain user charges. The owner of record according to the records on file with the office of the county assessor shall be responsible for the payment of sewer user charges as specified in this title. Until paid, all rates, tolls, charges and damages provided in this title institute a lien on and against the property served and may be foreclosed on as provided by law. 
(Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 2390, Add, 02/25/2008) 
Section 13.27.015 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. 2503, § 31, adopted Sept. 8, 2014, repealed § 13.27.015, entitled "Charges payable by owner", which derived from: Ord. 1283, adopted 1980; Ord. 1421, adopted 1983; Ord. 2013, adopted Dec. 14, 1998; Ord. 2043, adopted Nov. 22, 1999; and Ord. 2420, adopted Jan. 26, 2009. 
Section 13.27.020 - Billing period. 
A.  The billing period for the charges shall be quarterly for all sewer users, except as otherwise provided herein. The payments shall be due and payable as noted on the sewer bill. 
B.  Sewer accounts which are based upon water flow measurements shall be billed monthly. 
(Ord. 1393 § 1, 1983: Ord. 1283 § 5 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.27.040 - Late charges for delinquent fees. 
A.  A twenty-five (25) percent late charge shall be assessed against delinquent quarterly fees. Late charges shall be computed upon each unpaid fee and shall not be compounded. All late charges shall be added to bills and become a lien against the premises pursuant to Section 13.27.070. 
B.  An eight and three-tenths (8.3) percent late charge shall be assessed against delinquent monthly fees. Late charges shall be included in each monthly billing cycle for delinquent fees and thereafter added to bills for subsequent months. 
(Ord. 2390, Amended, 02/25/2008; Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; Ord. 1714, 1991: Ord. 1606 § 2, 1988: Ord. 1283 § 5 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.27.050 - Standby charge. 
    There shall be no reduction in charges for any premises to which a sewer service connection exists during any period of vacancy. All dischargers who have sewer user charges which are based on water use shall be subject to a standby charge during periods of vacancy or nonuse of facilities. This standby charge shall not be less than one (1) unit of service per month times the effective dollar rate for one (1) single-family residential dwelling unit. 
(Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; Ord. 1321 § 5, 1981: Ord. 1283 § 5 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.27.060 - Termination of charges. 
    The sewer service charge shall be terminated upon the receipt of an affidavit of sewer connection severance or building demolition and verification by the public works department. Any discharger that has the sewer service charge terminated will only be allowed to reconnect to the sewer system after obtaining a building permit and paying the applicable connection fees. 
(Ord. 2420, Amended, 01/26/2009; Ord. 1283 § 5 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.27.070 - Billing-Liens for nonpayment. 
A.  All bills for sewer service charges as set forth in this title shall become due and payable at the office of the director of finance on or before the last day of the billing period and shall become delinquent on the first day of the following billing period. Service charges shall begin to accrue on the day on which service becomes available. The city may institute litigation at any time for the collection of delinquent charges, together with court costs, attorneys' fees and other costs attributable to such litigation, including administration charges in the amount of five dollars ($5.00). No part of the administrative charges may be waived. 
B.  As provided by Nevada law, any sewer service charge which becomes delinquent shall become a lien against the premises upon recording the same in the office of the Recorder of Washoe County. In addition to the foregoing, the City of Sparks Finance Department may cause to have a person's delinquent charges for sewerage collected on the county's tax roll in the same manner, by the same persons, and at the same time as, together with and not separately from, the county's general taxes. The City of Sparks Finance Department shall have the right to collect from such person(s) four (4) percent of the amount of the delinquent charges for sewerage to be collected on the tax roll or the amount estimated by the county treasurer which is necessary to collect and distribute those delinquent charges, whichever is greater. 
C.  In addition to the foregoing, the finance director may institute an action in small claims court for the delinquent charges. If such action is instituted, the costs shall include, but not be limited to, an administration charge in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00). No part of the administration charge may be waived. 
D.  Severance of connection. In addition to the foregoing, the finance director may, after a determination has been made of the name of the person chargeable, the premises, and the delinquent charges due, order the sewer connection to be severed for default in payment of sewer fees and the cost of such severance assessed as provided in subsection A above, to the person chargeable for the sewer fees. 
E.  No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business in any premises having delinquent sewer fees chargeable thereto until such delinquent charges and penalties have been paid. 
(Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; Ord. 2019, Amended, 03/22/1999; Ord. 1606 § 4, 1988; Ord. 1393 § 2, 1983: Ord. 1283 § 5 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.27.080 - Appeals. 
A.  A discharger who disputes a sewer bill of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) or more, including late charges, may file a written petition for adjustment of such bill with the city clerk. The city manager shall appoint a billing review committee to consider the petition. The committee shall hold a hearing within thirty (30) days after filing of a petition and shall notify the petitioner of the time and place of hearing not less than five (5) calendar days prior to the hearing. The committee shall report its findings to the city manager who is authorized to adjust the sewer bill. Said committee or the city manager may require a petitioner to provide financial statements, engineering reports or such other information as may be relevant in determining the merits of the petition. A sewer bill may be adjusted to assure equality of user charges for all users in a user class, to afford relief from errors in billing or for such other cause which furthers the just assessment of sewer charges. A petitioner aggrieved by the decision of the city manager may appeal to the city council by filing a written appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) days after receipt of the city manager's decision. 
B.  In the case of a discharger who disputes a sewer bill or any portion thereof, including late charges, in an amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) or less, a written petition must be made with the city clerk who shall thereafter forward the petition to the city director of finance. The director of finance may require the petitioner to provide relevant information in order to determine the merit of the petition and may, if equitable, thereafter adjust or otherwise afford relief from errors in billing or sewer assessment charges. The finance director shall thereafter provide the petitioner with a written decision. A petitioner aggrieved by the decision of the finance director may appeal to the city council by filing a written appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) days after receipt of the written decision from the finance director. The city council after reviewing the original petition and the written decision of the finance director may, by unanimous vote, direct the clerk to schedule the matter for public hearing. If the vote of the city council is not unanimous, the decision of the finance director shall be deemed affirmed and final. 
(Ord. 1915, 1997: Ord. 1714, 1991: Ord. 1606 § 5, 1988: Ord. 1283 § 5 (part), 1980) 
Chapter 13.30 - WASTEWATER FACILITIES CONSTRUCTION 

Section 13.30.010 - Prior approval of plans. 
    All construction plans and specifications of connection to the collection system must be approved by the public works director before issuance of building, construction or sewer connection permits. This applies to all incorporated areas of the city and those unincorporated areas which will use the city's wastewater facilities. 
    The public works director may require that the plans be prepared under the supervision of and signed by an engineer of suitable training registered in the State of Nevada. Prior to the issuance of any permits to replace any plumbing fixture or equipment, all such fixture units or equipment must be approved by the public works director. All wastewater and storm water dischargers shall comply with Sections 13.36 and 13.65 of this title prior to and during utilization of the city's sanitary and storm water collection, treatment and disposal facilities. 
(Ord. 2291, Amended, 08/22/2005; Ord. 2186, Amended, 08/25/2003; Ord. 2043, Amended, 11/22/1999; Ord. 1283 § 6 (part), 1980) 
Section 13.30.020 - Plumbing fixture unit standards. 
    All plumbing fixture units must meet the following design standards: 
A.  Toilets and water closets discharge shall not exceed three and one-half (3.5) gallons per flush. 
B.  Urinals discharge shall not exceed one and one-half (1.5) gallons per flush. 
C.  Shower heads discharge shall not exceed three and one-half (3.5) gallons per minute under working pressure. Orifices may be used to reduce flow. 
D.  No fixture shall be allowed that has a continuous flow of water of a constant or automatic nature. 
E.  Grease, interceptors and sand/oil separators shall be constructed to prevent any bypass of matter prohibited in the wastewater system. Grease interceptors shall be a minimum capacity of seven hundred fifty (750) gallons and shall be sized using the 2003 Uniform Plumbing Code Appendix H (Table H-1) sizing criteria. Grease traps are prohibited unless approved by the public works director. Sand/oil separators shall have a minimum capacity of one thousand (1,000) gallons except when otherwise required by the public works director. 
F.  A common grease interceptor, defined as an interceptor accepting wastewater from more than one (1) sewer user must be approved by the public works director. The owner of the premises connected to the wastewater facilities shall maintain the common grease interceptor. The owner, according to the records on file with the office of the county assessor, is responsible for maintaining the common grease interceptor on the schedule outlined in the environmental control permit issued by the public works director. 
G.  Trash enclosures containing a grease rendering receptacle shall include a trench drain connected to the sanitary sewer. Location of the trench drain shall be determined by the public works director. 
H.  Facilities using water for cooling shall not discharge the cooling water to the wastewater system or storm drain system. 
I.  Industrial/commercial process water shall be pretreated, if necessary, to meet discharge requirements of Chapter 13.36 of this title. If process water can be recirculated or reused, equipment shall be installed to accomplish the recirculation or reuse.
