B.  Major streets serving other than single family purposes shall have a dedicated right-of-way of not less than eighty feet and shall be improved to a width of not less than sixty-six feet, curb face to curb face. 
C.  Entrance or collectors' streets serving no more than two hundred fifty lots for single family dwelling purposes only shall have a dedicated right-of-way of not less than fifty-five feet and shall be improved to a width of not less than forty-two feet, curb face to curb face. 
D.  Maximum length of cul-de-sac streets shall be four hundred feet and shall have a dedicated way of not less than fifty-five feet and shall be improved to a width of not less than forty-two feet, curb face to curb face. Each cul-de-sac shall be provided with a turnaround which shall have a minimum dedicated right-of-way radius of forty-five feet with an improved section of not less than forty feet. A cul-de-sac street servicing not more than ten lots may be not less than forty-five feet wide with an improved section of not less than thirty-six feet, curb face to curb face. 
E.  All streets shall have a minimum grade of three-tenths percent where L-type gutters are used or a minimum of four-tenths percent slope where roll-type curbs are used in industrial areas. Vertical curves shall be provided in all changes in grade where the algebraic difference is two percent or more. 
F.  No centerline curve radius of less than one hundred feet shall be provided on any street. 
G.  Curves on streets shall be designed to accommodate traffic at the speed designated for that street. 
H.  In mountainous or difficult areas where it is impossible or impracticable to provide streets of the standards set forth, lesser widths of streets may be provided. Such widths are to be determined by the planning commission with the approval of the public works director; provided that no such street shall have a grade exceeding twelve percent and then for a limited distance only. The public works director may further require off-street parking areas in conjunction with such reduced street widths and increased grades. 
I.  No street or highway shall have a grade of more than six percent unless shown on the master plan of streets and highways to have a greater grade, or unless such street is subject to subsection H of this section. 
J.  Any street or highway intersecting any other street or highway shall intersect at an angle as near to a right angle as is practicable, but in no event shall an intersection be allowed at an angle of less than sixty degrees. 
K.  At each right angle intersection, the property line at each block corner shall be rounded with a curve having a radius of not less than twenty feet on collector streets nor less than thirty feet on major or arterial streets. Where streets intersect at angles of less than right angles or where other peculiar conditions of traffic or intersections occur, the planning commission may, with the approval of the public works director, or the public works director may, require a different radius. 
L.  In the event it becomes necessary to design a street along a boundary of a subdivision, such street may, with the approval of the public works director, be dedicated one-half the required width if it is practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is developed. Such portion of streets shall be distinctly designated upon the map or plat as being a portion only of a street and not a street of full width. Whenever there already exists a dedicated or recorded one-half street or alley on an adjoining plat, the other one-half must be dedicated on the proposed plat to make the street or alley complete. Whenever a one-half street lying along the boundary of a subdivision is dedicated, it shall be improved to a paved width of not less than twenty-nine feet in width, curb face to edge of pavement. 
M.  Reserve strips of land controlling access to or egress from other property or to or from any street or alley shall not be permitted with any subdivided area. 
N.  An access street from the existing paved streets outside the subdivision boundary to the subdivision boundary shall be improved and paved with full width improvements as designated by the public works director. 
O.  Street Names. 
1.  No street names shall be used which will be duplicated or be confused with the names of existing streets in the city or county. 
2.  New streets which are extensions of or obviously in alignment with existing streets shall bear the name of the existing street. 
P.  Street structural sections shall consist in depth of not less than ten inches Type II base, two and one-half inches asphaltic concrete and one-half inch open-graded aggregate asphalt wearing surface. 
Variations in the depths indicated may be allowed by the public works director providing adequate tests have been made and an alternate structural section can be designed by an approved method. 
Additional depth of section may be required if projected traffic volumes and/or soil conditions warrant a greater structural section. 
(Ord. 848 § 15, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.185.) 
Section 17.16.060 - Alleys. 
A.  Alleys shall be provided in commercial and industrial districts except where other definite and assured provision is made for service access, such as off-street loading and unloading and parking adequate for the proposed use. 
B.  No alleys shall be less than twenty feet in width and all alley construction shall be in accordance with the city standard specifications. 
(Ord. 848 § 16, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.220.) 
Section 17.16.070 - Curb and gutter-Sidewalks, driveways and curb cuts. 
A.  Curb and gutter and sidewalks shall be installed on all streets within the city. Sidewalks in residential areas shall not be less than four feet in width. Sidewalks in commercial areas shall not be less than five feet in width. 
B.  Where car storage on any residential lot is accessible from the street or access for motor vehicles is desired in business, commercial or industrial districts, provisions shall be made for a driveway. All driveways shall enter all properties with a standard curb cut. The width of the cuts shall be as set forth in the design standards. 
C.  All construction for curb and gutter, sidewalks, driveway approaches and curb cuts shall be in accordance with the city standard details and specifications. 
(Ord. 848 § 17, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.240.) 
Section 17.16.080 - Pedestrian ways. 
A.  Whenever blocks are one thousand feet or more in length, pedestrian ways of not less than five feet in width on dedicated right-of-way may be required through blocks where deemed necessary for circulation and access to schools, playgrounds or similar public facilities. 
B.  All pedestrian ways shall be paved with Portland cement concrete and construction shall be in accordance with city standard specifications. 
(Ord. 848 § 18, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.250.) 
Section 17.16.090 - Public utility easements. 
    Public utility easements shall be provided where required to adequately accommodate all public utilities. 
(Ord. 848 § 19, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.260.) 
Section 17.16.100 - Underground utilities. 
    All utility distribution facilities, including but not limited to electric, communication and cable television lines, to be installed in or for the purpose of supplying service to any residential, commercial or industrial estates (M-E) subdivision or record of survey, shall be placed underground except as follows: 
A.  Surface-mounted transformers located in conformance to applicable setbacks, pedestal-mounted terminal boxes, meter cabinets and concealed ducts; 
B.  Poles supporting wires carrying more than twenty-five KV or street lights; 
C.  Utility lines in existence or proposed beyond one-fourth mile from any existing development in which utilities are underground. 
The subdivider or developer is responsible for complying with the requirements of this section and shall make the necessary arrangements with the utility companies involved for the installation of the facilities in accordance with such applicable tariffs, rules and regulations of the utilities as may be on file with the Nevada Public Service Commission, and in accordance with any pertinent franchise arrangements. 
The planning commission, acting upon the recommendation of a technical advisory committee consisting of the public works directors of Reno and Sparks and the Washoe County engineer, may modify or waive the requirements of this section in the consideration of tentative subdivision or record of survey plats, if topographical, soil, economic or other conditions make underground installation of the facilities unreasonable or impractical. The subdivider or developer shall produce adequate factual evidence to substantiate any contention that such underground utility installation is unreasonable or impractical. 
Industrial subdivisions or developments, other than those classified or intended to be industrial estates (M-E) subdivisions or developments, are excluded from the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 657 § 1, 1966: 1962 Code § 55.265.) 
Section 17.16.110 - Electricity supply and street lights. 
A.  The electricity supply shall be adequate for domestic use and street lighting. 
B.  Street light standards shall be located as mutually agreed by the Sierra Pacific Power Company and the director of public works. 
C.  The placement of street light standards shall be shown on all subdivision plats prior to their submission. Placements shall be subject to the approval of the Sierra Pacific Power Company and the director of public works. 
D.  Spacing of street lights shall be such that they will provide a level of lighting approved by the director of public works. 
(Ord. 848 § 20, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.270.) 
Section 17.16.120 - Water supply and fire hydrants. 
A.  The water supply shall be adequate for all domestic use and fire protection needs. 
B.  Fire hydrants shall be located not less than eighteen inches from the back of the curb to the center of the fire hydrant. 
C.  Water lines to hydrants shall conform to recommendations of the National Board of Fire Underwriters and shall be clear of pedestrian lanes. 
(1962 Code § 55.280.) 
Section 17.16.130 - Sewers. 
A.  Sewage collection or treatment or collection and treatment shall comply with the laws of the state and all local ordinances, be subject to the approval of the public works director and conform to all standards and specifications of the city. 
B.  Sanitary sewer lines shall be designed to have a minimum velocity of two feet per second and a maximum velocity of eight feet per second. No sanitary sewer line other than service laterals shall have a pipe diameter of less than eight inches. Sewer lines shall be installed to provide laterals extending to each lot. Such laterals shall have a minimum pipe diameter of four inches and be constructed to the property line. 
C.  Sewer pipe installed in a traveled way shall have a minimum coverage of three feet or be properly reinforced. 
D.  Maximum distance between manholes shall not exceed three hundred fifty feet unless specifically approved by the public works director. A manhole shall be installed at the end of each sewer line. All sewage facilities shall be installed within the public street right-of-way. Installation of sewage facilities may be permitted in dedicated easements providing readily available access is provided for maintenance purposes. 
E.  Each sheet of sewer plans and profiles submitted to the public works director shall show all required information as herein required. Each plan view shall show lot lines, lot and block numbers, the exact location of the sewer line with reference to property lines, the location of manholes and house laterals, with reference to property lines. Each profile shall show the original ground line flow line of the proposed sewer construction, design line of the proposed street construction, top of manhole elevations, invert elevations, stationing of each manhole, size and type of pipe, percent of grade and exact distance between manholes. 
(Ord. 848 § 21, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.290.) 
Section 17.16.140 - Drainage. 
A.  Each subdivider shall provide the necessary means to assure complete drainage of his property, making use of state or city drains, natural watercourses or constructed tributaries, and shall comply with the requirements of this section. 
B.  Drainage channels shall be so designed as to maintain a minimum velocity of two feet per second and a maximum velocity of eight feet per second. Design of drainage facilities shall be based on the June 1964 city storm drain report and shall comply with Chapters 15.04 and 15.08 of this code. 
C.  Flow lines of L-type curb and gutters shall have a minimum grade of three-tenths percent. Roll-top curb and gutters used in industrial areas shall have a minimum slope of four-tenths percent. Construction shall be in conformity to the city construction standards. 
D.  Valley gutters shall be required across intersections where necessary to provide proper drainage. The construction of valley gutters shall conform to the city design standards. 
E.  Each subdivider shall submit to the public works director sufficient information in the form of maps and profiles to indicate the proper drainage of surface water to natural drainage courses or into a developed system. If surface water is to cross land intended to be used as private lots, rights-of-way and easements must be indicated on the proposed plat. Location and width of such easements shall be shown and marked "Easement for Drainage and for Public Utility." 
F.  Storm waters shall be collected in an enclosed underground storm drain piping system designed in conformance with the June 1964 city storm drain report and laid to the grade and depth required by the public works director. 
G.  No storm water drainage pipes shall be less A than ten inches in diameter and shall conform to the city standard specifications. 
H.  Standard headwalls and grates shall replaced on all pipe culverts up to and including seventy-two inches in diameter. The design size and material used shall comply in all cases with the city standard specifications. 
I.  Catch basins and drop inlets shall be installed at low points and vertical curves at all major street intersections and at other points where ponding of water could block traffic or flood adjoining property. Where the street is on a constant grade, catch basins and inlets should be installed at sufficient intervals to prohibit the flow in the gutter from encroaching on the outside travel lane for a storm with a five year return period. The distance between catch basins shall not exceed one thousand linear feet measured along the street's centerline from center to center of the catch basins. Flow along gutters into the inlets shall be computed by the rational formula in accordance with the June 1964 city storm drain report. 
J.  Each subdivider of residential lands shall be required to submit a development plan for his subdivision plan showing clearly the drainage for each lot. Each lot should be designed so that no water will run off onto adjacent lots. The lots shall be graded so that water runs to the front of the lot and into the street or into other enclosed drainage facilities provided by the subdivider. 
(Ord. 848 § 22, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.300.) 
Section 17.16.150 - Modifications in extreme cases. 
    The public works director may, in extreme cases, to meet topography, engineering requirements or drainage problems, modify the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 848 § 23, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.310.) 
Section 17.16.160 - Payment for facilities of greater capacity or size than required for a particular subdivision to be serviced. 
A.  The city may require the subdivider to provide sanitary sewers and streets of greater capacity and width than required for any particular subdivision. The public works director shall determine the size of sewers and width of streets required for the proper development of the city. 
B.  It shall be the policy of the city that the city will pay the additional cost for oversizing sanitary sewers and shall pay the additional cost for city streets that are wider than the required normal width city street. Subdividers and the city may enter into agreements setting forth the cost sharing and method of payment for over-sized facilities. 
(Ord. 995 § 1, 1974.) 
Chapter 17.20 - FINAL MAPS AND PLANS 
Sections: 

Section 17.20.010 - Final map-Filing. 
A.  Not less than ten days prior to the filing of any final map with the city council, the subdivider shall submit two prints of the final map to the public works director. The public works director shall check the map as to accuracy of dimensions, placing of monuments, establishment of survey records shown on the map and conformance of the map with the tentative map approved by the planning commission. 
B.  The prints shall be accompanied by: 
1.  A worksheet showing the closure of the exterior boundaries of the proposed subdivision and of lots and blocks therein; 
2.  A complete set of construction plans as required by the public works director showing typical street sections, centerline and curb grades, sanitary sewer and storm drain locations and invert grades and elevations; 
3.  Construction plans for manholes, catch basins and other appurtenant structures; 
4.  An estimate of quantities required to complete the improvements. 
C.  The minimum allowable error of closure shall be 1/10,000. Temperature and tension correction shall be applied to all measured distances in conformance with the standards adopted by the Federal Board of Surveys and Maps in May 1925. 
(Ord. 848 § 25, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.320.) 
Section 17.20.020 - Filing of complete plans. 
A.  After a final plan has been submitted to the public works director, the subdivider shall file with the public works director, at least thirty days prior to the meeting of the city council at which approval of the subdivision is sought, complete plans covering, but not limited to, the specifications and locations of all alleys, streets, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, sewer mains, fire hydrants, subsurface drainage and other features of the subdivision. 
B.  The plans shall include: 
1.  The original of the final plat; 
2.  A plan and profile of each street showing clearly existing grades and finished grades, distances, elevations, topography and other pertinent features; 
3.  A plan and profile of each storm drain and sewer line showing manhole locations, distances and grades, top of manhole elevations and invert of manhole elevations. Storm drain and sewer line plan and profile may be combined with street plan profiles; 
4.  A grading plan showing the drainage for each lot with existing ground elevations and proposed finished lot grade elevations; 
5.  Plans for streets, storm drains or sanitary sewers which may be extended in the future shall include sufficient information to assure that such extension of improvements can be accomplished by continuing approximately the same alignment and grade as the proposed improvements; 
6.  The time schedule for construction of off-site improvements; 
7.  Plans and profiles of all utilities showing the location of all surface-mounted equipment. These plans may be shown with the street plans and profiles or other appropriate plans. 
C.  The complete plans, when submitted to the public works director, shall be accompanied by a plan checking fee. Plan checking fees, public improvement inspection fees and material testing fees are set by resolution of the City Council. Schedules of these fees are available from the City Clerk and are posted wherever permits are obtained and fees paid. Neither the plan checking fee nor the inspection and testing fee are returnable. 
D.  Following any corrections required by the public works director, the subdivider shall, within ten days prior to presenting the final plat and plans to the city council, resubmit to the public works director: 
1.  The original final corrected subdivision plat; 
2.  The original or reproducible corrected improvement plans, specifically plans referred to in subdivisions 2 through 4 of subsection B of this section; 
3.  Any other plans or specifications as may be required by the public works director. 
E.  Should the subdivider fail to submit the required corrected subdivision plat and improvement plans within one year of the initial submittal, he shall be required to resubmit the complete plans together with the plan check fee. 
(Ord. 1763, 1992: Ord. 1250 § 1, 1979: Ord. 1056 § 1, 1976: Ord. 848 § 26, 1971: Ord. 656 § 1, 1966: Ord. 542 § 1, 1963: 1962 Code § 55.330.) (Ord. 2024, Amended, 05/24/1999; 1978, Amended, 03/16/1998) 
Section 17.20.030 - Final map-Form. 
    The final map shall be drawn with black waterproof India ink on tracing cloth of good quality, but affidavits, certificates and acknowledgements may be legibly stamped or printed with opaque ink upon the original or a separate affidavit sheet. The size of each sheet shall be twenty-four inches by thirty-two inches. A marginal line shall be drawn completely around each sheet leaving a blank margin of one inch at the top, bottom and right edges and a two-inch margin at the twenty-four-inch left edge. 
(1962 Code § 55.340.) 
Section 17.20.040 - Final map-Contents. 
A.  Every final map shall show all data required for the tentative map, except contour lines, position of trees and buildings, relationship to streets and highways beyond the area shown on the map and proposed use of lots, and shall in addition contain the information required by this section. 
B.  Monuments set in concrete per the City of Sparks Standard Details for Public Works Construction shall be shown and set at all points of tangency, curvature, or points of intersections of streets of the subdivision and at boundaries of the subdivisions where streets of the subdivision abut against existing streets. The monuments must be clearly stamped and be legible with the number of the responsible registered professional land surveyor shown on the monument, i.e. brass cap. 
Any property corner must have a five-eighth ( 5/8 ) inch diameter reinforced steel bar, a minimum length of eighteen (18) inches with a yellow plastic cap affixed to it with the professional land surveyor's registration number clearly and visibly stamped on it. However, front lot corners may be shown with a scribed cut on the projection of the property line at the top of the front face of the concrete curb. 
C.  The basis of bearings for subdivision final maps and parcel maps must be shown on the map as defined by the Record of Survey recorded in the Official Records of Washoe County, Nevada, known as "Record of Survey for the City of Sparks of City-wide GPS Control Survey" File No. 1834848, Record of Survey Map No. 2775 which is based upon the North American Datum of 1983 (NAD83). 
The maps must show or call out a coordinate referring to the GPS Control Survey and must refer to the coordinate as a modified or ground coordinate. 
Notation of horizontal ties must be made to the nearest quarter corner or section corner of the National Geodetic Survey (NGS) to the subdivision and the GPS Horizontal Survey. The plat shall show all recorded distances and bearings of adjoining tracts. 
D.  All dedicated rights-of-way adjacent to, terminating on or entering into the area being subdivided shall be shown by name and broken line. 
E.  The subdivision plats shall show bearing and length of all lines and the radius, central angle, length of curve and tangent of curve of all curved lines. Each lot shall be numbered and each street named. The exterior boundary of the land for subdivision shall be shown by a border and all elements shall be definitely established by bearing and distance. 
F.  The plat shall be to scale not to exceed one hundred feet to the inch. A legend shall be shown clarifying all markings. All distances shall be to the nearest one-hundredth of a foot and be shown in feet and decimals thereof. All angles shall be shown to the nearest second by degrees, minutes and seconds. 
G.  A blank space three inches by five inches shall be reserved at the lower right-hand comer of the plat for stamps of approval and recording. 
H.  Parcels within the subdivision which are not part of the subdivision shall be marked as such. 
I.  Accuracy of subdivision field work shall be not less than one foot in ten thousand. 
J.  A certificate indicating that all outstanding liens or claims against the property sought to be subdivided have been paid or otherwise cleared, and that the proposed subdivision is free of all such encumbrances, shall accompany the final map. 
K.  The final map shall include, but not be limited to, the following certificates and jurats on the title sheets: 
1.  Certificate of ownership and dedication; 
2.  Certificate of trustee, lienholder, or security interest holder approval; 
3.  Certificate of utility easements and approval; 
4.  Certificate of licensed professional land surveyor; 
5.  Certificate of city engineer or city surveyor; 
6.  Certificate of owner of record; and, 
7.  Washoe County tax certificate; 
8.  Division of Water Resources certificate; 
9.  Washoe County Health Department certificate; 
10.  City council certificate; 
11.  Title company certificate; 
12.  Necessary jurats of acknowledgment. 
L.  All right-of-way easements shall be clearly designated. Roadways with limited access shall be so designated on the final map. Public utility easements outside dedicated rights-of-way shall be clearly indicated. A symbol, indicating the location of surface-mounted utility equipment other than street lights shall be placed on the final map to clearly indicate the location of all surface-mounted installations. 
(Ord. 1864, 1995: Ord. 1056 § 2, 1976: Ord. 848 § 27, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.350.) 
Chapter 17.21 - PARCEL MAPS 
Sections: 

Section 17.21.010 - Parcel map filing-Requirements. 
A.  A person who proposes to divide any land within the city into four or fewer lots shall file a parcel map with the public works director. 
B.  All parcel maps filed pursuant to this section shall be subject to the requirements and conditions of Chapter 278 of Nevada Revised Statutes. 
C.  All parcel maps must comply with the survey requirements of Section 17.20.040 of this code. 
(Ord. 1864, 1995: Ord. 1441 § 1, 1984: Ord. 1034 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Section 17.21.020 - Parcel map review. 
A.  The public works director shall review and approve, conditionally approve or disapprove a parcel map and, if unusual circumstances exist, may waive the requirements for a parcel map or survey. 
B.  As a condition of parcel map approval, water rights, water supply facilities, storm drainage facilities and sewer facilities must be dedicated as if the parcel map were a subdivision subject to the requirements of Section 17.12.075 of this code. 
(Ord. 1494 § 1, 1985: Ord. 1441 § 2, 1984: Ord. 1034 § 1 (part), 1975.) (1985, Amended, 04/13/1998) 
Section 17.21.030 - Appeal procedure. 
A.  Any person who has filed a parcel map pursuant to Section 17.21.010 may appeal the decision of the public works director to the planning commission as provided in Chapter 278 of Nevada Revised Statutes. 
B.  No person shall have the right to appeal any decision of the public works director refusing to waive title requirement of a parcel map. 
(Ord. 144 § 13, 1984: Ord. 1034 § 1 (part), 1975.) 
Chapter 17.24 - IMPROVEMENTS 
Sections: 

Section 17.24.010 - Improvement requirements. 
    The subdivider shall agree to improve, at his own expense and within a period of twenty-four months, in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the public works director and city council, all lands shown on the final plat designated as streets, highways, public ways and easements, including: 
A.  All grading, drainage and rough gravel to grade; 
B.  Installation to grade in the location shown, and to the depth and of the material specified, of all sanitary, storm or surface water drain pipes and mains, together with manhole laterals and catch basins in a manner and at a place approved by the public works director; 
C.  Construction of adequate and permanent culverts, bridges and other similar structures at points where needed in conformity with current State Department of Highways specifications and city practice; 
D.  Installation of all fire hydrants of the size and location designated by the chief of the fire department of the city and shown on the map submitted to the bonding agency; 
E.  Provision and installation of all signs required and shown on the plans submitted and approved in the manner, location and size directed by the public works director; 
F.  Installation of all sidewalks where required and of all curbs, gutters and other improvements required by the provisions of this title; 
G.  1.  Where a water supply ditch or water course is located within or adjacent to a subdivision, the public works director may require the ditch or water course to be piped, lined, fenced or otherwise improved to protect property, maintain public safety and preserve the integrity of the ditch or water course. 
2.  No private storm drainage run-off shall be allowed to flow or discharge into any water supply ditch without the approval of the ditch company or owner of the ditch. 
3.  Where a water supply ditch or water course is located within or adjacent to a subdivision, improvements and access required for the operation and maintenance of the ditch or water course shall be provided. 
H.  Improvement of all dedicated walkways,where shown, by five foot concrete paving and a minimum three foot chain link fence on each side; 
I.  Paving shall be installed and shall meet city engineering standards; 
J.  Street Lights and the Necessary Standards For Such Lights. Types of lights, types of standards, their location and spacing shall be subject to the approval of the Sierra Pacific Power Company and the director of public works. Installation shall meet the general requirements of Sections 17.16.100 and 17.16.110. 
K.  The public works director shall inform the developer of the appeal process. 
(Ord. 1770, 1993: Ord. 848 § 28, 1971: Ord. 481 § 1, 1962: 1962 Code § 55.360.) 
Section 17.24.020 - Exceptions. 
A.  Trunk line sewers, channels for flood control and improvements not solely for the benefit of the subdivision concerned, and full improvements of routes designated primary or secondary on the master plan of street sand highways of the city, may not be required under the provision of Section 17.24.010 unless included in the subdivider's agreement. 
B.  If greater than normal rights-of-way improvement is required, the subdivider shall be responsible for the installation of only that portion of the rights-of-way which would normally be charged against him. 
(1962 Code § 55.370.) 
Chapter 17.28 - COMPLETION AND INSPECTION 
Sections: 

Section 17.28.010 - Surety bonds, cash deposits, and other forms of security. 
A.  All improvements and final plat procedures required by this title shall be completed and a good and sufficient surety bond written by a surety company authorized to do business in the state shall be filed with the city clerk prior to final plat approval and certification. 
B.  In lieu of filing a surety bond, the subdivider may deposit cash or a letter of credit issued by a bank as defined by Nevada Revised Statutes 657.010, which is authorized under the provisions of Chapter 659 of Nevada Revised Statutes to do business and has capitalization of more than one million dollars. 
C.  The bond or cash deposit shall be in an amount fixed by the public works director to insure that all improvements required by section 17.24.010 are provided and installed by the subdivider within a period of twenty-four months. 
D.  At the end of a twelve-month period a bond may be renegotiated or cash deposit reduced on the approval of the public works director in consideration of improvements installed. 
E.  If the subdivider fails to complete the provision and installation of the improvements required by Section 17.24.010 within the time allowed by this section, the city clerk may cause the bond, cash deposit or other form of security to be forfeited in the amount necessary to finish the uncompleted portion of the improvements. 
(Ord. 848 § 29, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.380.) (1921, Amended, 05/27/1997) 
Section 17.28.020 - Inspections. 
A.  The subdivider shall notify the public works director of the date and hour work on any of the following items is expected to begin, notification to be given not less than twenty-four hours in advance and if thereafter conditions develop to delay the start of work, the subdivider shall notify the public works director of the delay not less than two hours before the work was to begin: 
1.  Laying of sewer lines; 
2.  Backfilling of sewer lines; 
3.  Pouring concrete for curbs, gutters, sidewalks or valley gutters; 
4.  Placing of Type I base course; 
5.  Placing of Type II base course; 
6.  Priming base course; 
7.  Placing pavement; 
8.  Sealing or placing surface treatment; 
9.  Laying of storm drains; and, 
10.  Other improvements required by Section 17.24.010. 
B.  All improvements to be made under the provisions of this title shall be inspected to assure satisfactory work. The final completion of all such improvements shall be subject to the approval of the public works director. 
(Ord. 848 § 30, 1971: 1962 Code § 55.390.) 
Section 17.28.030 - Indemnification. 
    During the entire period of construction, the city shall be saved harmless by the subdivider for any damage occurring within the subdivision development or adjacent area as a result of his activities. 
(1962 Code § 55.400.) 
Chapter 17.30 - TOWNHOUSE AND CONDOMINIUM SUBDIVISIONS 
Sections: 

Section 17.30.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to safeguard the public health, safety, convenience and general welfare and to bring about orderly, coordinated development by establishing minimum standards of design and improvement of any townhouse or condominium subdivision hereafter platted in the incorporated area of the city. 
(Ord. 1253 § 2 (part), 1980. 
Section 17.30.020 - Application. 
A.  The filing of a tentative subdivision map for new condominiums or townhouses or for the conversion of apartments to condominiums or townhouses shall follow the procedures which pertain to the subdivision of land as outlined in previous sections of this title. 
B.  Concurrently with the filing of a tentative subdivision map for all condominium or townhouse developments of more than six units, an application for a special use permit shall be filed with the public works director. 
The following information shall be incorporated into the application for review: 
1.  Two sets of the following graphic information in the form of legible, scaled drawings: 
a.  Site plan clearly showing setbacks, yards and grades, 
b.  Floor plans, 
c.  Parking lay-out indicating stall and aisle sizes as well as indicating whether enclosed or uncovered, 
d.  A detailed landscaping plan of existing and/or proposed planting; 
2.  A general identification and statistical information report which contains: 
a.  Street address, 
b.  Name of legal owner, 
c.  Legal description, 
d.  Reserved. 
e.  Number of stories in each building, 
f.  Density in dwelling units per acre, 
g.  Overall height, 
h.  Total number of parking spaces, 
i.  Total number of units, 
j.  Site area, 
k.  Area of site to be covered by structures, 
l.  Area of site to be landscaped, 
m.  Floor area per unit, 
n.  Type of construction, 
o.  Total amount of storage space per unit, 
p.  Location of trash enclosures. 
(Ord. 1253 § 2 (part), 1980.) 
Section 17.30.030 - Standards. 
A.  All condominium or townhouse projects constructed or converted shall comply with the applicable standards found in the adopted building and construction codes of Title 15 of this code. 
B.  All condominium or townhouse projects constructed or converted shall comply with the applicable standards in the adopted fire prevention and protection codes found in Title 14 of this code. 
C.  All condominium or townhouse projects constructed or converted shall provide parking as required in Chapter 20.49 of this code. 
D.  All landscaping necessary on any condominium or townhouse project shall be of a size and type acceptable to the public works director. 
E.  The city shall be included as a party to the Covenants, Conditions and Restrictions for purposes of enforcing maintenance standards as provided in Chapter 278A of the Nevada Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. 1253 § 2 (part), 1980.) 
Section 17.30.040 - Conversions. 
    In addition to the requirements and procedures set forth in other sections of this chapter, applicants for condominium or townhouse conversions shall provide the information and comply with the regulations required by this section. 
A.  Existing Condition of Project. 
1.  A statement of specific information concerning characteristics of the project consisting of the following: 
a.  Rental history for each unit for previous three years; 
b.  Monthly vacancy rate for the development during preceding three years; 
c.  Proposed sale price of each unit; 
d.  Proposed homeowner association fee; 
e.  Statistical data on all tenants including name, address, age, family relationships, handicaps and other information pertinent to the ability of the tenant to move or purchase. 
2.  The subdivider shall provide, at his own expense and in a format acceptable to the city, a comprehensive building and grounds condition report. This report shall contain the following information: 
a.  An evaluation of the structural condition of each building in the project; 
b.  An evaluation of the condition of all site features such as parking areas, accessory buildings, landscaped areas, driveways, sidewalks, carports, any amenities, fences and utility systems; 
3.  The report will be prepared by a licensed civil engineer and will be reviewed by the public works director or his designated representative to determine if the conditions found are satisfactory, repairable or unrepairable. 
4.  The public works director will then evaluate the structure and grounds and make a recommendation as to what alterations to the building and grounds are necessary to insure that any converted complex does not place an undue financial burden on the homeowner association. Alterations which are required immediately shall be performed prior to final subdivision map approval. In the event an alteration does not require immediate completion, but will be necessary within three years of the date of final subdivision map approval, the public works director shall estimate the cost of said alteration, and the developer shall deposit said estimated cost in an account for the use of the homeowner association. 
This information and evaluation will be incorporated into the special use permit review process for city council evaluation. 
B.  Physical Standards for Condominium and Townhouse Conversions. 
1.  Private Storage Space. Each unit shall have at least two hundred cubic feet of enclosed, weatherproofed and secure private storage space outside the living area of the unit. 
2.  Landscaping. If the existing landscaping is inadequate or deficient, the public works director shall require a complete landscaping plan as a part of the special use permit review. 
3.  Conditions of Equipment and Appliances. The developer shall provide written certification to the buyer of each unit that all dishwashers, garbage disposals, stoves, refrigerators, hot water heaters and tanks, and air conditioners are in operable working condition as of the close of escrow. Further, the developer shall guarantee the above-mentioned appliances for one year after close of escrow of each individual unit. 
C.  Tenant Safeguards. 
1.  A notice of intent to convert shall be delivered to each tenant within fifteen days after the tentative subdivision map is filed with the public works director. 
2.  The form of the notice shall be as approved by the public works director and shall contain the following information: 
a.  Name and address of current owner; 
b.  Name and address of proposed subdivider; 
c.  Approximate date on which the final subdivision map is to be filed; 
d.  Notice of tenant's right of first refusal; 
e.  Notice of tenant's approximate vacation date; 
f.  Notice of right to moving expenses. 
3.  Tenant's Right of First Refusal. Any present tenant or tenants of any unit shall be given a nontransferable right of first refusal to purchase the unit occupied, at the price offered the public. 
The right of first refusal shall extend for a period of at least ninety days after final map approval or initial offering for sale, whichever is later in time. 
4.  Vacation of Units. Each nonpurchasing tenant not in default under the obligations of the rental agreement or lease under which he occupies his unit shall have not less than one hundred twenty days from the date of city council approval of the final subdivision map to vacate the premises. 
5.  Special Cases. 
a.  Any nonpurchasing tenant, aged sixty-two years or older, or handicapped, shall be given upon request an extended lease of six months for each year he or she has resided in the project, but not less than five years. This lease will stipulate that the monthly rent on the unit so leased will increase only as much as the Consumer Price Index as formulated by the United States Department of Labor. 
b.  Any nonpurchasing tenant with two or more children under the age of eighteen residing in the unit shall be given, if requested, the same lease arrangements as outlined in subparagraph (a) of this section. 
6.  Moving Expenses. The subdivider shall provide moving expenses to any tenant who relocates from the building after receipt of notification from the subdivider, according to the following schedule based on the length of tenancy on the date of receipt of notification: 
Length of Tenancy Moving Expenses 
a. Less than six months $150.00 b. Six months to two years $300.00 c. More than two years $500.00  
D.  Finding of Fact. The city council shall not approve an application for the conversion of apartments to townhouses or condominiums unless the council finds: 
1.  All provisions of this chapter are met; 
2.  The proposed conversion is consistent with the policies of the city master plan; 
3.  That the proposed conversion will not create a shortage of rental housing such that an imbalance between rental and ownership housing exists; 
4.  That the current rental housing vacancy rate is above five percent; and 
5.  That the overall design and physical condition of the condominium conversion does not adversely impact the health, safety and welfare of the community. 
E.  Bonding. The subdivider shall furnish a performance bond or other acceptable security for an amount not less than one hundred percent of the estimated cost of improvements. The calculation of estimated costs for each specified improvement shall be determined by the public works director and his assistants. 
(Ord. 1253 § 2 (part), 1980.) 
Chapter 17.32 - PENALTIES 
Sections: 

Section 17.32.010 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation which violates any of the provisions of this title, or of the planning act, shall be punished as provided in Section 1.12.010 of this code. 
(1962 Code § 55.410.) 
Chapter 17.33 - MAINTENANCE DISTRICTS 
Sections: 

Section 17.33.010 - Purpose. 
A.  Under NRS 278.4787, a developer who proposes to divide land in Sparks for transfer or development into four or more lots pursuant to NRS 278.360 to 278.460, inclusive, or chapter 278A of NRS may, in lieu of providing for the creation of an association for a common-interest community, request the City Council to assume the maintenance of certain improvements. This chapter establishes the procedures for making such requests and, if approved, for establishing and administering maintenance districts by the city. 
(Ord. 2169, Add, 03/17/2003) 
Section 17.33.020 - Definitions. 
A.  Unless otherwise defined herein, the terms listed in SMC 17.08.010 through 17.08.260, as amended shall have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections. 
B.  As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them. 
Assessed Property means each lot, parcel, or residential dwelling which will be assessed in the district to pay for a portion of the Project Costs. Property within a maintenance district which is owned by a school district or the federal government shall not be Assessed Property. 
Community Development Director means the Assistant City Manager who oversees the Community Development Department, or equivalent. 
Development means land divided for transfer or development into four or more lots pursuant to NRS 278.360 to 278.460 (regarding subdivisions of land), inclusive, or chapter 278A of NRS. 
Developer means the subdivider under NRS 278.360 to 278.460, or the land owner under NRS chapter 278A 
Finance Director means the Director of Finance. 
Parks Director means the Director of the Parks and Recreation Department. 
Petitioner means the Developer or owners of Assessed Property who petition to the City to maintain the Project under subsections 17.33.030 A or B below. 
Project means all improvements to be maintained by the city and for which a maintenance district is authorized under NRS 278.4787, as amended and existing at the time a petition is filed with the City, including: 
a.  Landscaping on the perimeter or median strip of a Development (as defined in NRS 278.4781), 
b.  Public lighting (as defined in NRS 278.4783), 
c.  Security walls (as defined in NRS 278.4785 and NRS 271.302) 
d.  Trails, parks and open space which provide a substantial public benefit or which are required by the City Council for the primary use of the public, per NRS 278.4787 (1) (d). Trails described in NRS 278.4787 (5) are not included in this definition. 
Project Costs includes all costs that are or will be incurred in maintaining the Project in accordance with the approved maintenance plan, including, but not limited to, the costs identified in subsection 17.33.070. A below. 
Project Land means the real property (including fixtures) on which the Project is located. 
Regulations means the administrative regulations and manual adopted by the Parks Director regarding the administration of Maintenance Districts under this ordinance. 
(Ord. 2169, Add, 03/17/2003) 
Section 17.33.030 - Requests for city to assume maintenance of a project. 
A.  1.  A Developer may request, by petition, 
a.  that the city assume maintenance responsibilities for a Project to be constructed in a Development; or 
b.  to establish a master maintenance district for a series of Developments within a planned development whereunder all the requirements for a maintenance district for a single subdivision would be established, and individual units of the planned development would be added, by petition, as they are developed. The petition shall include (i) all of the requirements under paragraph 17.033.030.C below for the first Development and (ii) a copy of the CC&Rs and the conditions of approval for the planned development which must include, to the satisfaction of the Parks Director, provisions allowing maintenance districts to be established. 
2.  The petition must be filed with the Parks Director before applying for approval of the final map of the subdivision or final approval of a planned development. 
B.  The owners of Assessed Property may, by petition, request that the city assume maintenance responsibilities for an existing Project in an existing Development under the conditions set forth in NRS 278.4787.7 
C.  The petition must be signed by a majority of the owners of the Assessed Property, must request that the city agree to assume maintenance responsibilities and establish a maintenance district under this chapter and NRS 278.4787, and must provide the information required by the Regulations. 
D.  The Parks Director may enter into agreements to convert or combine preexisting maintenance districts into districts under this ordinance provided that the conversion is authorized by NRS 278.4787 and the conversion or combination would be in accordance with this ordinance. 
E.  The desirability hearing before the city council contemplated in NRS 278.4787 (4) is hereby waived, and the Parks Director shall proceed to review and determine whether or not to establish the district as follows. 
(Ord. 2169, Add, 03/17/2003) 
Section 17.33.040 - Appointment of parks director and parks and recreation commission; responsibilities. 
A.  The Parks Director is hereby designated under NRS 278.4787.3 to approve or disapprove petitions and administer maintenance districts in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance. 
B.  The Parks and Recreation Commission is hereby delegated the authority to conduct fiscal year reviews and approvals of ongoing Project Costs, budgets and assessments in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Regulations. 
C.  The Parks Director shall establish and may from time to time amend administrative regulations consistent with this ordinance. The Regulations and amendments need not be approved by the City Council prior to their enactment, but may be reviewed by the City Council at any time. 
(Ord. 2169, Add, 03/17/2003) 
Section 17.33.050 - Procedures for review of petitions and establishment of maintenance districts. 
A.  Within five working days after receiving a petition, the Parks Director shall determine whether the petition complies with the Regulations, and shall reject it if it does not comply. If the Parks Director fails to reject the petition within five working days after it is received, the petition will be deemed accepted. Petitions which have been rejected may be resubmitted at any time. 
B.  If a petition is accepted for consideration and the Parks Director later seeks information from the petitioner, the time period set forth in subparagraph D below is tolled until the information is received, and if the petitioner fails to provide it within 30 days, the petition is deemed rejected. 
C.  Upon acceptance of a petition, the Parks Director shall review the petition with the Finance Director and the Community Development Director and shall consult with them in determining whether it would be desirable for the City to assume the maintenance of the proposed improvements and establish a maintenance district. 
D.  Subject to subparagraph B above, within 60 days after the petition is accepted the Parks Director shall make a preliminary determination whether it would be desirable for the City to assume the maintenance of the Project and establish a maintenance district. 
E.  If the Parks Director determines that it is not desirable to approve the petition, he shall inform the petitioner in writing within ten days after the determination and shall explain the reasons why the determination was made. 
F.  If the Parks Director determines that it is desirable to establish the maintenance district, he shall prepare and review with the Finance director, Community Development Director, and City Attorney: 
1.  A maintenance plan detailing the improvements to be maintained, the schedule and levels of maintenance (including long term maintenance and replacement costs) and the estimated time and expense that may be involved; 
2.  An allocation plan which determines the relative benefits and allocates costs between the city and the Assessed Property in accordance with Section 17.033.060 below. 
3.  A financing plan prepared in accordance with the Regulations detailing Project Costs, district set up costs and initial reserves to be established, and how initial and annual costs are to be allocated and the projected revenues and expenses for the first year of operations; 
4.  An assessment roll for that portion of costs to be paid by the owners of Assessed Properties, which includes the amount of assessment for each Assessed Property calculated as set forth in Section 17.33. 070 and how and where the assessments are to be paid; 
5.  If the Project is to be included as a part of an existing district, an analysis whether existing property owners in the district will be benefitted by the assumption of maintenance of the Project and whether the amount new assessments allocated to them is reasonably related to the benefits received from the Project. 
G.  The Parks Director shall hold a public hearing to review the foregoing and any other matters prescribed in the Regulations. The Parks Director may hold the hearing with the Parks and Recreation Commission who may advise the Parks Director. The Parks Director shall give notice of the hearing to the petitioner and to all owners of Assessed Property by mailing a copy of the notice by first class U.S. mail, postage prepaid not less than ten nor more than 30 days before the hearing. The notice shall include (i) a map or description of the maintenance district area, (ii) a statement whether a separate maintenance district will be established or whether the district will be included in another maintenance district, (iii) a general description of the maintenance services to be performed, (iv) a general description of the Assessed Property, (v) the proposed amount of the annual assessments or a description of where the proposed assessment roll may be obtained, (vi) the date, time, and location of the public hearing and a statement that all persons may present their views at the hearing, and (vii) a statement that decisions of the Parks Director may be appealed to the City Council. A copy of the notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation once not less than ten nor more than 30 days before the hearing. 
H.  Following the public hearing, the Parks Director may make any adjustments to the maintenance plan, the allocation plan, the financing plan, and the assessment roll and shall make a final determination of the desirability of assuming maintenance of the Project. If the Parks Director decides not to assume the maintenance of the Project, he shall inform the petitioner in writing, and shall explain why. If the Parks Director decides to assume the maintenance of the Project, he shall finalize the plans and assessment roll and may enter into an agreement with the Developer which shall contain the elements set forth in the Regulations. Upon adoption, the maintenance plan, allocation plan, financing plan, assessment roll and agreement with the Developer shall be filed with the City Clerk. 
I.  Once the foregoing are filed with the City Clerk, the Parks Director shall adopt an order which 
1.  Creates a new maintenance district or a new unit of assessment in an existing district, or includes new units of Assessed Property in an existing district. The description of the new Assessed Property shall include the assessor's parcel number and legal description prepared in form and with sufficient detail suitable for recording in the official records of Washoe County. 
2.  Adopts the maintenance plan, allocation plan, finance plan, and agreement with the Developer on file with the City Clerk, and states that they are subject to change by the Parks Director after consultation with the Parks and Recreation Commission; 
3.  Approves the assessment roll, which shall be attached to the order, and states that assessment amounts are subject to change by the Parks Director after consultation with the Parks and Recreation Commission; 
4.  States that the assessment constitutes a lien upon the Assessed Property and that the lien must be executed, and has the same priority, as a lien for property taxes, or as may otherwise be provided by law, including NRS 278.4787. 
5.  States that the maintenance district shall be administered in accordance with this Chapter, and the Regulations. 
6.  Lists all conditions which must be met before the City accepts dedication of the Project and assumes the maintenance responsibilities. 
7.  States that the order may be appealed to the Sparks City Council by filing a written appeal with the City Clerk within 30 days from the date that the order is mailed to Assessed Property Owners as provided in Section 17.33.120 below. 
8.  Addresses any other matters that the Parks Director determines to be relevant to the maintenance of the improvements. 
J.  The Parks Director shall mail, by first class mail, the order to each owner of the Assessed Property, as indicated in the records of the County Assessor, and shall deliver a copy to each member of the City Council. 
K.  When the appeal period stated in the order expires the Parks Director shall prepare and record in the Official Records of Washoe County a notice of the creation of the maintenance district which shall have the Order and Assessment Roll attached. 
L.  Unless otherwise agreed, Project Land shall be dedicated to the City which may be accomplished either by notation on the final subdivision map (which notation shall include a reference to this chapter) or by separate deed. If the land is not to be dedicated, an easement shall be granted by the Project Land owner(s) sufficient to enable the City to maintain the Project. 
(Ord. 2169, Add, 03/17/2003) 
Section 17.33.060 - Determination of benefit and cost allocations between assessed property and city. 
A.  Pursuant to NRS 278.4787.3(c), the Parks Director shall use the following method to determine the relative proportions in which the assumption of the maintenance of the Project by the city will benefit the Assessed Properties and the public. To determine the relative proportion of benefits, the Parks Director shall use the presumptions listed below, but may evaluate each proposed Project on its own merits to determine if a different proportion is warranted based on information presented to him by the Petitioner or otherwise available to him. The relative proportions of benefit shall be expressed as percentages. Project Costs will then be allocated to the Assessed Properties (as a group) in the percentage of the benefit to the Development and to the City in the percentage of the benefit to the public. The amount of costs allocated to the Assessed Property as a group will be divided and assessed against individual properties as provided in Section 17.033.070 below. 
B.  For Landscaping Projects. 
1.  Landscaping Projects along interior streets of Developments are presumed to benefit the Development 100% and the public 0%. This presumption contemplates that the enhanced land values and pedestrian safety benefits inure only to residents in the Development and their invitees. 
2.  Landscaping Projects along arterial streets and major thoroughfares are presumed to benefit the Development 100% and the public 0%. This presumption contemplates that the enhanced land values and pedestrian safety benefits inure only to residents in the Development and their invitees. However, the Parks Director may determine that some benefit inures to persons outside the Development if the Landscaping Project includes a sidewalk that connects other developments with commercial facilities, in which case the Parks Director may increase allocations to other developments in the same District, or to the City based on expected pedestrian use along the Development frontage. 
C.  For Public Lighting Projects. 
1.  All public lighting projects are presumed to benefit the Development 100% and the public 0%. This presumption contemplates that the security and safety benefits inure only to the properties within the illumination sphere of the lights If, however, the Public Lighting Project is part of a Landscaping Project which is determined to benefit persons other than those in the Development as provided in Subparagraph B.2 above, similar allocations may be made for public lighting. 
D.  For Security Walls 
1.  All Security Wall Projects are presumed to benefit the Development 100% and the public 0%. This presumption contemplates that the security and sound protective benefits of the walls inure only to the residences within the Development. 
E.  For trails, parks and open space 
1.  Trail projects described in NRS 278.4787. 5 (trails listed in the recreation plan) shall be presumed to benefit the Development and the Public as follows. The hardscape and benches shall be presumed to benefit the public and shall be paid and the costs of maintaining them shall be borne by the city. This presumption is based on the regional nature of the trails. The landscaping shall be presumed to benefit the Development and the costs of maintaining it shall be allocated to the Assessed Properties. This presumption is based on the fact that the landscaping provides an asthetic buffer between the Development and the trail, and provides a greenbelt for the Development. 
2.  Parks, open space and nonregional trails. Trail, park and open space Projects shall not be included in Maintenance Districts unless they provide a substantial public benefit or are required by the City for the primary use of the public. All of the playgrounds, tot lots, and basketball courts shall be presumed to benefit the Development and all the costs shall be allocated to the Assessed Properties. This presumption is based on the fact such facilities are positioned for the benefit of and are used primarily by children within walking distance. All of the landscaping, Bar B Que and picnic facilities are presumed to benefit the public and the costs shall be allocated to the city. This presumption is based on the fact that these facilities attract and benefit a broader range of people who will travel a greater distance. 
(Ord. 2169, Add, 03/17/2003) 
Section 17.33.070 - Allocation of costs among assessed properties; assessment rolls. 
A.  Allocation of costs among individual lots of Assessed Property 
Unless a different allocation is set by the Parks Director under subparagraph B. 3 below or is agreed upon by all of the Assessed Property owners existing at the time the order is mailed to them under section 17.33.050.J; 
1.  Each residential dwelling (including apartments and units in multifamily complexes) shall be assessed an equal amount. 
2.  Non-dwelling units (commercial properties, public facilities etc) shall not be included in Maintenance Districts if the construction and maintenance of facilities is a part of zoning entitlements. 
B.  Assessment standards. 
1.  Assessments shall be made only against Assessed Property that is or will be benefitted by the Project as determined by the Parks Director. The individual circumstances or desires of a particular property owner does not determine the benefit to the Assessed Property. 
2.  The sum of assessments may not exceed Project Costs. 
3.  The Parks Director may establish subclasses of similarly situated properties in the assessment roll and adjust assessments according to the benefits relative to other subclasses of properties. 
(Ord. 2169, Add, 03/17/2003) 
Section 17.33.080 - Administration of district; assessments. 
A.  Regulations. The Regulations shall provide for the administration of maintenance districts, including the establishment of budgets. 
B.  Contracts; administration. Maintenance services performed under this chapter may be performed by the city or by independent contractors retained by the City under standard public works contract procedures established in the City's procurement code. The Parks Director Contracts may be combined with contracts for other activities in order to maximize cost efficiency. The Parks Director shall supervise city staff or the contractors, and shall periodically inspect the Projects for compliance with the maintenance schedule. 
C.  Project Costs. Project Costs which may be included in assessments include all costs involved in performing the maintenance activities undertaken by the City and in administering the maintenance assessment district, including (but not limited to): 
1.  Costs of city employees or independent contractors (including professional services); 
2.  Cost of all materials, supplies, replacements, and parts used; 
3.  Utility costs for water and power; 
4.  Annual contributions to or replenishment of reserves for long term maintenance costs such as painting, replacements, repaving, repairs, and the like; 
5.  Cost of providing insurance for public liability; 
6.  Administrative costs, including, but not limited to, mailing and publication costs, copy costs, computer costs (including hardware and software), costs of collecting and enforcing liens, legal fees, consulting fees; 
7.  Administrative fees, including accounting fees, supervision fees, legal fees and other administrative costs for administering the district and maintaining the Project; and 
8.  Repayment of reserves, loans or advances, with interest, made to cover any shortfalls for the previous year. 
D.  Payment of Project Costs. The City shall pay its proportionate share of the Project Costs, and shall levy assessments against the Assessed Property as provided in the Regulations. 
E.  Assessment Liens. Once the Assessment Roll is mailed, assessments shall constitute a lien upon the Assessed Property. The lien attaches on July 1 of each year for which the assessment is levied. The lien must be executed, and has the same priority, as a lien for property taxes of as otherwise provided by Nevada law. The lien shall be a perpetual lien against the Assessed Property until the assessment and any penalty charges and interest which may accrue thereon has been paid in full. The Regulations shall establish procedures for collection of assessments and enforcement of liens. 
F  Penalties for nonpayment. If any person fails to pay an assessment when due, a penalty shall be imposed in the amount specified in the Regulaltions. 
G.  Waiver of all or part of interest and penalty for late payment of assessments. If the Finance Director finds that a person's failure to make a timely return or payment of assessments is the result of circumstances beyond his control and occurred despite the exercise of ordinary care, the Finance Director may relieve him of all or part of any interest or penalty, or both. A person seeking this relief must file a statement under oath setting forth the facts upon which he bases his claim with the Finance Director. The Finance Director shall disclose, upon the request of any person the name of the person and the amount of the relief. All decisions of the Finance Director may be appealed to the City Council, but must be done so within 60 days from notice of the decision is given in writing. 
H.  NRS Chapter 361 provisions applicable. The following provisions shall apply to assessments made hereunder: 
1.  NRS 361.484 Abatement of taxes on real property acquired by Federal Government, state or political subdivision. 
2.  NRS 361.450 Liens for taxes: Attachment; expiration of lien on mobile home. 
3.  NRS 361.330 Informality and failure to act within time required not to invalidate assessment or collection of tax. 
4.  NRS 361.065 Property of school districts exempted. 
5.  NRS 361.765 Correction of clerical and typographical errors on tax rolls. 
(Ord. 2169, Add, 03/17/2003) 
Section 17.33.090 - Dissolution of maintenance district. 
A.  A common interest unit owners association duly established and validly existing for a Development under NRS 116.3101 may apply to the Parks Director to dissolve the maintenance district and allow the association to assume all maintenance responsibilities for the Project. The Parks Director shall investigate the request to and make a determination decide whether or not the relinquishing of the dedicated property and maintenance responsibility to the association: (i) is likely to result in equal or better maintenance of the facilities, taking into account the resources, governance, experience, and resolve of the association, (ii) is in the best interest of the general public, (iii) is in the best interest of the City, and (iv) is in the best interest of the owners of the lots and parcels in the subdivision. Toward that end, the Parks Director may negotiate and execute agreements with the association establishing maintenance standards and providing adequate surety or assurances that the association will meet those standards, releasing reserve funds held by the City, compensating the city for the loss of the dedicated property, and other matters deemed advisable by the Parks Director. If the Parks Director determines that the considerations herein are in favor of doing so, may dissolve the maintenance district by an order. The Regulations shall specify the procedures for dissolution of the district. 
(Ord. 2169, Add, 03/17/2003) 
Section 17.33.100 - Review and appeals of decisions of parks director and parks and recreation commission. 
A.  All decisions and orders of the Parks Director and Parks and Recreation Commission may be appealed to this Council in accordance with the following procedure. 
1.  Any person may request an appeal by filing a written request with the City Clerk. The written request must describe the decision or order being appealed, why the person believes it is erroneous, and what the person desires for the City Council to do. All information that the appellant has which would refute the decision or order shall be submitted to the City Clerk either with the appeal or not later than three weeks before the date of the hearing scheduled to hear the appeal. 
2.  Requests for appeals of decisions and orders of the Parks Director must be filed within thirty days after the decision or order is written and mailed to those persons identified in the Regulations. 
3.  Requests for appeals of decisions and orders of the Parks and Recreation Commission must be filed with the City Clerk within thirty days after the date of the meeting when the decision or order was made. 
4.  The City Clerk shall immediately forward the appeal to the City Manager, Mayor and Parks Director. 
5.  The City Manager, Mayor or Parks Director may stay implementation of the decision or order pending determination of the appeal. 
6.  If implementation of the decision or order has not been stayed, the City Clerk shall place the appeal on the agenda for the next regularly scheduled Council Meeting for which the normal agenda deadline may be met. If implementation of the order or decision has been stayed, the City Clerk shall place the appeal on the a regularly scheduled Council Meeting within 45 days from the date the appeal was received. The appeal shall be placed on the agenda as a public hearing. Notice of the hearing shall be sent to the petitioner. 
7.  The Parks Director shall prepare a staff report explaining the decision or order, what information was used in making the decision or order, and the procedure that was followed in making the decision or order. A copy of any reports or information used in making the decision or order shall be attached to the Staff Report. A copy of the Staff Report and supporting information shall be provided to the appellant at least five days before the appeal is heard by the Council. 
8.  The City Council shall conduct a public hearing. The City Council may review the decision or order de novo. The hearing may be continued from time to time. 
B.  When the Parks Director has issued an order to establish, expand, or dissolve a maintenance district, he shall send a copy of the order to members of the City Council, and shall wait for 30 days before recording the order. Any member of the Council may request a review of the order by contacting the City Clerk, who shall notify the Parks Director and shall schedule the review for the next regularly scheduled meeting of the Council for which normal agenda deadline can be met. 
(Ord. 2169, Add, 03/17/2003) 
Title 20 - ZONING CODE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2512, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Aug. 24, 2015, replaced former Title 20, entitled "Zoning and Land Use Controls," in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Title 20, Chs. 20.01-20.110, pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume for a listing of ordinances which amended this former title. 

Chapter 20.01 - GENERAL 
Sections: 

Section 20.01.001. - Purpose. 
    This title regulates and restricts the use and improvement of land and controls the location, soundness, and use of structures, to: 
 Promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience or general welfare of the community; 
 Preserve the quality of the air and water resources; 
 Promote the conservation of open space and the protection of other natural and scenic resources from unreasonable impairment; 
 Enhance the aesthetics of the community; 
 Provide for recreational needs; 
 Protect life and property in areas subject to floods, landslides and other natural disasters; 
 Conform to the adopted population and master plans; 
 Develop a timely, orderly and efficient arrangement of transportation and public facilities and services; 
 Take into account the relative suitability of the land for development, and to insure that any development of the land is commensurate with the character and physical limitations of the land; 
 Lessen traffic congestion; 
 Prevent overcrowding of land and undesirable concentrations of population. 
(Ord. 2512, § 1(Exh. A), Add. 08/24/2015) 
Section 20.01.002. - Title. 
    This title is known and cited as the "City of Sparks Zoning Code." 
(Ord. 2512, § 1(Exh. A), Add. 08/24/2015) 
Section 20.01.003. - Applicability. 
    This title applies to the erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair or use of any building, structure or land. 
(Ord. 2512, § 1(Exh. A), Add. 08/24/2015) 
Section 20.01.004. - Consistency with plans. 
    The City finds that this title is consistent with, and implements, the Sparks Master Plan and the Truckee Meadows Regional Plan. 
(Ord. 2512, § 1(Exh. A), Add. 08/24/2015)

Section 20.02.004 - Residential single-family districts (SF). 
    Purpose: This district establishes uses, densities and intensities that are compatible with neighborhoods that are primarily single-family in character. The districts accommodate a range of development types, from conventional large lot subdivisions to smaller lots with a more urban setting. This section establishes two development options: (1) conventional development that incorporates minimum lot size, setback, and coverage standards, and (2) design development that incorporates design and density standards. 
A.  Uses. Refer to Section 20.02.013 (Use Table). 
B.  Area Regulations. 
1.  No lot or parcel shall be reduced in area as to be less in any dimension than is required by the requirements applicable to the zoning district in which the lot is located. 
2.  No portion of any lot or parcel of land which is part of the required a for an existing building shall be used as a part of the required area of any other lot or parcel or proposed building. 
3.  When part of any lot or parcel is sold or transferred and the areas of that portion or the portion remaining no longer conforms to the required areas as defined in the zoning district in which the lot or parcel is located, the portion sold or transferred and the portion remaining are considered one parcel to determine the permitted number and location of buildings allowed to be replaced on both parcels. 
C.  Dimensional Standards.
